         <tei:p>Synopsis</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The history of the classification of the Hemiuroidea and the features which have been used as criteria for<tei:lb/>distinguishing the higher taxa, such as adult morphology, life-cycle patterns and cercarial anatomy, are<tei:lb/>discussed. It is suggested that the best basic criterion currently available is the functional morphology of<tei:lb/>the adult.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Explanations of the terminology with comments on the systematic significance and possible function<tei:lb/>of the features used in the study of hemiuroid taxonomy are included.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A classification of the Hemiuroidea is presented with keys and definitions of the taxa to the generic<tei:lb/>level. The classification and definitions are based, where possible, on original observations of sectioned<tei:lb/>material. The Hemiuroidea is divided into fourteen families. The Accacoeliidae contains the Accacoeliinae<tei:lb/>and Paraccacladiinae, the latter subfamily consisting of only one genus. The Azygiidae consists of two<tei:lb/>subfamilies, the Azygiinae and Leuceruthrinae. The Bathycotylidae, Isoparorchiidae and Ptychogonimidae<tei:lb/>contain single genera, while the Hirudinellidae contains three monotypic genera. The Bunocotylidae is</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bull. Br. Mus. not. Hist. (Zool.) 36 (2) : 35-146 Issued 26 July, 1979</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>36 D. I. GIBSON &amp; R. A. BRAY</tei:p>
         <tei:p>redefined and contains the Bunocotylinae, Aphanurinae, Opisthadeninae (including Neotheletrum gen.<tei:lb/>nov.) and Theletrinae subfam. nov. The Derogenidae is also redefined and contains the Derogeninae,<tei:lb/>Gonocercinae and Halipeginae. The hemiuroids from the teleost swim-bladder, with the exception of<tei:lb/>Isoparorchis, are placed in the Dictysarcidae, which is composed of the Dictysarcinae, Albulatrematinae<tei:lb/>and Cylindrorchiinae subfam. inq. The Hemiuridae is restricted to ecsomate forms and contains the<tei:lb/>following subfamilies: Hemiurinae, Dinurinae, Elytrophallinae, Glomericirrinae, Hypohepaticolinae,<tei:lb/>Lecithochiriinae, Lethadeninae, Plerurinae subfam. nov. and Pulmoverminae. The Lecithasteridae is<tei:lb/>redefined and is composed of the Lecithasterinae, Hysterolecithinae (including Thulinia gen. nov.),<tei:lb/>Macradeninae, Prolecithinae, Quadrifoliovariinae and Trifoliovariinae. The Sclerodistomidae contains<tei:lb/>the Sclerodistominae, Prosogonotrematinae and Prosorchiinae. The Sclerodistomoididae fam. nov. is<tei:lb/>erected for Sclerodistomoides, and in the Syncoeliidae, the Syncoeliinae and Otiotrematinae are redefined.<tei:lb/>An index to the generic names used in this classification is included.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The criteria which may be used as indicators of the relative 'primitiveness' of various taxa or to illus-<tei:lb/>trate phylogenetic relationships within the group are discussed. In relation to this, evolutionary trends<tei:lb/>within three organ-systems, (1) the seminal storage and disposal apparatus in the female reproductive<tei:lb/>system, (2) the vitellarium and (3) the terminal genitalia, are studied in detail. Using evidence from this<tei:lb/>study, an evolutionary picture for the Hemiuroidea is presented, and its relationships with the<tei:lb/>Didymozooidea and the Paramphistomoidea are commented upon.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I. Introduction</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The superfamily Hemiuroidea Looss, 1899, is a group within the Digenea which includes species<tei:lb/>usually parasitic in the gut, particularly in the stomach, of fishes. They are found predominantly<tei:lb/>in marine teleosts, but also occur in freshwater teleosts, elasmobranchs and occasionally in<tei:lb/>amphibians and reptiles. It is not unusual for progenetic forms to occur in molluscs and other<tei:lb/>marine, and occasionally freshwater, invertebrates. In addition to the alimentary canal of fishes,<tei:lb/>examples are known from the gall-bladder, swim-bladder, body-cavity, mouth, gills and from<tei:lb/>the skin, whilst all known species of one group are found in the lung of sea-snakes. Overall, the<tei:lb/>hemiuroids form a very diverse group, not only in habitat, but also in morphology. Indeed, the<tei:lb/>wide variations in adult morphology, even within proposed higher taxa, have resulted in a good<tei:lb/>deal of confusion with regard to the validity, composition and systematic relationships of these<tei:lb/>taxa.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The superfamily was erected, under the name Hemiurida, by Dollfus (1923), and comprised<tei:lb/>the families Hemiuridae, Accacoeliidae and Syncoeliidae. Prior to this Looss (1907, 1908) had<tei:lb/>carefully re-described many species of hemiuroids and set a basic pattern on which later authors,<tei:lb/>notably Odhner (1911), Poche (1926) and Fuhrmann (1928), were able to build. These early<tei:lb/>workers based their classifications entirely upon adult morphology and divided the group into a<tei:lb/>small number of families, although not always indicating the relationships between these families.<tei:lb/>Odhner (1911), for example, grouped three families together, the Hemiuridae, Azygiidae and<tei:lb/>Didymozoidae. Since Odhner, the concept of the Hemiuridae has been sub-divided, condensed<tei:lb/>and sub-divided again on numerous occasions. Systematic histories of the Hemiuroidea have<tei:lb/>been compiled by Chauhan (1954), Skrjabin &amp; Guschanskaja (1954, 1956, 1960) and more<tei:lb/>recently by Stunkard (1973), although the latter author has omitted the important contributions<tei:lb/>of Chauhan (1954), Manter &amp; Pritchard (19600) and Mehra (1962). In order to avoid repetition,<tei:lb/>we have condensed several of the more recent conceptions of the Hemiuroidea in the form of<tei:lb/>Table 1. It can be seen from this table that Odhner's original conception was split by Yamaguti<tei:lb/>(1971) into three superfamilies and eighteen families, one of which, the Hemiuridae, contains<tei:lb/>twenty-five subfamilies. The large number of higher taxa in this rather uncritical work of Yama-<tei:lb/>guti appears to be the result of the acceptance of inadequate descriptions as being accurate.<tei:lb/>Stunkard (1973) summarized the problem succinctly as follows: 'in the course of the past hundred<tei:lb/>years, a large number of trematodes have been described, many on inadequate and erroneous<tei:lb/>information and based often on a single specimen. New genera and higher taxonomic categories<tei:lb/>have been erected to receive these dubious species.' Yamaguti, for example, has accepted three<tei:lb/>genera in three different families for forms which we consider to be synonymous with the genus<tei:lb/>Elongoparorchis Rao, 1961.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Recent conceptions of the Hemiuroidea, and of the Digenea in general, have been greatly</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE HEMIUROIDEA</tei:p>
         <tei:p>37</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>38 D. I. GIBSON &amp; R. A. BRAY</tei:p>
         <tei:p>influenced by the work of La Rue (1957), who sub-divided the Digenea into two groups, the<tei:lb/>Epitheliocystidia and the Anepitheliocystidia, depending upon the epithelial or membranous<tei:lb/>nature of the lining of the cercarial excretory vesicle. The Azygiidae was placed in the latter group,<tei:lb/>while the remainder of the hemiuroids with 'known' life-histories were placed in the former. This<tei:lb/>work has resulted in the majority of recent workers considering the Azygiidae to be distinct from<tei:lb/>the Hemiuroidea, at least at the superfamily level (see Odening, 1974). Work by Powell (1972,<tei:lb/>1973, 1975) and Gibson (1974) indicated that it is likely that all cercariae have a syncytial lining<tei:lb/>to the excretory vesicle. This casts grave doubts upon the validity of La Rue's conceptions.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Yamaguti (1971) stated that life-cycle patterns may be an important systematic feature; but,<tei:lb/>due to a lack of knowledge with regard to the life-histories of this group, this aspect appears to<tei:lb/>be of little use in its classification. The little that is known suggests that, even within one family,<tei:lb/>the life-cycle can vary considerably in detail (see Chabaud &amp; Buttner, 1959; Sinclair et al., 1973;<tei:lb/>Bray &amp; Gibson, 1977). Stunkard (1973) gave a useful four-page summary of the present knowledge<tei:lb/>of the hemiuroid life-cycle, and Yamaguti (1975) lists much of this information in more detail.<tei:lb/>Stunkard introduced his contribution as follows : The wide divergence of opinion concerning<tei:lb/>the systematics and classification of the hemiuroid trematodes is the result, in large measures, of<tei:lb/>lack of knowledge of their life-cycles and developmental stages. Data are meager, fragmentary,<tei:lb/>often faulty, and sometimes erroneous.' He summarized his findings thus: 'The miracidia of the<tei:lb/>hemiuroid, azygiid and didymozoid species are unique and very similar. All are aciliate, provided<tei:lb/>with an anterior circle of spines, and the surface of the body bears bristles . . . The cercariae<tei:lb/>develop in rediae; they lack penetration and cystogenous glands, and develop into the cysto-<tei:lb/>phorous stage which is characteristic for hemiurid trematodes. Typically they are eaten by<tei:lb/>copepods and the metacercariae occur as unencysted larvae in the hemocoel of the crustaceans or<tei:lb/>other planktonic invertebrates that feed on copepods . . . The striking similarity of the larval<tei:lb/>stages, and the fact that they are peculiar to the hemiurid trematodes, portends genetic homo-<tei:lb/>geneity and despite adult adaptations to different situations, the thesis of Odhner and Fiihrmann<tei:lb/>that the Azygiidae, Hemiuridae and Didymozoidae are closely related is probably correct'. We<tei:lb/>agree that these groups do seem to be closely related, although we are reluctant to place too much<tei:lb/>emphasis on larval stages, especially considering the recent work of Devaraj (1972) and Schell<tei:lb/>(1975), who have described ciliated, non-spinous miracidia for the hemiuroids Isoparorchis<tei:lb/>hypselobagri (Billet, 1898) and Lecithaster salmonis Yamaguti, 1934, respectively. Similarly, a<tei:lb/>small number of cystophorus cercaria such as, Cercaria vaullegeardi Pelseneer, 1906, are known<tei:lb/>to develop in daughter-sporocysts and not rediae (see Popiel, 1976). We are not convinced of the<tei:lb/>primitive nature of the cercaria relative to the adult, because of the morphological similarities<tei:lb/>between what we consider to be primitive hemiuroids and the aspidogastreans (see below). The<tei:lb/>hypothesis that the present adult digenean evolved from a mature, free-swimming cercaria-like<tei:lb/>adult is presented by Cable (1965, 1974). It appears more likely to us that the adult forms from<tei:lb/>vertebrates arose directly from primitive molluscan parasites, in much the same way as many aspi-<tei:lb/>dogastreans, and that the crustacean host and the cercarial stage are more recent developments.<tei:lb/>Pearson (1972) and Rohde (1972) discuss the two contrasting hypotheses concerning the evolu-<tei:lb/>tionary significance of the digenean life-cycle. It seems likely that the morphological differences<tei:lb/>in cercariae, hitherto used as systematic indicators, are, at least to some extent, the result of the<tei:lb/>ecological requirements of the life-history. If, for example, the crustacean host is benthic, then<tei:lb/>the cercarial tail will tend to be of a different shape to that of a species which has a pelagic crusta-<tei:lb/>cean host. In other superfamilies, such as the Allocreadioidea, there appear to be major differences<tei:lb/>in the cercariae of different families. A similar argument also applies when considering the<tei:lb/>chaetotaxy of cercariae as a systematic criterion. In the latter case there is no reason why the<tei:lb/>hypertrophy or atrophy of the nervous system does not depend upon the ecological requirements<tei:lb/>of the life-history. One additional disadvantage in using larval characteristics or life-history for<tei:lb/>systematic purposes, is that for the majority of determinations only adult-specimens are available<tei:lb/>for study. The lack of knowledge with regard to the larval stages and life-histories of the great<tei:lb/>majority of genera, however, remains the greatest limitation to their value in systematics. We<tei:lb/>suggest, therefore, that the use of life-history details, and particularly cercarial morphology,<tei:lb/>should be treated with at least as much caution as the use of adult morphology.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE HEMIUROIDEA 39</tei:p>
         <tei:p>We consider that neither the gross morphology of the adult, due to its variability, nor the use<tei:lb/>of life-cycle patterns and cercarial morphology, due to a lack of knowledge and understanding with<tei:lb/>regard to their significance, are able to provide us with a satisfactory classification. In our opinion,<tei:lb/>functional morphology appears to offer the best alternative. In order to use this concept, one must<tei:lb/>have a detailed knowledge of the morphology of an organ or organ-system and an understanding<tei:lb/>of its probable function. Once its function is understood, one can then comprehend the require-<tei:lb/>ments for such an organ in order that the animal might complete its life-history. With an under-<tei:lb/>standing of the function and requirement for particular organs and organ-systems, one can<tei:lb/>rationalize many of the diverse variations which occur in different taxa, and recognize where<tei:lb/>development or atrophy has occurred. This sheds light, not only upon the systematics, but also<tei:lb/>upon the phylogenetic relationships of the taxa. It also tends to expose inaccurate descriptions<tei:lb/>and is a useful aid in suggesting the probable structure of particular organs in inadequately des-<tei:lb/>cribed taxa. The following classification, which we propose for the Hemiuroidea, is based,<tei:lb/>therefore, upon adult morphology associated with an attempted understanding of the function<tei:lb/>of organs and organ-systems. This functional aspect has permitted us to try and base our con-<tei:lb/>cepts upon a combination of features, rather than upon one critical feature.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>II. Definitions of hemiuroid structures* with comments<tei:lb/>on their systematic value and possible function</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Accessory excretory organ (vesicle) - see Manter' s organ.<tei:lb/>Annulations or annular plications - see plications.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Blind seminal receptacle - a type of seminal receptacle which does not communicate with the<tei:lb/>exterior via Laurer's canal, but which is linked to the oviduct by a short duct (Fig. 1) and usually<tei:lb/>has a thick wall. It serves as a seminal store, and its presence, except in the cases in the Tri-<tei:lb/>foliovariinae and Derogeninae where it appears to have arisen from a canalicular seminal recepta-<tei:lb/>cle by the loss of Laurer's canal, appears to be a good systematic feature at the subfamily level.<tei:lb/>It is worth noting that when a blind seminal receptacle is present, the uterine seminal receptacle<tei:lb/>(q.v.) is lost. See seminal receptacle.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Canalicular seminal receptacle - a large proximal dilation of Laurer's canal which is normally<tei:lb/>filled with fresh, as opposed to spent, spermatozoa (Fig. 1). This type of seminal receptacle (q.v.)<tei:lb/>in the majority of cases is possibly a recent adaptation associated with the use of Laurer's canal<tei:lb/>as a vagina (Gibson &amp; Bray, 1975). See seminal receptacle.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cirrus - an intromittent copulatory organ which is formed from or encloses the male duct only.<tei:lb/>It is rare in hemiuroids, occurring only in the members of the Hirudinellidae. Although its<tei:lb/>presence in certain other hemiuroid groups has been indicated in the literature, in two such cases,<tei:lb/>the hemiurid Glomericirrus and the derogenid Arnola, our observations of sectioned material<tei:lb/>show that this structure is definitely absent, there being a sinus-organ (q.v.) present. The occur-<tei:lb/>rence of a cirrus in the Hemiuroidea, therefore, is most likely a feature of importance at the family<tei:lb/>level. It is unlikely, however, that the 'cirrus' of the hirudinellids is homologous with the cirrus<tei:lb/>common in many groups of Digenea.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cirrus sac - a muscular sac which surrounds the terminal portion of the male duct including the<tei:lb/>cirrus. Its function appears to aid the eversion of the cirrus (q.v.) and the expulsion of sperma-<tei:lb/>tozoa, as it often encloses the seminal vesicle (q.v.), during copulation by exerting hydrostatic<tei:lb/>pressure upon its contents. It is to some extent, therefore, analogous with the sinus-sac (q.v.).<tei:lb/>This structure occurs in the Hirudinellidae: its reported presence in other hemiuroid groups,<tei:lb/>such as the Halipeginae, we consider to be extremely doubtful. The presence of a cirrus-sac is in<tei:lb/>our opinion a feature of importance at the family level in the Hemiuroidea.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>* It should be noted that a smaller glossary of terms used in hemiuroid systematics was produced by Manter (1970).<tei:lb/>There are, however, significant differences between some of our definitions and those of Manter.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>usr</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 1. The different types of seminal receptacle present in the Hemiuroidea: A. Uterine seminal<tei:lb/>receptacle; B. Rudimentary seminal receptacle; C. Canalicular seminal receptacle; D. Blind<tei:lb/>seminal receptacle, [bsr, blind seminal receptacle; csr, canalicular seminal receptacle; Lc, Laurer's<tei:lb/>canal; rsr, rudimentary seminal receptacle; usr, uterine seminal receptacle.]</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE HEMIUROIDEA 41</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cyclocoel - the name given to the gut-caeca when fused terminally, thus forming a complete<tei:lb/>caecal ring. The advantage of this caecal arrangement is unknown. This feature is of generic im-<tei:lb/>portance only, as it occurs widely in unrelated groups both within and outside the Hemiuroidea.<tei:lb/>The apparent cyclocoel found in large specimens of Hirudinella appears to be a subterminal fusion<tei:lb/>of the gut-caeca which takes place during the development of the animal.<tei:lb/>' DrUsenmageri 1 - this structure, the name of which means 'glandular stomach', is found at the<tei:lb/>'shoulder'-region of the gut-caeca in many hemiuroids. It is usually an expanded region lined by<tei:lb/>large, glandular cells forming a villous luminal surface, which is readily distinguished from the<tei:lb/>lining of the remainder of the caecum. Its function is not known, but it is probably a region of<tei:lb/>specialized secretion and/or digestion. It does not appear to be of systematic significance as it<tei:lb/>occurs widely in distantly related hemiuroids, but it is apparently absent in the azygiids. Manter<tei:lb/>(1970) refers to these structures as 'precaecal sacs'.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ecsoma - this is the name given to the posterior region of the body of an adult digenean, when it<tei:lb/>is capable of being retracted within the body (soma). This structure, which appears to be unique<tei:lb/>to the Hemiuridae, is occasionally referred to as a 'tail' or the specimens are referred to as<tei:lb/>'appendiculate' or 'ecsomate'. The gut-caeca, uterus and, on rare occasions, the ovary and vitel-<tei:lb/>larium may extend into the ecsoma, and the excretory pore opens terminally on it. The mechanism<tei:lb/>of extension is not known, although the body-wall clearly contains longitudinal and circular<tei:lb/>muscles; but within the ecsoma are numerous large, vesicular cells which might be involved with<tei:lb/>this process, acting as a hydrostatic skeleton. Its function is thought to be that of a feeding organ<tei:lb/>which is extruded during periods when the pH or the osmolarity of the stomach contents is at a<tei:lb/>tolerable level. It should be noted that hemiurids tend to occur in the lumen of the stomach,<tei:lb/>especially the pyloric region, of marine teleosts and are, therefore, subject to great variations in<tei:lb/>pH and osmolarity (MacKenzie &amp; Gibson, 1970). We suggest that other groups present in the<tei:lb/>stomach of these fish, such as the derogenines, tend to live more in the cardiac end of the stomach<tei:lb/>and only migrate down into the lumen during periods of more neutral pH and/or low osmolarity.<tei:lb/>These suggestions are made on the basis of observations of Derogenes varicus and Hemiurus<tei:lb/>communis. In relation to this function, the development of the ecsoma appears to be associated<tei:lb/>with the development of plications (q.v.) of the tegument.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>As the ecsoma occurs only in the hemiurids, this feature is of importance at the family level. In<tei:lb/>some groups, however, such as in some of the lecithochiriine genera, the ecsoma may be reduced<tei:lb/>in size.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Egg-filaments - in a few hemiuroids the egg-shell may be drawn out at the poles to form filaments.<tei:lb/>Usually, these are unipolar and may be of variable length. Occasionally, they are bipolar and may<tei:lb/>bear more than one filament (e.g. Anguillotrema). It is likely that these filaments are part of a<tei:lb/>mechanism associated with the acquisition of the first intermediate host. They may, for example,<tei:lb/>become attached to the gill-filaments of the mollusc. In the case of Hypohepaticola, which tends<tei:lb/>to be a tissue-parasite, the spine-like filament may aid the exit of the egg from the tissue by a<tei:lb/>mechanism similar to that found in schistosomes. The presence of egg-filaments is a feature of<tei:lb/>only generic importance, as it occurs spasmodically throughout the group, particularly in the<tei:lb/>Derogenidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ejaculatory duct - the entire male duct distal to the seminal vesicle can theoretically be referred<tei:lb/>to as the ejaculatory duct. Regions such as the pars prostatica (q.v.) and cirrus (q.v.) are modi-<tei:lb/>fications of the ejaculatory duct. In the hemiuroids, however, the region generally referred to as<tei:lb/>the ejaculatory duct is an unmodified region of this duct and is, therefore, without an alternative<tei:lb/>name. When present, it occurs between the pars prostatica and the hermaphroditic duct (q.v.) [or<tei:lb/>terminus of the male system]. It may occur entirely or partly inside or outside the sinus-sac (q.v.).<tei:lb/>This region of the duct is of little systematic importance, except perhaps at the specific level ; but<tei:lb/>it is long in certain lecithasterids, especially in the Macradenininae. Occasionally, unmodified<tei:lb/>regions of the male duct occur between the seminal vesicle and the pars prostatica or separating<tei:lb/>two regions of the pars prostatica. These regions, however, are not referred to as the ejaculatory<tei:lb/>duct, but usually as tubular extensions of the seminal vesicle or aglandular regions of the pars<tei:lb/>prostatica.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>42 D. I. GIBSON &amp; R. A. BRAY</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ejaculatory vesicle - a dilation of the ejaculatory duct (q.v.) within the sinus-sac (q.v.). This<tei:lb/>feature occurs in certain lecithochiriine genera and, in its glandular form (see prostatic vesicle),<tei:lb/>in the Glomericirrinae, Hysterolecithinae and the remainder of the lecithochiriines. It appears<tei:lb/>to function as a small seminal reservoir as part of a mechanism to increase the amount of sperma-<tei:lb/>tozoa ejected from the sinus-sac during copulation. Nasir &amp; Diaz (1971) suggest that an ejacula-<tei:lb/>tory vesicle is merely a prostatic vesicle from which the cellular lining has been lost, hence we<tei:lb/>suggest that it might be more appropriate to refer to the prostatic vesicle as a 'glandular ejacula-<tei:lb/>tory vesicle' (see p. 93). The presence of an ejaculatory vesicle or a glandular ejaculatory vesicle<tei:lb/>(prostatic vesicle) is a feature of importance at the subfamily level.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Excretory vesicle (bladder) - in hemiuroids this is essentially Y-shaped, the arms often uniting<tei:lb/>dorsally to the pharynx or oral sucker. The presence of blind arms is a feature of no more than<tei:lb/>generic importance, as it appears to occur widely in distantly related forms, and indeed we have<tei:lb/>not used it at the generic level in the case of the azygiid genus Otodistomum. There are a number<tei:lb/>of modifications of the basic structure of this organ, especially in the stouter hemiuroids. These<tei:lb/>include: (1) in the Sclerodistomidae there are one or two Manter's organs (q.v.), often called<tei:lb/>'accessory excretory vesicles', which communicate with this organ distally; (2) in Hirudinella,<tei:lb/>Botulus and Sclerodistomum the arms form a branching system of tubules or diverticula; (3) in<tei:lb/>some of the primitive groups, such as the Accacoeliidae, Hirudinellidae and Syncoeliidae, the<tei:lb/>excretory arms are usually arranged so that initially they pass forward dorsally and ventrally^<tei:lb/>instead of laterally ; and (4) in the Ptychogonimidae the excretory arms unite twice in the forebody</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fischthars organ - this is a name given by Yamaguti (1971) for a round vesicle of unknown<tei:lb/>function, lined with epithelial cells and surrounded by a dense mass of gland-cells, which appar-<tei:lb/>ently opens dorsally to the right of Mehlis' gland (q.v.) in Pelorohelmins palawanensis Fischthal &amp;<tei:lb/>Kuntz, 1964. There is no evidence of such a structure in specimens under the name of P. ghanensis<tei:lb/>Fischthal &amp; Thomas, 1968, from the collection of the British Museum (Natural History). It is<tei:lb/>possible, therefore, that Yamaguti may have mistaken Juel's organ (q.v.) for this structure. He<tei:lb/>also, however, describes this structure in Meristocotyle varani Fischthal &amp; Kuntz, 1964, a species<tei:lb/>of unknown relationship; but in this case it is the distal dilation of Laurer's canal which opens<tei:lb/>dorsally. [We should point out that we regard Pelorohelmins to be a synonym of Elongoparorchis.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Genital atrium - a receptacle present in most hemiuroids between the hermaphroditic duct and<tei:lb/>the genital pore, which probably acts as a vagina during copulation. Spermatozoa are probably<tei:lb/>deposited within this structure by the copulatory organ of another worm when cross-insemination<tei:lb/>occurs, and it is then either sucked back into the hermaphroditic duct by the action of the sinus-<tei:lb/>sac or, more likely, forced back (the sinus-organ being retracted to receive it) by the action of the<tei:lb/>muscular walls of the genital atrium which are contractile. The lining of the genital atrium is<tei:lb/>continuous with the sinus-organ (or in the case of the hirudinellids, the 'cirrus'), and appears to<tei:lb/>contribute significantly to the formation of its outer surface as it extends. In some of the hirudinel-<tei:lb/>lids the genital atrium may be everted through the genital pore, thus giving extra length to the<tei:lb/>'cirrus' (see Fig. 12D of Gibson &amp; Bray, 1977). This also occurs in Isoparorchis (Fig. 2), where it<tei:lb/>adds additional length to the sinus-organ.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The contractile nature of this organ makes it of limited taxonomic value, even at the specific<tei:lb/>level, although its apparent total absence may be of some value. It is often reduced or absent in<tei:lb/>species which must rely upon self-insemination or which possess only a temporary sinus-organ.<tei:lb/>When the sinus-organ and sinus-sac are absent, it is difficult to distinguish the genital atrium from<tei:lb/>the hermaphroditic duct. In such cases, these two terms often appear to have been used inter-<tei:lb/>changeably.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Genital pore - the aperture through which the contents of the genital ducts pass to the exterior.<tei:lb/>It usually, in the Hemiuroidea, forms the mouth of the genital atrium, but occasionally occurs at<tei:lb/>the distal end of the hermaphroditic duct, when the genital atrium (q.v.) is absent, or at the union<tei:lb/>of the male and female ducts when both the hermaphroditic duct and the genital atrium are<tei:lb/>absent. The genital pore is not always the most distal part of the terminal genital apparatus, as<tei:lb/>during copulation the copulatory organ, or even the genital atrium, is thrust through the genital</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE HEMIUROIDEA</tei:p>
         <tei:p>43</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 2 Sagittal sections through the terminal genitalia of Isoparorchis : A. Withdrawn; B. Extruded,<tei:lb/>[so, sinus-organ; wga, wall of genital atrium.]</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>44 D. I. GIBSON &amp; R. A. BRAY</tei:p>
         <tei:p>pore. This structure is of little systematic importance as it occurs mid-ventrally in the anterior<tei:lb/>forebody in all hemiuroids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hermaphroditic duct - a duct commonly linking the terminal male and female ducts with the<tei:lb/>genital atrium. The duct itself appears to have arisen partly as a modification of the genital atrium<tei:lb/>and partly from the fusion of the male and female ducts. It is normally quite distinct from the<tei:lb/>genital atrium; but, in certain cases, when the sinus-sac and sinus-organ are absent, it is difficult<tei:lb/>to distinguish these structures. An hermaphroditic duct occurs in most hemiuroids, commonly<tei:lb/>within the sinus-sac and almost always within the sinus-organ, when the latter structure is<tei:lb/>present. Annular muscles are sometimes clearly seen in its walls, e.g. Elytrophalloides, and<tei:lb/>probably serve to transport eggs and spermatozoa along its length by peristalsis. In some genera,<tei:lb/>such as Paradinurus and Hemiurus, the proximal part of the hermaphroditic duct is lined by<tei:lb/>villous, glandular cells of unknown function: this region may serve a similar function to the<tei:lb/>prostatic vesicle (q.v.) of the lecithochiriines. The distal part of the hermaphroditic duct in<tei:lb/>Hemiurus is lined with cuticular papillate structures: as this is the region which forms the outer<tei:lb/>surface of the temporary sinus-organ, it presumably aids the maintenance of the union during<tei:lb/>copulation. There are indications in Halipegus that the hermaphroditic duct in some species of<tei:lb/>this genus may be transitory, developing from the sinus-organ as it extends.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The absence of an hermaphroditic duct, except in the case of the Hirudinellidae and in Halipegus,<tei:lb/>is of generic importance only, because of: (1) the inability to distinguish it in some cases from<tei:lb/>the genital atrium ; and (2) the fact that degeneration of the terminal genitalia, due to the increa-<tei:lb/>sing importance of self-insemination, appears to have occurred independently on a number of<tei:lb/>occasions.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hermaphroditic sac - see sinus sac.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Inner vesicle- this is the name given by Juel (1889) to the sac-like structure (Fig. 3), filled with<tei:lb/>active and/or disintegrating spermatozoa found within the structure which we have called Juel's<tei:lb/>organ (q.v.). In the rudimentary form of Juel's organ (see rudimentary Juel's organ) this sac-like<tei:lb/>structure has not been enveloped, and is referred to here as a 'rudimentary seminal receptacle'<tei:lb/>(q.v.). According to Juel (1889) and Lander (1904), the inner vesicle normally appears to have an<tei:lb/>aperture at its distal end, and presumably it is through this that the disintegrating spermatozoa<tei:lb/>and vitelline material pass into the outer, amorphous mass of Juel's organ. The inner vesicle,<tei:lb/>which may be oval or in the form of a convoluted tube, appears to act, therefore, as a 'killing<tei:lb/>chamber' for the excess reproductive material.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This structure is present in all of the groups where a fully developed Juel's organ occurs, and<tei:lb/>its taxonomic significance is as discussed for the latter organ. It should be noted that in the case<tei:lb/>of certain didymozooids the inner vesicle does not appear to be entirely enveloped by the outer<tei:lb/>mass of Juel's organ.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>JueVs organ - in many hemiuroids, and all hemiurids, Laurer's canal does not open dorsally,<tei:lb/>but leads into an organ which has been referred to as a 'seminal receptacle' or, more recently 'the<tei:lb/>pouch of Laurer's canal' (Madhavi &amp; Rao, 1974). It was apparently first described by Juel (1889),<tei:lb/>and we, therefore, felt (Gibson &amp; Bray, 1975) that Juel's organ was an appropriate designation.<tei:lb/>It consists of an oval or globular sac containing an amorphous granular material, with the<tei:lb/>occasional (?) amoeboid cells embedded in it (Figs 3 A &amp; 4A). An 'inner vesicle' (q.v.), either<tei:lb/>globular and/or tubular, lies within this mass and contains spent (but often active) or partly<tei:lb/>disintegrated spermatozoa, vitelline material and, occasionally, ova. The inner vesicle is fed by<tei:lb/>Laurer's canal, which may be long or short, depending upon the proximity of Juel's organ to<tei:lb/>Mehlis' gland. The other end of the inner vesicle opens into the outer mass of Juel's organ.<tei:lb/>Sometimes Juel's organ and Mehlis' gland are apparently enclosed by a common membranous<tei:lb/>sheath, but in other species Juel's organ lies outside the sheath surrounding Mehlis' gland.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The function of Juel's organ is, apparently, as a disposal unit for excess reproductive material,<tei:lb/>which enables these resources to be recycled and is thus economically advantageous to the worm<tei:lb/>compared with the situation where Laurer's canal acts as a drain for these products. It is possible</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>Jo</tei:p>
         <tei:p>B</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 3 Diagrammatic representation of a fully developed (A) and a rudimentary (B) Juel's organ,<tei:lb/>[iv, 'inner vesicle'; Jo, Juel's organ; Lc, Laurer's canal; rJo, rudimentary Juel's organ; rsr,<tei:lb/>rudimentary seminal receotacle: usr. uterine seminal receptacle.!</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>46 D. I. GIBSON &amp; R. A. BRAY</tei:p>
         <tei:p>that the (?) amoeboid cells in the outer mass of Juel's organ might be involved in the final break-<tei:lb/>down of this waste material. A fully developed Juel's organ is found in all hemiurids (sensu<tei:lb/>stricto), the aphanurine bunocotylids, the dictysarcids, the hysterolecithine lecithasterids and in<tei:lb/>some halipegine derogenid genera. It also occurs, in a slightly modified form, in the nemato-<tei:lb/>bothriine didymozooids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In certain derogenine and sclerodistomid genera Juel's organ possesses no inner vesicle. This<tei:lb/>form, which we consider to be more primitive, we have referred to as a 'rudimentary Juel's<tei:lb/>organ' (q.v.). In this case there is usually a rudimentary seminal receptacle (q.v.), from which<tei:lb/>the 'inner vesicle' is later formed, that leads via a region of Laurer's canal of varying length into<tei:lb/>an amorphous mass, resembling the outer region of the fully developed Juel's organ (Figs 3B &amp;<tei:lb/>4B). The presence of a fully developed Juel's organ we consider to be a feature of significance at<tei:lb/>the subfamily level, except in the case of the Halipeginae, where it is of generic importance<tei:lb/>only (but see Genarchopsis).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Laurer's canal -a. duct which links the oviduct with either the exterior, a seminal receptacle (q.v.)<tei:lb/>or with Juel's organ (q.v.). Its function has long been a matter of contention. Looss (1893) wrote<tei:lb/>a paper entitled, '1st der Laurers'che Kanal der Trematoden eine Vagina?' and he, Goto (1893)<tei:lb/>and Johnston (1912) believed that it functioned as a 'sperm-drain'. Cohn (1902, 1903) and<tei:lb/>Palombi (1931), however, have described examples where Laurer's canal is used as a vagina. This<tei:lb/>work led Hyman (1951) to state, 'Laurer's canal in flukes was formerly considered to serve as an<tei:lb/>exit for superfluous sperm and yolk cells but is now known to function in copulation'. Our recent<tei:lb/>work (Gibson &amp; Bray, 1975) with hemiuroids has indicated that Laurer's canal does in fact<tei:lb/>function in this group as a drain for excess and/or spent seminal and vitelline material, and we<tei:lb/>suggest that in other groups the use of this canal as a vagina during copulation is a more recent<tei:lb/>development associated with the loss of a uterine seminal receptacle (q.v.) and the development<tei:lb/>of a functional seminal receptacle as a proximal dilation of this canal, i.e. a canalicular seminal<tei:lb/>receptacle (q.v.). It should be noted that Juel's organ appears to be a modification of Laurer's<tei:lb/>canal. The nature of Laurer's canal and its presence or absence are often useful features at the<tei:lb/>subfamily or family level, except in the cases of the Derogeninae, Halipeginae, Prosorchiinae and<tei:lb/>Trifoliovariinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Manner's organ (accessory excretory organ or vesicle) - a tubular vesicle lined with an epithelium<tei:lb/>and usually surrounded by bundles of muscle, especially longitudinal muscle. It occurs dorsal to<tei:lb/>the excretory vesicle (q.v.) into which it opens postero-ventrally close to the excretory pore. It<tei:lb/>is a feature of the Scerodistomidae, occurring singly in Prosogonotrema, Prosorchis and<tei:lb/>Prosorchiopsis and paired in Sclerodistomum. Gibson &amp; Bray (1977) suggest that it might occur<tei:lb/>in Distoma gigas Nardo, 1827, a giant digenean of uncertain systematic position. The name<tei:lb/>Manter's organ appears to have been coined by Yamaguti (1971), and is in our opinion more<tei:lb/>acceptable than the appellation 'accessory excretory organ (vesicle)', as the function of this organ<tei:lb/>is unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mehlis' gland- a cluster of gland-cells which surround the region of the ovovitelline canal which<tei:lb/>links the oviduct and the uterus: this is usually the region of the ootype (q.v.). It is thought to<tei:lb/>produce a mucous secretion which lubricates the uterus and a lipoprotein secretion which forms<tei:lb/>a membrane around the ovum and vitelline cells upon which shell-material is then deposited<tei:lb/>(Smyth, 1966). It also seems likely that it may produce a secretion which activates the spermatozoa.<tei:lb/>Mehlis' gland appears to be of little systematic importance, except that, although in the<tei:lb/>majority of hemiuroids it is post-ovarian [the oviduct leaves the ovary posteriorly], in the azygiids<tei:lb/>and accacoeliine accacoeliids it is pre-ovarian [the oviduct leaves the ovary anteriorly]. It is<tei:lb/>likely that there are several exceptions to this rule, such as the prosorchiine sclerodistomids. In<tei:lb/>certain hemiuroids Mehlis' gland appears to be enclosed along with Juel's organ by a membranous<tei:lb/>sac (see Madhavi &amp; Rao, 1974).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Melralerm - a name given to the terminal region of the uterus, when it can be distinguished<tei:lb/>morphologically from the rest of this organ. It is of little taxonomic importance in this group, as<tei:lb/>it is usually difficult to distinguish and often tends to grade into the uterus-proper. It is usually</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE HEMIUROIDEA</tei:p>
         <tei:p>47</tei:p>
         <tei:p>rs</tei:p>
         <tei:p>rsr<tei:lb/>Lc</tei:p>
         <tei:p>rJo</tei:p>
         <tei:p>01</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3<tei:lb/>3</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 4 Sections of a fully developed (A) and a rudimentary (B) Juel's organ, [gc, gut-caeca; iv, inner<tei:lb/>vesicle; Jo, Juel's organ; Lc, Laurer's canal; Mg, Mehlis' gland; o, ovary; rJo, rudimentary Juel's<tei:lb/>organ; rs, ventral sucker; rsr, rudimentary seminal receptacle; u, uterus; usr, uterine seminal<tei:lb/>receptacle; v, vitellarium].</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>48 D. I. GIBSON &amp; R. A. BRAY</tei:p>
         <tei:p>muscular, often surrounded by small gland-cells and in some dinurines it has a villous lining.<tei:lb/>In Erilepturus (= Uterovesiculurus) it appears to form a distinct dilate sac.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ootype - a region of the female duct (ovovitelline canal) where egg-formation and possibly<tei:lb/>fertilization occur. This is normally the region, surrounded by Mehlis' gland (q.v.), which links<tei:lb/>the oviduct with the uterus. In the hemiuroids this region does not appear to be vesicular as in<tei:lb/>many other digeneans, but is present as a narrow tube. Although we have seen soft egg-shells in<tei:lb/>this region in Isoparorchis, Otodistomum and some hemiurids, in othe'rs, such as Derogenes,<tei:lb/>Pulmovermis and Syncoelium, the ootype appears to extend into the first part of the uterus, as<tei:lb/>egg-shell formation occurs in a region not surrounded by Mehlis' gland. We are referring to this<tei:lb/>region as a uterine ootype (q.v.). The systematic significance of these variations of the ootype have<tei:lb/>not been studied ; but it seems unlikely that they may be of any value above, perhaps, the generic<tei:lb/>level.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ovary - in the hemiuroids this is usually oval in shape, but in certain groups, such as the lecithas-<tei:lb/>terids, syncoeliids and dictysarcids, it is commonly composed of 4 or 5 distinct lobes. In one instance<tei:lb/>(Isoparorchis) the ovary is tubular. The position of the ovary in relation to the testes is an impor-<tei:lb/>tant systematic criterion at the subfamily level, except in the case of some of the macrodeninine<tei:lb/>lecithasterids. The ovary is post-testicular in most groups, but is pre-testicular in the azygiine<tei:lb/>azygiids, the ptychogonimids, the gonocercine derogenids and certain macradeninine lecithasterid<tei:lb/>genera, and occurs between the testes in the bathycotylids. The ovary occurs in the hindbody in<tei:lb/>all groups, except for the prosogonotrematine sclerodistomids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Oviduct - the duct linking the ovary and the ootype (q.v.). It receives Laurer's canal and the<tei:lb/>common vitelline duct before, or sometimes in the case of the common vitelline duct, slightly<tei:lb/>after entering Mehlis' gland (q.v.). The oviduct appears to leave the ovary posteriorly in the<tei:lb/>majority of hemiuroids, the exceptions being the azygiids, the accacoeliine accacoeliids and<tei:lb/>possibly odd genera, such as Prosorchiopsis, in other groups.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pars prostatica - the region of the male duct between the seminal vesicle and either the ejaculatory<tei:lb/>duct or the hermaphroditic duct. It is normally surrounded by prostatic gland-cells and lined by<tei:lb/>what appear to be anuclear gland-cells which often project into the lumen presenting a papillate<tei:lb/>or villous appearance: it is possible, however, that the latter are merely internal extensions of<tei:lb/>the outer gland-cells. The function of this region is not known for certain, but it may produce a<tei:lb/>secretion which protects and lubricates the spermatozoa during ejaculation. It may also be in-<tei:lb/>volved in the activation of spermatozoa during ejaculation. The shape of this duct, i.e. whether it<tei:lb/>is vesicular or tubular, is of specific value, and so is its length. The presence of a vesicular pars<tei:lb/>prostatica has often been confused with a prostatic vesicle (q.v.). When the external gland-cells<tei:lb/>are severely restricted in their distribution by surrounding parenchyma or are bound by a fibrous<tei:lb/>membrane, they are spoken of as being 'delimited'. In certain cases an aglandular duct links the<tei:lb/>pars prostatica and the seminal vesicle; this is usually referred to as a tubular extension of the<tei:lb/>seminal vesicle or as an aglandular region of the pars prostatica. An aglandular region also links<tei:lb/>the two parts of the pars prostatica in the dinurine hemiurid Mecoderus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Peduncle - this is a stalk upon which the ventral sucker may be surmounted. It occurs only in a<tei:lb/>few species of hemiuroids. It may be of some taxonomic importance at the generic level ; but it is<tei:lb/>often variable in size, sometimes being either difficult to distinguish or prominent in the same<tei:lb/>species, e.g. in Accacladium serpentulum Odhner, 1928, as described by Bray &amp; Gibson (1977).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Permanent sinus-organ - see sinus-organ (permanent).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Plications - regular backwardly directed thickenings of the tegument which surround or partly<tei:lb/>surround the body transversely. They are a feature unique to the hemiurids and the aphanurine<tei:lb/>bunocotylids; but only occur in certain genera, being a feature normally considered to be of<tei:lb/>systematic importance at the generic level (a notable exception being the genus Aphanurus, but<tei:lb/>see p. 65). They may occur over the whole body (soma) or just part of it, and tend to be better<tei:lb/>developed anteriorly than posteriorly, especially in the dorsal field. They are never present on the</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE HEMIUROIDEA 49</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ecsoma. Care should be taken not to confuse these regular tegumental thickenings with a rugate<tei:lb/>appearance caused by contraction, with small transverse ridges caused by circular muscles in<tei:lb/>the body-wall of poorly preserved material (these do occur on the ecsoma), and with transverse<tei:lb/>folds of the body-wall surrounding the suckers of certain bunocotylid genera.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Plications appear to be a primitive hemiurid feature which arose in association with the<tei:lb/>ecsoma (q.v.). They are possibly a feature which permits the thickening of the somatic tegument<tei:lb/>during periods of low pH or high osmolarity when the ecsoma is withdrawn, and yet still allows<tei:lb/>full and easy extension and contraction of the body during periods of activity. Certain genera,<tei:lb/>which possibly no longer inhabit the pyloric region of the stomach or which are parasitic in<tei:lb/>physiologically 'stomachless' fish (see Barrington, 1957), have lost this feature.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pre-acetabular pit - see presomatic pit.<tei:lb/>Precaecal sac - see ' Driisenmagerf '.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pre-oral lobe - a small region of the body anterior to the oral sucker. In some instances it may<tei:lb/>actually overhang the anterior margin of the oral sucker. It has no apparent systematic impor-<tei:lb/>tance, except that it is glandular in one species of Otodistomum (see Gibson &amp; Bray, 1977), as it<tei:lb/>appears to occur, at least to some extent, in all hemiuroids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Presomatic pit (preacetabular pit) - a deep, concave depression, circular or oval in section, which<tei:lb/>is present mid-ventrally just anterior to the ventral sucker. It occurs in certain lecithochiriine<tei:lb/>genera, in the plerurine genus Synaptobothrium and apparently in the aphanurine genus<tei:lb/>Mitrostoma. Great care should be taken in its use as a taxonomic criterion as it is easily confused<tei:lb/>with the ventro-cervical groove (q.v.), which is common in many hemiurids. In the genus<tei:lb/>Lecithochirium this structure can be either present or absent, being very small and difficult to<tei:lb/>distinguish in the type-species: this does not appear, therefore, to be a useful character in dis-<tei:lb/>tinguishing Lecithochirium and Sterrhurus (see p. 93).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The presomatic pit often has a region of glandular tissue around its base ; but its actual func-<tei:lb/>tion is not understood. Lloyd (1938) has suggested that it acts as a chemo-sensory organ and that<tei:lb/>it may be associated with the extrusion and withdrawal of the ecsoma : it would appear that the<tei:lb/>latter certainly cannot be the case in Mitrostoma.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Prostatic sac -a term coined by Gibson (1976) for the muscular sac which surrounds the pars<tei:lb/>prostatica and the seminal vesicle of the azygiids. Its function is not known for certain, but<tei:lb/>presumably it aids the evacuation of spermatozoa and prostatic secretion during ejaculation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Prostatic vesicle - a dilation of the ejaculatory duct within the sinus-sac, which is usually lined by<tei:lb/>glandular cells and occurs in addition to an external pars prostatica. Essentially, it is identical to<tei:lb/>an ejaculatory vesicle (q.v.), except for the presence of the glandular cells. As the latter cells can<tei:lb/>apparently be lost, it does seem unwise to distinguish a prostatic vesicle from an ejaculatory<tei:lb/>vesicle, and, in view of the possibility of confusing the former structure, both nomenclaturally<tei:lb/>and morphologically, with a 'vesicular pars prostatica' (q.v.), it might be advisable to refer to the<tei:lb/>prostatic vesicle as being a 'glandular ejaculatory vesicle'. This structure occurs for certain only<tei:lb/>in the lecithochiriine, glomericirrine and hypohepaticoline genera, and is possibly a feature of<tei:lb/>importance at the subfamily level (if included as a type of ejaculatory vesicle). We do not consider<tei:lb/>that this structure occurs in any of the plerurine or pulmovermine genera, for in these cases the<tei:lb/>pars prostatica itself appears to be partly enclosed by the sinus-sac in cases when the latter is<tei:lb/>present. The function of a prostatic vesicle is probably identical to that suggested for an ejacula-<tei:lb/>tory vesicle.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Receptaculum seminis - see seminal receptacle.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Receptaculum seminis uterinum - see uterine seminal receptacle.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Rudimentary Juel's organ - a form of Juel's organ (q.v.) which lacks an 'inner vesicle' (q.v.). It<tei:lb/>has a granular appearance and is present usually at the distal end (Figs 3B &amp; 4B), but occasionally<tei:lb/>more proximally, of Laurer's canal. It presumably has a similar function to a fully developed<tei:lb/>Juel's organ, into which it has probably evolved in more advanced forms by enveloping the</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>50 D. I. GIBSON &amp; R. A. BRAY</tei:p>
         <tei:p>rudimentary seminal receptacle (q.v.) and forming an 'inner vesicle'. Small, black structures can<tei:lb/>be seen within the amorphous mass which fills this organ: we wonder whether these might be<tei:lb/>bacteria which may carry out the final breakdown of the excess seminal and vitelline material,<tei:lb/>much as we suggest that (?) amoeboid cells might do in a fully developed Juel's organ.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A rudimentary Juel's organ is known to occur in certain derogenine derogenid and prosogono-<tei:lb/>trematine and prosorchiine sclerodistomid genera, but its taxonomic significance, even at the<tei:lb/>generic level, is uncertain. This organ also appears to occur in the aspidogastrean Aspidogaster<tei:lb/>conchicola von Baer, 1826 (see p. 123).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scales -a term used by Manter (1934) to describe the structures on the tegument of Dinosoma.<tei:lb/>We believe that they are probably just regularly crenulate plications (q.v.).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Seminal receptacle - a general term covering several different types of apparatus for the storage<tei:lb/>of spermatozoa in the female reproductive system. In our opinion the various forms of seminal<tei:lb/>receptacle should be clearly differentiated in descriptions, as they are important taxonomic<tei:lb/>criteria. We recognize four different kinds of seminal receptacle present in the Hemiuroidea<tei:lb/>(Fig. 1): (1) a 'blind seminal receptacle' (q.v.), which is a blind sac, linked to the oviduct by a<tei:lb/>short tube, occurring in most of the lecithasterid subfamilies, the opisthadenine bunocotylids and<tei:lb/>the derogenid genus Leurodera, and which appears to have evolved from Juel's organ (q.v.) or<tei:lb/>in some cases from a rudimentary or canalicular seminal receptacle; (2) a 'canalicular seminal<tei:lb/>receptacle' (q.v.), which is a large proximal dilation of Laurer's canal, and occurs frequently in<tei:lb/>other groups of digeneans, but apparently within the Hemiuroidea it occurs for certain only in<tei:lb/>the lecithasterid genus Trifoliovarium and in a modified form in the derogenid genus Progonus;<tei:lb/>(3) a 'rudimentary seminal receptacle' (q.v.), which is a small proximal dilation of Laurer's canal<tei:lb/>that, when present, always occurs together with a uterine seminal receptacle, but this form differs<tei:lb/>from the others in that it is not a store of fresh, quiescent spermatozoa and in that the small<tei:lb/>amount of spermatozoa which it does contain are spent, although often still active; and (4) a<tei:lb/>'uterine seminal receptacle' (q.v.), which is a store of spermatozoa present in the proximal region<tei:lb/>of the uterus, and occurs in the majority of hemiuroids. Another type is an 'oviducal seminal<tei:lb/>receptacle', which is formed as a dilation of the oviduct; but this type does not occur in the<tei:lb/>Hemiuroidea. With the exception the 'rudimentary' and 'uterine' types, the various forms of<tei:lb/>seminal receptacle do not normally occur together in the same individual.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Seminal sac - a term used by Manter (1947) for an oval, muscular sac which encloses a convoluted,<tei:lb/>tubular seminal vesicle in the bunocotylid Opisthadena dimidia Linton, 1910. It appears to be a<tei:lb/>modification of the muscular type of seminal vesicle where the muscular wall is clearly not<tei:lb/>associated with the membranous lining of the seminal vesicle. It also occurs in some of the other<tei:lb/>species of Opisthadena and in the hemiurid Elytrophalloides.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Seminal vesicle - a dilation of the vas deferens (q.v.) which forms a store of spermatozoa which<tei:lb/>is ready for ejaculation. It is often provided with a muscular wall or with sphincter muscles which<tei:lb/>constrict it into portions. These modifications, which are often of systematic importance at the<tei:lb/>generic level, are involved with the evacuation of spermatozoa from the seminal vesicle, through<tei:lb/>the pars prostatica and into the hermaphroditic duct, often against the hydrostatic pressure pro-<tei:lb/>duced by the sinus-sac (q.v.). The shape of the seminal vesicle is also often of specific or generic<tei:lb/>value, as is its position in relation to the ventral sucker. In the more primitive forms it is usually<tei:lb/>tubular. In the hemiuroids the seminal vesicle is normally free in the parenchyma, but in certain<tei:lb/>halipegine derogenids it may be partly or completely enclosed within the sinus-sac., in the azygiids<tei:lb/>it is contained within a prostatic sac (q.v.), and in certain species of Opisthadena it forms a<tei:lb/>'seminal sac' (q.v.).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Sinus-organ (permanent) - a copulatory organ of variable size which is usually formed externally<tei:lb/>from the wall of the normally well-developed genital atrium and internally from the herma-<tei:lb/>phroditic duct. This type of sinus-organ is contractile, but is still visible in sections as a small<tei:lb/>cone when completely retracted. It usually occurs in one of two forms, although intermediate<tei:lb/>forms are sometimes found (Fig. 5):</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>B</tei:p>
         <tei:p>tso</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 5 The types of sinus-organ occurring in the Hemiuroidea: A. Muscular sinus-organ;<tei:lb/>B. Amuscular sinus-organ; C. Temporary sinus-organ, [so, permanent sinus-organ; ss, sinus-sac;<tei:lb/>tso, temporary sinus-organ.]</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>52 D. I. GIBSON &amp; R. A. BRAY</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(1) 'Muscular' - where it is probably everted entirely or partly by its own intrinsic musculature<tei:lb/>(when partly, the remaining force is supplied by hydrostatic pressure produced by the sinus-sac:<tei:lb/>see Gibson &amp; Bray, 1974): this form occurs in many of the more primitive hemiuroid groups<tei:lb/>(see p. 129);</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(2) 'Amuscular'* - a form, associated with the presence of a thick-walled (muscular) seminal<tei:lb/>vesicle, which is probably everted entirely, or almost entirely, by hydrostatic pressure produced<tei:lb/>by the sinus-sac upon its contents: this form occurs in the elytrophalline and glomericirrine<tei:lb/>hemiurids, the muscular seminal vesicle being required to force spermatozoa into the herma-<tei:lb/>phroditic duct against the hydrostatic pressure built up by the walls of the sinus-sac.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The presence or absence and type of sinus-organ are often useful taxonomic criteria up to the<tei:lb/>subfamily level; but the sectioning of specimens is essential and great caution must be exercised<tei:lb/>in the use of this feature. See sinus-organ (temporary).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Sinus-organ (temporary) - an amuscular or weakly muscled copulatory organ, formed from the<tei:lb/>hermaphroditic duct by hydrostatic pressure within the sinus-sac, which is a transitory structure<tei:lb/>(Fig. 5). It is usually only present during copulation, but also occurs occasionally in fixed speci-<tei:lb/>mens. The genital atrium is usually small or apparently absent in forms with a temporary sinus-<tei:lb/>organ. Naturally 'permanent' [see sinus-organ (permanent)] and 'temporary' types of sinus-organ<tei:lb/>cannot occur in the same species of worm. The two forms, however, may be difficult to distinguish<tei:lb/>when only a small number of specimens is available for study. A temporary sinus-organ may be<tei:lb/>associated with slight thickenings in the wall of the seminal vesicle, but is more often associated<tei:lb/>with the presence of sphincter muscles which tend to partition the seminal vesicle and are capable<tei:lb/>of exerting pressure, thus forcing spermatozoa into the sinus-sac against its internal hydrostatic<tei:lb/>pressure during ejaculation. As the genital atrium tends to be short or absent, the temporary<tei:lb/>sinus-organ itself is also short, and, therefore, the hydrostatic pressure required to extrude it is<tei:lb/>reduced. The sinus-sac tends, therefore, to be smaller than in forms with an amuscular permanent<tei:lb/>sinus-organ. A temporary sinus-organ occurs in the more advanced forms of hemiurids, bunocoty-<tei:lb/>lids and lecithasterids. As this transitory structure is rarely seen everted, it is of no systematic<tei:lb/>significance.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Sinus-sac or hermaphroditic sac - a muscular sac which surrounds the base of the genital atrium,<tei:lb/>if present, and encloses the hermaphroditic duct and/or the terminal portions of the ejaculatory<tei:lb/>duct and uterus. Its apparent function is to aid the eversion of a permanent sinus-organ (q.v.) or<tei:lb/>the production of a temporary sinus-organ (q.v.) from the hermaphroditic duct. It may also aid<tei:lb/>the expulsion of spermatozoa and eggs, especially the former in cases where an ejaculatory (or<tei:lb/>prostatic) vesicle (q.v.) or the seminal vesicle is enclosed within the sinus-sac. In certain instances,<tei:lb/>e.g. in some of the plerurine hemiurids, there may be a large proximal gap in the wall of the<tei:lb/>sinus-sac at the point through which the male and female ducts pass: this is known as an 'open-<tei:lb/>type' of sinus-sac and is probably a vestigial form. In other groups of hemiuroids the sinus-sac<tei:lb/>may be reduced, or in some cases completely lost. Sectioning is essential when the sinus-sac is<tei:lb/>apparently absent, as the vestiges of this structure are often insignificant. This feature is frequently<tei:lb/>of some importance at the family level, as it is missing in the Azygiidae and Hirudinellidae, which<tei:lb/>possess a 'prostatic sac' (q.v.) and a 'cirrus-sac' (q.v.), respectively; but great care should be<tei:lb/>exercised in the utilization of this feature, as it appears to have been lost independently in certain<tei:lb/>genera from a number of distantly related hemiuroid groups, e.g. Gonocerca, Syncoelium,<tei:lb/>Tetrochetus, Prolecitha and Bunocotyle.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Temporary sinus-organ - see sinus-organ (temporary).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Testes - there are usually two globular testes present in hemiuroids. Exceptions are the syncoeliids,<tei:lb/>which either have a much larger number (11-18) of large oval masses (referred to as testes, al-<tei:lb/>though there are only two vasa erTerentia) or possess apparently follicular testes, and two lecithas-<tei:lb/>terid genera, Monorchiaponurus and Monorchimacradena, which are reported to have one testis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>* Presumably there are some longitudinal muscle fibres present which permit contraction of this type of sinus-organ.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE HEMIUROIDEA 53</tei:p>
         <tei:p>An important feature at the subfamily level (except in some members of the Macradenininae)<tei:lb/>is the relationship between the ovary and the testes, the ovary usually being post-testicular. In<tei:lb/>the azygiine azygiids, the ptychogonimids, the gonocercine derogenids and certain macradeninine<tei:lb/>lecithasterids, however, it is pretesticular, and in the bathycotylids it is inter-testicular. The<tei:lb/>relative positions of the testes and their shape are of little value above the specific level, except<tei:lb/>that in the dictysarcid genus Elongoparorchis they do appear to be consistently elongate. The<tei:lb/>testes normally occur in the hindbody, except in the prosogonotrematine and prosorchiine<tei:lb/>sclerodistomids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Uroproct - the aperture of the excretory vesicle when the base of the latter organ communicates<tei:lb/>directly with the distal extremities of the gut-caeca. A uroproct, therefore, serves as an orifice for<tei:lb/>the evacuation of waste-products from both the excretory and alimentary systems. This structure<tei:lb/>occurs independently and regularly in the Accacoeliidae, Hirudinellidae, Ptychogonimidae and<tei:lb/>Otiotrematinae, but, except for the Accacoeliinae and the Ptychogonimidae, it does not occur in<tei:lb/>all of the genera in these groups. It is normally considered to be a feature of generic importance.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Uterine ootype - the proximal region of the uterus, present in some species, into which the region<tei:lb/>of egg-formation extends. Its systematic importance is not understood. See ootype.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Uterine seminal receptacle or receptaculum seminis uterinum - a term given to the proximal region<tei:lb/>of the uterus when it is filled with 'fresh' spermatozoa and is, therefore, acting as a seminal store<tei:lb/>(Fig. 1). This region can normally only be differentiated from the remainder of the uterus by the<tei:lb/>presence of spermatozoa. It is the commonest form of seminal receptacle (q.v.) present in the<tei:lb/>Hemiuroidea, being absent only in the lecithasterids (with the exception of the Hysterolecithinae),<tei:lb/>the opisthadenine bunocotylids and in the derogenids Progonus and Leurodera. This type of<tei:lb/>seminal receptacle is probably associated with cross-insemination, using the genital atrium as a<tei:lb/>vagina, or with self-insemination, and differs from all other types of seminal receptacle in that<tei:lb/>spermatozoa pass towards the ovary through the ootype. In the past many workers have mistaken<tei:lb/>this structure for a canalicular seminal receptacle (q.v.), but in sectioned material the two can<tei:lb/>easily be distinguished. Except in the cases of the derogenids Progonus and Leurodera, the presence<tei:lb/>or absence of this type of seminal receptacle is an important systematic feature at the subfamily<tei:lb/>level. Great care must be exercised with the use of this feature because it is by nature transitory,<tei:lb/>and, when empty, it is not recognizable as a seminal store. We have observed, in sectioned<tei:lb/>material, specimens of Hirudinella and Prosorchiopsis (forms possessing a uterine seminal recep-<tei:lb/>tacle) which do not have any spermatozoa in the proximal region of the uterus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Uterus - a duct, normally full of eggs, which links the ootype with the hermaphroditic duct,<tei:lb/>genital atrium or genital pore. The distal extremity may be modified to a form metraterm (q.v.),<tei:lb/>and the proximal extremity may form a uterine seminal receptacle (q.v.) or a uterine ootype (q.v.).<tei:lb/>In addition to transporting eggs, the proximal region of the uterus appears to be involved in the<tei:lb/>hardening and tanning of the egg-shells. The uterus often coils between the ovary and the ventral<tei:lb/>sucker, but it may loop well posterior to the ovary and in some cases coils in the forebody. Its<tei:lb/>distribution tends to be of generic importance and occasionally of subfamilial importance,<tei:lb/>especially in cases where it reaches into the post-ovarian field or is entirely pre-ovarian.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Vasa efferentia - single narrow ducts which connect each testis with the vas deferens (q.v.). In<tei:lb/>the Syncoeliinae, where there are 11-18 so-called testes, there are the usual two vasa efferentia,<tei:lb/>and the ducts linking these testes to the vasa efferentia are called 'collecting ducts'. The vasa<tei:lb/>efferentia are of no apparent systematic importance in the Hemiuroidea.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Vas deferens - a duct formed by the fusion of the two vasa efferentia (q.v.), which, in almost all<tei:lb/>cases, is dilate, filled with spermatozoa and referred to as the seminal vesicle (q.v.). In itself,<tei:lb/>therefore, it is of no systematic importance, although in certain groups there is a narrow duct<tei:lb/>linking the seminal vesicle with the pars prostatica (q.v.).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ventro-cervical groove - a transverse crevice which occurs on the ventral surface immediately<tei:lb/>anterior to the ventral sucker in many hemiurids. It appears to have no actual function, as it is</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>54 D. I. GIBSON &amp; R. A. BRAY</tei:p>
         <tei:p>simply caused by the close proximity of the oral and ventral suckers in some of these genera. The<tei:lb/>size of this feature appears to be dependent upon the degree of contraction which occurs in the<tei:lb/>forebody during fixation. It appears to have no systematic value, except that it has occasionally<tei:lb/>been mistaken for a presomatic pit (q.v.).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Vitellarium - a structure of variable morphology that produces vitelline (yolk) cells which<tei:lb/>accompany the ovum in egg-formation. The form of the vitellarium is a valuable taxonomic<tei:lb/>criterion ranging from the species to the family level. The common arrangements of the vitellarium<tei:lb/>in the Hemiuroidea are as follows (see Fig. 7): (1) follicular; (2) linked follicles, giving a chain-<tei:lb/>like tubular arrangement; (3) convoluted tubules which are often branched; (4) about seven<tei:lb/>tubules, usually arranged four on one side of the body and three on the other; (5) about seven<tei:lb/>oval to digitiform lobes; (6) two oval or slightly lobed masses; and (7) a single oval mass. These<tei:lb/>forms tend to grade into one another, but it is noticeable that the seven-lobed vitellarium occurs<tei:lb/>widely throughout the group. The arrangement of the vitellarium is discussed in more detail on<tei:lb/>p. 124. One unusual feature occurs in the Accacoeliinae, where the sinistral side of the system is<tei:lb/>reduced to a vestige. In certain instances, especially in the Lecithasteridae and the Derogenidae,<tei:lb/>the relationship between the vitellarium and the ovary is useful systematically; but the vitellarium<tei:lb/>or at least the origin of the main vitelline ducts is usually post-ovarian, although exceptions to<tei:lb/>this include the azygiids and the accacoeliine accacoeliids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>III. A classification of the Hemiuroidea with keys and definitions<tei:lb/>Introduction</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The following classification, which we propose for the Hemiuroidea, is based upon adult morpho-<tei:lb/>logy associated with an attempt to understand the function of the organs and organ-systems<tei:lb/>(see p. 39). This relies heavily upon comparative morphology, as do most of the previous classi-<tei:lb/>fications. The main problem with this, as discussed above, is that much of the descriptive work<tei:lb/>over the years has been inadequate. Many workers around the turn of the century gave detailed<tei:lb/>and careful descriptions, based upon sectioned material. Work of this standard has been the<tei:lb/>exception, rather than the rule, since that time. In attempting to provide a feasible classification<tei:lb/>we have, therefore, examined as many species as possible, both in serial sections and whole-<tei:lb/>mounts. The lack of certain material has left large gaps, which have had to be filled with a critical<tei:lb/>appraisal of the literature. In certain groups, and in particular in many individual genera, much<tei:lb/>of the detail necessary to classify the animals has not been supplied by the original authors. In<tei:lb/>these cases our classification is particularly tentative, and we have usually indicated where we<tei:lb/>consider our knowledge to be totally inadequate. In some instances, using our knowledge of the<tei:lb/>groups as a whole and assessing the functional requirements present, we have assumed the<tei:lb/>morphology of certain undescribed or apparently wrongly interpreted structures. While this<tei:lb/>may seem somewhat unsatisfactory, some of our interpretations were proved correct during the<tei:lb/>course of the work, e.g. before specimens were obtained we correctly assumed the presence of a<tei:lb/>sinus-sac, rather than a cirrus-sac, in Arnold and Glomericirrus, and we correctly assumed the<tei:lb/>presence of Juel's organ in Elongopat -orchis and in many of the hemiurids (sensu stricto).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>As far as the systematics of this group is concerned, we have faced many problems in weighing<tei:lb/>the relative values of different factors. At one time we were inclined to give considerable weight<tei:lb/>to the details of the terminal genitalia, and also to the vitellarium. While these factors may have<tei:lb/>significance at the generic or subfamily level, they do seem to be susceptible to development or<tei:lb/>regression in certain groups. The details of the proximal region of the female system have, we<tei:lb/>believe, a fundamental value in distinguishing subfamilies, although there are exceptions to this,<tei:lb/>for in the Derogenidae and the Trifoliovariinae a variety of conditions occur. The presence of<tei:lb/>Juel's organ, for example, seems to be of considerable importance; but, even in this case, care<tei:lb/>has to be taken, and the complete morphological pattern must be taken into consideration.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Definitions of the taxa are presented ; but features common to a group of taxa are given in the<tei:lb/>definition of the higher taxa, rather than repeated throughout the group. Features, especially</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE HEMIUROIDEA 55</tei:p>
         <tei:p>those taken from the literature, which we believe to be questionable, are indicated by question-<tei:lb/>marks.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Wherever possible material was examined, especially in serial section. The abbreviations used<tei:lb/>to indicate what material we have seen are given after the generic name, and are as follows:<tei:lb/>T=type-material of type-species; t=non-type material of type-species ; n=material of non-type-<tei:lb/>species; w=whole-mount; s=serial sections. The absence of this information indicates that the<tei:lb/>data have been derived from the literature.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>We have attempted to provide dichotomous keys to the taxa. Rather than relying upon the<tei:lb/>most obvious of criteria, we have tried to produce keys which work, with the result that the sec-<tei:lb/>tioning of material, while always advisable, may in fact be essential. These keys must be used<tei:lb/>with care, and with the understanding that this classification is based upon polythetic assemblages<tei:lb/>of characters. Soft-bodied animals, such as digeneans, give few good metrical or meristic charac-<tei:lb/>ters, so that it is very important to possess a good understanding of the overall morphology while<tei:lb/>attempting to determine these worms.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Some readers may note that the authorities which we have given for some of the family-<tei:lb/>group names differ from those presented by some other workers. These workers appear to have<tei:lb/>followed a recent trend which tends to confuse systematics and nomenclature. In using the<tei:lb/>authority for the original mention of the family-group name, irrespective of suffix, we are follow-<tei:lb/>ing Article 36 of the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>As with any work of this kind, our classification must be considered provisional. We hope that<tei:lb/>it may be helpful in stimulating and encouraging a closer and more careful examination of the<tei:lb/>worms in this group.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Superfamily HEMIUROIDEA Looss, 1899</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Azygioidea Liihe, 1909<tei:lb/>Accacoelioidea Odhner, 1911<tei:lb/>Isoparorchioidea Travassos, 1922</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Body small to large; oval to cylindrical. Ecsoma present or absent. Body-surface smooth, rugate<tei:lb/>or plicated (or 'scaley'); never spiny, but occasionally papillate. Oral and ventral suckers well<tei:lb/>developed, occasionally small. Ventral sucker normally in middle or anterior half of body,<tei:lb/>occasionally just inside posterior half of body; occasionally pedunculate. Prepharynx absent.<tei:lb/>Pharynx well developed; normally oval, occasionally modified. Oesophagus usually short,<tei:lb/>occasionally long. 'Driisenmagen' present or absent. Gut-caeca usually end blindly near posterior<tei:lb/>extremity, occasionally form cyclocoel or uroproct. Testes normally two, rarely one or follicular;<tei:lb/>normally tandem to symmetrical, preovarian and near middle of body; occasionally in forebody<tei:lb/>or post-ovarian. Seminal vesicle oval to tubular; occasionally constricted into portions usually<tei:lb/>thin- but occasionally thick-walled; in fore- or hindbody; normally external to sinus-sac, rarely<tei:lb/>partly or entirely internal. Pars prostatica tubular to vesicular; long or short; normally external<tei:lb/>to sinus-sac, rarely internal; usually in forebody, occasionally entirely inside, or extending into,<tei:lb/>hindbody. Ejaculatory duct usually present; usually short; often within sinus-sac or sinus-organ;<tei:lb/>normally unites with metraterm to form hermaphroditic duct; occasionally within 'cirrus-sac'.<tei:lb/>Hermaphroditic duct usually present; usually within sinus-sac and/or sinus-organ. Sinus-sac<tei:lb/>present or absent; oval to cylindrical; normally enclosing ejaculatory duct and part of metraterm<tei:lb/>and/or hermaphroditic duct; occasionally additionally enclosing ejaculatory (prostatic) vesicle<tei:lb/>or seminal vesicle and/or pars prostatica. Permanent sinus-organ present or absent within genital<tei:lb/>atrium; conical to tubular; muscular or non-muscular. Temporary sinus-organ sometimes formed<tei:lb/>from hermaphroditic duct. 'Cirrus-sac', enclosing ejaculatory duct only, and 'cirrus' rarely<tei:lb/>present. Genital atrium large, small or absent. Common genital pore mid-ventral in forebody.<tei:lb/>Ovary usually oval, occasionally lobed, rarely tubular or follicular; usually post-testicular,<tei:lb/>occasionally pre-testicular, rarely inter-testicular; normally in hindbody, rarely in forebody.<tei:lb/>Mehlis' gland usually post-ovarian, occasionally pre-ovarian. Uterine seminal receptacle plus<tei:lb/>Laurer's canal and/or Juel's organ or blind seminal receptacle alone normally present. Uterine<tei:lb/>coils usually fill much of hindbody, occasionally extending well into forebody, rarely entirely in<tei:lb/>forebody. Eggs normally oval; usually small, numerous; occasionally with spine, filament(s) or</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>56 D. I. GIBSON &amp; R. A. BRAY</tei:p>
         <tei:p>threads. Vitellarium normally follicular, tubular or composed of a small number (often seven)<tei:lb/>oval to tubular lobes or one to three (usually two) entire or lobed masses; often post-ovarian,<tei:lb/>occasionally pre-ovarian; sometimes extending throughout hindbody or into forebody, rarely<tei:lb/>entirely in forebody. Excretory pore terminal; vesicle Y-shaped; arms united in forebody or not.<tei:lb/>Manter's organ (accessory excretory vesicle) rarely present. Parasitic in gut, especially stomach,<tei:lb/>primarily of marine teleosts, but commonly occur in freshwater teleosts and elasmobranchs,<tei:lb/>occasionally in holosteans, amphibians, reptiles and progenetic in invertebrates; occasionally<tei:lb/>recorded from gills, skin, body-cavity, swim-bladder and other organs.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to Hemiuroidea</tei:p>
