         <tei:p>presomatic pit absent OPISTHADENA</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3. A. Vitellarium 2 symmetrical, oblique or tandem masses ..... GENOLINEA<tei:lb/>B. Vitellarium 3 masses, the anterior pair being symmetrical and the posterior mass being the</tei:p>
         <tei:p>largest NEOTHELETRUM</tei:p>
         <tei:p>OPISTHADENA Linton, 1910</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Body elongate. Transverse ridge (fold) of body-wall around body immediately posterior to<tei:lb/>ventral sucker. Testes tandem; posterior to middle of body. Seminal vesicle in hindbody; usually<tei:lb/>tubular and sinuous, but reported as enclosed within muscular, ovoid sac ['seminal sac' of<tei:lb/>Manter, 1947] or as being saccular. Pars prostatica tubular; not reaching further forward than<tei:lb/>posterior margin of ventral sucker. Ejaculatory duct long. Sinus-sac oval. Hermaphroditic duct<tei:lb/>may be sub-divided. Sinus-organ apparently present as small cone, at least temporarily. Ovary<tei:lb/>close to testes. Uterus mainly pre-ovarian. Vitellarium two symmetrical to oblique masses; post-<tei:lb/>ovarian. Excretory arms diverticulate; united in forebody. Parasitic in stomach of marine teleosts<tei:lb/>(especially Kyphosus}.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPE-SPECIES. Opisthadena dimidia Linton, 1910 [by original designation].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENOLINEA Manter, 1925 [t(w,s); n(w,s)]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Parasterrhurus Manter, 1934<tei:lb/>Intuscirrus Acena, 1947<tei:lb/>Pseudobunocotyla Yamaguti, 1965</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Body spindle-shaped to slightly elongate. Transverse ridge usually present around body immedia-<tei:lb/>tely posterior to ventral sucker (often inconspicuous and frequently not reported); similar ridge<tei:lb/>may surround oral sucker. Large pre-oral lobe may be present. Ventral sucker normally in<tei:lb/>anterior half of body, (?) occasionally near middle; sphincter muscles sometimes present around<tei:lb/>aperture. Testes tandem to oblique; close to ovary. Seminal vesicle small; tubular; convoluted in<tei:lb/>forebody, occasionally dorsal or postero-dorsal to ventral sucker. Pars prostatica tubular to<tei:lb/>vesicular; short. Ejaculatory duct short or absent. Sinus-sac oval to elongate oval; small. Sinus-<tei:lb/>organ occasionally present (? temporary). Ovary near middle of hindbody. Uterus usually in both<tei:lb/>pre- and post-ovarian fields, occasionally post-vitelline distribution is limited. Metraterm reported<tei:lb/>in some instances to be spinous (?). Vitellarium two compact (occasionally lobed), symmetrical,<tei:lb/>oblique or tandem masses; posterior or postero-lateral to ovary. Excretory arms united in fore-<tei:lb/>body. Parasitic mainly in stomach of marine teleosts.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPE-SPECIES. Genolinea lalicauda Manter, 1925 [by original designation].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENT. The position of the ventral sucker near the middle of the body in G. dactylopagri<tei:lb/>Manter, 1954, is much further posterior than normally occurs in this family. The morphology<tei:lb/>of this species suggests that it is related to Lewodera Linton, 1910, as Manter (1954) initially<tei:lb/>believed, and both are recorded from related percoid families of teleosts.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MITROSTOMA Manter, 1954</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Body elongate. Thickened projection present on each side of body at level of posterior margin of<tei:lb/>ventral sucker. Nipple-shaped protuberance (? vestige of ecsoma) may be present at posterior<tei:lb/>extremity. Weakly muscled pre-oral lobe bears mouth. Structure resembling (?) presomatic pit<tei:lb/>apparently present anterior to ventral sucker. Ventral sucker with 'sphincter muscles in anterior<tei:lb/>and posterior halves'. Testes tandem; close to ovary; near middle of hindbody. Seminal vesicle</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>68 D. I. GIBSON &amp; R. A. BRAY</tei:p>
         <tei:p>tubular; convoluted; entirely in hindbody. Pars prostatica tubular; reaches forward to caecal<tei:lb/>bifurcation. Ejaculatory duct short or absent. Sinus-sac short; pyriform; (?) protrusible. Ovary<tei:lb/>in posterior half of hindbody. Uterus mainly pre-ovarian, but does extend into post-vitelline<tei:lb/>region. Vitellarium two oblique to symmetrical, post-ovarian masses. Excretory arms united in<tei:lb/>forebody. Parasitic in intestine of marine teleosts.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPE-SPECIES. Mitrostoma nototheniae Manter, 1954 [by original designation].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENT. There are several features of the genus Mitrostoma, such as the overall arrangement of<tei:lb/>the organs, the apparent presence of a presomatic pit and the reported presence of a nipple-shaped<tei:lb/>protuberance at the posterior extremity of one specimen, which suggests that it might be a hemiurid<tei:lb/>with a lost or vestigial ecsoma, no longer required because of its intestinal habitat. Manter (1954),<tei:lb/>however, reported that a blind seminal receptacle was present. The presence of this type of<tei:lb/>seminal receptacle, as opposed to a uterine seminal receptacle, and the great morphological<tei:lb/>similarity between this parasite and Genolinea bower si (Leiper &amp; Atkinson, 1914), reported from<tei:lb/>related nototheniid hosts (Prudhoe &amp; Bray, 1973), indicate that its position within the Opistha-<tei:lb/>deninae is probably correct.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>NEOTHELETRUM gen. nov.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Body small; elongate to spindle-shaped. Tegumental fold around body posterior to ventral sucker<tei:lb/>apparently absent. Body-surface smooth. Ventral sucker in anterior half of body. Pre-pharynx<tei:lb/>absent. Pharynx well developed. Oesophagus short; often with small diverticulum. Gut-caeca end<tei:lb/>blindly near posterior extremity. Testes 2; oval; oblique to symmetrical; usually separated from<tei:lb/>ventral sucker by loops of uterus; occasionally sandwiched between ventral sucker and ovary.<tei:lb/>Seminal vesicle small ; tubular to saccular ( ? occasionally bipartite) ; in forebody. Pars prostatica<tei:lb/>short; tubular to vesicular. Ejaculatory duct short or absent. Sinus-sac small; oval. Small tem-<tei:lb/>porary sinus-organ may form. Hermaphroditic duct short; formed within sinus-sac. Genital<tei:lb/>atrium small. Genital pore mid-ventral in forebody. Ovary oval (may occasionally be bilobed);<tei:lb/>post-testicular; near middle of hindbody. Blind seminal receptacle antero-dorsal to ovary.<tei:lb/>Laurer's canal, Juel's organ and both canalicular and uterine seminal receptacle presumably<tei:lb/>absent. Uterus almost entirely in hindbody; usually with roughly equal amounts in pre- and post-<tei:lb/>ovarian fields; occasionally with majority of uterus in post-ovarian field. Eggs small; numerous;<tei:lb/>without filaments. Vitellarium three compact, entire or slightly indented masses; anterior pair<tei:lb/>symmetrical, connected by narrow isthmus; posterior mass larger, may be slightly bilobed<tei:lb/>[vitellarium is essentially two tandem masses, the anterior of which is divided into two distinct<tei:lb/>lobes: the vitellarium may appear as two tandem masses in lateral view]; post-ovarian. Excretory<tei:lb/>arms united in forebody or not. Parasitic in stomach of marine teleosts.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPE-SPECIES. Neotheletrum lissosomum (Manter, 1940) n. comb.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENT. Neotheletrum differs from Theletrum in that: (1) a blind rather than a uterine seminal<tei:lb/>receptacle is present; (2) much of the uterus is post-ovarian rather than being between the ovary<tei:lb/>and testes; (3) the anterior vitelline mass is consistently divided into two; and (4) the tegumental<tei:lb/>ridge around the body immediately posterior to the ventral sucker is absent.<tei:lb/>The additional species which we include in this genus are as follows :</tei:p>
         <tei:p>N. frontilatum (Manter, 1969) n. comb.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>N. gravidum (Manter, 1940) n. comb.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>N. magnasaccum (Sogandares-Bernal &amp; Sogandares, 1961) n. comb, [possibly a synonym<tei:lb/>of N. lissosomum].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>N. pomacentri (Nahhas &amp; Cable, 1964) n. comb.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>N. frontilatum, which Yamaguti (1971) considers to belong to Hysterolecithoides, differs from the<tei:lb/>other species of Neotheletrum in that the uterus is almost entirely post-ovarian, the testes are<tei:lb/>close behind the ventral sucker and close to the ovary, and the excretory arms are not united in<tei:lb/>the forebody. On these grounds a case could be made for erecting a new genus for this species;<tei:lb/>but we have included it in Neotheletrum as there seems little point in further sub-division at<tei:lb/>present.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE HEMIUROIDEA 69</tei:p>
         <tei:p>THELETRINAE subfam. nov.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Body elongate. Ecsoma absent. Body-surface smooth ; papillae may be present ventrally in fore-<tei:lb/>or hindbody; transverse ridge may be present around body near posterior margin of ventral<tei:lb/>sucker and possibly around oral sucker. Oral and ventral suckers well developed ; ventral sucker<tei:lb/>in anterior half of body. Prepharynx absent. Pharynx well developed. Oesophagus short. Gut-<tei:lb/>caeca end blindly near posterior extremity, (?) or at level of ovary. Testes two; pre-ovarian;<tei:lb/>tandem to oblique; near middle of hindbody; separated from ovary by majority or large part of<tei:lb/>uterine coils. Seminal vesicle tubular or (?) saccular; in forebody, but sometimes reaching back to<tei:lb/>posterior margin of ventral sucker. Pars prostatica short; tubular or slightly vesicular. Ejaculatory<tei:lb/>duct short or apparently absent. Sinus-sac usually small; oval or elongate oval; weakly developed;<tei:lb/>enclosing hermaphroditic duct; may extrude slightly through genital pore. Permanent sinus-<tei:lb/>organ absent (?), but temporary sinus-organ may form. Genital atrium small or absent. Ovary<tei:lb/>oval ; near posterior extremity or at least well inside posterior half of hindbody. Laurer's canal<tei:lb/>and both canalicular or blind seminal receptacle absent [Laurer's canal reported present (?) in<tei:lb/>Indoderogenes], Uterine seminal receptacle present. Juel's organ assumed to be present. Uterus<tei:lb/>almost entirely or mainly in hindbody (small part of uterus is coiled in forebody of Monoleci-<tei:lb/>thotremd) ; mainly pre-ovarian, with large proportion of uterine coils between ovary and testes.<tei:lb/>Eggs numerous; small; without filaments. Vitellarium one entire or two tandem to oblique, entire<tei:lb/>or slightly lobed masses ; posterior or postero-lateral to ovary. Excretory vesicle Y-shaped ; arms<tei:lb/>united in forebody. Parasitic normally in stomach of marine teleosts.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENT. This subfamily is erected for forms which resemble the Opisthadeninae; but lack a<tei:lb/>blind seminal receptacle, possess a uterine seminal receptacle (plus presumably Juel's organ) and<tei:lb/>contain a large concentration of uterine coils between the ovary and testes. The position of<tei:lb/>Indoderogenes Srivastava, 1937, discussed below, is problematical; but in gross morphology it<tei:lb/>does appear to key satisfactorily to this subfamily.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The sinus-sac in both Theletrum and Monolecithotrema often appears to be slightly extruded<tei:lb/>through the genital pore. It is not clear from our observations of the type-species if this is in<tei:lb/>fact so, or whether a temporary sinus-organ is formed by an eversion of the hermaphroditic duct.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to Theletrinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 . A. Vitellarium single (great care should be taken with this observation, as at certain angles the</tei:p>
         <tei:p>vitellarium of Theletrum appears to be single); transverse ridge posterior to ventral<tei:lb/>sucker absent; some uterine coils in forebody . . . . MONOLECITHOTREMA<tei:lb/>B. Vitellarium double; uterus not coiled in forebody ....... 2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2. A. Seminal vesicle tubular; transverse ridge normally present posterior to ventral sucker;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>gut-caeca terminate near posterior extremity ...... THELETRUM</tei:p>
         <tei:p>B. Seminal vesicle saccular; transverse ridge posterior to ventral sucker not reported; gut-<tei:lb/>caeca apparently terminate at level of anterior margin of ovary. . INDODEROGENES</tei:p>
         <tei:p>THELETR UM Linton, 1910 [t( w)]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Transverse tegumental ridge present around body immediately posterior to ventral sucker and<tei:lb/>possibly around oral sucker. Papillae may be present ventrally in hindbody. Gut-caeca terminate<tei:lb/>at posterior extremity. Testes fairly close together, but separated by uterus. Seminal vesicle<tei:lb/>tubular. Pars prostatica slightly vesicular. Sinus-sac elongate oval; thin-walled; sheath-like; may<tei:lb/>be partly extruded through genital pore. Ovary close to posterior extremity. Uterine coils en-<tei:lb/>tirely or almost entirely in hindbody; few or no coils posterior to vitellarium. Vitellarium two<tei:lb/>oblique, entire or slightly lobed masses; close together; posterior or postero-lateral to ovary;<tei:lb/>at posterior extremity of body. Parasitic in stomach (occasionally intestine) of marine teleosts.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPE-SPECIES. Theletrum fust if orme Linton, 1910 [by original designation].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENT. We agree with Yamaguti (1971) that this genus is monospecific. We do not agree,<tei:lb/>however, that the remainder of the species allocated to this genus should be placed in Genolinea<tei:lb/>Manter, 1925, and have, therefore, erected a new genus, Neotheletrum, in the Opisthadeninae to</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>70 D. I. GIBSON &amp; R. A. BRAY</tei:p>
         <tei:p>accommodate them (see p. 68). Our observations of the type-species confirm that a uterine<tei:lb/>seminal receptacle is present as indicated by Yamaguti's (1971) and possibly Vigueras' (1958)<tei:lb/>figures. Bunocotyle sudatlantica Parukhin, 1976, may belong to this genus, as it possesses many<tei:lb/>morphological similarities and is recorded from the same family of host (Chaetodontidae).<tei:lb/>Parukhin's (19760) description, however, indicates that there is a single vitelline mass and a<tei:lb/>cyclocoel present. Nevertheless, when viewed from certain angles T. just if or me can appear to<tei:lb/>possess only one vitelline mass, and the presence or absence of a cyclocoel is often difficult to<tei:lb/>ascertain in this family. Certainly, Parukhin's material does not fit within our concept of<tei:lb/>Bunocotyle.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(^INDODEROGENES Srivastava, 1937</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Transverse ridge around body posterior to ventral sucker apparently absent. Gut-caeca terminate<tei:lb/>close to anterior margin of ovary. Testes separated by uterine coils. Seminal vesicle saccular<tei:lb/>(flask-shaped). Pars prostatica tubular. Sinus-sac (?) absent. Hermaphroditic duct short. Sinus-<tei:lb/>organ small ( ? temporary). Genital atrium small. Ovary close to posterior extremity. Laurer's<tei:lb/>canal reported present (?). Uterine coils entirely or almost entirely in hindbody; entirely or<tei:lb/>almost entirely pre-ovarian. Vitellarium two tandem to oblique masses; posterior or postero-<tei:lb/>lateral to ovary ; at posterior extremity of body. Parasitic in stomach of marine teleosts.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPE-SPECIES. Indoderogenes purii Srivastava, 1937 [by monotypy].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENT. This genus, initially defined in an abstract by Srivastava (19376) and later (1941) des-<tei:lb/>cribed in more detail, is known from only three specimens. In gross morphology it appears<tei:lb/>similar to the other two genera of this subfamily, although Srivastava (1941) reported the presence<tei:lb/>of Laurer's canal. We have some doubts about this, as such an observation on whole-mounts with<tei:lb/>a large, dense uterine field, as his figure indicates, must be questionable. Despite the fact that no<tei:lb/>mention was made by Srivastava of the presence of a sinus-sac, there may have been one present,<tei:lb/>as this structure is either small or weakly developed in the other genera of this subfamily.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>If Laurer's canal is proved to be present by future workers, this genus should be transferred to<tei:lb/>the Halipeginae Poche, 1926, where, although sharing some of its features with Deropegus<tei:lb/>McCauley &amp; Pratt, 1961, its gross morphology does not conform to the normal derogenid pattern.<tei:lb/>In addition, unlike the majority of halipegines this genus was recorded from a marine teleost,<tei:lb/>although the locality of the record, an almost land-locked bay in the Bay of Bengal, is brackish<tei:lb/>at certain times of the year.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MONOLECITHOTREMA Yamaguti, 1970 [T(w)]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Transverse ridges around body absent. Papillae may be present ventrally in forebody. Gut-caeca<tei:lb/>terminate blindly at posterior extremity. Testes close together, but sometimes separated by uterus.<tei:lb/>Seminal vesicle tubular ; usually extending back dorsally to ventral sucker. Pars prostatica tubular;<tei:lb/>poorly developed ; linked to seminal vesicle by aglandular duct. Sinus-sac small ; poorly developed ;<tei:lb/>may be slightly extruded through genital pore. Ovary well inside posterior half of hindbody.<tei:lb/>Small proportion of uterus may be coiled in forebody; small part of uterus extends posteriorly to<tei:lb/>vitellarium. Vitellarium one large, entire mass; immediately post-ovarian. Parasitic in stomach<tei:lb/>of marine teleosts.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPE-SPECIES. Monolecithotrema kala Yamaguti, 1970 [by original designation].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENT. Examination of 14 paratype-specimens mounted on a single slide shows that a uterine<tei:lb/>seminal receptacle is present, and that Yamaguti was probably mistaken in his observation of a<tei:lb/>small seminal receptacle between the ovary and the vitellarium. This structure corresponds with<tei:lb/>the position of Mehlis' gland, but might also have been part of the uterine seminal receptacle,<tei:lb/>JuePs organ (until sectioned material is examined we are assuming that this is present) or even a<tei:lb/>diverticulum of the gut-caeca. As in Theletrum, the uterine seminal receptacle tends to extend<tei:lb/>posteriorly to the vitellarium.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE HEMIUROIDEA 71</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Family DEROGENIDAE Nicoll, 1910</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Halipegidae Poche, 1926<tei:lb/>Liocercidae Ejsmont, 1931</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Body normally small; usually spindle-shaped to elongate oval. Ecsoma absent. Body-surface<tei:lb/>smooth. Oral and ventral suckers well developed; ventral sucker usually near middle of body,<tei:lb/>occasionally more anterior or posterior. Pharynx well developed. Oesophagus short. 'Driisen-<tei:lb/>magen' usually present. Gut-caeca end blindly or form cyclocoel. Testes two; symmetrical to<tei:lb/>tandem; pre- or post-ovarian; in hindbody. Seminal vesicle thin- walled; oval, elongate or tubular;<tei:lb/>not constricted into portions; in forebody; occasionally partly or wholly enclosed within sinus-<tei:lb/>sac. Pars prostatica usually tubular, occasionally vesicular; occasionally enclosed within sinus-<tei:lb/>sac. Ejaculatory duct short or absent; often within sinus-sac. Sinus-sac normally present, occasion-<tei:lb/>ally absent ; usually small and oval ; often weakly developed ; may enclose all or part of pars<tei:lb/>prostatica and seminal vesicle. Permanent sinus-organ present as small cone or absent. Herma-<tei:lb/>phroditic duct normally present; occasionally absent; usually short. Genital atrium present or<tei:lb/>absent; usually small. Genital pore mid-ventral in forebody. Ovary oval; pre- or post-testicular.<tei:lb/>Mehlis' gland normally post-ovarian or occasionally at level of ovary. Seminal storage and dis-<tei:lb/>posal apparatus variable. Laurer's canal usually present; either opening dorsally to exterior or<tei:lb/>leading into Juel's organ ; often dilated proximally to form small rudimentary seminal receptacle,<tei:lb/>which is occasionally enlarged to form an apparently functional canalicular seminal receptacle.<tei:lb/>Juel's organ absent or present in either rudimentary or fully-developed state. Blind seminal<tei:lb/>receptacle present rarely. Uterine seminal receptacle normally present; rarely absent. Uterus may<tei:lb/>or may not extend posterior to vitellarium ; significant proportion of uterus usually coiled in<tei:lb/>forebody. Eggs numerous; with or without filaments or threads; rarely with anopercular spine.<tei:lb/>Vitellarium one or two masses ; entire or lobed (lobes normally shallow, rarely digitate) ; pre- or<tei:lb/>post-ovarian; symmetrical, oblique or tandem. Excretory vesicle Y-shaped; arms united in fore-<tei:lb/>body. Parasitic usually in gut (normally stomach) of freshwater and marine teleosts, but occasion-<tei:lb/>ally recorded from amphibians, reptiles and freshwater shrimps.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENT. This is a family which does not have a constant seminal storage and disposal apparatus<tei:lb/>in the female system. As discussed below (p. 124), the variations of this apparatus probably occur<tei:lb/>because they are a diverse and successful, but relatively primitive group, which appear to have<tei:lb/>evolved at about the time when the first modifications of the primitive arrangement of the seminal<tei:lb/>storage and disposal apparatus began to occur. The variety of conditions found in this group tend<tei:lb/>to parallel those which have occurred during the evolution of some of the more advanced hemi-<tei:lb/>uroids, such as the hemiurids, bunocotylids and lecithasterids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to Derogenidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 . A. Testes posterior to ovary and vitellarium GONOCERCINAE (p. 74)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>B. Testes anterior to ovary and vitellarium ......... 2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2. A. Parasites primarily of freshwater teleosts, but occasionally present in brackish water or</tei:p>
         <tei:p>marine teleosts close to the ancient Sarmatic Sea region [Caspian. Black and Mediterra-<tei:lb/>nean Seas], in amphibians, in reptiles and in freshwater shrimps; ventral sucker<tei:lb/>occasionally anterior to middle of body; uterus not present posterior to vitellarium;<tei:lb/>sinus-sac, when present, may enclose part of or entire seminal vesicle and/or pars</tei:p>
         <tei:p>prostatica HALIPEGINAE (p. 75)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>B. Parasitic in marine teleosts ; ventral sucker not present in anterior half of body ; uterus often<tei:lb/>extends posterior to vitellarium; sinus-sac present, never enclosing any part of pars<tei:lb/>prostatica or seminal vesicle DEROGENINAE (p. 71)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Subfamily DEROGENINAE Nicoll, 1910</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(?) Liopyginae Ejsmont, 1931<tei:lb/>(?) Liocercinae Ejsmont, 1931<tei:lb/>Genarchinae Skrjabin &amp; Guschanskaja, 1955<tei:lb/>Orthoruberinae Nasir &amp; Gomez, 1977</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>72 D. I. GIBSON &amp; R. A. BRAY</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ventral sucker in middle or posterior to middle of body. Gut-caeca end blindly or form cyclocoel.<tei:lb/>Testes pre-ovarian; symmetrical to oblique. Seminal vesicle small; globular to tubular. Pars<tei:lb/>prostatica usually tubular, occasionally vesicular; short or long. Sinus-sac present; globular to<tei:lb/>cylindrical. Permanent sinus-organ present; small; cone-shaped. Hermaphroditic duct normally<tei:lb/>short. Genital atrium small; often filled by sinus-organ. Ovary close behind testes. Laurer's canal<tei:lb/>present or absent; opening dorsally or into rudimentary Juel's organ; may be dilated proximally<tei:lb/>forming large rudimentary or functional canalicular seminal receptacle. Blind seminal receptacle<tei:lb/>present when Laurer's canal and uterine seminal receptacle absent; latter usually present. Uterus<tei:lb/>coiled throughout hindbody and part of forebody; significant proportion of uterus often present<tei:lb/>posterior to vitellarium. Eggs without filaments or threads, but may have anopercular spine.<tei:lb/>Vitellarium two symmetrical to tandem, oval or slightly indented masses ; posterior or occasionally<tei:lb/>lateral and postero-lateral to ovary. Parasitic in gut (mainly stomach) of marine teleosts.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to Derogeninae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1. A. Uterus not normally extending posterior to vitellarium ...... 4</tei:p>
         <tei:p>B. Significant proportion of uterus posterior to vitellarium ...... 2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2. A. Cyclocoel present PROGONUS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>B. Gut-caeca end blindly ............ 3</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3. A. Eggs drawn into sharp point at anopercular pole .... DEROGENOIDES<tei:lb/>B. Eggs lacking point at anopercular pole DEROGENES</tei:p>
         <tei:p>4. A. Vitelline masses tandem to oblique, lateral and postero-lateral to ovary; blind seminal</tei:p>
         <tei:p>receptacle present LEURODERA</tei:p>
         <tei:p>B. Vitelline masses symmetrical to oblique, post-ovarian; Laurer's canal and presumably</tei:p>
         <tei:p>uterine seminal receptacle present GONOCERCELLA</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENT. Initially, we considered Gonocercella and Leurodera to be members of the Halipeginae<tei:lb/>because of the pre-vitelline distribution of the uterus. The fact that they parasitize marine teleosts<tei:lb/>and the structure of the terminal genitalia, however, clearly associated them with the Derogeninae.<tei:lb/>It could also be argued that Arnold, Magnibursatus and Tyrrhenia, which are present in teleosts<tei:lb/>from the brackish to marine conditions of the Black and Mediterranean Seas, should be included<tei:lb/>in the Derogeninae. The structure of the terminal genitalia, however, is different from that of the<tei:lb/>latter group. In addition, these three genera are morphologically related to some of the Asian<tei:lb/>halipegines from freshwater and can be historically and zoogeographically related to the hali-<tei:lb/>pegines of the central Asian region via the ancient Sarmatic Sea.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DEROGENES Liihe, 1900 [n(w,s)]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(1) Liopyge Looss, 1899<tei:lb/>(l)Liocerca Looss, 1902</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gut-caeca end blindly near posterior extremity. Testes symmetrical to oblique. Seminal vesicle<tei:lb/>globular to tubular and sinuous. Pars prostatica short to long. Sinus-sac globular. Male and female<tei:lb/>ducts unite within sinus-organ. Ovary usually close behind testes; may be lateral to posterior<tei:lb/>testis when latter is oblique. In D. varicus Laurer's canal opens distally into rudimentary Juel's<tei:lb/>organ and dilates proximally forming large rudimentary seminal receptacle. Uterine seminal<tei:lb/>receptacle present. Uterine field usually extends from posterior extremity to region of genital<tei:lb/>pore; significant proportion of uterus posterior to vitellarium. Eggs without anopercular spine.<tei:lb/>Vitelline masses symmetrical to oblique; globular or slightly indented; post-ovarian. Parasitic in<tei:lb/>stomach, oesophagus or occasionally gall-bladder of marine ( ? and freshwater) teleosts.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPE-SPECIES. Derogenes ruher Liihe, 1900 [by monotypy].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENT. The overall morphology ofLiopyge bonnieri (Monticelli, 1893) is probably identical to<tei:lb/>that of Derogenes, if the vitellarium and the testes have been confused. It is difficult to believe,<tei:lb/>however, that an experienced worker like Monticelli would make such a mistake, especially as he<tei:lb/>originally considered his specimens to be Distoma varicum [now Derogenes varicus (Miiller,<tei:lb/>1780)], and later re-named them Distoma bonnieri. Monticelli recorded this species from Trig/a</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE HEMIUROIDEA 73</tei:p>
         <tei:p>gurnardus in the English Channel. Evidence against the validity of the genus Liopyge is that in<tei:lb/>spite of the abundance of this host it has never been found a second time, although Derogenes<tei:lb/>various has been recorded from the English Channel in Trigla gurnardus by Nicoll (1914) and in<tei:lb/>T. lucerna by Nicoll (1914), Baylis &amp; Jones (1933) and by ourselves: we have re-checked the<tei:lb/>determination of the last two records. Until there is more conclusive evidence for the existence<tei:lb/>of Liopyge, therefore, we are including this genus, and its synonym Liocerca, as questionable<tei:lb/>synonyms of Derogenes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The genus Pronopyge Looss, 1 899, has been considered to be a close relative of Liopyge (see<tei:lb/>Yamaguti, 1971). Its type-species was originally quoted as P. ocreata (Rudolphi, 1802); but<tei:lb/>Fasciola ocreata of Rudolphi (1802) was shown by Odhner (1911) to be a species of Hemiurus,<tei:lb/>and, as stated by Poche (1926), Pronopyge must be considered a junior synonym of the latter<tei:lb/>genus. Monticelli (1891) considered Distoma ventricosum Rudolphi, 1819 (and van Beneden, 1871)<tei:lb/>[nee D. ventricosum (Pallas, 1774)], and Distomum carolinae Stossich, 1889, to be synonyms of<tei:lb/>Fasciola ocreata Rudolphi, 1802. Figures of these two species by van Beneden (1871) and Stossich<tei:lb/>(1889) and of'Apoblema ocreata' by Monticelli (1891) suggest that they belong to the fellodistomid<tei:lb/>genus Pseudopentagramma Yamaguti, 1971 (a junior synonym of Pronoprymna Poche, 1926 - see<tei:lb/>Bray &amp; Gibson, in prep.) and they are similar to figures of Pseudopentagramma symmetrica<tei:lb/>(Chulkova, 1939) produced by Margolis &amp; Ching (1965).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DEROGENOIDES Nicoll, 1913</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gut-caeca end blindly. Testes symmetrical to oblique. Seminal vesicle small; globular. Pars<tei:lb/>prostatica short. Sinus-sac somewhat cylindrical with proximal end slightly enlarged. Sinus-<tei:lb/>organ (?) presumably present. Ovary immediately posterior to testes. Laurer's canal and Juel's<tei:lb/>organ (?). Seminal receptacle (? rudimentary) reported. Uterine seminal receptacle (?). Much of<tei:lb/>uterus present posterior to vitellarium. Eggs drawn out to sharp point at anopercular pole.<tei:lb/>Vitelline masses entire; symmetrical; post-ovarian. Parasitic in stomach and intestine of marine<tei:lb/>teleosts.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPE-SPECIES. Derogenoides ovacutus Nicoll, 1913 [by original designation].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENT. Derogenoides skrjabini Vlasenko, 1931, was made the type-species of Magnibursatus<tei:lb/>by Naidenova (1969). D. tetralecithum Roman, 1955, and possibly D. sargi Pogoreltseva, 1954,<tei:lb/>also appear to be halipegines.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GONOCERCELLA Manter, 1940</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ventral sucker in posterior half of body. Gut-caeca end blindly. Testes oblique. Seminal vesicle<tei:lb/>tubular; coiled. Pars prostatica vesicular. Sinus-sac small. Sinus-organ a muscular cone. Ovary<tei:lb/>immediately posterior to testes; close to posterior extremity. Laurer's canal opens dorsally (ac-<tei:lb/>cording to MacCallum, 1913). Blind or canalicular seminal receptacle absent. Uterine seminal<tei:lb/>receptacle presumably present. Juel's organ presumably absent. Uterus mainly coiled in forebody ;<tei:lb/>not reaching posterior to vitellarium. Eggs without anopercular spine. Vitelline masses entire;<tei:lb/>symmetrical; post-ovarian; close to posterior extremity. Parasitic in stomach of marine teleosts.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPE-SPECIES. Gonocercella pacifica Manter, 1940 [by original designation].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>LEURODERA Union, 1910 [n(w)]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Orthoruberus Nasir &amp; Gomez, 1977</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Body oval; stout. Gut-caeca end blindly near posterior extremity. Testes symmetrical; largely or<tei:lb/>partly extra-caecal. Seminal vesicle tubular; slightly sinuous. Pars prostatica short; with few to<tei:lb/>many external gland-cells ; may be partly tubular and vesicular anteriorly. Sinus-sac oval. Sinus-<tei:lb/>organ small (well developed and conical in Orthoruberus}. Ovary just posterior to testes; close to<tei:lb/>posterior extremity. Laurer's canal, Juel's organ and uterine seminal receptacle apparently absent.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>74 D. I. GIBSON &amp; R. A. BRAY</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Blind seminal receptacle present; large; antero-ventral, antero-lateral or antero-dorsal to ovary.<tei:lb/>Uterus anterior to vitellarium; much of it pre-testicular. Eggs without anopercular spine. Vitelline<tei:lb/>masses entire or slightly indented; tandem to oblique; lateral and postero-lateral to ovary.<tei:lb/>Parasitic in gut (mainly stomach) of marine teleosts (especially Pomadasyidae).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPE-SPECIES. Leurodera decora Linton, 1910 [by original designation].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENT. Leurodera ocyri Travassos, Teixeira de Freitas &amp; Blihrnheim, 1965, and L. inaequalis<tei:lb/>Travassos, Teixeira de Freitas &amp; Buhrnheim, 1966, are not, in our opinion, specimens of Leurodera.<tei:lb/>The descriptions appear to resemble Lecithophyllum and Aponurus, and Overstreet (1973) con-<tei:lb/>sidered these two species to be synonyms of Aponurus pyriformis (Linton, 1910).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>PROGONUS Looss, 1899 [t(w,s)]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Genarches Looss, 1902</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cyclocoel present. Testes symmetrical. Seminal vesicle elongate, spindle-shaped, elongate oval or<tei:lb/>globular. Pars prostatica short; slightly vesicular. Sinus-sac small; globular. Ovary sinistral; half-<tei:lb/>way between testes and posterior extremity. Canalicular seminal receptacle present. Laurer's<tei:lb/>canal ends blindly after passing dorsally through cyclocoel. Rudimentary JueFs organ present as<tei:lb/>small dilations of Laurer's canal at distal extremity and especially at junction with seminal<tei:lb/>receptacle. Uterine seminal receptacle absent. Uterus extends posteriorly to vitellarium ; fills most<tei:lb/>of hindbody and some of forebody. Eggs without anopercular spine. Vitelline masses entire;<tei:lb/>symmetrical; post-ovarian. Parasitic in stomach of marine teleosts.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPE-SPECIES. Progonus muelleri (Levinsen, 1881) [by original designation].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENT. In agreement with Poche (1926) and Bray (in press), Progonus Looss, 1899, cannot be<tei:lb/>considered a junior homonym ofProgona Berg, 1 882 (Recommendation of Article 36, International<tei:lb/>Rules of Zoological Nomenclature, 1926; Article 56(a), International Code of Zoological<tei:lb/>Nomenclature, 1961).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The apparent canalicular seminal receptacle present in this genus is essentially a type of blind<tei:lb/>seminal receptacle, especially as Laurer's canal does not open dorsally. The canalicular seminal<tei:lb/>receptacle (sensu stricto) is not found in the Hemiuroidea, except in the case of Trifoliovarium, and<tei:lb/>is normally associated with the use of Laurer's canal as a vagina during copulation (see Gibson &amp;<tei:lb/>Bray, 1975).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Subfamily GONOCERCINAE Skrjabin &amp; Guschanskaja, 1955<tei:lb/>Hemiperinae Yamaguti, 1958</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ventral sucker posterior to middle of body. Gut-caeca end blindly. Testes post-ovarian; tandem<tei:lb/>to symmetrical; near posterior extremity. Seminal vesicle usually small; oval to tubular; in fore-<tei:lb/>body. Pars prostatica tubular; short; linked to seminal vesicle by short, aglandular duct. Sinus-<tei:lb/>sac absent or poorly developed. Sinus-organ absent or present as small, blunt cone. Herma-<tei:lb/>phroditic duct absent or short. Genital atrium small or apparently absent. Ovary between testes<tei:lb/>and vitellarium. Laurer's canal present; opening dorsally; dilated proximally forming small rudi-<tei:lb/>mentary seminal receptacle. JueFs organ absent. Uterine seminal receptacle present. Uterus en-<tei:lb/>tirely pre-ovarian; most of coils usually in forebody. Eggs filamented or not. Vitellarium two<tei:lb/>entire or indented, oval masses; symmetrical; antero- to postero-lateral to ovary. Parasitic in<tei:lb/>stomach or branchial cavity of marine teleosts.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to Gonocercinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1. A. Eggs without filaments; sinus-sac and sinus-organ absent (but see comment on Gonocerca)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GONOCERCA<tei:lb/>B. Eggs filamented; sinus-sac weakly developed; sinus-organ present. . . HEMIPERA</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE HEMIUROIDEA 75</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GONOCERCA Manter, 1925 [t(w,s&gt;]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ventral sucker in posterior half of body. Testes tandem to almost symmetrical; at posterior<tei:lb/>extremity of body. Seminal vesicle small; thin-walled; oval; close behind genital pore. Pars<tei:lb/>prostatica short; tubular. Sinus-sac and sinus-organ absent [see Comment]. Hermaphroditic<tei:lb/>duct absent (assuming that the small cavity into which male and female ducts open is the genital<tei:lb/>atrium). Genital atrium small or apparently absent. Ovary median. Uterus entirely pre-ovarian;<tei:lb/>largely in forebody. Eggs without filaments. Vitelline masses lateral or antero-lateral to ovary;<tei:lb/>entire to indented. Parasitic in stomach of marine teleosts (especially in mid-ocean).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPE-SPECIES. Gonocerca phycidis Manter, 1925 [by monotypy].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENT. Manter (1934) described G. phycidis and G. crassa with a genital papilla present in<tei:lb/>both, and Laurer's canal absent in the latter. Our sectioned material of G. phycidis indicates that<tei:lb/>a sinus-organ is absent and that a well-developed Laurer's canal is present (see Gibson, 1976:<tei:lb/>figs 14b and 14c).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Since Manter's work there have also been conflicting opinions as to the presence of Laurer's<tei:lb/>canal in G. crassa, Yamaguti (19386) stating it to be present and Rees (1953) absent. Both Rees<tei:lb/>(1953) and Brinkmann (1975) agree that a small but distinct genital atrium and genital papilla<tei:lb/>^sinus-organ) are present in G. crassa. If this is so, this species can hardly be considered to be<tei:lb/>congeneric with the other species of the genus. In view of the great morphological variability of<tei:lb/>G. phycidis and the morphological similarity with Derogenes varicus, with which G. crassa has<tei:lb/>been recorded, we consider that any change in its taxonomic status should await a complete<tei:lb/>redescription.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HEMIPERA Nicoll, 1913 [t(w,s)]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hemiperina Manter, 1934</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ventral sucker in posterior half of body. Testes symmetrical to oblique at posterior extremity.<tei:lb/>Seminal vesicle oval to tubular. Pars prostatica tubular; short. Seminal vesicle and pars prostatica<tei:lb/>may apparently be enclosed by common, sub-globular, parenchymatous capsule. Sinus-sac<tei:lb/>weakly developed ; with diffuse musculature ; enclosing base of sinus-organ and proximal region<tei:lb/>of genital atrium. Sinus-organ a blunt cone. Male and female ducts may open separately on sinus-<tei:lb/>organ or form short hermaphroditic duct. Ovary median. Uterus entirely pre-ovarian; largely in<tei:lb/>forebody. Eggs filamented. Vitelline masses antero- to postero-lateral to ovary; entire or slightly<tei:lb/>indented. Parasitic in stomach or branchial cavity of marine teleosts.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPE-SPECIES. Hemipera ovocaudata Nicoll, 1913 [by original designation].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Subfamily HALIPEGINAE Poche, 1926</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Arnolinae Yamaguti, 1958<tei:lb/>Monovitellinae Ataev, 1970</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ventral sucker usually near middle of body, occasionally more anterior or posterior. Gut-caeca<tei:lb/>end blindly or form cyclocoel. Testes pre-ovarian; symmetrical to oblique or occasionally tandem<tei:lb/>to oblique. Seminal vesicle globular to tubular; sometimes entirely or partly internal. Pars<tei:lb/>prostatica tubular to vesicular; normally short; sometimes internal. Sinus-sac present or absent;<tei:lb/>usually weakly developed ; may enclose pars prostatica and all or part of seminal vesicle. Sinus-<tei:lb/>organ present or absent; when present usually small, poorly developed and cone-shaped. Herma-<tei:lb/>phroditic duct usually short, occasionally long; rarely absent. Genital atrium small. Ovary<tei:lb/>usually close to posterior extremity. Laurer's canal present; with dorsal pore or short and leading<tei:lb/>into Juel's organ. Rudimentary seminal receptacle often present when Laurer's canal opens<tei:lb/>dorsally. Blind or canalicular seminal receptacle absent. Uterine seminal receptacle present.<tei:lb/>Uterus entirely or almost entirely anterior to vitellarium; coils extend into forebody, except in<tei:lb/>cases with ventral sucker inside anterior half of body. Eggs with or without filaments or threads.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>76 D. I. GIBSON &amp; R. A. BRAY</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Vitellarium one or two masses at posterior extremity of body; usually entire, but sometimes with<tei:lb/>indistinct or digitate lobes. Excretory bifurcation normally in hindbody, occasionally in forebody.<tei:lb/>Usually parasitic in gut (normally stomach) of freshwater teleosts; also recorded from brackish<tei:lb/>water and marine teleosts close to the ancient Sarmatic Sea region (Caspian, Black and Mediter-<tei:lb/>ranean Seas), amphibians, reptiles and freshwater shrimps (the majority of genera occur in Asia).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENT. Certain genera of halipegines are closely related, differing basically in the apparent<tei:lb/>presence or absence of filaments or threads on the eggs or in the degree of union between the two<tei:lb/>vitelline masses. One such group comprises Allotangiopsis, Chenia, Genarchopsis, Monovitella<tei:lb/>and Tangiopsis, all of which occur in central, southern and south-east Asia. Another such group<tei:lb/>is Arnold, Magnibursatus and possibly Anguillotrema and Tyrrhenia, which, with the exception of<tei:lb/>Anguillotrema from central China, come from the Black or Mediterranean Seas.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>There appear to be fundamental differences in the seminal disposal apparatus in the female<tei:lb/>reproductive system, as some genera possess Laurer's canal with a dorsal opening and others<tei:lb/>have a fully developed Juel's organ. The systematic significance of this must await further work,<tei:lb/>because the arrangement in most of the genera is as yet unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to Halipeginae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1. A. Eggs with filaments or threads .......... 2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>B. Eggs without filaments or threads 8</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2. A. Cyclocoel present ...........</tei:p>
         <tei:p>B. Gut-caeca end blindly .4</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3. A. Cyclocoel and excretory bifurcation in forebody .... ALLOTANGIOPSIS<tei:lb/>B. Cyclocoel and excretory bifurcation in hindbody .... GENARCHOPSIS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>4. A. Vitellarium a single mass CHENIA</tei:p>
         <tei:p>B. Vitellarium two similar masses .......... 5</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5. A. Vitelline masses entire; sinus-sac completely enclosing pars prostatica and seminal</tei:p>
         <tei:p>vesicle; ventral sucker in anterior half of body; uterine coils retained in hindbody</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MA GNIBURSA TVS<tei:lb/>B. Vitelline masses usually lobed; ventral sucker near middle of body or more posterior;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>uterine coils extend into forebody ......... 6</tei:p>
         <tei:p>6. A. Vitelline masses lobed (usually with 4 and 5 small lobes) or occasionally entire . . 7<tei:lb/>B. Vitelline masses with about 8 digitate extensions ..... THOMETREMA</tei:p>
         <tei:p>7. A. Sinus-sac encloses pars prostatica and entire seminal vesicle; vitelline masses lobed</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ANGUILLOTREMA</tei:p>
         <tei:p>B. Sinus-sac usually weakly developed or (?) absent, sometimes enclosing prostatica gland-<tei:lb/>cells, occasionally enclosing pars prostatica, rarely enclosing distal extremity of seminal<tei:lb/>vesicle; vitelline masses usually lobed, occasionally entire . . . HALIPEGUS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>8. A. Cyclocoel present; ventral sucker near middle of body; uterine coils extend into forebody 10<tei:lb/>B. Gut-caeca end blindly 9</tei:p>

         <tei:p>10. A. Vitellarium a single mass MONOVITELLA</tei:p>
         <tei:p>B. Vitellarium two similar masses situated close together .... TANGIOPSIS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>11. A. Sinus-sac encloses pars prostatica and seminal vesicle ARNOLA</tei:p>
         <tei:p>B. Sinus-sac small, not enclosing pars prostatica and seminal vesicle. . . DEROPEGUS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HALIPEGUS Looss, 1899 [t(w); n(w,s)]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Genarchella Travassos, Artigas &amp; Pereira, 1928<tei:lb/>Vitellotrema Guberlet, 1928<tei:lb/>Dollfuschella Vercammen-Grandjean, 1960<tei:lb/>Progenarchopsis Fischthal, 1976<tei:lb/>Paravitellotrema Watson, 1976</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ventral sucker near middle of body. Gut-caeca end blindly. Testes symmetrical to slightly<tei:lb/>oblique. Seminal vesicle saccular. Pars prostatica short; often reduced. Sinus-sac usually weakly</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE HEMIUROIDEA 77</tei:p>
         <tei:p>developed or ( ?) absent ; often enclosing pars prostatica and, on some occasions, distal extremity<tei:lb/>of seminal vesicle. Temporary sinus-organ may be developed as conical papilla (may occasionally<tei:lb/>be permanent); on some occasions male and female ducts open separately through this papilla.<tei:lb/>Hermaphroditic duct, when present, short. Genital atrium normally small. Ovary usually separa-<tei:lb/>ted from testes by uterus, but not always. Laurer's canal present, with dorsal pore; proximal<tei:lb/>region dilate forming rudimentary seminal receptacle. Juel's organ absent. Uterus not extending<tei:lb/>posteriorly to vitellarium; usually with about equal distribution in fore- and hindbodies. Eggs<tei:lb/>with long, single filament at anopercular pole. Vitellarium two relatively symmetrical masses;<tei:lb/>usually clearly four- and five-lobed, sometimes indistinctly lobed or entire. Parasitic in upper<tei:lb/>regions of gut (usually stomach) of freshwater teleosts, amphibians and reptiles; those from<tei:lb/>amphibians often recorded from mouth, one record from ear (Cosmopolitan).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPE-SPECIES. Halipegus ovocaudatus (Vulpian, 1859) [by monotypy].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENT. Our concept of Halipegus may be considered wide; but, until more of the constituent<tei:lb/>species have been carefully and critically described, we believe that this concept is the most useful.<tei:lb/>In particular there appears to be a need for careful descriptions of the terminal genitalia in this<tei:lb/>genus: that of the type-species, for instance, is poorly known. The vitellarium is rather variable,<tei:lb/>the paired masses being distinctly lobed in the type-species and in most other species in the genus,<tei:lb/>weakly or indistinctly lobed in some species [e.g. H. kessleri (Grebnitzky, 1872)] and entire in<tei:lb/>some species [e.g. H. [Vitellotrema] fusipora (Guberlet, 1928), H. [=Genarchella] parva<tei:lb/>(Travassos, Artigas &amp; Pereira, 1928) and the two species of Paravitellotrema Watson, 1976].<tei:lb/>Halipegus cryptorchis Mane-Garzon &amp; Gascon, 1973, is morphologically similar to Deropegus,<tei:lb/>especially in the rather anterior position of the ventral sucker. It differs, however, in the eggs<tei:lb/>being filamented and that part of the uterus is coiled in the forebody.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ALLO TANGIOPSIS Yamaguti, 1971</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ventral sucker in middle of body. Cyclocoel present in forebody. Testes symmetrical to oblique.<tei:lb/>Seminal vesicle tubular, stout, recurved. Pars prostatica short, tubular; not delimited. Sinus-sac<tei:lb/>forms muscular wall surrounding hermaphroditic duct (?). Sinus-organ absent (?). Laurer's canal<tei:lb/>and Juel's organ (?). Seminal receptacle reported [presumably either rudimentary type or Juel's<tei:lb/>organ]. Uterine seminal receptacle situated, at least partly, in distal region of uterus. Uterus not<tei:lb/>reaching posterior to vitellarium; significant proportion present in forebody. Eggs filamented.<tei:lb/>Vitellarium two lobed masses; slightly oblique; at posterior extremity. Excretory bifurcation in<tei:lb/>forebody. Parasitic in gonads of freshwater shrimps as (?) progenetic metacercaria (China).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPE-SPECIES. Allotangiopsis shanghaiensis (Yeh &amp; Wu, 1955) [by original designation].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENT. This genus is similar to Tangiopsis, differing only in the presence of filamented eggs<tei:lb/>and in the anterior positions of the cyclocoel and the excretory bifurcation. The latter differences<tei:lb/>might be explained by the relatively caudal position of the ventral sucker, a characteristic of<tei:lb/>metacercariae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ANGUILLOTREMA Chin &amp; Ku, 1974</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ventral sucker in posterior half of body. Gut-caeca end blindly. Testes symmetrical. Seminal<tei:lb/>vesicle tubular; coiled; internal. Pars prostatica vesicular; internal. Sinus-sac large; weakly<tei:lb/>muscled; enclosing pars prostatica and seminal vesicle. Sinus-organ muscular; conical. Laurer's<tei:lb/>canal and Juel's organ (?). Uterus entirely anterior to vitellarium; large proportion in forebody.<tei:lb/>Eggs with a filament at each end and small threads surrounding base of filament at one end.<tei:lb/>Vitellarium two masses with four and five lobes; symmetrical at posterior extremity. Parasitic in<tei:lb/>stomach of eels in freshwater (China).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPE-SPECIES. Anguillotrema papillatum Chin &amp; Ku, 1974 [by original designation].</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>78 D. I. GIBSON &amp; R. A. BRAY</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ARNOLA Strand, 1942 [t(w,s)]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Arnoldia Vlasenko, 1931, nee Mayer-Eymar, 1887</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ventral sucker in anterior half of body. Gut-caeca end blindly close to posterior extremity. Testes<tei:lb/>oblique; separated by uterus. Seminal vesicle coiled, tubular; internal. Pars prostatica short,<tei:lb/>straight; internal. Sinus-sac enclosing seminal vesicle and pars prostatica plus metraterm distally.<tei:lb/>Permanent sinus-organ absent. Short hermaphroditic duct and genital atrium present. Ovary<tei:lb/>immediately posterior to hind testis. Short, dilate Laurer's canal, containing sperm, opens into<tei:lb/>well-developed Juel's organ. Uterine seminal receptacle present. Uterus entirely anterior to<tei:lb/>vitellarium; coils not extending into forebody. Eggs without filaments. Vitellarium two sym-<tei:lb/>metrical masses; situated close together at posterior extremity; slightly indented, usually indicating<tei:lb/>three and four lobes. Parasitic in stomach of marine teleosts (Diplodus) in Black Sea and Adriatic<tei:lb/>Sea.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPE-SPECIES. Arnold microcirrus (Vlasenko, 1931) [by original designation].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENT. The low salinity of the Black Sea and the similarity between this genus and several<tei:lb/>genera from freshwater in Central Asia and the Far East suggest that Arnola might be a relict<tei:lb/>from the ancient Sarmatic Sea, which arose in the upper Miocene epoch, contained brackish water<tei:lb/>and extended from the Black Sea region easterly into Central Asia. Our finding Arnola in the<tei:lb/>Adriatic Sea in no way invalidates this hypothesis, as a connection between this region of the<tei:lb/>Mediterranean Sea and the Sarmatic Sea (then called the Karangat Sea) occurred briefly during<tei:lb/>the Pleistocene epoch [see Zenkevitch, 1947; Ekman, 1953; Miller, 1972].<tei:lb/>This genus appears to be closely related to Magnibursatus, Anguillotrema and Tyrrhenia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CHENIA Hsu, 1954</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ventral sucker just posterior to middle of body. Gut-caeca terminate blindly at level of ovary.<tei:lb/>Testes oblique. Seminal vesicle a curved, elongate sac. Pars prostatica internal (?; see figure 1 of<tei:lb/>Hsu). Sinus-sac enclosing attenuated anterior portion of seminal vesicle and pars prostatica.<tei:lb/>Sinus-organ not reported. (?) Seminal receptacle (presumably either rudimentary or Juel's organ)<tei:lb/>reported. Uterus entirely pre-ovarian; coils extending into forebody. Eggs reniform; with two<tei:lb/>filaments at one pole. Vitellarium single compact mass at posterior extremity. Parasitic in gut of<tei:lb/>freshwater gobiid teleosts (China).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPE-SPECIES. Chenia cheni Hsu, 1954 [by monotypy].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DEROPEGUS McCauley &amp; Pratt, 1961<tei:lb/>Parahalipegus Wootton &amp; Powell, 1964</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ventral sucker in anterior half of body. Gut-caeca end blindly near posterior extremity. Testes<tei:lb/>tandem, oblique or symmetrical. Seminal vesicle saccular. Pars prostatica short; tubular to<tei:lb/>slightly vesicular; surrounded by dense layer of gland-cells. Sinus-sac apparently present, but<tei:lb/>weakly developed; small. Sinus-organ a muscular cone. Ovary usually separated from testes by<tei:lb/>loops of uterus. Laurer's canal present; apparently opening dorsally; slightly dilated proximally,<tei:lb/>forming a rudimentary seminal receptacle. Juel's organ presumably absent. Uterine coils not ex-<tei:lb/>tending into forebody; one loop may reach posterior to vitellarium. Eggs without filaments.<tei:lb/>Vitellarium two symmetrical to oblique, entire or slightly lobed masses; close to posterior<tei:lb/>extremity. Parasitic in stomach of amphibians and teleosts in freshwater (North America).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPE-SPECIES. Deropegus aspina (Ingles, 1936) [by original designation].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENARCHOPSIS Ozaki, 1925</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ophiocorchis Srivastava, 1933</tei:p>
         <tei:p>( ?) Pseudogenarchopsis Yamaguti, 1971</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE HEMIUROIDEA 79</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ventral sucker in posterior half, or occasionally in middle, of body. Cyclocoel present in hind-<tei:lb/>body; oesophageal pouch often present. Testes usually oblique, occasionally symmetrical.<tei:lb/>Seminal vesicle tubular to elongate-saccular; coiled. Pars prostatica short; may be slightly vesi-<tei:lb/>cular. Sinus-sac not clearly described, but may be weakly developed and enclose pars prostatica<tei:lb/>and perhaps distal extremity of seminal vesicle. Sinus-organ a strongly muscular, blunt cone.<tei:lb/>Ovary usually sinistral and well posterior to testes. Laurer's canal opening into well-developed<tei:lb/>Juel's organ, or apparently opening dorsally (?). Uterus entirely pre-ovarian; coils extending into<tei:lb/>forebody. Eggs with long, polar filament. Vitellarium two entire or indented masses at posterior<tei:lb/>extremity; symmetrical to oblique. Parasitic mainly in stomach of freshwater teleosts, but there<tei:lb/>are two records from amphibians and two probable accidental infestations of snakes (Southern<tei:lb/>Asia and Far East).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPE-SPECIES. Genarchopsis goppo Ozaki, 1925 [by original designation].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENT. Genarchopsis thapari Gupta &amp; Chakrabarti, 1967, from the intestine of a snake, is<tei:lb/>known only from four immature worms, and it is probably a fish-parasite which has been in-<tei:lb/>gested by the wrong host. Yamaguti (1971) erected the genus Pseudogenarchopsis for this species;<tei:lb/>but his only apparent valid criterion for doing so is that this species is purported to have a cirrus-<tei:lb/>sac. As far as Ophiocorchis is concerned, this genus is said to differ from Genarchopsis in posses-<tei:lb/>sing an oesophageal pouch. Rai (1972) found this feature either present or absent in one species<tei:lb/>(G. goppo), and it cannot be considered a character of generic importance.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A well-developed Juel's organ in G. punctati Agrawal, 1966, was described by Anjaneyulu<tei:lb/>(1967) and Madhavi &amp; Rao (1974); but Ozaki (1925) described G. goppo, the type-species, as<tei:lb/>having Laurer's canal which opened dorsally. It seems unlikely that species with such apparently<tei:lb/>different seminal and vitelline disposal apparatus could be congeneric, but more detailed infor-<tei:lb/>mation is required on G. goppo and other species in this genus in order to resolve this problem.<tei:lb/>Both Rai (1972) and Pandey (1975) also note the presence of Laurer's canal in G. goppo, but<tei:lb/>neither of them states how it terminates.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MAGNIBURSATUS Naidenova, 1969</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ventral sucker in anterior half of body. Gut-caeca end blindly close to posterior extremity. Testes<tei:lb/>oblique, in anterior hindbody. Seminal vesicle coiled, tubular; internal. Pars prostatica short,<tei:lb/>straight; internal. Sinus-sac enclosing seminal vesicle and pars prostatica, plus the metraterm<tei:lb/>distally; in forebody. Sinus-organ absent. Short hermaphroditic duct or genital atrium present.<tei:lb/>Laurer's canal ends blindly (? in Juel's organ). Uterine seminal receptacle present. Ovary near<tei:lb/>posterior extremity; separated from testes by uterus. Uterus entirely anterior to vitellarium;<tei:lb/>coils not extending into forebody. Eggs with several (? six to eight) filaments (? threads) at each<tei:lb/>end. Vitellarium two oblique to symmetrical masses; close together at posterior extremity.<tei:lb/>Parasitic in stomach of euryhaline or marine teleosts (Black Sea region).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPE-SPECIES. Magnibursatus skrjabini (Vlasenko, 1931) [by original designation].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MONOVITELLA Ataev, 1970</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ventral sucker in middle of body. Cyclocoel present in hindbody. Testes symmetrical. Seminal<tei:lb/>vesicle saccular. Pars prostatica short; vesicular. Sinus-sac reported absent (figure suggests it<tei:lb/>might be present as weakly muscled, tubular jacket of hermaphroditic duct). Sinus-organ<tei:lb/>absent (?). Genital atrium short. Ovary lateral; apparently extra-caecal ; situated between right<tei:lb/>testis and vitellarium. Laurer's canal and Juel's organ (?). Uterus almost entirely anterior to<tei:lb/>vitellarium, but descending loop reaches close to posterior extremity; coils extend into forebody.<tei:lb/>Eggs not filamented. Vitellarium a single, entire mass; lateral; apparently extra-caecal between<tei:lb/>ovary and posterior extremity. Parasitic in intestine of brackish water teleosts (Caspian Sea).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPE-SPECIES. Monovitella cyclointestina Ataev, 1970 [by original designation].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENT. Monovitella, despite certain apparent differences, is remarkably similar to Tangiopsis,</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>80 D. I. GIBSON &amp; R. A. BRAY</tei:p>
         <tei:p>both of which are reported from gobiid fishes. Future work might show the two to be synonymous.<tei:lb/>Chenia is also morphologically similar and reported from gobiid fishes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TANGIOPSIS Skrjabin &amp; Guschanskaja, 1955</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ventral sucker in middle of body. Cyclocoel present; caeca unite anterior to testes. Testes sym-<tei:lb/>metrical to oblique. Seminal vesicle tubular; recurved. Pars prostatica small; free in parenchyma<tei:lb/>(according to Tang, 1951; but his figure suggests that the prostatic glands may be delimited or<tei:lb/>that the duct is vesicular and he has omitted the external gland-cells). Sinus-sac apparently absent.<tei:lb/>Temporary sinus-organ may be present (?). Ovary between right testis and vitellarium. Laurer's<tei:lb/>canal opens dorsally. Juel's organ presumably absent. Rudimentary seminal receptacle apparently<tei:lb/>present. Uterus not passing posterior to vitellarium; almost entirely pre-ovarian; coils extend into<tei:lb/>forebody ; apparently filled with spermatozoa throughout most of its length. Eggs without fila-<tei:lb/>ments. Vitellarium two slightly indented, symmetrical masses ; close together at posterior extremity ;<tei:lb/>united by short duct. Parasitic in stomach of freshwater teleosts (China).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPE-SPECIES. Tangiopsis chinensis (Tang, 1951) [by original designation].<tei:lb/>COMMENT: This genus is similar to Monovitella.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>THOMETREMA Amato, 1968</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ventral sucker in middle of body. Gut-caeca end blindly near posterior extremity. Testes oblique<tei:lb/>to symmetrical; separated by loops of uterus. Seminal vesicle tubular; stout; attenuated anterior-<tei:lb/>ly; recurved. Pars prostatica with narrow lumen; surrounded by dense, oval mass of gland-cells.<tei:lb/>Sinus-sac not reported, but possibly present surrounding long hermaphroditic duct (see figures of<tei:lb/>Szidat, 1954). Sinus-organ present as small papilla in base of oval genital atrium (not reported by<tei:lb/>Amato, 1968). Ovary near posterior extremity; separated from testes by many loops of uterus;<tei:lb/>may have slightly irregular outline. Laurer's canal and Juel's organ (?). Uterus entirely pre-<tei:lb/>ovarian ; coils extending into forebody. Eggs with one polar filament. Vitellarium two symmetrical<tei:lb/>masses of about eight short, digitate lobes, which are irregularly expanded distally. Parasitic in<tei:lb/>stomach of freshwater teleosts (Plecostomus}, occasionally in estuarine conditions (South<tei:lb/>America).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPE-SPECIES. Thometrema magnified (Szidat, 1954) n. comb. [syn. T. portoalegrensis Amato,<tei:lb/>1968 - type by original designation].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENT. This genus was erected for a new species, T. portoalegrensis, from Plecostomus com-<tei:lb/>mersoni in Brazil by Amato (1968). The species Gonocercella magnified was described by Szidat<tei:lb/>(1954) from the same host in the estuary of the River Plate and from Plecostomus plecostomus in<tei:lb/>a neighbouring locality to Amato's record. Szidat's description is identical to that of Amato,<tei:lb/>with the exception that he described and figured the terminal genitalia in more detail and did<tei:lb/>not observe the filament on the egg. Considering that there is no evidence that Szidat teased out<tei:lb/>the eggs or sectioned his specimens, we have little hesitation in synonymizing the two species, as<tei:lb/>the presence of filamented eggs is often difficult to ascertain in whole-mounts.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYRRHENIA* Paggi &amp; Orecchia, 1975</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ventral sucker near middle of body. Gut-caeca end blindly near posterior extremity. Testes<tei:lb/>oblique. Seminal vesicle saccular, but attenuated distally; internal. Pars prostatica (?) short,<tei:lb/>tubular (according to Paggi &amp; Orecchia the prostatica cells empty into the hermaphroditic duct);<tei:lb/>internal. Sinus-sac enclosing entire seminal vesicle and pars prostatica, plus metraterm distally.<tei:lb/>Permanent sinus-organ absent. Hermaphroditic duct short. Genital atrium apparently absent (or<tei:lb/>small). Laurer's canal present, with rudimentary seminal receptacle. Juel's organ absent. Uterine</tei:p>
         <tei:p>* Paggi &amp; Orecchia (1974) first used this name in an abstract, but without an accompanying description.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE HEMIUROIDEA 81</tei:p>
         <tei:p>seminal receptacle present. Ovary immediately posterior to hind testis. Uterine coils reach pos-<tei:lb/>teriorly to vitellarium and extend into forebody. Eggs without filaments. Vitellarium two entire,<tei:lb/>symmetrical masses; situated close together immediately posterior to ovary and close to posterior<tei:lb/>extremity. Parasitic in stomach and on gills of marine teleosts (Blennius) in Mediterranean<tei:lb/>(Tyrrhenian) Sea.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPE-SPECIES. Tyrrhenia blennii Paggi &amp; Orecchia, 1975 [by original designation].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CHELATREMA Gupta &amp; Kumari, 1970, gen. inq.<tei:lb/>Genus of uncertain position</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This genus was erected in an abstract by Gupta &amp; Kumari (1970) for a new species, C. smythi<tei:lb/>[type by monotypy], from the Indian freshwater fish Chela baccala. It is said to belong to the<tei:lb/>subfamily Arnolinae of the family Hemiuridae. The genus is unrecognizable from the brief<tei:lb/>definition given, and appears to have characters unusual, or unknown, in the Hemiuroidea.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Family DICTYSARCIDAE Skrjabin &amp; Guschanskaja, 1955</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cylindrorchiidae Poche, 1926</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Aerobiotrematidae Yamaguti, 1958</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pelorohelminthidae Fischthal &amp; Kuntz, 1964</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Albulatrematidae Yamaguti, 1965</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tetrasteridae Oshmarin, 1965</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dollfustravassosiidae Teixeira de Freitas &amp; Kohn, 1967</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Body usually large; oval; stout or flattened. Ecsoma absent. Body-surface smooth. Oral and<tei:lb/>ventral suckers well developed; ventral sucker in anterior half of body. Pharynx well developed.<tei:lb/>Oesophagus short. 'Driisenmagen' normally present (?). Gut-caeca end blindly close to posterior<tei:lb/>extremity. Testes two; large; symmetrical; oval or elongate; pre-ovarian; just posterior to ventral<tei:lb/>sucker. Seminal vesicle tubular; in forebody. Pars prostatica tubular. Sinus-sac well developed,<tei:lb/>poorly developed or absent. Permanent sinus-organ absent (? or present as small papilla); tem-<tei:lb/>porary sinus-organ may form. Genital atrium small or absent. Hermaphroditic duct well develop-<tei:lb/>ed or indistinguishable from genital atrium ; sometimes appears to be continuation of metraterm<tei:lb/>with ejaculatory duct entering laterally. Ovary oval or with four (or five) short or elongate lobes;<tei:lb/>normally separated from testes by loops of uterus. JuePs organ* and uterine seminal receptacle<tei:lb/>present. Laurer's canal and blind or canalicular seminal receptacle absent. Uterus almost entirely<tei:lb/>retained in hindbody; mainly pre-ovarian or with many loops in post-ovarian field. Eggs without<tei:lb/>filaments; may link together and form chains. Vitellarium with six to eight (usually seven,<tei:lb/>arranged three and four) oval to digitiform lobes, or with two lateral acinous groups of follicles<tei:lb/>or two compact multilobulate masses ; postero- to antero-lateral or posterior to ovary. Excretory<tei:lb/>arms united in forebody. Parasitic in swim-bladder of physostomatous teleosts in a marine<tei:lb/>environment.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENT: The almost unique niche of these parasites in the swim-bladder of physostomatous<tei:lb/>teleosts is shared in the Hemiuroidea by the genus Isoparorchis. Although considered to be closely<tei:lb/>related to the members of the Dictysarcidae by many authors, the latter genus differs because it<tei:lb/>occurs in a freshwater teleost and possesses several primitive features, such as Laurer's canal, a<tei:lb/>tubular vitellarium and a well-developed, muscular sinus-organ.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to Dictysarcidae</tei:p>

         <tei:p>B. Uterine field mainly post-ovarian . . CYLINDRORCHIINAE subfam. inq. (p. 83)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>* Observed in Elongoparorchis (see Madhavi &amp; Rao, 1974) and Dictysarca (see Manter, 1947).</tei:p>

         <tei:p>82 D. I. GIBSON &amp; R. A. BRAY</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2. A. Ovary oval (entire or irregularly lobed); vitellarium two compact multilobulate masses or<tei:lb/>two acinous bunches of follicles; hermaphroditic duct indistinguishable from genital</tei:p>
         <tei:p>atrium DICTYSARCINAE (p. 82)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>B. Ovary 4- (or 5-) lobed ; vitellarium 6-8 (usually 7) digitiform to oval lobes ; hermaphroditic</tei:p>
         <tei:p>duct distinguishable from genital atrium. . . . ALBULATREMATINAE (p. 82)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Subfamily DICTYSARCINAE Skrjabin &amp; Guschanskaja, 1955</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Body stout. Cuticular ridge may encircle mid-hindbody. Testes oval; entire or irregularly lobed.<tei:lb/>Sinus-sac and sinus-organ absent. Hermaphroditic duct indistinguishable from genital atrium;<tei:lb/>tubular; short. Ovary oval; entire or irregularly lobed; in posterior third of hindbody. Uterus<tei:lb/>mainly pre-ovarian, but some loops present in post-ovarian field. Vitellarium two compact<tei:lb/>multilobulate masses or two acinous bunches of follicles; antero- or postero-lateral to ovary.<tei:lb/>Usually parasitic in marine eels.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to Dictysarcinae</tei:p>

         <tei:p>acinous follicles AEROBIOTREMA</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DICTYSARCA Linton, 1910</tei:p>
         <tei:p>No cuticular ridge present encircling mid-hindbody. Testes irregularly lobed. Seminal vesicle<tei:lb/>sinuous. Pars prostatica well developed. Hermaphroditic duct appears to be continuation of<tei:lb/>metraterm, with ejaculatory duct entering laterally. Ovary large; irregularly lobed. Vitellarium<tei:lb/>two compact, multilobulate masses; antero-lateral to ovary. Parasitic in moray eels (Gymnothorax)<tei:lb/>and sea-horses (Hippocampus).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPE-SPECIES. Dictysarca virens Linton, 1910 [by original designation].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>AEROBIOTREMA Yamaguti, 1958</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cuticular ridge present encircling mid-hindbody. Testes entire. Seminal vesicle sigmoid. Pars<tei:lb/>prostatica straight. Ovary small; entire. Vitellarium two acinous bunches of follicles; one antero-<tei:lb/>and one postero-lateral to ovary. Excretory arms with numerous anastomosing side branches,<tei:lb/>mostly lying close to caeca. Parasitic in marine eels (Muraenesox).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPE-SPECIES. Aerobiotrema muraenesocis Yamaguti, 1958 [by original designation].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Subfamily ALBULATREMATINAE Yamaguti, 1965</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pelorohelminthinae Fischthal &amp; Kuntz, 1964<tei:lb/>Tetrasterinae Oshmarin, 1965</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Body flattened to stout. Testes large; oval or elongate. Sinus-sac present; well or poorly developed.<tei:lb/>Hermaphroditic duct distinguishable from genital atrium. Ovary four (or five) distinct, oval or<tei:lb/>elongate lobes; in middle or posterior half of hindbody. Uterus mainly pre-ovarian or extending<tei:lb/>throughout hindbody. Vitellarium seven (occasionally six or eight) digitiform to oval lobes;<tei:lb/>immediately posterior or postero-lateral to ovary. Parasitic in marine ( ? or brackish water)<tei:lb/>teleosts.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to Albulatrematinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>LA. Vitelline lobes, ovarian lobes and testes oval ; ovary in middle of hindbody ; significant pro-<tei:lb/>portion of uterus post-ovarian. ....... ALBULATREMA</tei:p>

         <tei:p>THE HEMIUROIDEA 83</tei:p>
         <tei:p>B. Vitelline lobes and ovarian lobes digitiform; testes elongate; ovary well inside posterior</tei:p>
         <tei:p>half of hindbody; most of uterus pre-ovarian . . . . ELONGOPARORCHIS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ALBULATREMA Yamaguti, 1965</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Body stout. Testes oval. Seminal vesicle tubular; narrow; convoluted [according to Yamaguti,<tei:lb/>1965, the seminal vesicle is replaced by a vas deferens, the distal portion of which is strongly<tei:lb/>muscular, convoluted and enclosed by an apparently muscular capsule]. Pars prostatica sigmoid;<tei:lb/>delimited. Sinus-sac well developed; bulbous. Temporary sinus-organ may be present. Genital<tei:lb/>atrium absent or (?) small. Ovary in middle of hindbody; ovarian lobes oval. Uterus extends<tei:lb/>throughout hindbody, much of it post-ovarian. Vitelline lobes oval to pyriform. Parasitic in<tei:lb/>marine (? or brackish water) teleosts (Albuld).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPE-SPECIES. Albulatrema ovale Yamaguti, 1965 [by original designation].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ELONGOPARORCHIS Rao, 1961 [n(w)]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pelorohelmins Fischthal &amp; Kuntz, 1964</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tet raster Oshmarin, 1965</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dollfustravassosius Teixeira de Freitas &amp; Kohn, 1967</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Body flattened to stout. Testes elongate. Seminal vesicle sinuous; may reach dorsally to ventral<tei:lb/>sucker. Pars prostatica short. Sinus-sac poorly developed; present only distally as vestige sur-<tei:lb/>rounding base of genital atrium. Sinus-organ a small papilla-like structure (? temporary).<tei:lb/>Hermaphroditic duct relatively long; formed as continuation of metraterm, with ejaculatory<tei:lb/>duct entering laterally. Genital atrium oval or elongate-oval. Ovary well inside posterior half of<tei:lb/>hindbody; ovarian lobes digitiform. Uterus mainly pre-ovarian. Eggs may be linked together<tei:lb/>forming chains. Vitelline lobes digitiform; with condensed follicular appearance. Parasitic<tei:lb/>especially in catfishes, such as Arius.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TYPE-SPECIES. Elongopar orchis pneumatis Rao, 1961 [by original designation].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENT. In some descriptions of species of this genus Mehlis' gland has been considered to be<tei:lb/>the ovary and the ovary to be anterior lobes of the vitellarium (see Fischthal &amp; Kuntz, 1964a;<tei:lb/>Teixeira de Freitas &amp; Kohn, 1967; Fischthal &amp; Thomas, 1968; but cf. Yamaguti, 1971).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Subfamily CYLINDRORCHIINAE Poche, 1926, status emend, (subfam. inq.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>[Original description inadequate.] Body elongate-oval. Testes elongate. Terminal genitalia not<tei:lb/>known. Ovary small; oval; just inside posterior half of hindbody. Uterus convoluted posterior<tei:lb/>to ovary ; straight anterior to ovary. Vitellarium two clusters of small follicles ; antero-lateral to<tei:lb/>ovary. Parasitic in marine (? or brackish water) teleosts (Tetrodori).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CYLINDRORCHIS Southwell, 1913, gen. inq.<tei:lb/>Defined as subfamily.<tei:lb/>TYPE-SPECIES. Cylindrorchis tenuicutis Southwell, 1913 [by original designation].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENT. We have included Cylindrorchis as a genus inquirendus because the original description<tei:lb/>of C. tenuicutis is inadequate. Southwell (1913) states: 'As only very few specimens of this parasite<tei:lb/>were obtained, it was found impossible to satisfactorily make out with certainty, the precise<tei:lb/>details of the reproductive system. I am therefore not certain that the following description is<tei:lb/>absolutely correct in every detail'. If Southwell had confused the uterus with the vitellarium, the<tei:lb/>vitellarium for the ovary and the ovary for Mehlis' gland or JueFs organ, then it is conceivable<tei:lb/>that he may have been dealing with immature specimens of Ehngoparorchis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Theoretically, the oldest family-group name available in this family is Cylindrorchiidae Poche,<tei:lb/>1926; but, due to the questionable validity of Cylindrorchis, we feel that it would be inadvisable,<tei:lb/>at this stage, to use this genus as the type-genus of the family.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>84 D. I. GIBSON &amp; R. A. BRAY</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Family HEMIURIDAE Looss, 1899</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lecithochiriidae Liihe, 1901</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dinuridae Looss, 1907</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Elytrophallidae Skrjabin &amp; Guschanskaja, 1954</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Body usually small, but elongate. Ecsoma present, occasionally reduced or vestigial. Body-<tei:lb/>surface smooth or with annular plications; the latter occasionally being serrate giving a scaley<tei:lb/>appearance. Presomatic pit or ventro-cervical groove occasionally present. Oral and ventral<tei:lb/>suckers well developed; usually close together. Pharynx well developed. Oesophagus usually<tei:lb/>short. 'Driisenmagen' normally present. Gut-caeca terminate blindly; usually within ecsoma.<tei:lb/>Testes two; tandem, oblique or symmetrical; pre-ovarian; in hindbody. Seminal vesicle tubular,<tei:lb/>saccular or constricted into portions; muscular or thin-walled; in fore- or hindbody. Pars prosta-<tei:lb/>tica of variable length; usually tubular, but occasionally vesicular; may be linked to seminal<tei:lb/>vesicle by aglandular duct. Ejaculatory duct, if present, usually short. Sinus-sac usually well<tei:lb/>developed, occasionally reduced or absent. Prostatic or ejaculatory vesicle occasionally present<tei:lb/>within sinus-sac. Hermaphroditic duct usually enclosed within sinus-sac. Permanent sinus-<tei:lb/>organ and genital atrium well developed, small or absent; temporary sinus-organ may form from<tei:lb/>hermaphroditic duct in some cases. Genital pore mid-ventral at level of oral sucker or pharynx.<tei:lb/>Ovary oval; usually entire; post-testicular. Mehlis' gland post-ovarian. Laurer's canal and<tei:lb/>canalicular or blind seminal receptacle absent. Juel's organ and uterine seminal receptacle present.<tei:lb/>Uterus coiled mainly in pre- and/or post-ovarian region of hindbody; few or no coils present in<tei:lb/>forebody; initially descending into or towards ecsoma and then ascending towards forebody.<tei:lb/>Eggs numerous; small; embryonated; rarely with a polar filament. Vitellarium varies between<tei:lb/>forms with seven tubular branches (three on one side of body, four on other) and forms with<tei:lb/>two distinct, oval masses; mainly post-ovarian. Excretory vesicle Y-shaped; arms united in fore-<tei:lb/>body or not. Parasitic mainly in gut, especially stomach, of marine teleosts, occasionally present<tei:lb/>in gut of freshwater teleosts and lung of sea-snakes.</tei:p>
