         <tei:p>95 Trifoliovarium</tei:p>
         <tei:p>99 Tubulovesicula</tei:p>
         <tei:p>76 Tyrrhenia</tei:p>
         <tei:p>74 Unilacinia<tei:lb/>108 Uroproctinella</tei:p>
         <tei:p>95 Uterovesiculurus</tei:p>
         <tei:p>85 Vitellotrema .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>112 Voitrema</tei:p>
         <tei:p>113 Xenodistomum<tei:lb/>113</tei:p>
         <tei:p>88<tei:lb/>61<tei:lb/>61<tei:lb/>67</tei:p>
         <tei:p>107<tei:lb/>95<tei:lb/>78</tei:p>
         <tei:p>110</tei:p>
         <tei:p>111<tei:lb/>88</tei:p>
         <tei:p>111<tei:lb/>98</tei:p>
         <tei:p>104</tei:p>
         <tei:p>108<tei:lb/>59<tei:lb/>64</tei:p>
         <tei:p>114</tei:p>
         <tei:p>112<tei:lb/>92<tei:lb/>92<tei:lb/>88<tei:lb/>97</tei:p>
         <tei:p>115<tei:lb/>80<tei:lb/>83<tei:lb/>59<tei:lb/>69<tei:lb/>80</tei:p>
         <tei:p>105<tei:lb/>95</tei:p>
         <tei:p>109<tei:lb/>88<tei:lb/>80</tei:p>
         <tei:p>109<tei:lb/>99<tei:lb/>87<tei:lb/>76<tei:lb/>97<tei:lb/>61</tei:p>
         <tei:p>IV. A discussion on the evolution of the Hemiuroidea</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Evolutionary trends in the Hemiuroidea</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The presentation of any evolutionary picture for the Platyhelminthes must remain hypothetical,<tei:lb/>as it is unlikely that there will ever be any fossil record due to the soft-bodied nature of these<tei:lb/>animals. Possible evolutionary patterns can only be exposed by the knitting together of general<tei:lb/>morphological trends in organs, organ-systems and whole animals. Having distinguished a trend,<tei:lb/>there is the problem of deciding which way the trend is moving, and hence which is the primitive<tei:lb/>and which is the advanced condition. In addition, the possibility should not be forgotten that an<tei:lb/>intermediate form is primitive and that evolution is proceeding in two opposite directions. In<tei:lb/>order to assess which form is primitive, it is helpful to adopt the use of certain external indicators.<tei:lb/>As far as parasitic helminths are concerned useful indicators include:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1. The supposed 'primitiveness* of the host</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Although superficially it appears more likely that the more archaic and primitive vertebrates<tei:lb/>harbour more archaic and primitive parasites, this is not necessarily so. Owing to the variable</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE HEMIUROIDEA 119</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ecological factors involved, archaic hosts can harbour what appear to be 'advanced' parasites,<tei:lb/>and vice versa. In addition, there are often widely differing opinions as to the relative ages<tei:lb/>of certain groups of vertebrates, and this tends to limit its value as an indicator. One might<tei:lb/>expect, however, that a group of helminths restricted to birds would be more advanced than<tei:lb/>one restricted to elasmobranchs. Unfortunately, the vast majority of the hemiuroids are<tei:lb/>parasitic in fishes, and, although certain primitive groups are recognized, it is not known<tei:lb/>for certain whether elasmobranchs are more primitive than bony fishes (Osteichthyes).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Amongst the hemiuroids only the azygiids appear to occur in fishes which are widely held to be<tei:lb/>primitive. Otodistomum commonly occurs in the shark Hexanchus and has been recorded from<tei:lb/>Chlamydoselachus and Heterodontus, and both Azygia and Leuceruthrus occur in the holostean<tei:lb/>Amia. Other groups occuring in elasmobranchs are the ptychogonimids and the syncoeliids, the<tei:lb/>Ptychogonimidae and the Otiotrematinae being entirely restricted to these hosts. Azygia has<tei:lb/>also been recorded from Acipenser, a member of primitive group Chondrostei; but little emphasis<tei:lb/>can be placed upon this result as Derogenes and several species of hemiurid have also been<tei:lb/>recorded from this host. This apparent mixture of what we believe to be 'primitive' and relatively<tei:lb/>'advanced' forms is possibly associated with the migratory habit of sturgeons and the low degree<tei:lb/>of host-specificity exhibited by some of the more 'advanced' hemiuroids. There is also a single<tei:lb/>record of Halipegus from the related chondrostean Polyodon. Except for certain halipegine<tei:lb/>derogenids, which occur in amphibians and, rarely, in amphibious snakes, and the pulmovermine<tei:lb/>hemiurids, which are restricted to the lungs of sea-snakes, the remainder of the hemiuroids occur<tei:lb/>in teleosts.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2. The habitat of the host</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Parasites of aquatic vertebrates will tend to be more primitive than those from terrestrial<tei:lb/>vertebrates, because aquatic vertebrates tend to be more primitive than terrestrial vertebrates<tei:lb/>and because it is much easier to envisage the origins of parasitic platyhelminths in aquatic<tei:lb/>conditions. All the hemiuroids are parasitic in aquatic or amphibious hosts, the majority<tei:lb/>being parasitic in marine teleosts, but a few groups are commonly found in freshwater hosts.<tei:lb/>Unfortunately, there is no conclusive evidence to suggest that teleosts arose in freshwater,<tei:lb/>or vice versa, although a freshwater origin is preferred by some workers. It should be<tei:lb/>emphasized that any evidence based upon the habitat of the host should be treated with<tei:lb/>caution, as various hosts may have passed from fresh- to salt-water or from water to land,<tei:lb/>and back, on more than one occasion during the course of their evolution.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Amongst the hemiuroids, only the azygiids and the halipegine derogenids are successful parasites<tei:lb/>of freshwater fishes, and only the isoparorchiids, a very small group, are restricted to these hosts.<tei:lb/>One interesting coincidence is that all three of the azygiid genera from freshwater fishes occur in<tei:lb/>North America, two being endemic, and that this is the only region of the world where holostean<tei:lb/>fishes survive. Another possible coincidence is that the majority of halipegine genera and the<tei:lb/>majority of isoparorchiid records occur in Asia, especially in the southern half of the continent:<tei:lb/>this location is the possible centre of evolution and radial dispersion of freshwater teleosts (see<tei:lb/>Darlington, 1957).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3. Host-specificity</tei:p>
         <tei:p>One might expect helminths with a high-degree of host-specificity to be more primitive than<tei:lb/>those with a low-degree. This is because it is likely that highly specific associations develop<tei:lb/>over a long period of time, and once they have arisen the further evolution of the parasite<tei:lb/>itself tends to be restricted to within the limits of the evolution of the host. This is a very<tei:lb/>general feature, however, and as digeneans tend to have a low degree of host-specificity with<tei:lb/>regard to their vertebrate host, it is of limited value.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>It is worth noting, nevertheless, that the host-range of the adult forms of certain groups and<tei:lb/>genera do tend to be restricted. The accacoeliines, with the exception of Tetrochetus, occur only<tei:lb/>in molid teleosts and the ptychogonimids appear to be entirely or almost entirely restricted to<tei:lb/>galeomorph sharks. Bathycotyle and Hirudinella parasitize scombroid and coryphaenid teleosts,</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>120 D. I. GIBSON &amp; R. A. BRAY</tei:p>
         <tei:p>and Botulus and Lampritrema are usually restricted to Alepisaurus and Lampris, respectively.<tei:lb/>Prominent among other examples are the macradeninine and quadrifoliovariine lecithasterids,<tei:lb/>which occur only in acanthurid teleosts. Alternatively, many members of the Hemiuridae,<tei:lb/>Lecithasteridae, Bunocotylidae and Derogenidae appear to exhibit little or no host specificity<tei:lb/>amongst marine teleosts, although certain individual species or genera may appear to be highly<tei:lb/>host-specific. One species of Halipegus is reported to occur in freshwater teleosts and amphibians.<tei:lb/>The azygiids are present in freshwater teleosts, elasmobranchs, holosteans and rarely in chondro-<tei:lb/>steans, and although they appear to be restricted to certain groups of elasmobranchs, they appear<tei:lb/>to exhibit little host-specificity.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>It is obvious in many of the above cases, e.g. the accacoeliines, that much of the apparent<tei:lb/>host-specificity is ecological rather than immunological or physiological, and it is likely that<tei:lb/>ecologically based host-specificity has less evolutionary significance, as it would appear that an<tei:lb/>ecological restriction is a prerequisite for the development of other types of host-specificity. Our<tei:lb/>lack of knowledge of the life-history in many cases, however, prohibits the differentiation of these<tei:lb/>types. Nevertheless, the above examples do tend to illustrate the fact that there is a tendency for<tei:lb/>the successful groups, such as derogenids, hemiurids, lecithasterids and bunocotylids to exhibit<tei:lb/>in general a low degree of host-specificity, while the smaller groups, such as accacoeliids,<tei:lb/>hirudinellids, ptychogonimids, etc. tend to be more restricted. If our hypothesis that host-<tei:lb/>specificity is acquired over a long period of association is correct, then it is likely that these smaller<tei:lb/>groups will tend to be more primitive than the larger. The azygiids occupy an anomalous position<tei:lb/>in that to some extent they are restricted to particular groups of fishes, but within these groups<tei:lb/>they are widespread. This might be explained by the fact that they are a small, but successful,<tei:lb/>group which occupy niches, i.e. the stomach of freshwater fishes and elasmobranchs, where<tei:lb/>competition from other digeneans is severely limited.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>4. Related groups</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Undoubtedly the most important evidence can be taken from features common in groups<tei:lb/>which are held to be related to, and perhaps more primitive than, the group under study.<tei:lb/>Digeneans, monogeneans, cestodes and aspidogastreans are generally thought to have<tei:lb/>evolved from primitive rhabdocoel turbellarians, possibly similar to the Dalyellida, which<tei:lb/>may inhabit the mantle-cavity or viscera of bivalves. Most authorities now agree that the<tei:lb/>Aspidogastrea is the closest relative of the Digenea, and Rohde (1971a) in an abstract states:<tei:lb/>'The Aspidogastrea are considered to be primitive, direct decendents of turbellarians, which<tei:lb/>are not yet closely adapted to parasitism and have not yet incorporated the vertebrate host<tei:lb/>as a fixed component in their life-cycle. They are closely related to the ancestors of the<tei:lb/>Digenea. Aspidogastrea and Digenea are both primarily parasites of molluscs.' In the same<tei:lb/>context Rohde (1971b) refers to the Aspidogastrea as 'living fossils'. It is likely, therefore,<tei:lb/>that features common to the Aspidogastrea and Digenea either must be primitive or are<tei:lb/>features produced by parallel or convergent evolution. Some primitive features may also be<tei:lb/>common in other parasitic platyhelminths and in the rhabdocoels; but, since these groups<tei:lb/>are successful, widely specialized and more distantly related, great care should be taken in<tei:lb/>the interpretation of any correlations, as the same features have undoubtedly been evolved<tei:lb/>independently by parallel and convergent evolution. Beklemishev (1964 [1969]), for example,<tei:lb/>states, when discussing the reproductive system of the Platyhelminthes : 'In spite of the great<tei:lb/>diversity of these adaptations, which appear independently in the various groups, the prob-<tei:lb/>lems involved are repeatedly solved by similar methods, and that in animals far apart in the<tei:lb/>system.'</tei:p>
         <tei:p>When attempting to decide which of a group is primitive, one must, therefore, look for a succes-<tei:lb/>sion of trends which tend to flow in the same direction. It is unlikely, however, that one will<tei:lb/>encounter all of the trends proceeding 'satisfactorily' in the same animal. It is a fact that parallel<tei:lb/>and convergent evolution do occur, and each species is adapted to its particular niche rather than<tei:lb/>to illustrate an evolutionary picture. Parallel evolution is important because, as the members of<tei:lb/>the group originally shared the same gene-pool, the same mutations are likely to occur down the<tei:lb/>separate evolutionary branches, and thus the same features may evolve independently in several</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE HEMIUROIDEA 121</tei:p>
         <tei:p>different sub-groups. It is essential, therefore, that one looks at the overall trends in the group as<tei:lb/>a whole. This is especially important where the loss of organs may have occurred.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In an attempt to show the evolutionary trends within the Hemiuroidea, we have followed<tei:lb/>three different organs and organ-systems in which definite trends do occur. These are: (1) the<tei:lb/>seminal storage and disposal apparatus in the female reproductive system; (2) the vitellarium;<tei:lb/>and (3) the terminal genitalia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(1) Seminal storage and disposal apparatus in the female reproductive system. One of the most<tei:lb/>significant, but not one of the most obvious, trends in the Hemiuroidea is the development of<tei:lb/>the seminal storage and disposal apparatus, especially the latter, in the female system. In the<tei:lb/>majority of hemiuroids the proximal region of the uterus forms a seminal reservoir and is termed<tei:lb/>the uterine seminal receptacle. As a uterine seminal receptacle occurs in the Aspidogastrea (see<tei:lb/>Rohde, 197 la), it is likely that this condition is primitive in digeneans. Evidence from other<tei:lb/>platyhelminth-groups is difficult to interpret as they are specialized and involve, in the case of<tei:lb/>the Turbellaria, a vagina (copulatory canal) and several different types of seminal receptacle, and,<tei:lb/>in the case of the Monogenea and Cestoda, usually a vagina (or vaginae) with a dilation which<tei:lb/>forms a seminal receptacle. However, in some rhabdocoel turbellarians such as Mesostoma, a<tei:lb/>seminal receptacle in the form of a dilation of the oviduct does occur. Considering that the ovo-<tei:lb/>vitelline canal, which is the equivalent of the uterus in the Digenea, is short and that there is no<tei:lb/>Mehlis' gland, this feature is somewhat similar to a uterine seminal receptacle.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>As stated above, the sperm in the majority of hemiuroids is stored in the proximal region of<tei:lb/>the uterus. From the uterus small amounts of activated sperm pass through Mehlis' gland,<tei:lb/>where presumably fertilization of the ova usually occurs. Excess and spent sperm, plus excess<tei:lb/>vitelline material, are then disposed of via Laurer's canal, which in certain groups, e.g. the<tei:lb/>Azygiidae, Accacoeliidae and Hirudinellidae, connects the oviduct with the exterior via a dorsal<tei:lb/>pore (see Fig. 6; arrangement A). Such sperm and vitelline material in Laurer's canal can be<tei:lb/>seen in sectioned material: occasionally ova are also present. This process is naturally very<tei:lb/>wasteful, and it is apparent that certain turbellarians and monogeneans have developed an<tei:lb/>analogous duct, the genito-intestinal canal, which disposes of similar residues by transporting<tei:lb/>them into the gut, in order that this material can be re-processed. Our work has shown that some<tei:lb/>hemiuroids appear to have evolved a special organ, Juel's organ, within which this waste-material<tei:lb/>is degraded and re-absorbed. It is clear that this organ did not arise overnight, as traces of its<tei:lb/>development can be seen in present forms. In groups, such as Gonocercinae, Syncoeliinae and<tei:lb/>Isoparorchiidae, the proximal region of Laurer's canal is slightly dilated, forming a rudimentary<tei:lb/>seminal receptacle, within which excess spermatozoa and vitelline material are stored before<tei:lb/>passing along the remainder of the canal (see Fig. 6; arrangement B). Our observations suggest<tei:lb/>that the excess material is killed or stored until it dies, and that it may begin to disintegrate within<tei:lb/>the rudimentary seminal receptacle, before being passed along the canal. The distal part of the<tei:lb/>canal in these groups tends to be slightly glandular in nature, and the pore itself is often tightly<tei:lb/>closed by a sphincter: thus, it is possible that some re-absorption may occur in these distal<tei:lb/>regions. In forms such as Derogenes and apparently Prosorchis, a rudimentary Juel's organ is<tei:lb/>found (see Fig. 6; arrangement C). In these cases the Laurer's canal does not open to the exterior,<tei:lb/>as the distal part of the duct is modified and forms an oval structure with a similar amorphous<tei:lb/>appearance to that of a fully-developed Juel's organ. During the course of evolution, Laurer's<tei:lb/>canal has become shorter, thus bringing the rudimentary Juel's organ and rudimentary seminal<tei:lb/>receptacle closer together. In Prosogonotrema these two structures are very close together<tei:lb/>(Fig. 4B). This process has continued until the rudimentary Juel's organ completely envelopes<tei:lb/>the rudimentary seminal receptacle, thus forming a complete Juel's organ (see Fig. 6; arrangement<tei:lb/>D). The enclosed rudimentary seminal receptacle has been known in the past as the 'inner vesicle'<tei:lb/>(Juel, 1889; Lander, 1904). A complete Juel's organ has been observed in Genarchopsis<tei:lb/>(Anjaneyulu, 1968; Madhavi &amp; Rao, 1974), Elongoparorchis (Madhavi &amp; Rao, 1974), in<tei:lb/>numerous hemiurids, knowingly or unknowingly, by several authors, including Juel (1889) and<tei:lb/>Lander (1904), and by ourselves in various hemiurids, Hysterolecitha and Arnola. A final deve-<tei:lb/>lopment, which appears to have occurred during the development of the Opisthadeninae, and</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>usr</tei:p>
         <tei:p>B</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 6 Different arrangements of the seminal storage and disposal apparatus in the female<tei:lb/>reproductive system (see text), [bsr, blind seminal receptacle; Jo, Juel's organ; Lc, Laurer's canal;<tei:lb/>rJo, rudimentary Juel's organ; rsr, rudimentary seminal receptacle; usr, uterine seminal receptacle.]</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE HEMIUROIDEA 123</tei:p>
         <tei:p>probably the majority of the lecithasterids, is that the inner vesicle expands to fill Juel's organ,<tei:lb/>thus forming a blind seminal receptacle (see Fig. 6; arrangement E). The uterine seminal receptacle<tei:lb/>is lost in these groups. A blind seminal receptacle tends to be a large, thick-walled structure,<tei:lb/>which is connected to the oviduct by a narrow duct: the sole remnant of the original Laurer's<tei:lb/>canal. This final development presumably means that the spermatozoa pass through Mehlis'<tei:lb/>gland in the opposite direction to that which normally occurs in the remainder of the hemiuroids.<tei:lb/>Spent spermatozoa and excess vitelline material are, therefore, voided via, or broken down and<tei:lb/>re-absorbed by, the uterus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The evidence, which suggests that the presence of Laurer's canal opening to the exterior in<tei:lb/>conjunction with a uterine seminal receptacle is primitive, is that this is exactly the same~arrange-<tei:lb/>ment which occurs in the majority of aspidogastreans (e.g. Multicotyle, Lophotaspis, Cotylo-<tei:lb/>gasteroides, Macraspis}. The development of a seminal and vitelline disposal organ, however,<tei:lb/>is not limited to the Juel's organ of some hemiuroids. It appears that analogous structures may<tei:lb/>have developed in an aspidogastrean and certain turbellarians. Stafford (1896) described Laurer's<tei:lb/>canal of Aspidogaster conchicola Baer, 1826, as ending blindly in the form of a 'thick-walled bulb',<tei:lb/>and Voeltzkow (1888) refers to the same structure as a 'receptaculum vitelli' because it appeared<tei:lb/>to contain vitelline residues.* The absorption of excess sperm by the Turbellaria is discussed by<tei:lb/>de Beauchamp (1961, p. 31). He notes that, in addition to the genito-intestinal canal which<tei:lb/>occurs in some groups, there appear to be several different organs involved: these include the<tei:lb/>'vesicle of Lang' of the polyclads (see Bock, 1927), the 'vesicula resorbiens' of the Kalyptorhynchia,<tei:lb/>and the copulatory bursa, which is found in many turbellarians. It is clear that, while there is<tei:lb/>a need to dispose of excess and spent seminal and vitelline material, there is in free-living<tei:lb/>helminths a strong selective pressure for the development of an organ of re-absorption, which<tei:lb/>thus aids the animal's economy. Owing to the ready availability of food, this pressure is probably<tei:lb/>much less in the parasitic forms, as demonstrated by the number of digeneans which still use<tei:lb/>Laurer's canal as a seminal and vitelline drain, but it would still appear to be advantageous to the<tei:lb/>economy of the parasite for it to develop a less wasteful system. If the actual biology of these<tei:lb/>digeneans is examined in detail, it is clear that many hemiuroids are stomach-parasites, and that<tei:lb/>they have developed mechanisms which protect them from the low pH and, in the case of marine<tei:lb/>teleosts, the high osmolarity of the environment (MacKenzie &amp; Gibson, 1970; Gibson, 1971).<tei:lb/>The hemiurids which live in such conditions apparently withdraw their ecsoma and contract,<tei:lb/>with the result that they are protected by their thick tegument, and the derogenids from the<tei:lb/>stomach tend to migrate anteriorly towards the oesophagus during periods of low pH or high<tei:lb/>osmolarity. These parasites, therefore, contrary to intestinal forms, do not appear to be in a<tei:lb/>position to feed at all times. It would seem, consequently, that it is advantageous for these<tei:lb/>parasites to re-utilize some of its waste-material in order to help maintain egg-production during<tei:lb/>periods when feeding is limited.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The presence of a structure resembling a rudimentary Juel's organ in Aspidogaster conchicola<tei:lb/>does suggest that Juel's organ may also be a primitive feature; but this structure appears not to<tei:lb/>have been observed in other aspidogastreans. In addition, it appears that a similar structure may<tei:lb/>be present in digeneans unrelated to the hemiuroids, e.g. Styphlodora bascaniensis Goldberger,<tei:lb/>1911 (see Goldberger, 19116), and Cyclocoelum sharadi Bhalerao, 1935 (see Madhavi &amp; Rao,<tei:lb/>1974), and that this feature has not apparently been reported in other species of these genera<tei:lb/>whica have been examined. It would seem, therefore, that a distal modification of Laurer's canal,<tei:lb/>which appears to be associated with the degradation of seminal and vitelline material, has been<tei:lb/>independently evolved on at least four different occasions. This would appear to vindicate<tei:lb/>Beklemishev's statement quoted above. Only in the hemiuroids, however, does this organ appear<tei:lb/>to have developed further, i.e. past the 'rudimentary' stage, and only in the hemiuroids is it<tei:lb/>common to entire groups. In other instances, it appears to have been developed independently by</tei:p>
         <tei:p>* Voeltzkow claimed to have seen the canal open to the exterior in young animals, and that the 'receptacle' developed<tei:lb/>as the animal matured. Stafford, however, was of the opinion that Laurer's canal developed as an outgrowth from<tei:lb/>the oviduct.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>124 D. I. GIBSON &amp; R. A. BRAY</tei:p>
         <tei:p>species, possibly recently, to meet their present ecological requirements. This is supported by the<tei:lb/>fact that none of the latter species are gut-parasites, and, therefore, such a development would<tei:lb/>probably be economically advantageous.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Many digeneans have lost Laurer's canal, or have altered its function, i.e. in some groups it is<tei:lb/>used as a vagina. The latter occurrence we consider to be an advanced feature (Gibson &amp; Bray,<tei:lb/>1975), and species which use this method of copulation (one sided, as opposed to the possibility<tei:lb/>of reciprocal copulation where the genital atrium is used) normally have a thin-walled canalicular<tei:lb/>seminal receptacle, formed as a proximal dilation of Laurer's canal, and no uterine seminal<tei:lb/>receptacle, e.g. Diphterostomum bmsinae (Stossich, 1889) and Haploporus benedeni (Stossich,<tei:lb/>1887) - see Palombi (1931). We should emphasize that remarkably few digeneans have ever been<tei:lb/>seen in the act of copulation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Assuming, from the above evidence, that the presence of Laurer's canal opening dorsally and<tei:lb/>a uterine seminal receptacle are, in the Hemiuroidea, primitive characters, it is not unreasonable<tei:lb/>to presume that Juel's organ has evolved in the manner described above. The derivation of the<tei:lb/>blind seminal receptacle of the opisthadenines and the majority of the lecithasterids from Juel's<tei:lb/>organ is not so obvious. If one discounts the possibility that it arose independently as a diverti-<tei:lb/>culum of the oviduct, there appears to be only one other alternative. That is, its independent<tei:lb/>derivation from the rudimentary seminal receptacle. In the Lecithasteridae, Trifoliovarium has a<tei:lb/>large, functional canalicular seminal receptacle which has presumably evolved directly from a<tei:lb/>rudimentary seminal receptacle. The blind seminal receptacle of the related Cladolecithotrema<tei:lb/>has presumably evolved by the loss of Laurer's canal. Alternatively, in Hysterolecitha and<tei:lb/>presumably Hysterolecithoides Juel's organ is present. The blind seminal receptacle of the re-<tei:lb/>mainder of the lecithasterids could, therefore, have evolved from either a rudimentary seminal<tei:lb/>receptacle or Juel's organ. As the inner vesicle of Juel's organ appears to have been derived from<tei:lb/>the rudimentary seminal receptacle, this is essentially the same thing; but the thick, fibrous wall<tei:lb/>of the blind seminal receptacle is quite different to the relatively thin-walled type of seminal<tei:lb/>receptacle which usually occurs in digeneans. This suggests that the wall of the blind seminal<tei:lb/>receptacle may be derived from the outer capsule of Juel's organ. There is also evidence that the<tei:lb/>blind seminal receptacle of the opisthadenines has evolved from Juel's organ of the hemiurids<tei:lb/>and, as discussed below, that a similar blind seminal receptacle appears to have arisen inde-<tei:lb/>pendently from Juel's organ in the Didymozooidea.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Although the form of the seminal storage and disposal system tends to be relatively constant<tei:lb/>within a family or subfamily, there is a notable exception to this. In the Derogenidae a variety of<tei:lb/>conditions occur: (1) many halipegines, such as Halipegus, possess Laurer's canal, which opens<tei:lb/>dorsally, and a uterine seminal receptacle; (2) other forms, such as the Gonocercinae, afe similar<tei:lb/>except that a small, but distinct, rudimentary seminal receptacle occurs; (3) in the remainder of<tei:lb/>the halipegines, such as Genarchopsis [but see p. 79] and Arnola, a fully developed Juel's organ<tei:lb/>is present ; and (4) in the derogenines a continuous variation of conditions occur : (a) Derogenes<tei:lb/>possesses a large rudimentary seminal receptacle containing spermatozoa which is connected by<tei:lb/>Laurer's canal to a rudimentary Juel's organ ; (b) in Progonus the rudimentary seminal receptacle<tei:lb/>is further enlarged to function as the only seminal store, the uterine seminal receptacle being lost,<tei:lb/>and the rudimentary Juel's organ is present at the junction of the seminal receptacle and Laurer's<tei:lb/>canal, which ends blindly; and (c) in Leurodera Laurer's canal and the rudimentary seminal<tei:lb/>receptacle appear to have been lost, leaving a blind seminal receptacle. The variation which<tei:lb/>occurs in this group can perhaps be explained by the fact that it is a large, successful group,<tei:lb/>possibly with primitive origins, arising at about the time when the first variations of the primitive<tei:lb/>seminal storage and disposal apparatus, such as the development of Juel's organ, were beginning<tei:lb/>to occur. It is possible that parallel evolution is responsible for some of the conditions which<tei:lb/>occur in this group and their apparent similarity to the arrangements in other hemiuroid groups.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(2) Vitellarium. There appears to be a very clear trend in the form of the vitellarium in the<tei:lb/>Hemiuroidea. Briefly, commencing with a follicular form, and passing through tubular and seven-<tei:lb/>lobed stages, the vitellarium is finally reduced to two, or occasionally one, oval masses. The trend<tei:lb/>begins with the follicular vitellarium which occurs in the Azygiidae (Fig. 7; arrangement A).</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE HEMIUROIDEA</tei:p>
         <tei:p>125</tei:p>
         <tei:p>B</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 7 Different arrangements of the vitellarium (see text).</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>126 D. I. GIBSON &amp; R. A. BRAY</tei:p>
         <tei:p>These follicles become linked together along the collecting ducts, thus giving a chain-like appear-<tei:lb/>ance, as occurs in the syncoeliid Otiotrema and to some extent in the accacoeliid Tetrochetus<tei:lb/>(Fig. 7; arrangement B). The vitellarium then becomes distinctly tubular, consisting of many<tei:lb/>long, often convoluted, tubules, which may be branched (Fig. 7 ; arrangement C). The latter type<tei:lb/>of vitellarium occurs in the Accacoeliidae, Hirudinellidae and Isoparorchiidae. The next stage<tei:lb/>is that the number of tubules, which are usually unbranched, is reduced to seven: these usually<tei:lb/>being arranged with three on one side of the body and four on the other (Fig. 7 ; arrangement D) ;<tei:lb/>e.g. some sclerodistomids and some hemiurids, such as Dinurus and Stomachicola. The length of<tei:lb/>the seven tubules is then gradually reduced, so that they pass through digitiform (e.g. Lecitho-<tei:lb/>cladium, Plerurus, Ectenurus), tear-shaped (e.g. Elytrophallus, Lecithaster, Hysterolecitha) and<tei:lb/>oval (Prolecitha, Dichadena, Lecithophyllum, Syncoelium) stages (Fig. 7; arrangement E). The<tei:lb/>seven lobes, whether tubular, digitiform, tear-shaped or oval, may form a rosette arrangement,<tei:lb/>with three lobes on one side and four on the other, or may form two separate groups of three<tei:lb/>and four lobes which are connected by the collecting ducts. Presumably from the latter arrange-<tei:lb/>ment have developed forms, such as Dinosoma and Arnold, with two vitelline masses which are<tei:lb/>distinctly three- and four-lobed (Fig. 7; arrangement F). The lobation then tends to be almost or<tei:lb/>entirely lost (e.g. Hemiurus, Br achy phallus), resulting in forms, such as Derogenes, Lethadena<tei:lb/>and Myosaccium, with two totally unlobed, oval masses. In genera such as Bunocotyle,<tei:lb/>Monolecithotrema, Monovitella and Chenia the vitellarium is present as a single entire or slightly<tei:lb/>lobed mass (Fig. 7; arrangement G). This mass was probably, and almost certainly in the latter<tei:lb/>two cases, formed from the fusion of two oval masses ; but there is a possibility that it could be<tei:lb/>the result of either the loss of one mass or the condensation of a rosette-arrangement.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>It must be emphasized here that the above is only a general trend in the form of the vitellarium,<tei:lb/>as there is a certain amount of variation within each group, particularly within the hemiurids<tei:lb/>and the lecithasterids. For example, a relatively common feature of the lecithasterids is a doubling<tei:lb/>of the number of vitelline lobes. In addition, the number of vitelline tubules or lobes, commonly<tei:lb/>seven in many of the hemiuroids, is variable, six, eight or nine frequently being reported. The<tei:lb/>presence of nine (four and five) lobes is especially common on the two vitelline masses of the<tei:lb/>halipegine derogenids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>As the various links in the above pattern do appear to illustrate the trend relatively clearly,<tei:lb/>the only real problem is to find evidence which indicates that the follicular arrangement of the<tei:lb/>vitellarium is primitive. It appears, however, that a follicular vitellarium is found in the majority<tei:lb/>of monogenean and cestode groups, in all aspidogastreans and also in some rhabdocoel turbel-<tei:lb/>larians, e.g. Mesostoma. This suggests very strongly that the follicular arrangement is primitive.<tei:lb/>It is likely that the duplication of the vitelline glands, resulting in the follicular arrangement,<tei:lb/>occurred as an early development to accommodate an increase in egg-production. This would<tei:lb/>have been especially necessary when the 'ancestral rhabdocoel' became an obligate parasite. This<tei:lb/>is emphasized by evidence from the digenean Schistosoma mansoni Sambon, 1907, which<tei:lb/>indicates that thirty to forty vitelline cells are present in each egg (Gonnert, 1955). The wide-<tei:lb/>spread spacial arrangement of this highly metabolically active organ-system in the 'primitive'<tei:lb/>forms is probably a mechanism to aid the absorbtion of nutrients from the surrounding<tei:lb/>parenchymatous tissue, rather like the roots of a tree. Even though food is often continually<tei:lb/>available to the 'primitive' hemiuroids, such as the azygiids and hirudinellids, they tend to be<tei:lb/>rather large for digeneans, and, therefore, still have certain problems with regard to the diffusion<tei:lb/>of nutrients. The more 'advanced' hemiuroids tend to be smaller in size, and, therefore, there is<tei:lb/>no longer such a need for a widespread follicular, dendritic or simple tubular vitelline system,<tei:lb/>as the problems associated with the diffusion of nutrients are reduced. In addition, there is more<tei:lb/>competition for space, as the uterus tends to take up a much greater proportion of the body.<tei:lb/>This latter factor, plus the economic advantage in reducing the distance involved in the trans-<tei:lb/>portation of vitelline material, adequately explains the reduction of the vitellarium to a small<tei:lb/>rosette or to one or two masses.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>One apparent contradiction is the vitelline structure of the syncoeliine syncoeliids, which, as<tei:lb/>it consists of seven oval lobes, indicates that it is far more 'advanced' than the remainder of the</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE HEMIUROIDEA 127</tei:p>
         <tei:p>anatomy. The premature reduction in the size of the vitellarium can be explained, however, by<tei:lb/>certain modifications in the process of egg-formation which appear to occur in this group. Our<tei:lb/>observations suggest that the eggs of Copiatestes are produced in a uterine ob'type (see glossary),<tei:lb/>have a membranous 'shell' and contain only one, or a very small number, of vitelline cells.<tei:lb/>During the egg's passage down the uterus the vitelline cell(s) appear to replicate many times, the<tei:lb/>membranous 'shell' permitting the diffusion of nutrients into the egg as a source of material and<tei:lb/>energy for this process. Not until a full complement of vitelline cells is present, at about the<tei:lb/>middle of the uterus, does the egg-shell become thicker, tanned and hardened. The demand on<tei:lb/>the vitellarium for vitelline cells appears, therefore, to be greatly reduced, possibly by a factor<tei:lb/>of twenty to thirty times. Some aspects of egg-shell formation have been described by Gibson<tei:lb/>(1976) for Copiatestes filiferus (Leuckart, in Sars, 1885) and by Coil &amp; Kuntz (1963) for the<tei:lb/>related Syncoelium spathulatum Coil &amp; Kuntz, 1963.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3. Terminal genitalia. The terminal genitalia of the Hemiuroidea show a great number of<tei:lb/>modifications; but do in fact, with a small number of exceptions, illustrate one basic trend. There<tei:lb/>are, however, a number of variations in the general pattern, and it is likely that some features of<tei:lb/>this trend have been evolved independently by parallel evolution. In order to understand both<tei:lb/>the nature of the trend and the variation, we must first examine the function of these structures.<tei:lb/>The function of the male terminal genital apparatus is that of ejecting spermatozoa and enabling<tei:lb/>it to enter the female system, either of another worm or of the same individual. The function of<tei:lb/>the female terminal genitalia is that of ejecting eggs into the environment, and, we suggest in the<tei:lb/>case of the Hemiuroidea, receiving spermatozoa from the male terminal genitalia of either<tei:lb/>another worm or of the same individual. As indicated above, it is clear from our studies of<tei:lb/>Laurer's canal (Gibson &amp; Bray, 1975) that in the Hemiuroidea, when this duct is present, it<tei:lb/>functions as a seminal and vitelline drain, not as a vagina (Trifoliovarium may be an exception).<tei:lb/>Evidence from the work of Nollen (1968), who used 3 H-thymidine-labelled spermatozoa in<tei:lb/>Philophthalmus megalurus (Cort, 1914) suggests that cross-insemination occurs in the majority<tei:lb/>of cases whenever possible ; but that, when only single worms are present in a host, self-insemina-<tei:lb/>tion occurs regularly. Nollen also noted that labelled spermatozoa disappeared from the uterine<tei:lb/>seminal receptacle within fourteen to sixteen days of copulation, which indicates that repeated<tei:lb/>insemination is required. It would appear, therefore, that self-insemination is a mechanism which<tei:lb/>has evolved to enable lone specimens in a host to produce fertile eggs. It seems very likely that in<tei:lb/>some genera self-insemination has become increasingly important, to the extent that the male<tei:lb/>copulatory apparatus has atrophied. In some cases, such as Bathycotyle, Gonocerca, Aerobiotrema,<tei:lb/>Syncoelium (sensu stricto) and Tetrochetus, where the copulatory apparatus has completely disap-<tei:lb/>peared or has been reduced to a vestige, they must, it appears, rely solely upon self-insemination.<tei:lb/>It is likely that the latter phenomenon has occurred independently in several different groups<tei:lb/>both within and outside the Hemiuroidea. To illustrate this point, the terminal genitalia and the<tei:lb/>seminal storage and disposal system of the opecoeline opecoelids are almost identical to those<tei:lb/>which occur in Gonocerca. Too much systematic importance, therefore, should not be placed<tei:lb/>upon the absence or reduction of the copulatory apparatus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The main trend in the structure of the terminal genitalia of the Hemiuroidea appears to be as<tei:lb/>follows. It commences as a simple sinus-organ, produced as a protrusion of the base of the<tei:lb/>genital atrium, and containing both of the simple, tubular male and female ducts. These ducts<tei:lb/>come together and unite near the summit of this organ, forming a short hermaphroditic duct<tei:lb/>which opens via a terminal pore. The close proximity of the male and female ducts which opens<tei:lb/>into a common genital atrium aids both reciprocal cross-insemination and self-insemination, and,<tei:lb/>similarly, the development of an hermaphroditic duct further facilitates self-insemination. This<tei:lb/>latter arrangement (Fig. 8; arrangement A) occurs in the azygiids, where the sinus-organ is a<tei:lb/>highly contractile, permanent structure, but is usually found in a relatively contracted state. The<tei:lb/>sinus-organ of the azygiids, which presumably acts as a copulatory organ and possibly aids the<tei:lb/>extrusion of eggs through the genital pore, is formed from the proximal region of the wall of the<tei:lb/>genital atrium, and it uses its own intrinsic musculature for extension and contraction. The<tei:lb/>genital atrium presumably serves as a vagina during copulation, and it is likely that the muscular</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>128</tei:p>
         <tei:p>D. I. GIBSON &amp; R. A. BRAY</tei:p>
         <tei:p>SO</tei:p>
         <tei:p>B</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ss</tei:p>
         <tei:p>aso</tei:p>
         <tei:p>H</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 8 Different arrangements of the terminal genitalia (see text),<tei:lb/>[aso, amuscular sinus-organ; hd, hermaphroditic duct; so, muscular sinus-organ; ss, sinus-sac.]</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE HEMIUROIDEA 129</tei:p>
         <tei:p>action of its wall forces the spermatozoa, deposited during copulation, back into the hermaphro-<tei:lb/>ditic duct through the aperture of the contracted sinus-organ.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Following on from the type A arrangement, the sinus-organ becomes a relatively larger<tei:lb/>structure in its contracted state, and some of its intrinsic musculature begins to concentrate into<tei:lb/>a thin, diffuse sac-like structure surrounding its base (Fig. 8; arrangement B). At the same time,<tei:lb/>the hermaphroditic duct tends to lengthen, usually reaching at least to the base of the sinus-organ.<tei:lb/>This arrangement can be seen gradually developing in Prosorchis, Copiatestes, Isoparorchis,<tei:lb/>Sclerodistomum, Accacoelium and Prosogonotrema, resulting in a type C arrangement (Fig. 8)<tei:lb/>where the diffuse, muscular thickening at the base of the sinus-organ, which is referred to as the<tei:lb/>sinus-sac, becomes more apparent in the latter four examples, and, in addition, the intrinsic<tei:lb/>musculature of the sinus-organ itself tends to become slightly reduced. We consider that the<tei:lb/>sinus-sac aids the extrusion of the sinus-organ by exerting hydrostatic pressure upon its contents<tei:lb/>(Gibson &amp; Bray, 1974). Many of the derogenids tend to have an arrangement very similar to<tei:lb/>that of Prosogonotrema, except that the cone-shaped sinus-organ tends to be small. In the dinurine<tei:lb/>hemiurids the sinus-sac is better developed (Fig. 8 ; arrangement D), becoming an enlarged oval<tei:lb/>or tubular structure with a thick, muscular wall, and the sinus-organ is usually cone-shaped, often<tei:lb/>with a slight reduction in its intrinsic musculature. The sinus-organ may be large, as in<tei:lb/>Paradinurus, or small, as in Dinurus, and it should be mentioned that in a small number of<tei:lb/>dinurines, such as Stomachicola, the sinus-organ is absent or reduced to a rudiment: in the latter<tei:lb/>cases the sinus-sac is also reduced in size. It is noticeable that at about the stage of the type D<tei:lb/>arrangement, the seminal vesicle, which until now has normally been tubular, tends to become<tei:lb/>more saccular and often develops sphincters and thus becomes partitioned. These appear to be<tei:lb/>modifications caused by the fact that, during ejaculation, the spermatozoa now have to be<tei:lb/>forced into the hermaphroditic duct against the hydrostatic pressure produced when the sinus-sac<tei:lb/>aids the eversion of the sinus-organ. The next stage (Fig. 8 ; arrangement E) is that the intrinsic<tei:lb/>musculature of the sinus-organ is then lost, resulting in the fact that it must be entirely everted<tei:lb/>by hydrostatic pressure. This arrangement can be seen in the Elytrophallinae and in the Glomeri-<tei:lb/>cirrinae, especially in the former, where the sinus-organ appears to be almost totally amuscular,<tei:lb/>the sinus-sac is well developed and the seminal vesicle is surrounded by an extremely thick<tei:lb/>muscular wall. The latter structure is presumably necessary because of an increased hydrostatic<tei:lb/>pressure necessary to evert the sinus-organ. In the next stage (Fig. 8 ; arrangement F) the genital<tei:lb/>atrium is reduced in size and a permanent sinus-organ is lost. The latter is replaced by a short,<tei:lb/>temporary sinus-organ, rarely seen in fixed specimens, which is formed by evagination of the<tei:lb/>hermaphroditic duct under hydrostatic pressure. As the hydrostatic pressure is less than that<tei:lb/>required in the type E arrangement, because of the much smaller sinus-organ and genital atrium,<tei:lb/>pressure is usually exerted on the seminal vesicle by sphincter muscles or by a thin, muscular layer<tei:lb/>in its wall, rather than by a thick, muscular wall. This arrangement occurs in the Hemiurinae,<tei:lb/>Lecithochiriinae, Stomachicola and a small number of related dinurines, the Opisthadeninae, the<tei:lb/>Lecithasterinae and the Quadrifoliovariinae. Finally, in the Hysterolecithinae, Trifoliovariinae,<tei:lb/>Lethadeninae, Plerurinae, Macradenininae, Dictysarcinae, Prolecithinae and Gonocercinae, the<tei:lb/>sinus-sac is gradually atrophied (Fig. 8; arrangement G) until in genera such as Aerobiotrema<tei:lb/>and Gonocerca, it is lost completely (Fig. 8; arrangement H). Presumably, as mentioned above,<tei:lb/>in the latter groups the ability to cross-inseminate becomes reduced and is finally lost altogether.<tei:lb/>It is worth noting that there is a slight deviation within the Hemiuridae, in that the Glomericir-<tei:lb/>rinae, with the type E arrangement, and the Lecithochiriinae, with the type F arrangement, have<tei:lb/>developed an ejaculatory [prostatic] vesicle. This appears to be a modification of the ejaculatory<tei:lb/>duct, the function of which is not known for certain. It may, however, form a temporary storage<tei:lb/>organ as part of a mechanism for ejecting larger quantities of spermatozoa during each ejacula-<tei:lb/>tion. If this is true, then the glandular cells, which often line it, may function, with regard to the<tei:lb/>stored sperm, in the same way that the pars prostatica does to normal quantities of sperm passing<tei:lb/>through this duct during ejaculation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>One group, the Hirudinellidae, stand out as being totally distinct from the remainder of the<tei:lb/>hemiuroids in that they possess a 'cirrus-sac'. This structure almost certainly developed inde-<tei:lb/>pendently of the sinus-sac; but it does appear to be analogous. The reason why such a structure</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>130 D. I. GIBSON &amp; R. A. BRAY</tei:p>
         <tei:p>has developed in this group is probably because its ancestors lost, or did not develop, an<tei:lb/>hermaphroditic duct, with the result that the copulatory organ ('cirrus') did not contain the<tei:lb/>female duct. In this group, therefore, both the male and the female ducts have developed their<tei:lb/>own finger-like projections from the wall of the genital atrium. It seems certain that the 'cirrus-<tei:lb/>sac' of the hirudinellids is not homologous with the cirrus-sac which is found in many other<tei:lb/>groups of digeneans. At first sight, it is somewhat difficult to see how the hirudinellid arrangement<tei:lb/>could have evolved from the type A arrangement; but other morphological features of the<tei:lb/>hirudinellids suggest a relatively close affinity with some of the other 'primitive' hemiuroids. For<tei:lb/>this reason, it seems unlikely that the hirudinellids split away very early in hemiuroid evolution<tei:lb/>before the development of an hermaphroditic duct. It is possible, however, to envisage the<tei:lb/>gradual separation of the male and female ducts of the type A arrangement, where the hermaphro-<tei:lb/>ditic duct is short, much in the same way as appears to have occurred in some species of Halipegus,<tei:lb/>where the two ducts open separately at the end of the sinus-organ. It is very unlikely that the<tei:lb/>Hirudinellidae resemble the ancestral form of the hemiuroids, as it is difficult to imagine how an<tei:lb/>hermaphroditic duct could have been derived from the hirudinellid arrangement.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>We can assume that the presence of apparatus well adapted to enable cross-insemination to<tei:lb/>occur is the primitive condition in the hemiuroids, as cross-insemination occurs in all other<tei:lb/>groups of helminths. Even in the primitive hemiuroids, however, it is almost certain that self-<tei:lb/>insemination does occur, and Dawes (1946) notes that self-insemination of lone specimens of the<tei:lb/>aspidogastrean Aspidogaster conchicola has been observed. It seems likely that the type A<tei:lb/>arrangement in our trend is primitive. It is a fact that the majority of hemiuroids differ from the<tei:lb/>majority of helminths in that the copulatory organ is not the usual cirrus, which is often enclosed<tei:lb/>by a cirrus-sac. Nevertheless, all of the structures termed 'cirrus' are not homologous, as the<tei:lb/>copulatory organs of many groups of animals have a phallic appearance. In addition, it is un-<tei:lb/>likely that all of the structures termed 'cirrus-sac' are homologous, as similar 'sacs' surround the<tei:lb/>base of, and are associated with the protrusion of, many eversible organs, e.g. the proboscis sac<tei:lb/>of the Acanthocephala. If we examine the aspidogastreans, the majority of species do possess a<tei:lb/>cirrus-sac, but several do not. There appears to be no evidence in the latter group for the presence<tei:lb/>of an hermaphroditic duct. As it seems difficult to envisage the development of an hermaphroditic<tei:lb/>duct, similar to that occurring in the hemiuroids, from a form with a cirrus-sac, it is possible that<tei:lb/>the rhabdocoel-like ancestors of the digeneans possessed a temporary penis-papilla ('cirrus'),<tei:lb/>lacking a penis-bulb ('cirrus-sac'), which was formed from the wall of the genital atrium. Com-<tei:lb/>mencing with such a structure, it is possible to envisage the development of all of the variations<tei:lb/>of the terminal genitalia which occur in the Digenea and Aspidogastrea.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A suggested evolutionary scheme within the Hemiuroidea</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Published works on evolution within the Digenea are few. Aspects of this subject have been<tei:lb/>discussed by workers such as Odening (1974), and detailed comments on particular groups have<tei:lb/>been given by others, such as Bayssade-Dufour &amp; Maillard (1974); but only a few workers, such<tei:lb/>as Poche (1926) and Cable (1974), appear to have indicated detailed evolutionary relationships<tei:lb/>within the Digenea as a whole. The majority of evidence in the more recent work has come from<tei:lb/>larval morphology and details of the life-history. As discussed in our introduction, we believe<tei:lb/>that much of the evidence based upon such information is questionable. Admittedly data from<tei:lb/>the intra-molluscan stages are likely to be of some value, but only at the higher taxonomic levels,<tei:lb/>and, as indicated on p. 38, there are some anomalies. If, as Rohde (1972) suggests, the cercariae<tei:lb/>were 'invented' by the digenean ancestors as a mechanism to aid the transmission from the<tei:lb/>molluscan host to the vertebrate host, evidence based upon cercarial morphology, especially as<tei:lb/>this larval stage is more susceptible to environmental changes than the others, is somewhat<tei:lb/>dubious. Although the majority of phylogenetic hypotheses on the evolution of and within the<tei:lb/>Digenea have been based upon larval characteristics, there is evidence that workers are beginning<tei:lb/>to reappraise the value of adult morphology. Powell &amp; Sogandares-Bernal (1970), for instance,<tei:lb/>stated: 'While on the subject of larval trematodes, the systematic value of comparative anatomical<tei:lb/>studies of the terminal genitalia and sensory structures of adult worms should be emphasized.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE HEMIUROIDEA 131</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Homologies and analogies of terminal genitalia (for example in the Hemiuroidea) should prove<tei:lb/>useful in determining phylogenetic relationships.'</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Using evidence outlined in the trends illustrated above, we have attempted to build a hypo-<tei:lb/>thetical picture of the evolution of the Hemiuroidea. Our proposed relationships are expressed<tei:lb/>in Fig. 9. We believe that the most primitive groups are the azygiids and the ptychogonimids, and<tei:lb/>that the most closely related of these to the ancestors of the remainder of the hemiuroids appear to<tei:lb/>be the leuceruthrine azygiids. These groups exhibit a combination of primitive characters, such<tei:lb/>as a follicular vitellarium, a sinus-organ without an accompanying sinus-sac and with Laurer's<tei:lb/>canal acting as a seminal and vitelline drain. The Leuceruthrinae, which appears to exist as a<tei:lb/>single species, possesses the same gonadal arrangement as that which occurs in the vast majority<tei:lb/>of the remainder of the hemiuroids. Another interesting feature which may indicate primitiveness<tei:lb/>in this group is that in known azygiid life-cycles the cercariae are eaten directly by the definitive<tei:lb/>host. This suggests the possibility that the azygiids evolved before the acquisition of the second<tei:lb/>intermediate host which occurs in most digenean life-cycles. Other primitive groups are the<tei:lb/>Hirudinellidae, Bathycotylidae, Isoparorchiidae, Syncoeliidae, Accacoeliidae and Sclerodisto-<tei:lb/>moididae, and it seems likely that they, especially the latter four, have arisen from a common<tei:lb/>ancestor. Nevertheless, there are features of the syncoeliids, such as the presence of seven<tei:lb/>vitelline lobes in the syncoeliines, which suggest that they are more advanced than indicated by<tei:lb/>the position which we have allocated to them in our 'evolutionary picture'; but, as discussed<tei:lb/>above (p. 126), these anomalies can be explained. In the latter groups a sinus-sac develops (a<tei:lb/>'cirrus-sac' in the case of the hirudinellids) and the vitellarium becomes tubular. In our opinion<tei:lb/>the remainder of the hemiuroids have evolved from an ancestor resembling the present-day<tei:lb/>sclerodistomids, although most probably lacking Manter's organ and with more posteriorly<tei:lb/>situated gonads. From this ancestral form, which presumably possessed a vitellarium consisting<tei:lb/>of seven tubules, a well-developed sinus-organ and sinus-sac, and Laurer's canal (which although<tei:lb/>opening dorsally was on the point of evolving a rudimentary Juel's organ), four main lines appear<tei:lb/>to have evolved. These are: (1) the modern members of the Sclerodistomidae; (2) the Derogenidae;<tei:lb/>(3) the Lecithasteridae, Dictysarcidae and the Didymozooidea (see p. 133); and (4) the Hemi-<tei:lb/>uridae and Bunocotylidae. The development of Juel's organ, in the rudimentary and or the<tei:lb/>fully developed form, has occurred in all of these groups. As forms with Laurer's canal opening<tei:lb/>dorsally also occur in three of the groups, it seems more likely that Juel's organ has arisen inde-<tei:lb/>pendently by parallel evolution than by the concurrent evolution of forms with and without this<tei:lb/>organ in all of these three groups.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The sclerodistomids are the only one of these groups which either have not developed a<tei:lb/>complete Juel's organ or in which no members of the group possessing such an organ survive,<tei:lb/>although rudimentary forms occur in Prosogonotrema and Prosorchis. It would appear that despite<tei:lb/>the position of the gonads, the prosogonotrematine and prosorchiine genera are perhaps more<tei:lb/>closely related to the other three groups outlined above than the sclerodistomines.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Derogenidae are a very successful group with a complex mixture of primitive and advanced<tei:lb/>features, especially with regard to the nature of the seminal storage and disposal apparatus in the<tei:lb/>female reproductive system. Nevertheless, the majority of members tend to be relatively similar<tei:lb/>in gross morphology, although it seems likely that the three subfamilies of this group separated<tei:lb/>quite early in the evolution of the group. They probably owe their success to the fact that they<tei:lb/>tend to fill niches where competition is somewhat reduced, i.e. the stomach of oceanic fishes, in<tei:lb/>the case of the Gonocercinae and the Derogeninae, and both the stomach of brackish water and<tei:lb/>freshwater fishes and the mouth and eustachian tubes of amphibians, in the case of the<tei:lb/>Halipeginae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Lecithasteridae appear to have evolved via forms similar to Trifoliovarium, but still<tei:lb/>retaining a uterine seminal receptacle and a rudimentary seminal receptacle. From this form<tei:lb/>developed the modern members of the Trifoliovariinae and, after the independent formation of<tei:lb/>Juel's organ, the Hysterolecithinae. The remainder of the lecithasterids could have evolved from<tei:lb/>forms similar to Trifoliovarium by the loss of Laurer's canal, much in the same way as<tei:lb/>Cladolecithotrema has probably developed ; but it seems more likely that they have evolved from<tei:lb/>hysterolecithine ancestors. This is suggested by the great morphological similarity between the</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>132</tei:p>
         <tei:p>D. I. GIBSON &amp; R. A. BRAY</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 9 A suggested evolutionary tree for the Hemiuroidea.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE HEMIUROIDEA 133</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hysterolecithinae and some of the other lecithasterids and because the thick-walled nature of<tei:lb/>the blind seminal receptacle in the rest of the lecithasterids suggests that it might have evolved<tei:lb/>from Juel's organ by hypertrophy of the 'inner vesicle'. It is also apparent, because of the<tei:lb/>presence of Juel's organ and other morphological similarities, that not only the Dictysarcidae,<tei:lb/>but also the Didymozooidea (see below), may have evolved from hysterolecithine ancestors.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In the largest group, the Hemiuridae, an ecsoma in association with a plicated tegument<tei:lb/>appears to have developed (see p. 41), although the former is occasionally reduced and the<tei:lb/>latter is often completely lost. These adaptations appear to be associated with the hostile habitat<tei:lb/>of the majority of hemiurids, the stomach of marine teleosts which is a region of variable pH<tei:lb/>and osmolarity. The most primitive group appears to be the Dinurinae, some of which have<tei:lb/>features in common with some of the modern sclerodistomids, although all appear to possess a<tei:lb/>fully developed Juel's organ. The dinurines probably gave rise to the elytrophallines by the<tei:lb/>development of an amuscular sinus-organ and associated changes in the seminal vesicle. The<tei:lb/>elytrophallines could then have given rise to: (1) the Glomericirrinae, by the development of an<tei:lb/>ejaculatory (prostatic) vesicle, which in turn gave rise to forms, such as the Lecithochiriinae, by<tei:lb/>the loss of a permanent sinus-organ; and (2) the Hemiurinae and the Lethadeninae, by the loss<tei:lb/>of a permanent sinus-organ. The Bunocotylidae appear to have evolved from ancestral hemiurines<tei:lb/>by the loss of the ecsoma. It is worth noting that some members of the Aphanurinae still retain<tei:lb/>a plicated tegument. In the members of the Bunocotylinae, which are extremely small, Juel's<tei:lb/>organ appears to have been lost, there apparently being no obvious mechanism for disposing of<tei:lb/>excess seminal and vitelline material. It is possible that these compact and apparently advanced<tei:lb/>worms utilize not only space, but also spermatozoa and vitelline material, more efficiently, thus<tei:lb/>reducing the value such a specialized organ. In the opisthadenines Juel's organ appears to have<tei:lb/>developed into a blind seminal receptacle, much in the same way as we suggest it developed in<tei:lb/>the majority of the lecithasterids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Throughout the evolution of this group it is clear that there is a general decrease in body-size,<tei:lb/>ranging from the giant azygiids and hirudinellids to the minute bunocotylids. Associated with<tei:lb/>this decrease in size is a more efficient utilization of body-space, such as the development of a<tei:lb/>compact vitellarium, and a more efficient utilization of excess reproductive products. In addition,<tei:lb/>although less certain, there appears to be an increase in the proportion of the body occupied by<tei:lb/>the uterus, and an increase in the dependency upon self-fertilization, thus reducing the need for<tei:lb/>large and complex terminal genitalia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Some comments on the relationship of the Didymozooidea and the Paramphistomoidea to the<tei:lb/>Hemiuroidea</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Didymozooidea are a group which several early workers, such as Odhner (1907) and Poche<tei:lb/>(1926), considered to be evolved from hemiuroid stock. This early work was based upon adult<tei:lb/>morphology. Baer &amp; Joyeux (1961), however, basing their hypothesis on the work of Ishii (1935)<tei:lb/>which indicated that adults of this group developed directly from eggs, recognized the<tei:lb/>Didymozoidea as a new subclass, distinct from the Digenea, within the class Trematoda. Recently<tei:lb/>Cable (1955, 1974), using evidence from larval stages, has reiterated Odhner's initial hypothesis<tei:lb/>that this group is derived from hemiuroid stock. Skrjabin (1955) and Yamaguti (1971) present the<tei:lb/>didymozooids as a distinct suborder and superfamily, respectively, to the hemiuroids, but do<tei:lb/>not comment on any relationship between the two.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>If those didymozooid genera with a simpler and more conventional morphology, such as<tei:lb/>Nematobothrium van Beneden, 1858,* are examined, several similarities with the hemiuroids are<tei:lb/>apparent. The testes are normally pre-ovarian and the ovary normally occurs anterior to the<tei:lb/>vitellarium. The male and female terminal ducts fuse, often forming a short hermaphroditic duct,<tei:lb/>and open via a common genital pore, and in some instances a small terminal papilla not unlike<tei:lb/>a sinus-organ is present. In addition, the shape and arrangement of the gonads in juvenile speci-<tei:lb/>mens of Didymocystis acanthocybii Yamaguti, 1938 (as figured by Yamaguti, 1970), are very</tei:p>
         <tei:p>* The conception of the genus used here is that of Yamaguti (1971).</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>134</tei:p>
         <tei:p>D. I. GIBSON &amp; R. A. BRAY</tei:p>
         <tei:p>similar to those of the dictysarcid hemiuroid Elongoparorchis. More convincing, however, are the<tei:lb/>facts that a uterine seminal receptacle is present in Nematobothrium robustum Yamaguti, 1970,<tei:lb/>and that Odhner (1907) has described what appears to be a well-developed Juel's organ in the<tei:lb/>closely related N. scombri (Taschenburg, 1879) (Fig. 10A). Although the latter structure in<tei:lb/>Nematobothrium spp. has usually been referred to as a seminal receptacle, Yamaguti (1970),<tei:lb/>when describing Neonematobothrioides poonui, noted that it contained germ-cells and vitelline<tei:lb/>material, in addition to spermatozoa. An apparent Juel's organ was also seen by Dollfus (1935)<tei:lb/>in Nematobothrium pelamydis (Taschenburg, 1879). Juel's organ of the didymozooids appears to<tei:lb/>differ slightly from that in the hemiurids, for example, in that the 'inner vesicle' is not completely<tei:lb/>enclosed proximally by the outer region of the organ, suggesting that it is perhaps slightly more<tei:lb/>primitive (see p. 121). The presence of Juel's organ and a uterine seminal receptacle, however,<tei:lb/>does not appear to be the usual condition in the more highly developed didymozooids. In the<tei:lb/>majority of these cases the uterine seminal receptacle has apparently been lost and Juel's organ<tei:lb/>appears to have become transformed into a blind seminal receptacle, which is connected to the<tei:lb/>oviduct by a short duct, much in the same way as blind seminal receptacles have probably been<tei:lb/>formed in the majority of lecithasterids and the opisthadenine bunocotylids. In sections of an<tei:lb/>unidentified didymozooine [close to Didymocystis Ariola, 1902] from Katsuwonus pelamys off<tei:lb/>Papua New Guinea, the outer half of the blind seminal receptacle has a thick wall, possibly being<tei:lb/>the vestige of the outer region of Juel's organ, and the inner half (that closest to the duct) of this<tei:lb/>seminal receptacle has a thin wall, possibly being formed from the part of the 'inner vesicle' not<tei:lb/>enclosed by the outer region of Juel's organ (Fig. 10B).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>These observations on the gross morphology and on the nature of the seminal storage and<tei:lb/>disposal apparatus in the proximal female reproductive system of certain didymozooids suggest<tei:lb/>to us that this group did evolve from hemiuroid stock close to the origins of the Dictysarcidae<tei:lb/>probably from an ancestral form of hysterolecithine lecithasterid (see Fig. 9).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>B</tei:p>
         <tei:p>bsr</tei:p>
         <tei:p>t w</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 10 Parts of the seminal storage and disposal apparatus in the female reproduction system of<tei:lb/>two didymozooids: A. Nematobothrium scombri (modified after Odhner, 1907); B. Unidentified<tei:lb/>didymozooine. [bsr, blind seminal receptacle; eiv, external 'inner vesicle'; iiv, internal 'inner<tei:lb/>vesicle'; Jo, Juel's organ; tw, thick-walled region of blind seminal receptacle.]</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE HEMIUROIDEA 135</tei:p>
         <tei:p>It is also worth noting that there are certain morphological features which suggest that there<tei:lb/>may be affinities between the paramphistomoids and some of the more primitive hemiuroids.<tei:lb/>These include a follicular vitellarium, the absence of a prepharynx, paired testes which are usually<tei:lb/>pre-ovarian, the presence of Laurer's canal in association with a uterine seminal receptacle and<tei:lb/>similar terminal genital apparatus. The paramphistomoids differ fundamentally in adult<tei:lb/>morphology only in the fact that the excretory pore is dorsal rather than being terminal. Although<tei:lb/>the hindbody is almost absent in this group, there is also a tendency for its reduction in certain<tei:lb/>hemiuroids, especially in the Sclerodistomidae. The paramphistomoids are generally considered to<tei:lb/>be stomach parasites of terrestrial vertebrates: several genera have, however, been recorded from<tei:lb/>teleosts. One particular group, the Brumptiidae Stunkard, 1925, appears to be morphologically<tei:lb/>very similar to the hemiuroids in that its members possess a well-developed sinus-sac and an<tei:lb/>hermaphroditic duct, and, in the lateral fields, there is a distinct hindbody present in the form of<tei:lb/>lobes, being somewhat similar to, but smaller than, those which occur in the syncoeliid Otiotrema.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Although workers such as Dawes (1936) have considered the paramphistomoids to be very<tei:lb/>primitive, Cable (1974) places this group well up one of the branches of his evolutionary tree.<tei:lb/>He also places it on quite a distinct branch to the hemiuroids, although Poche (1926) had placed<tei:lb/>them much closer together. Evidence from adult morphology suggests that the paramphistomoids<tei:lb/>might have been derived from hemiuroid stock close to the point where the syncoeliids and<tei:lb/>hirudinellids evolved. Nevertheless, there does appear to be fundamental differences in the<tei:lb/>morphology of the larval stages and the life-history which tend to preclude any serious con-<tei:lb/>sideration of this relationship until the significance of these differences is fully understood.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acknowledgements</tei:p>

      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>British Museum (Natural History)<tei:lb/>Monographs &amp; Handbooks</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The British Museum (Natural History) employs a staff of over 350<tei:lb/>research scientists working on zoology, entomology, palaeontology,<tei:lb/>botany and mineralogy. The results of their research in these<tei:lb/>fields are published both in the Museum's scientific journals - the<tei:lb/>Bulletins - and in monographs, many of which are co-published<tei:lb/>with commercial scientific publishers. Many of these works are<tei:lb/>not only of significance to such key areas as medicine, agriculture<tei:lb/>and the oil industry, but also to amateurs interested in birds,<tei:lb/>butterflies, fishes, etc.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Museum also publishes more popular books on natural history<tei:lb/>which are the work of their scientists and include a high<tei:lb/>illustrative content</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lists are available free on request to :</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Publications Sales</tei:p>
         <tei:p>British Museum (Natural History)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cromwell Road</tei:p>
         <tei:p>London SW7 5BD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Standing orders placed by educational institutions earn a discount<tei:lb/>of 10% off our published price.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p/>
         <tei:p>Titles to be published in Volume 36</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A guide to the species of the genus Aspidisca.<tei:lb/>By Irene C. H. Wu &amp; C. R. Curds.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Hemiuroidea : terminology, systematics and evolution.<tei:lb/>By D. I. Gibson &amp; R. A. Bray.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Notes on the anatomy of Macrochirichthys macrochirus<tei:lb/>Valenciennes, 1844, with comments on the Cultrinae (Pisces,<tei:lb/>Cyprinidae). By G. J. Howes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Miscellanea</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Anatomy, relationships and classification of the families<tei:lb/>Citharinidae and Distichodontidae (Pisces, Characoidea).<tei:lb/>By R. P. Van.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Printed by Henry Ling Ltd, Dorchester</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>Bulletin of the</tei:p>
         <tei:p>British Museum (Natural History)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Notes on the anatomy of Macrochirichthys<tei:lb/>macrochirus (Valenciennes), 1844, with<tei:lb/>comments on the Cultrinae (Pisces,<tei:lb/>Cyprinidae)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>G. J. Howes</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Zoology series Vol 36 No 3 27 September 1979</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>The Bulletin of the British Museum (Natural History), instituted in 1949, is issued in four<tei:lb/>scientific series, Botany, Entomology, Geology (incorporating Mineralogy) and Zoology, and<tei:lb/>an Historical series.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Papers in the Bulletin are primarily the results of research carried out on the unique and<tei:lb/>ever-growing collections of the Museum, both by the scientific staff of the Museum and by<tei:lb/>specialists from elsewhere who make use of the Museum's resources. Many of the papers are<tei:lb/>works of reference that will remain indispensable for years to come.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Parts are published at irregular intervals as they become ready, each is complete in itself,<tei:lb/>available separately, and individually priced. Volumes contain about 300 pages and are not<tei:lb/>necessarily completed within one calendar year. Subscriptions may be placed for one or more<tei:lb/>series. Subscriptions vary according to the contents of the Volume and are based on a forecast<tei:lb/>list of titles. As each Volume nears completion, subscribers are informed of the cost of the<tei:lb/>next Volume and invited to renew their subscriptions. Orders and enquiries should be sent to:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Publications Sales,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>British Museum (Natural History),<tei:lb/>Cromwell Road,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>London SW7 5BD,<tei:lb/>England.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>World List abbreviation: Bull. Br. Mus. nat. Hist. (Zool.)</tei:p>

      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>Notes on the anatomy of Macrochirichthys<tei:lb/>macrochirus (Valenciennes), 1844, with comments on<tei:lb/>the Cultrinae (Pisces, Cyprinidae)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>G. J. Howes</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Department of ^Zoology, British Museum (Natural History), Cromwell Road, London SW7 5BD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Contents</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Introduction ............ 147</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Suspensorium and associated musculature 173</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pectoral girdle and associated cranial bones 177</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Comments on the Cultrinae and its relationships with the cheline group . . 193</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Acknowledgements ........... 199</tei:p>
         <tei:p>References 199</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Introduction</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The purpose of this paper is three-fold; to describe certain anatomical features of the piscivorous<tei:lb/>cyprinid Macrochirichthys macrochirus, to account for their structure in terms of function, and<tei:lb/>on the basis of those features considered to be derived ones, to postulate the taxon's relationships.<tei:lb/>The identification and assessment of these characters has led to a reappraisal of the Cultrinae,<tei:lb/>the subfamily to which Macrochirichthys is presently assigned, and to the delimitation of a<tei:lb/>monophyletic assemblage which includes Macrochirichthys but excludes many of the genera<tei:lb/>currently placed in the Cultrinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In an earlier paper describing in part the musculature and skeletal elements of Macrochirichthys<tei:lb/>(Howes, 1976), I pointed out a convergence (see p. 184) between this species and the characoid<tei:lb/>Rhaphiodon. The present studies (on Macrochirichthys) enable further comparisons to be made of<tei:lb/>skeletal and myological architecture in these two cypriniform genera.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Nomenclatural note</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The relatively unfamiliar generic name Securicula Giinther 1868 is introduced early in this paper.<tei:lb/>This name is used in place of Pseudoxygaster Banarescu 1967 for which reasons are stated on<tei:lb/>p. 191.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>List of study material</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Much of the material listed in a previous study (Howes, 1978) was re-examined and only additional<tei:lb/>specimens used for the present study are given here.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bull. Br. Mus. nat. Hist (Zool.) 36 (3) : 147-200 Issued 27 September 1979</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>

         <tei:p>X Axis of vertebral column</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Anatomical notes on Macrochirichthys macrochirus</tei:p>
         <tei:p>After each descriptive section there follows a comparison, with other cultrine and in some cases,<tei:lb/>non-cultrine genera.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The most outstanding features of Macrochirichthys are the almost straight to convex dorsal<tei:lb/>head profile, the oblique angle of the mouth and the greatly extended pectoral fins (Fig. 1). The<tei:lb/>body is elongate, tapering caudally and is markedly compressed with a prominent ventral keel;<tei:lb/>the scales are small, c. 120 in the lateral line, the lateral line is curved gently downwards and runs<tei:lb/>almost midlaterally; the dorsal and anal fins are placed far back; the length of the pectoral fin is<tei:lb/>almost twice that of the head and its tip extends to a point nearly half-way along the standard<tei:lb/>length; the pelvic fins are situated midway between the base of the pectorals and the origin of the<tei:lb/>caudal fin. The fish is intensely silver along the flanks, brassy dorsally and with a large black<tei:lb/>blotch at the base of the caudal fin. Juvenile specimens possess dark saddle-like markings between<tei:lb/>the head and the dorsal fin. Smith (1945) reports specimens of more than half a metre in length.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>There appears to be only a single species referrable to this genus (see Smith 1945 : 77-78 and<tei:lb/>p. 187). It is recorded from Thailand, Java, Sumatra, Borneo, Cambodia, Laos and south China<tei:lb/>(Weber &amp; De Beaufort, 1916; Smith, 1945; Wu, 1964; Taki, 1974).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>20mm<tei:lb/>Fig. 1. Outline drawing of Macrochirichthys macrochirus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cranium</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The horizontal dorsal outline of the head does not indicate the top of the cranium but marks the<tei:lb/>edge of the thick wedge of epaxial muscle mass that extends forward as far as the anterior border<tei:lb/>of the frontals. The cranium itself is aligned at an angle of 20 to the vertebral column (see<tei:lb/>p. 171). The skull is narrow and is, to the best of my knowledge, the most compressed in any<tei:lb/>cyprinid.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The frontals curve medially so as to form an elongate basin into which the epaxial muscle mass<tei:lb/>inserts (Fig. 2A). Laterally, each frontal is folded over to form a creased edge. Anteriorly the</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE ANATOMY OF MACROCHIRICHTHYS MACROCHIRUS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>151</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A B C</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 2 Cross-sections of the crania of A. Macrochirichthys macrochirus. B. Securicula gora. C.<tei:lb/>Parachela oxygastroides. Two sections are shown, through the sphenotic region (entire outline)<tei:lb/>and through the anterior part of the ethmoid region (inset outline). The extent of the frontals<tei:lb/>are indicated by the thickened line.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>frontals overlie the supraethmoid and cover that bone almost to its anterior margin (see below).<tei:lb/>In adults the frontal sensory canals converge to share a common opening at the midline (Fig. 3).<tei:lb/>In juveniles (30 mm SL) the frontals have not developed the concavity seen in the adult but are<tei:lb/>flat and the epaxial musculature extends only as a thin band along the midline to the anterior tip<tei:lb/>of the bones. Furthermore, at this stage of development the frontals have not extended forward to<tei:lb/>cover the supraethmoid and the sensory canals do not meet (cf. Figs 3 &amp; 4).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>For the ethmoid region the use of the terms supraethmoid and mesethmoid follows that of<tei:lb/>Weitzman (1967), Patterson (1975) and Dornesco &amp; Soresco (1971). The supraethmoid is the</tei:p>
         <tei:p>SE ME</tei:p>
         <tei:p>KE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3mm</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 3 Macrochirichys macrochirus ethmo-vomerine region in A. Dorsal view. B. Lateral view.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>152</tei:p>
         <tei:p>G. J. HOWES</tei:p>
