Approach is possibly from below, Macrochirichthys<tei:lb/>arresting its speed by extending the pectoral fins laterally and forward and seizing the prey by a<tei:lb/>rapid backward jerk of the head. Some evidence for this method of capture comes from personal<tei:lb/>observations, and from first-hand accounts of the feeding behaviour of Hydrolycus, a characoid<tei:lb/>closely related to Rhaphiodon (see above). Hydrolycus makes rapid spurts forward and slashes at<tei:lb/>its prey, which it sometimes 'throws' or tosses before swallowing it.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Relationships of Macrochirichthys</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Nomenclatural note</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In the following analysis the name Parachela is used. The genus is defined on p. 189, but its<tei:lb/>introduction at this point is necessary to facilitate the discussion of relationships. Parachela<tei:lb/>includes all those species presently assigned to the genus Oxygaster, with the exception of O.<tei:lb/>anomalura which now remains the sole representative of the genus Oxygaster.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Macrochirichthys belongs to a group of genera characterized by the possession of the following<tei:lb/>synapomorphies :</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1. A short supraethmoid overlapped by the frontals (see p. 152).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2. Narrow, medially depressed frontals with anteriorly converging canals (p. 151).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3. Modified triangular kinethmoid, sometimes articulating directly with the premaxillaries<tei:lb/>(p. 152).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>4. Socket locking premaxillaries (p. 172).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5. Parasphenoid contacting pterosphenoid (p. 156).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>6. A modified 1st centrum (tapered and anteriorly rounded) and second centrum (p. 162).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>7. Neural complex sloped backwards and sometimes articulating with the first supraneural<tei:lb/>(p. 165).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>8. Anterior supraneurals modified and articulating with succeeding elements (p. 165).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>9. Horizontally aligned cranial intermuscular bones (p. 158).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>10. Coracoid with a deeply incised ventral border or a reduced cleithral-coracoid fenestra<tei:lb/>(p. 177).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>11. Short upright cleithral limb (p. 177).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>12. Narrow, elongate supracleithrum (p. 177).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>13. Modified postcleithrum (p. 177).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>14. Anterior cranial extension of epaxial musculature (p. 150).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Characters 1, 3, 6, 11 and 13 are possessed by all the taxa included in the group, i.e. Macro-<tei:lb/>chirichthys, Parachela, Oxygaster, Securicula, Salmostoma and Chela. This assemblage is hereafter<tei:lb/>referred to as the cheline group (see p. 187).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Characters 1 and 3 are also found in Rasbora, Rasborinus, Aspidoparia and Danio; characters 2<tei:lb/>(part), 10, 1 1 and 14 are present in Pelecus. These genera are discussed on pages 191-194.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Chela can be immediately separated from the other cheline group genera on the basis of its<tei:lb/>cranial, pectoral girdle and axial skeletal morphology. The head is broad (wide frontals and</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>186 G. J. HOWES</tei:p>
         <tei:p>supraorbitals); the mesethmoid protrudes far laterally on either side of the reduced supraethmoid<tei:lb/>and extends forward as a shelf (p. 154 &amp; Fig. 8); the preethmoids are minute (p. 154); the kine-<tei:lb/>thmoid is a small triangular lamellar bone (see Fig. 5D); the parasphenoid and orbitosphenoid<tei:lb/>are connected via a deep orbitosphenoidal septum; the dentary is extremely shallow; the enlarged<tei:lb/>supracleithrum almost covers the upright limb of the cleithrum (Fig. 36E); the fenestra between<tei:lb/>the coracoid and cleithrum is reduced or absent; the transverse processes on the 1st vertebra are<tei:lb/>enlarged and caudally directed; the supraneurals are enlarged, lamellar and interlock.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The modifications of the ethmoid region; the shape of the mouth (p. 173), and the deep body are<tei:lb/>adaptations associated with a trend toward specialized surface or aerial feeding habits (p. 184).<tei:lb/>These several autapomorphies characterize Chela as representing the sister group of the other<tei:lb/>genera included in the cheline assemblage (see cladogram, Fig. 41).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Salmostoma (with Securicula; see below) appears to represent the plesiomorph lineage of the<tei:lb/>cheline group. It displays what might be regarded as 'first-stage' modifications resulting in the<tei:lb/>apomorph character complexes present in its sister taxa.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The frontals barely overlap the supraethmoid; the kinethmoid is rod-shaped; the infraorbitals<tei:lb/>are expanded and the 5th contacts the supraorbital ; the orbitosphenoid contacts the parasphenoid<tei:lb/>through a deep and narrow septum; the coracoids, although meeting each other along the midline,<tei:lb/>are not greatly expanded; the neural complex is long with an inclined dorsal border but is<tei:lb/>separated from the fourth neural spine; a quadrat e-metapterygoid fenestra is present; the anal<tei:lb/>fin is short (14-20 rays).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Derived features in Salmostoma are the deeply notched ethmovomerine block; wide lateral<tei:lb/>commissure; trigemino-facialis foramen situated within the prootic face; laterally extended<tei:lb/>parietals ; narrow elongate supracleithrum ; reduced postcleithrum ; acutely angled jaw with well-<tei:lb/>developed symphysial process (in some species; see p. 190).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Securicula, whilst retaining certain plesiomorph features (i.e. metapterygoid-quadrate fenestra;<tei:lb/>large 5th infraorbital contacting the supraorbital; short anal fin), possesses all the apomorph<tei:lb/>characters listed on p. 185, with the exceptions of 4 and 7. Although sharing with Macrochirichthys,<tei:lb/>Parachela and Oxygaster the incised coracoids, with Macrochirichthys and Parachela the medially<tei:lb/>depressed frontals and extended epaxial musculature, and with Macrochirichthys the contact<tei:lb/>between pterosphenoid and parasphenoid an even closer relationship with Salmostoma is suggested<tei:lb/>by the following synapomorphies: anterior trigemino-facialis foramen within the prootic (p. 156);<tei:lb/>narrow, elongate supracleithrum (p. 179); lateral processes of second centrum posteriorly directed,<tei:lb/>reduction of postcleithrum ; elongate axillary scale. On the basis of these characters I consider<tei:lb/>Securicula to represent the sister group of Salmostoma.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Oxygaster possesses 1, 3, 6, 7, 10, 11 and 13 of the apomorph characters listed on p. 185. It<tei:lb/>shares only with Parachela and Macrochirichthys the kinethmoid articulating with the pre-<tei:lb/>maxillaries, the elongate curved postcleithrum, and the long anal fin (26-36 rays; see below).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Plesiomorph features of Oxygaster are the flat cranial roof with the frontal sensory canals<tei:lb/>confined to the lateral edge of the bones; well-developed dilatator fossa; lamellar supraneurals;<tei:lb/>a straight lateral line; large scales.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Oxygaster is here recognized as a monotypic genus (see p. 187) which, together with Macro-<tei:lb/>chirichthys and Parachela, forms a sub-lineage of the cheline assemblage (see p. 187).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Parachela possesses all the apomorph characters listed on p. 185 apart from 5, 9 and 12. It<tei:lb/>shares only with Macrochirichthys the converging frontal canals, socket locking premaxillaries<tei:lb/>and elongate anterior supraneurals. Despite these synapomorphies there is still a large morpho-<tei:lb/>logical 'gap' between the two genera. Like Chela, Parachela snows a trend towards a specialized<tei:lb/>deep-bodied habitus in which the lateral line is strongly decurved and follows the ventral border<tei:lb/>of the body.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>From what has been said above Macrochirichthys is seen to belong to a subgroup of the cheline<tei:lb/>assemblage which also includes Oxygaster and Parachela. Macrochirichthys has tended towards<tei:lb/>an elongation of the body and, a correlated elongation of the anal fin, a character shared with<tei:lb/>the other two genera included in its subgroup (24-26 anal rays in Macrochirichthys; cf. 26-30 in<tei:lb/>Oxygaster and 26-36 in Parachela). Although Macrochirichthys is more highly derived than<tei:lb/>Parachela in terms of the specialized nature of the vertebral column and associated musculature,</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE ANATOMY OF MACROCHIRICHTHYS MACROCHIRUS 187</tei:p>
         <tei:p>it still retains the overall plesiomorphic fades of the cheline group. Although Parachela lacks the<tei:lb/>high degree of vertebral modifications of Macrochirichthys, or even Chela, the morphology of<tei:lb/>the 1st and 2nd centrum and the anteriorly extended epaxial musculature suggest that it too is<tei:lb/>capable of elevating the cranium to a marked degree.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thus, to summarize the interrelationships of the cheline group, it appears that the salmostomine<tei:lb/>lineage (i.e. Salmostoma and Securiculd) form the sister group to the oxygastrine lineage (i.e.<tei:lb/>Macrochirichthys, Parachela and Oxygaster}. Within this assemblage Macrochirichthys and<tei:lb/>Parachela share a common ancestor and form the sister taxon to Oxygaster. The salmostomine<tei:lb/>and oxygastrine lineages together comprise the sister group of the cheline lineage (i.e. Chela);<tei:lb/>see cladogram, Fig. 41.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Macrochirichthys, Parachela and Oxygaster have an almost completely overlapping distribution<tei:lb/>throughout the south-east Asian Archipelago, although, Oxygaster has not been recorded from<tei:lb/>Thailand or the Mekong drainage. Salmostoma is confined to India and Burma and its closest<tei:lb/>relative, Securicula, to eastern and northern India. Chela is widespread throughout India and the<tei:lb/>south-east Asian Archipelago.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>One explanation of this distribution would be to suppose that the ancestral group which<tei:lb/>gave rise to the lineages now represented by the cheline group was present in India (or proto-<tei:lb/>India). If it be accepted that Salmostoma represents the plesiomorph lineage of this group, then<tei:lb/>it is likely that the basal dichotomy between the salmostomine and cheline lineages occurred in<tei:lb/>that subcontinent with subsequent establishment of the cheline (i.e. Chela) lineage in south-<tei:lb/>eastern Asia. Securicula is seen as evolving from the salmostomine lineage within India. The<tei:lb/>oxygastrine assemblage, however, appears to have developed only within the south-east Asian<tei:lb/>Archipelago.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The cheline group: taxonomy and interrelationships</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fowler (1905) first introduced the name 'Chelinae' under which he listed only Macrochirichthys.<tei:lb/>No definition of the Chelinae or indication of their status was given, but the use of the stem<tei:lb/>'Chela' in this name implied the inclusion of the genus Chela with Macrochirichthys. Subse-<tei:lb/>quently, Fowler (1934) placed both genera in the Abramidae, thus following the classification of<tei:lb/>Weber &amp; de Beaufort (1916), a practice adhered to by all subsequent authors.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I have used the name cheline as an informal category and have purposely avoided its use as a<tei:lb/>subfamilial term because the interrelationships of this group with other taxa is at present imper-<tei:lb/>fectly known (see Howes, 1978).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The most recent author to consider the taxonomy of the genera now assigned to the cheline<tei:lb/>group is Banarescu( 1967, 19680, 1968c, 1969, \91\a). Most of these taxa he placed in the Cultrinae<tei:lb/>(Banarescu, 1967). Despite Banarescu's work there remain many problems concerning the<tei:lb/>taxonomy of the species now placed in the cheline group, and these are considered below:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Macrochirichthys Bleeker, 1860</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Type: Leuciscus uranoscopus Bleeker, 1850</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(=Leuciscus macrochirus Valenciennes, 1844)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fowler (1905) described a second species of Macrochirichthys from Borneo, M. snyderi. This<tei:lb/>description was based on a single specimen which differed from specimens of M. macrochirus in<tei:lb/>possessing dark transverse bands across the nape. Later, Weber &amp; de Beaufort (1916) placed<tei:lb/>M. snyderi in the synonomy of M. macrochirus. Fowler (1934) contested this decision, not only<tei:lb/>maintaining the validity of his species but describing yet another, M. laosensis from the Mekong<tei:lb/>River. Smith (1945), correctly in my opinion, relegated both M. synderi and M. laosensis to the<tei:lb/>synonomy of M. macrochirus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Oxygaster van Hasselt, 1823<tei:lb/>Type : Oxygaster anomalura van Hasselt, 1 823</tei:p>
         <tei:p>From the foregoing analysis it will be evident that there are major differences between the type</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>188</tei:p>
         <tei:p>G. J. HOWES</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>13<tei:lb/>ol</tei:p>
         <tei:p>e</tei:p>
         <tei:p>-</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE ANATOMY OF MACROCHIRICHTHYS MACROCHIRUS 189</tei:p>
         <tei:p>species of the genus O. anomalura and the other species presently assigned to the taxon (see<tei:lb/>Banarescu, 1969). The differences between the species are listed below:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Oxygaster anomalura Other Oxygaster species</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Epaxial musculature extends to parietal Epaxial musculature extends to anterior of frontals</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Frontals flat or convex, sensory canals confined Frontals depressed medially, canals converging<tei:lb/>to lateral edges anteriorly</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Well-developed transverse parietal ridge Parietal ridge absent</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Long lower jaw with symphysial process Short lower jaw with reduced symphysial process</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lateral process of 4th vertebra curved posteriorly Lateral process of 4th vertebra curved anteriorly</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Angle of neural complex to vertebral column 35 Angle of neural complex 40-45</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Anterior supraneurals lamellar Anterior supraneurals rod-shaped</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Kinethmoid expanded dorsally Kinethmoid curved anteriorly</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coracoids barely indented Coracoids deeply incised</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Supracleithrum elongate Supracleithrum short</tei:p>
         <tei:p>These morphological differences show that apart from cheline synapomorphies, Oxygaster<tei:lb/>anomalura possesses no other (derived) characters of the other Oxygaster species. I therefore<tei:lb/>consider that these other species be assigned to the genus Parachela (see below).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Parachela Steindachner, 1881</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Type : Parachela breitensteini Steindachner, 1881</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(= Chela hypophthalmus Bleeker, 1860)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This genus was characterized by Steindachner by its lacking of ventral fins. However, the descrip-<tei:lb/>tion was based on a single, aberrant specimen (see below). Apart from this abnormality Parachela<tei:lb/>brietensteini possesses all the characters listed above under the heading 'Other Oxygaster species'.<tei:lb/>In accordance with those characters the species assigned to Parachela are :</tei:p>
         <tei:p>P. oxygastroides (Bleeker, 1852)<tei:lb/>P. hypophthalmus (Bleeker, 1860)<tei:lb/>P. pointoni (Fowler, 1934)<tei:lb/>P. williaminae Fowler, 1934<tei:lb/>P. maculicauda (Smith, 1934)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Through the courtesy of Dr P. Kahsbauer I have been able to examine the holotype and<tei:lb/>unique specimen of Parachela breitensteini. There is no trace of ventral fins nor any part of the<tei:lb/>pelvic girdle (ascertained by radiography). Although abnormal in this respect, all other morpho-<tei:lb/>logical and meristic characters show that P. breitensteini is a specimen of Parachela hypophthalmus<tei:lb/>(Bleeker, 1830) and should thus be included in the synonymy of that species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fowler (1934) described a second Parachela species, P. williaminae which he placed in a sub-<tei:lb/>genus, Grandisquamachela, distinguished from Parachela by its larger scales (35 in the lateral line,<tei:lb/>cf. 60 in P. breitensteini. Banarescu (197 la) found that Fowler's (1934) description was also based<tei:lb/>on an aberrant specimen and placed the species in the genus Oxygaster. I have not seen the type<tei:lb/>of P. williaminae and so am provisionally accepting Banarescu's (1971#) contention that it is a<tei:lb/>valid species and is related to P. oxygastroides.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The species here assigned to Parachela were revised by Banarescu (1969) and for the most part I<tei:lb/>agree with his synonymies. However, concerning the taxon pointoni, Banarescu (1969) recognized<tei:lb/>Chela pointoni Fowler, 1934 as a valid species (of Oxygaster, i.e. Parachela) but later (Banarescu,<tei:lb/>1971a) he considered it to be a subspecies of Oxygaster anomalura van Hasselt, 1823. I have not<tei:lb/>seen the holotype of this species but from Fowler's description and the photograph published by</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>190 G. J. HOWES</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Banarescu (1969) it is clear that the epaxial muscles extend forward to the interorbital area and<tei:lb/>therefore the taxon should be referred to the genus Parachela. Its specific status must remain in<tei:lb/>doubt; according to Banarescu (1969) there are '. . . some 36 scales' in the lateral line, yet later<tei:lb/>(1971a) he gives a count of 43-44; Fowler (1934) in his original description gives 33. If Banarescu's<tei:lb/>197 la description is correct then I see no reason why P. pointoni should not be included in the<tei:lb/>synonymy of P. oxygastroides. Taki (1974) records P. pointoni from Laos, but his photograph is<tei:lb/>of an Oxygaster species, close to, or identical with O. anomalura.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Salmostoma Swainson, 1839<tei:lb/>Type: Cyprinus bacaila Hamilton-Buchanan, 1822</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This genus belongs to the plesiomorph sister-group of the oxygastrine lineage (see p. 187). The<tei:lb/>most recent revision is by Banarescu (19680) who recognizes 10 species. I have the following<tei:lb/>comments concerning these species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Salmostoma bacaila (Hamilton-Buchanan, 1822). The development of the symplectic and the<tei:lb/>associated metapterygoid-quadrate fenestra in this species have been commented on earlier<tei:lb/>(p. 175). It was considered that the nature of this feature, together with the long jaws, are indica-<tei:lb/>tive of a relatively derived status. This is further indicated by the elongate, deeply notched<tei:lb/>ethmoid region and the well-developed symphysial hook on the lower jaw. Banarescu (19680)<tei:lb/>states that this species is '. . . the most frequent of all', but then notes that its range is restricted<tei:lb/>to the Indus and Ganges drainages.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Salmostoma clupeoides (Bloch, 1782). As Banarescu (19680) suggests, this species may simply<tei:lb/>be a subspecies or perhaps a clinal group of S. bacaila from which it appears to differ only<tei:lb/>in the number of lateral line scales.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Salmostoma phulo (Hamilton-Buchanan, 1822). I cannot agree with Banarescu's (19680)<tei:lb/>division of this species into two subspecies, separated by a difference in the number of lateral<tei:lb/>line scales (99-1 12 in phulo phulo cf. 76-86 in phulo orissaensis). Later, Banarescu (19710) recorded<tei:lb/>the subspecies orissaensis from Madras based on a single specimen with a lateral line count of<tei:lb/>89, thus extending the range of this 'subspecies' for a further 700 miles. I have examined the types<tei:lb/>of S. phulo orissaensis and find many differences, apart from lateral line scale counts, between<tei:lb/>them and specimens of S. phulo phulo (e.g. shape of the 5th infraorbital; interorbital width;<tei:lb/>pectoral fin length; lower jaw length; shape of axillary scale), all of which Banarescu has ignored<tei:lb/>but which I believe indicate specific rather than subspecific status.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Salmostoma punjabensis (Day, 1872). Banarescu (19680) suggests that this taxon is possibly a<tei:lb/>subspecies of S. phulo. This is highly unlikely as 5 1 . punjabensis is known only from the Indus and<tei:lb/>S. phulo only from Assam, a separation of some 28 of latitude. My own comparison of the two<tei:lb/>types suggest these are indeed two quite distinct species characterized by differences in snout,<tei:lb/>jaw and pectoral fin length. Banarescu (19680) does not give measurements of the pectoral fin<tei:lb/>length which appears to be an important character in separating species of this genus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Salmostoma horai (Silas, 1951). Banarescu (19680) did not examine any specimens but accepted<tei:lb/>this as a valid species on the basis of Silas' description. Silas (1951) remarks that the lower jaw<tei:lb/>has a well-developed symphysial process and that the species differs from its congeners in<tei:lb/>possessing short vertical bands along the flanks.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Salmostoma acinaces (Valenciennes, 1842). A large scaled species which will probably prove to<tei:lb/>be polyspecific.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Salmostoma untrahi (Day, 1869). Banarescu (19680) noted the vertically aligned mouth and the<tei:lb/>long symphysial process of the lower jaw, this process is not developed in a specimen of 65 mm<tei:lb/>SL. Elsewhere I have commented on these features (p. 186) and suggest that S. untrahi repre-<tei:lb/>sents, like S. bacaila, a specialization towards the morphotype of Securicula.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Salmostoma boopis (Day, 1869). Banarescu (19680) notes. This species is close to S. acinaces,<tei:lb/>differing from it in number of scales, rays and gill rakers (but with overlap of extreme values!)'.<tei:lb/>I find that there is an overlap in all meristics and it seems likely that S. boopis is a synonym of<tei:lb/>S. acinaces (part).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Salmostoma sardinella (Valenciennes, 1842). Comments have already been made concerning</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE ANATOMY OF MACROCHIRICHTHYS MACROCHIRUS 191</tei:p>
         <tei:p>the form of the metapterygoid-quadrate fenestra in this species (p. 175) and its relatively special-<tei:lb/>ized nature.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Salmostoma sladdoni (Day, 1869); the only species of the genus apparently restricted to Burma.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Banarescu (19680) groups the species of Salmostoma into four lineages on the basis of geo-<tei:lb/>graphical distribution. Such a grouping is impossible on the material currently available, the<tei:lb/>total collections of which amount to c. 150 specimens (based on Banarescu, 19680). This interest-<tei:lb/>ing genus must be critically revised on an osteological basis before any assumptions can be<tei:lb/>made concerning intra-generic relationships.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Securicula Giinther, 1868</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Synonymy: Pseudoxygaster Banarescu, 1967</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Type : Cyprinus gora Hamilton- Buchanan, 1 822</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Banarescu (1967) erected the genus Pseudoxygaster for the species gora which previously had<tei:lb/>been assigned by various authors to either Chela or Oxygaster. Giinther (1868) had divided the<tei:lb/>genus Chela into two sections on the grounds of differences in the pectoral girdles. One of these<tei:lb/>divisions he named Securicula and included gora as the first-named species. Jordan (1919)<tei:lb/>recognized gora as the type species of Securicula by logotypy. Banarescu (1967, 19680) treated<tei:lb/>Securicula as a synonym of Salmostoma, presumably on the assumption that the other species<tei:lb/>listed by Giinther under Securicula are now recognized as belonging to the genus Salmostoma.<tei:lb/>I can find no grounds for not recognizing Securicula as a distinct taxon and accordingly treat<tei:lb/>Pseudoxygaster as its junior synonym.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The genus is monotypic, although Banarescu (1967) considered the possibility that there are<tei:lb/>two subspecies, an opinion based on a single specimen having fewer lateral line scales than the<tei:lb/>type.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Banarescu (1967) thought Securicula to be closely related to Macrochirichthys and Pelecus.<tei:lb/>Mirza, Alam &amp; Kausar (1974) and Mirza (1975) noted the presence of the metapterygoid-quadrate<tei:lb/>fenestra and Mirza (1975) considered the genus to be 'the most primitive of the Cultrinae of<tei:lb/>south Asia'. Contrary to this opinion I believe Securicula is the most highly evolved member of<tei:lb/>the Salmostomine lineage (see p. 187).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Chela Hamilton- Buchanan, 1822<tei:lb/>Type: Chela cachius Hamilton-Buchanan, 1822</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The most complete revision of the genus is that of Silas (1958) who recognized the subgenera<tei:lb/>Allochela and Neochela on the basis respectively of a complete or incomplete lateral line.<tei:lb/>Banarescu later (1968c) recognized a third subgenus Malay ochela with the pharyngeal teeth<tei:lb/>arranged in two instead of three rows as in the other taxa. However, Banarescu states that this<tei:lb/>is a variable character in other cyprinid genera - which it is - and therefore I see little to justify<tei:lb/>the subgenus Malayochela. There are, on the other hand, distinct differences in the development<tei:lb/>of the transverse processes of the 1st and 2nd vertebrae. Whether these differences are species<tei:lb/>specific or whether they can be used to define groups of species remains to be verified.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The relationships of Chela have been discussed on p. 186; the genus is seen as representing a<tei:lb/>highly evolved group of surface or aerial feeding specialists which departed early from the basic<tei:lb/>cheline stock.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Of the characters listed on p. 185 defining the cheline group, one - the frontals overlying the<tei:lb/>supraethmoid - is shared with Aspidoparia, Rasbora, Rasborinus and Danio; furthermore, a<tei:lb/>second feature - the expanded kinethmoid - is found in all but Aspidoparia. These four genera<tei:lb/>pose acute problems in determining phylogenetic relationships and will be discussed in greater<tei:lb/>detail.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Aspidoparia Heckel, 1843</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Type: Aspidoparia sardina Heckel, 1843</tei:p>
         <tei:p>( = Cyprinus morar Hamilton- Buchanan, 1822)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This genus shares with the other taxa assigned to the cheline group a short, triangular supra-<tei:lb/>ethmoid; anteriorly the ethmo-vomer block is deeply notched and posteriorly the supraethmoid is</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>192 G. J. HOWES</tei:p>
         <tei:p>covered by the frontals. However, the entire ethmoid block is short and strongly decurved<tei:lb/>anteriorly. Aspidoparia also shares with other chelines an elongate first supraneural which<tei:lb/>articulates with the neural complex. As in Salmostoma the kinethmoid is rod-shaped, the infra-<tei:lb/>orbitals large (the 5th contacting the supraorbital), the orbitosphenoid is joined to the para-<tei:lb/>sphenoid by a deep septum and there is a metapterygoid-quadrate fenestra (the smallest aperture<tei:lb/>of this nature in any of the genera possessing it - see p. 177). All these characters shared with<tei:lb/>Salmostoma are plesiomorph for the cheline group, as are the gently curved lateral line and<tei:lb/>short anal fin (9-12 rays).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Aspidoparia differs from other genera assigned to the chelines in the following features;<tei:lb/>the 1st vertebra is neither anteriorly tapered nor rounded and it bears strong, somewhat anteriorly<tei:lb/>directed lateral processes; the neural complex is upright and not inclined backwards ; the cleithrum<tei:lb/>is upright and has a high anterior ridge along its horizontal arm (resembling the condition in<tei:lb/>Danio); and finally the reduced parietals and well-developed supraoccipital process.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The jaws of Aspidoparia are markedly different from any cheline or for that matter, any<tei:lb/>cultrine. They are short, the lower jaw being curved strongly medially and the entire mouth<tei:lb/>inferiorly placed. The coronoid process of the obliquely angled dentary is situated at the middle of<tei:lb/>that bone. From the roof of the mouth there hangs a thick papillose nodule originating from<tei:lb/>below the vomer. The intestine of Aspidoparia is much coiled (the specimens dissected contained<tei:lb/>fine mud and silt in the gut).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Sorescu (1968) placed Aspidoparia amongst the cultrines because of resemblances between its<tei:lb/>pectoral girdle and those of certain other genera. By my definition of the cultrine group Aspidoparia<tei:lb/>cannot be placed there (p. 197). The synapomorphies mentioned above may be indicative,<tei:lb/>however, of a shared common ancestry between Aspidoparia and Salmostoma, in which case<tei:lb/>Aspidoparia can be seen as representing a specialized detrivorous branch of the cheline group<tei:lb/>(see Fig. 41).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>There appear to be two species of Aspidoparia; A. morar (Hamilton- Buchanan, 1822) and<tei:lb/>A.jaya (Hamilton- Buchanan, 1822). The species siamensis Sauvage, 1881, originally placed in the<tei:lb/>genus Morara, was placed in Aspidoparia by Smith (1945). He quoted Pellegrin as saying that<tei:lb/>siamensis did not belong to Aspidoparia, but although Smith included it in that genus he did so<tei:lb/>with hesitation. I have not seen Sauvage's specimens of Morara siamensis and so the correct<tei:lb/>placement of this taxon must await a revision of this species group.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>As mentioned above (p. 191) three other genera also share some of the characters used in<tei:lb/>defining the cheline group. These are Rasbora, Rasborinus and Danio.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The ethmoid region of some Rasbora species (including the type of the genus, R. rasbord)<tei:lb/>closely resembles that of Chela in that the mesethmoid extends laterally beyond the borders of<tei:lb/>the supraethmoid and protrudes as a shelf; the kinethmoid is also of the same lamellar type.<tei:lb/>Not all species of Rasbora possess these characters and some species (i.e. R. argyrotaenia and<tei:lb/>R. dusonensis) share derived characters with Luciosoma.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In Rasborinus and some species of Danio the ethmo-vomer is deeply notched anteriorly as in<tei:lb/>the chelines and cultrines (see p. 194).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>As with Rasbora there is a similar problem concerning the genus Danio. The species I have<tei:lb/>examined appear to have marked differences in certain characters, particularly in the form of<tei:lb/>the lower jaw. In Danio dangila, the type of the genus, the antero-ventral part of the dentary<tei:lb/>bears a semicircular notch, there is a strong lateral flange on the coronoid process of the dentary,<tei:lb/>and the kinethmoid is of a type closer to that of Rasbora than to the other Danio species. In<tei:lb/>Danio malabaricus, D. aequipinnatus and D. spinosus the kinethmoid is of the lunate type illustrated<tei:lb/>in Fig. 5E; the notch on the ventral surface of the dentary is widely separated from its fellow<tei:lb/>along the midline, thus forming a characteristic arrow-shaped gap when viewed from below<tei:lb/>(Fig. 42), and there is a crenelated fleshy ridge along the margin of the lower jaw. Danio devario<tei:lb/>differs from all these species not only in the rhomboidal form of the body but in the morphology<tei:lb/>of the ethmoid region, which resembles that of Chela. It lacks, however, any of the characters<tei:lb/>used to define the cheline group, apart from the overlapping of the dermethmoid by the frontals<tei:lb/>and the triangular lamellar kinethmoid.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The composite genera Danio and Rasbora must be revised before any phylogenetic relationships</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE ANATOMY OF MACROCHIRICHTHYS MACROCHIRUS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>193</tei:p>
         <tei:p>can be established between their various included taxa. Thus, at present I cannot say if Rasbora<tei:lb/>sensu stricto, Danio sensu stricto and Rasborinus are more closely related to the cheline than to<tei:lb/>any other group; indeed I am not even sure that the three taxa are closely related to each other.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2mm</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 42 Danio malabaricus, ventral aspect of the lower jaw.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Although Rasbora sensu stricto, Danio sensu stricto and Rasborinus share with the cheline<tei:lb/>group similarly modified ethmoids, there are no similar vertebral modifications. Whether such<tei:lb/>changes in the ethmoid region (i.e. overlap of the supraethmoid by the frontals) must necessarily<tei:lb/>be correlated with rearrangements in the structure of the vertebral column - as seems to have<tei:lb/>been the case in the chelines - is uncertain. However, studies on the African cyprinid genera<tei:lb/>Engraulicypris and Chelaethiops indicate that such changes in the ethmoid region are a 'pre-<tei:lb/>requisite' to vertebral modifications.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Comments on the Cultrinae and relationships with the cheline group</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The problem now remains as to the relationships of the cheline group with other assemblages<tei:lb/>of cyprinids and in this context the interrelationships of the taxa referred to the subfamily<tei:lb/>Cultrinae (to which the cheline genera are currently assigned) must be evaluated.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Of all the cyprinid subfamilial assemblages recognized at present there is probably none so<tei:lb/>ill-defined as the Cultrinae. Nikolsky (1954, 1955) first used the subfamily designation to include<tei:lb/>some genera which had previously been placed in the Abramidae, Xenocyprinidae and Danio-<tei:lb/>ninae. Silas (1958), in his review of Chela, pointed out that the Abramidinae (he made no mention<tei:lb/>of the Cultrinae; no doubt having overlooked Nikolsky's introduction of the taxon) seemed a<tei:lb/>group of convenience rather than a natural assemblage and thought that it included two major<tei:lb/>sub-groups, one in Thailand and the Malayan sub-region, the other in China.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Banarescu (1967) reviewed the Cultrinae, outlined its taxonomic history and pointed out the<tei:lb/>difficulties in defining the taxon. The characters Banarescu used were entirely superficial and<tei:lb/>apparently indiscriminate ones, and although he thought the subfamily represented a mono-<tei:lb/>phyletic unit he produced no arguments to show why. In fact his statement that the monophyly</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>194 G. J. HOWES</tei:p>
         <tei:p>of the Cultrinae is 'less evident' than that of some other subfamilies, and again 'the relationships<tei:lb/>between these genera are obscure' indicates Banarescu's uncertainty about the monophyletic<tei:lb/>integrity of the 21 genera he included in this group. Later, Banarescu (\91Qa) makes the point<tei:lb/>that the 'delimitation of the genera within the Cultrinae is difficult and rather arbitrary, while<tei:lb/>the species are in general well-differentiated'.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Sorescu (1968) studied the pectoral girdle in various cyprinids. On the basis of this study she<tei:lb/>made radical taxonomic changes by placing Aspidoparia morar, Barilius zambesensis and Alburnus<tei:lb/>alburnus in the Cultrinae. However, as pointed out by Howes (1978), she misinterpreted various<tei:lb/>similarities as indicating relationship instead of parallelism, and made no attempt to support her<tei:lb/>conclusions by using other morphological characters.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>During the course of studying Macrochirichthys I have had the opportunity to examine<tei:lb/>representatives of the genera placed in the Cultrinae by Banarescu (1967) and by Sorescu (1968).<tei:lb/>The following comments may serve to clarify the taxonomy and interrelationships of these taxa.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cutter Basilewski, 1855<tei:lb/>Type: Culler alburnus Basilewsky, 1855</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Erythroculter Berg, 1909<tei:lb/>Type: Culler erylhroplerus Basilewsky, 1855</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ischikauia Jordan &amp; Snyder, 1900<tei:lb/>Type: Opsariichlhys sleenackeri Sauvage, 1883</tei:p>
         <tei:p>These closely related genera can be considered together. All three share an almost identical<tei:lb/>cranial anatomy, i.e. deeply notched ethmoid, an anteriorly projecting vomer, well-developed and<tei:lb/>ovate preethmoids, narrow skull, long post-parietal platform (formed from the supraoccipital,<tei:lb/>parietal and epioccipital - see Howes, 1978), truncated supraoccipital process, well-developed<tei:lb/>posttemporal fossae, large dilatator fossae, formed from the frontal and sphenotic, the sphenotic<tei:lb/>process produced latero-posteriorly, the orbitosphenoid and parasphenoid in close contact,<tei:lb/>extensive intercalar, wide ectopterygoid, a quadrate foramen, short upper and lower jaws with a<tei:lb/>high coronoid process on the dentary, and a wide, vertically aligned neural complex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Many of these characters are widespread amongst cyprinids and must therefore be regarded as<tei:lb/>plesiomorph. However, there are indications that the morphology of the ethmoid region, of the<tei:lb/>post-parietal area of the cranium, and of the pectoral girdle, will provide useful characters<tei:lb/>positively to link these genera with others considered below.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Culler and Erythroculter differ from each other in the form of the lower jaw, which is also<tei:lb/>shorter in Culler (contained twice in head length, cf. 1-5 times in Erythroculter). The coronoid<tei:lb/>process is situated at the posterior end of the lower jaw in Cutter whereas it lies midway along the<tei:lb/>jaw in Erythroculter. Other differences are to be found in the width of the supraorbitals and length<tei:lb/>of the nasals.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ischikauia most closely resembles Erythroculter but differs both from that genus and from<tei:lb/>Culler in possessing a flexible 2nd dorsal spine instead of a well-ossified one.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Berg (1964 : 360) stated that Erythroculter is 'like Culler but abdomen keeled only behind the<tei:lb/>ventral base'. I doubt whether such a character by itself has any use in determining generic-level<tei:lb/>relationships (see p. 180).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Despite the fact that there have been two revisions of the genus Erythroculter (Yih &amp; Chu,<tei:lb/>1959 -not seen; Banarescu, 1967) both this genus and Culler have been inadequately defined<tei:lb/>and much nomenclatural confusion still exists. Banarescu (1967), following Yih &amp; Chu (1959),<tei:lb/>states that Culler erylhroplerus Basilewsky, the type species of the genus Erythroculter is in fact<tei:lb/>synonymous with Culler alburnus and therefore Erythroculter must become a synonym of Culler.<tei:lb/>As pointed out above there are significant differences between Culler and Erythroculter. In the<tei:lb/>course of this study specimens of Culler alburnus, Culler brevicauda, Erythroculter ilishaeformis<tei:lb/>and Erythroculter mongolicus were examined. The type specimens of Culler erylhroplerus are<tei:lb/>apparently lost (Banarescu, 1967) and if, as seems likely from the description of Basilewsky (1855),<tei:lb/>erylhroplerus is a synonym of alburnus, then Erythroculter must be a junior synonym of Culler.<tei:lb/>But, since there are synapomorph characters relating the species ilishaeformis, dabryi, hypselo-</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE ANATOMY OF MACROCHIRICHTHYS MACROCHIRVS 195</tei:p>
         <tei:p>notus, oxycephaloides and mongolicus which are not possessed by those referred to the genus<tei:lb/>Culler, the former group will have to be referred to the genus Chanodichthys Bleeker, 1860 (the<tei:lb/>next available name) with mongolicus as the type of the genus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The nomenclatural problem concerning the type species of the genus Culler was satisfactorily<tei:lb/>resolved by Myers (1940). This genus is in need of a thorough revision and the generic status of<tei:lb/>some species (e.g. C. lienlsinensis Abbott, 1901 and C. kashinensis Shaw, 1930) has to be clarified.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Longiculter Fowler, 1937<tei:lb/>Type: Longiculter siahi Fowler, 1937</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This is a perplexing taxon known only from the unique holotype. Fowler's (1937) statement that<tei:lb/>Longiculter differs from other cultrine genera in the elongate and compressed body means virtually<tei:lb/>nothing (see Smith, 1945). What is important is that the species appears to possess over 100 gill-<tei:lb/>rakers (rarely above 30 in cultrines and oxygastrines).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Banarescu (1967, 197 la) accepts Longiculter as a valid genus. In his 19710 paper Banarescu<tei:lb/>simply states 'Agree with Fowler's description', and he gives a gill-raker count of 107-128<tei:lb/>(Fowler gives 106).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Both this genus and the Culler species recorded from Thailand need to be re-examined critically.<tei:lb/>Regrettably I have no specimens of these taxa to hand but I suspect that the 'Culler' of Thailand<tei:lb/>will be found to be quite a different entity from the 'Culler' of China. Hora (1923) pointed out<tei:lb/>the differences between Culler siamensis and the other species assigned to that genus (see also<tei:lb/>Smith, 1945 : 87 on this point). Whether these Thailand forms will have to be placed in the<tei:lb/>cultrine or cheline group must await the availability of further specimens.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Megalobrama Dybowski, 1872<tei:lb/>Type: Megalobrama skolkovii Dybowski, 1872<tei:lb/>( = Megalobrama lerminalis (Richardson), 1 846)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This genus has the same osteological characteristics as Erylhroculler, but the member species are<tei:lb/>deeper bodied, have wider crania and less oblique mouths. One important character is the<tei:lb/>presence of sharp-edged horny sheaths in the upper and lower jaws.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The genus Sinibrama was established by Wu (1939) for the species Megalobrama macrops<tei:lb/>Giinther. Wu (1939) distinguished Sinibrama from Megalobrama on the basis of its shorter anal<tei:lb/>fin and bipartite (cf. tripartite) swimbladder. Banarescu (19700) considered this division worthy<tei:lb/>of only subgeneric rank. However, there are differences in the structure of the mouth, the horny<tei:lb/>sheaths being absent in M. macrops, which also has a different pattern of fleshy folds in the<tei:lb/>buccal cavity. I have also found differences in the structure of gill-rakers between macrops and<tei:lb/>other Megalobrama species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Parabramis Bleeker, 1864<tei:lb/>Type: Abramis pekinensis Basilewski, 1855</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This genus has the same osteological characters as Erylhroculler. However, the infraorbitals are<tei:lb/>more reduced than in that genus, the pharyngeal teeth are pointed and the ventral keel extends<tei:lb/>forward of the ventral fins (although this character is of a somewhat dubious nature, see p. 180).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ancherythroculter Wu, 1964<tei:lb/>Type: Chanodichthys kuremalsui Kimura, 1934</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I have been unable to examine specimens of any of the species assigned to this genus. According<tei:lb/>to Banarescu (1967) Ancherythroculter is separated from Erylhroculler on the basis of a bipartite<tei:lb/>(cf. tripartite) swimbladder, differences in the length of the anal fin and the shape of the scales.<tei:lb/>Banarescu (19710) recognized these as 'good generic' characters but earlier (19700) in the case of<tei:lb/>Megalobrama and Sinibrama had considered the same characters as worthy of only subgeneric<tei:lb/>distinction (see above).</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>196 G. J. HOWES</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Rasborinus Oshima, 1920</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Type: Rasborinus takakii Oshima, 1920</tei:p>
         <tei:p>( = Rasborinus lineata (Pellegrin), 1907)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mention has already been made of the possible relationship between this genus and Danio<tei:lb/>(p. 192).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paralaubuca Bleeker, 1863<tei:lb/>Type : Paralaubuca typus Bleeker, 1 863</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The osteology of the cranium and the axial skeleton is typically that of Culler. The distinctive<tei:lb/>character of this genus lies in the two quite separate lateral lines on the anterior part of the body<tei:lb/>(in some specimens there may even be three; see Banarescu 197 16 : 348).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pseudolaubuca Bleeker, 1864<tei:lb/>Type: Pseudolaubuca sinensis Bleeker, 1864</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The cranium is narrow and convex across the interorbital region. The orbitosphenoid and<tei:lb/>parasphenoid are widely separated by an orbitosphenoid septum. The ethmoid region, the first<tei:lb/>vertebra and neural complex are like those of Culler. There is an elaborate development of the<tei:lb/>supraneurals (see p. 170, Fig. 25) like that found in Chela. A parallel feature shared with Macro-<tei:lb/>chirichlhys is the lateral process of the hyomandibula. A revision of the genus was made by<tei:lb/>Banarescu (1964).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hemiculter Bleeker, 1859<tei:lb/>Type: Culler leucisculus Basilewski, 1835</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The cranium is as in Pseudolaubuca, but the premaxillary processes are elongate. This genus is<tei:lb/>almost identical with Toxabramis save for the possession of a non-serrated dorsal spine, a<tei:lb/>character which in other cyprinid genera (e.g. Barbus) is not indicative of generic status.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Banarescu (1968ft) revised the species of Hemiculter but made no mention of the relationships<tei:lb/>of the genus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Toxabramis Gunther, 1873<tei:lb/>Type: Toxabramis swinhonis Gunther, 1873</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Toxabramis is distinguished from Hemiculter because its pharyngeal teeth are in two and not three<tei:lb/>rows and it has a serrated and not a flexible dorsal fin spine. I have been unable to examine the<tei:lb/>osteology of Toxabramis in detail but superficial dissection of one of the syntypes of T. swinhonis,<tei:lb/>and an examination of radiographs, reveals a Culter-type organization of the cranial and axial<tei:lb/>skeletons. A revision of the genus was made by Banarescu (1963).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hemiculterella Warpachowski, 1887<tei:lb/>Type: Hemiculterella sauvagei Warpachowski, 1887</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The cranium is wide and flat; the orbitosphenoids are closely joined with the parasphenoid; the<tei:lb/>infraorbitals are large and the supraorbital almost contacts the 5th infraorbital. The lateral line<tei:lb/>is deeply curved anteriorly and follows an erratic course. The dilatator fossa is small and roofed<tei:lb/>by the frontal. The second dorsal spine is well-ossified.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The relationships of Hemiculterella are discussed below, p. 197. Possibly not all species<tei:lb/>presently ascribed to this genus should be included in it (see Banarescu, 197 la).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pelecus Agassiz. 1835<tei:lb/>Type: Cyprinus cullralus Linnaeus, 1758</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The cranium is wide and flat posteriorly; the frontals are depressed medially and accommodate<tei:lb/>the anterior extension of the epaxial musculature; the infraorbitals are reduced and the supra-<tei:lb/>orbital is small; the lower jaw is short and without a symphysial extension; the supraneurals are</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE ANATOMY OF MACROCHIRICHTHYS MACROCHIRUS 197</tei:p>
         <tei:p>well-developed; the lateral line is deeply curved anteriorly and follows an erratic course; the<tei:lb/>lateral line scales are numerous (90-1 15).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pelecus is the only supposedly European representative of the Cultrinae and was included in<tei:lb/>this subfamily by Banarescu (1967) on the grounds of its close resemblance to Oxygaster and<tei:lb/>Macrochirichthys. However, it differs in many respects from those and other cheline genera. The<tei:lb/>cranium, although showing a development of the frontals similar to that in Macrochirichthys,<tei:lb/>Parachela and Securicula, is wide posteriorly and has reduced parietals; an extensive auto-<tei:lb/>sphenotic accommodates a large dilatator and posttemporal fossae cf. pages 152-153); the<tei:lb/>supraethmoid is posteriorly sutured to the frontals instead of being overlapped by them. Although<tei:lb/>Pelecus resembles the cheline genera in the alignment of the neural complex, there are marked<tei:lb/>differences in its basic morphology. The second neural plate is reduced; the neural complex is<tei:lb/>greatly expanded antero-posteriorly and contacts the first supraneural above the 5th centrum,<tei:lb/>cf. 7th or 8th in Macrochirichthys; the supraneurals are lamellar. The 1st vertebra, although<tei:lb/>having a well-rounded anterior face, possesses broad lateral processes, the ends of which are<tei:lb/>directed ventro-posteriorly. Other differences from members of the cheline group are evident in<tei:lb/>the pectoral girdle. The upright part of the cleithrum in Pelecus is broadly lamellar; the supra-<tei:lb/>cleithrum extends halfway along the cleithrum; the postcleithrum is short and straight; the<tei:lb/>posterior border of the coracoid is straight and although, as in Parachela and Securicula, the<tei:lb/>ventral coracoid border is incised, the nature of this indentation is quite different (see p. 180;<tei:lb/>cf. Figs 33B &amp; 35C).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Although, as already mentioned, Pelecus possesses some of the apomorph characters listed on<tei:lb/>p. 185 as defining the cheline group, it lacks the characteristic morphology of the ethmo-vomerine<tei:lb/>region (p. 153). Furthermore, the vertebral column and pectoral girdle, although similar to those<tei:lb/>structures in the chelines are, in their basic morphology, more akin to those like structures in<tei:lb/>some leuciscines (see also Gosline, 1974 who includes Pelecus in the leuciscines). In short, they<tei:lb/>are the result of parallel evolution. Perhaps it is more correct to consider this as convergent<tei:lb/>evolution when it is remembered that Pelecus spends much of its life in brackish water where it<tei:lb/>appears to behave in a rather clupeoid fashion. Thus, those features in which it resembles some<tei:lb/>of the cheline genera may have been acquired under the different selection pressures of an esturine<tei:lb/>environment. This has resulted in the evolution of similar pelagic characters to the chelines but in<tei:lb/>dissimilar associations.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A likely candidate as the closest relative to Pelecus is Hemiculterella. With this genus Pelecus<tei:lb/>shares the flat, posterior cranium; the extensive sphenotic and dilatator fossa and the zig-zagged<tei:lb/>lateral line.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>To recapitulate; of the twenty-one genera listed by Banarescu (1967) as belonging to the<tei:lb/>Cultrinae, only six are thought to constitute a monophyletic assemblage - the cheline group.<tei:lb/>Of the taxa placed in the Cultrinae by Sorescu (1968) Aspidoparia has already been discussed<tei:lb/>(pp. 191); Barilius zambesensis although belonging to a discrete group of bariliines (unpublished<tei:lb/>obs.) possesses no derived characters which would include it amongst the cultrines; Alburnus<tei:lb/>alburnus may have a closer affinity with certain cultrines than do other taxa currently placed in the<tei:lb/>Leuciscinae. Of the remaining genera two related assemblages can be recognized.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I The cultrine group, comprising Culter, Erythroculter, Ischikauia, Parabramis, Megalobrama</tei:p>
         <tei:p>and Paralaubuca,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>II The hemicultrine group, comprising Hemiculter, Pseudolaubuca and Toxabramis (possibly</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Rasboriichthys (part) should also be included here).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Two other genera included in the Cultrinae by Banarescu (1967), Pelecus and Hemiculterella,<tei:lb/>are believed to be closely related to one another but not to any of the taxa listed above. Their<tei:lb/>relationships would seem to be with the Leuciscinae sensu lato.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Rasborinus appears to be related to Danio (see p. 192), a genus not included in the Cultrinae by<tei:lb/>Banarescu (1967).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The affinities of Ancherythroculter are at present unknown (p. 195), but do not appear to be<tei:lb/>with the cultrine or hemicultrine groups.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In his discussion on the relationships of the Cultrinae, Banarescu (1967) mentions the genus<tei:lb/>Nematabramis which Weber &amp; de Beaufort (1916) placed in the Abramidinae (thus including it</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>198 G. J. HOWES</tei:p>
         <tei:p>with Chela and Macrochirichthys). Banarescu (1967) does not accept any relationship between<tei:lb/>Nematabramis and any of his cultrine genera but states that it is 'evidently related to the Danioinae<tei:lb/>especially to Esomus\ Nematabramis is a peculiar taxon; there are transverse ridges along the<tei:lb/>surface of the frontal (Howes, 1978), a highly modified ethmoid region, a membraneous maxillary<tei:lb/>barbel and other characters which do not immediately suggest a close relative. I can find no<tei:lb/>osteological evidence to suggest a close relationship between Danio sensu stricto and Esomus as<tei:lb/>is implied by Banarescu (1967, 1971ft).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The other group mentioned by Banarescu (1967) as being a likely relative of the Cultrinae is the<tei:lb/>subfamily Xenocypridinae. According to Banarescu (1970ft) the characters defining this subfamily<tei:lb/>are: an inferior transverse mouth, smooth dorsal spine and compressed pharyngeal teeth with<tei:lb/>long grinding surfaces. I have examined the type species of Xenocypris, X. argentea and find<tei:lb/>that the dentary is extremely shallow and short, but it is broad so that medially it is narrowly<tei:lb/>separated from its fellow; the coronoid process of the lower jaw is high with a concave border;<tei:lb/>the ethmoid complex is deeply notched anteriorly and that there is an anterior chamber of the<tei:lb/>subtemporal fossa.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Two other genera are included in the Xenocypridinae, Plagiognathops and Distoechodon<tei:lb/>(sometimes recognized as subgenera of Xenocypris; see for example Nichols, 1943). Banarescu<tei:lb/>(1970ft) recognizes Plagiognathus as a valid, monotypic genus but Distoechodon as a 'polytypic<tei:lb/>subgenus'! From my own limited observations it appears that there is considerable difference<tei:lb/>in the structure of the gill-rakers between these various taxa. For example, Plagiognathus microdon<tei:lb/>more closely resembles Xenocypris (Disteochodon) tumirostris in this character than do either of<tei:lb/>these taxa resemble Xenocypris argenteus. As yet I have been unable to ascertain that they all<tei:lb/>share the apomorph osteological characters of Xenocypris argenteus listed above. This entire<tei:lb/>group is in need of critical revision and like so many other cyprinid 'subfamilies' the Xenocypri-<tei:lb/>dinae appears to be polyphyletic.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mirza (1975) thought the Cultrinae to be most closely related to the Danioinae but in the light<tei:lb/>of the comments concerning the composite nature of the genus Danio (p. 192) the designation<tei:lb/>'Danioinae' is meaningless. The basis Mirza chose for this relationship was the shared possession<tei:lb/>of the metapterygoid-quadrate fenestra in some members of the Cultrinae and in Opsariichthys<tei:lb/>and Zacco (presently included in the Danioinae). As pointed out elsewhere (p. 177; Howes, 1978)<tei:lb/>this character is plesiomorphic for the cyprinids and so cannot be regarded as an indicator of<tei:lb/>shared recent common ancestry. From work presently in progress it seems that Opsariichthys is<tei:lb/>not related to any member of the cheline or cultrine groups; indeed, its closest living relatives are<tei:lb/>currently included in the genus Barilius.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thus, at present the identity of the sister-group to the chelines must remain in doubt. It seems<tei:lb/>that a likely candidate will be identified as a monophyletic assemblage of taxa included here<tei:lb/>within the cultrine and hemicultrine groups (p. 197).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Conclusions</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Macrochirichthys' macrochirus is a highly specialized piscivore derived from an ancestral lineage<tei:lb/>now represented by the genera Salmostoma and Securicula. These taxa are members of a mono-<tei:lb/>phyletic assemblage (the cheline group) in which three lineages can be recognized, viz. the cheline,<tei:lb/>represented by Chela; the oxygastrine, by Macrochirichthys, Parachela and Oxygaster, and the<tei:lb/>salmostomine by Salmostoma and Securicula. Parallelism between Macrochirichthys and Securi-<tei:lb/>cula has in the past led to the erroneous assumption of their close relationship (Banarescu, 1967).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Cultrinae (Banarescu, 1967) have been shown to be a non-monophyletic assemblage<tei:lb/>although two groups of genera - the cultrine and hemicultrine - may be monophyletic. One of<tei:lb/>these is possibly the sister-group of the chelines.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Macrochirichthys is capable of a great degree of cranial elevation, made possible by the ball<tei:lb/>and socket connection of the basioccipital with the 1 st vertebra and modifications of the epaxial<tei:lb/>musculature. Cranial elevation is also possible - perhaps to an even greater degree - in Chela.<tei:lb/>Salmostoma represents the plesiomorph lineage in which there are seen pre-adaptations to this<tei:lb/>function, namely, a short post-parietal area with a posteriorly rounded cranium and a reduced</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE ANATOMY OF MACROCHIRICHTHYS MACROCHIRUS 199</tei:p>
         <tei:p>supraoccipital process; short ethmoid region overlapped by the frontals; rounding and shortening<tei:lb/>of the 1st vertebra with reduction of its lateral processes; a caudal inclination of the neural<tei:lb/>complex and modification of the anterior supraneurals. Such adaptations have resulted, on the<tei:lb/>one hand, in the evolution of forms such as Macrochirichthys and Securicula where the cranium<tei:lb/>is compressed and the dorsal musculature has extended across the skull roof; and on the other<tei:lb/>hand, in Chela, where the cranium has remained broad and there has been little modification to<tei:lb/>the dorsal muscle elements. Likewise, the protrusibility of the upper jaw is virtually lost in<tei:lb/>Macrochirichthys and Securicula but retained in Chela.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Further comparison between Macrochirichthys and the characoid Rhaphiodon has highlighted<tei:lb/>the major anatomical differences involved in achieving similar evolutionary status. It may be<tei:lb/>added here that a neck-bending mechanism similar to that of Rhaphiodon appears to be present<tei:lb/>in the siluroid Belodontichthys (pers. obs.).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acknowledgements</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I am greatly indebted to Dr P. Humphry Greenwood for his criticism of the manuscript and for<tei:lb/>his many helpful suggestions that have aided my research.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I am particularly grateful to Professor C. C. Lindsey for placing at my disposal the valuable<tei:lb/>(and, at that time, unpublished) observations he has made on the anatomy and behaviour of<tei:lb/>Chela, and to Dr P. Kahsbauer for locating and loaning to me the type specimen of Parachela<tei:lb/>breitensteini.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>My most sincere thanks go to my colleagues, Drs P. J. P. Whitehead and K. E. Banister, for<tei:lb/>their many helpful criticisms and discussions; to Margaret Clarke for her assistance with the<tei:lb/>taxonomic section of the paper, and to James Chambers for preparing alizarin specimens.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Grateful thanks also go to Christopher Evans for his assistance with preparing the figures, to<tei:lb/>Gina Sandford for typing the manuscript and for supplying specimens of Chela, and to David<tei:lb/>Bird and the late Keith Purbrick for providing information on live Macrochirichthys.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Finally, I must acknowledge the kindness of Dr Tyson Roberts who provided me with such<tei:lb/>beautiful specimens of Macrochirichthys from the Kapuas river together with photographs and<tei:lb/>data concerning live specimens.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>The British Museum (Natural History) employs a staff of over 350<tei:lb/>research scientists working on zoology, entomology, palaeontology,<tei:lb/>botany and mineralogy. The results of their research in these<tei:lb/>fields are published both in the Museum's scientific journals - the<tei:lb/>Bulletins - and in monographs, many of which are co-published<tei:lb/>with commercial scientific publishers. Many of these works are<tei:lb/>not only of significance to such key areas as medicine, agriculture<tei:lb/>and the oil industry, but also to amateurs interested in birds,<tei:lb/>butterflies, fishes, etc.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Museum also publishes more popular books on natural history<tei:lb/>which are the work of their scientists and include a high<tei:lb/>illustrative content</tei:p>

         <tei:p>The Bulletin of the British Museum (Natural History), instituted in 1949, is issued in four<tei:lb/>scientific series, Botany, Entomology, Geology (incorporating Mineralogy) and Zoology, and<tei:lb/>an Historical series.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Papers in the Bulletin are primarily the results of research carried out on the unique and<tei:lb/>ever-growing collections of the Museum, both by the scientific staff of the Museum and by<tei:lb/>specialists from elsewhere who make use of the Museum's resources. Many of the papers<tei:lb/>are works of reference that will remain indispensable for years to come.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Parts are published at irregular intervals as they become ready, each is complete in itself,<tei:lb/>available separately, and individually priced. Volumes contain about 300 pages and are not<tei:lb/>necessarily completed within one calendar year. Subscriptions may be placed for one or more<tei:lb/>series. Subscriptions vary according to the contents of the Volume and are based on a forecast<tei:lb/>list of titles. As each Volume nears completion, subscribers are informed of the cost of the<tei:lb/>next Volume and invited to renew their subscriptions. Orders and enquiries should be sent to:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Publications Sales,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>British Museum (Natural History),<tei:lb/>Cromwell Road,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>London SW7 5BD,<tei:lb/>England</tei:p>
         <tei:p>World List abbreviation: Bull. Br. Mus. nat. Hist. (Zool.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trustees of the British Museum (Natural History), 1979</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ISSN 0007-1498 Zoology series</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Vol 36 No 4 pp. 201-259<tei:lb/>British Museum (Natural History)<tei:lb/>Cromwell Road<tei:lb/>London SW7 5BD Issued 25 October 1979</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Department of Zoology, British Museum (Natural History), Cromwell Road, London, SW7 5BD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Introduction</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The need for a comprehensive taxonomic system for those amoebae with shells, usually referred<tei:lb/>to as testate amoebae, is long overdue. Nevertheless, before such a task is undertaken the valid<tei:lb/>criteria for each taxon should be established. The two main criteria used in recent classifications<tei:lb/>of testate amoebae in the Superclass Rhizopodea are the cytoplasmic form of the pseudopodia and<tei:lb/>the structure of the shell. The present study is concerned only with the latter, so the proposals<tei:lb/>concerning the mechanisms of pseudopodial movement suggested by Bovee &amp; Jahn (1966) have<tei:lb/>not been considered. Furthermore, the changes put forward here are modifications of the<tei:lb/>classifications of Loeblich &amp; Tappan (1961, 1964) and Deflandre (1953) -(referred to as the<tei:lb/>'legally-based system' by Bovee &amp; Jahn). In these classifications the shape and composition of the<tei:lb/>shell has been used to determine the divisions at the superfamily and family level. Four basic types<tei:lb/>of shell are recognized : first, the proteinaceous shell, usually composed of numerous alveoli;<tei:lb/>secondly, the agglutinate shell composed of extraneous material bound by an organic cement;<tei:lb/>thirdly, the siliceous shell usually composed of shell plates; and finally, the calcareous shell<tei:lb/>which may have an outer organic lining.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The divisions proposed here relate to the third type of shell structure, and concern those<tei:lb/>animals which make their own siliceous shell components. To date, that includes most of the<tei:lb/>species belonging to the subclass Filosia, and some species belonging to the subclass Lobosia,<tei:lb/>namely Difflugia oviformis Cash, 1909, Quadrulella symmetrica (Wallich, 1863) and Lesquereusia<tei:lb/>spiralis (Ehrenberg, 1840). Other testate amoebae in the subclass Lobosia which have siliceous<tei:lb/>plates, for example, species belonging to the genera Nebela and Heleopera have agglutinate shells,<tei:lb/>made of captured shell plates or quartz particles. The shell plates of smaller testate amoebae,<tei:lb/>such as Euglypha, Assulina and Cyphoderia, are easily recognized in the shells of Nebela species,<tei:lb/>and MacK inlay (1936) suggested that these were obtained by predation after observing that<tei:lb/>Nebela collaris produced a membranous shell devoid of shell plates when grown in isolation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Discussion</tei:p>
         <tei:p>It is generally accepted that all testate amoebae secrete an organic material that either provides the<tei:lb/>entire shell, as in Arcella, or at least is used to cement the shell components together as in, for<tei:lb/>example, Nebela, Difflugia and Euglypha. Fine structure studies (Hedley &amp; Ogden, 1973, \914a;<tei:lb/>Netzel, 1975, \916a, 1977; Hedley et al, 1976, 1977) on species belonging to all four of the basic<tei:lb/>shell types have shown that this organic material is made in the Golgi complex of the cytoplasm,<tei:lb/>and have suggested how it is probably used in shell construction. In addition, the cytoplasmic<tei:lb/>changes associated with the formation and distribution of siliceous structures in Euglypha<tei:lb/>rotunda, E. acanthophora, E. strigosa, Trinema lineare and Difflugia oviformis have been described<tei:lb/>in detail by Hedley &amp; Ogden (1973, \974a, b) and Netzel (19766, 1977). These studies, based on<tei:lb/>laboratory cultures, include observations on the biology of these species, and cine-films illus-<tei:lb/>trating binary fission have been made by Netzel (197 la, b). The siliceous structures secreted by<tei:lb/>Euglypha species and Difflugia oviformis are formed in a membrane-bound vesicle within the<tei:lb/>cytoplasm, and are stored there prior to division. At division, they are arranged around a<tei:lb/>cytoplasmic extrusion to form a daughter shell identical to the parent. The term 'idiosomes' has<tei:lb/>been suggested (Netzel, 1972) for the siliceous structures secreted by Difflugia oviformis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bull. Br. Mus. nat. Hist. (Zool.) 36 (4) : 203-207 Issued 25 October 1979</tei:p>
         <tei:p>203</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>204 C. G. OGDEN</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Using the diagnosis of the family Difflugiidae given by Loeblich &amp; Tappan (1961, 1964), that<tei:lb/>the 'test is rarely chitinous, but is generally composed of foreign particles, not of secreted plates'<tei:lb/>and of the genus Difflugia- 'wall with pseudochitinous base and variable amounts of agglutinate<tei:lb/>material', it is apparent that Difflugia oviformis with its secreted shell does not agree with this<tei:lb/>definition. There would appear to be no justification in amending the diagnosis for an already<tei:lb/>overcrowded genus, instead it is proposed to create a new genus Netzelia to include D. oviformis<tei:lb/>and other species of Difflugia which secrete their own siliceous elements or idiosomes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A similar situation arises in the family Hyalospheniidae. The diagnosis for this family states -<tei:lb/>'test chitinous with siliceous plates or scales, rounded or angular, and may have foreign matter<tei:lb/>added'. Two of the genera included in this family are thought to secrete a proteinaceous shell,<tei:lb/>Hyalosphenia Stein, 1857 and Leptochlamys West, 1901, and two siliceous structures, Quadrullella<tei:lb/>Cockerell, 1909 and Lesquereusia Schlumberger, 1845. An ultrastructural study of Hyalosphenia<tei:lb/>papilio by Joyon &amp; Charret (1962) suggested that it had a proteinaceous shell, but little is known<tei:lb/>about the shell of Leptochlamys except that it was originally described as having a thin chitinous<tei:lb/>membrane. Information on the shell of Quadrulelia is still needed, although it is assumed that it<tei:lb/>secretes its own shell plates, because they have a distinct quadrangular shape (Fig. 1) which is<tei:lb/>restricted to this genus and Paraquadrula Deflandre, 1932 which has calcareous plates. Species<tei:lb/>belonging to Quadrulelia have previously been described as having calcareous, siliceous or<tei:lb/>chitinoid shells (Cash &amp; Hopkinson, 1909 ; 134-135). Elemental analysis of whole shells of Q.<tei:lb/>symmetrica, recently carried out in this laboratory using an energy dispersive X-ray analyser<tei:lb/>attached to a scanning electron microscope, have shown that they are composed mainly of<tei:lb/>silicon, with some potassium and calcium present. The amounts detected suggest that the shell<tei:lb/>plates are siliceous and that the organic cement which binds them may be strengthened by the<tei:lb/>other elements. The genus Lesquereusia contains several species whose shells are composed mainly<tei:lb/>of siliceous rods, three of these L. epistomum, L. modesta and L. spiralis have recently been<tei:lb/>redescribed (Ogden &amp; Hedley, 1980) and only L. modesta consistently incorporates irregular<tei:lb/>foreign particles amongst the rods in the shell.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Although clonal cultures of Lesquereusia spiralis have not yet been established, observations of<tei:lb/>this species in isolation, in this laboratory, have shown that it secretes a daughter shell made of<tei:lb/>curved rods similar to those of the parent. Some of the laboratory specimens were smaller than<tei:lb/>those reported from the wild (see Ogden &amp; Hedley, 1979), and this is thought to be due to a<tei:lb/>deficiency in the culture medium. A comparison between the curved rods of the smallest specimen,<tei:lb/>83 jim (Fig. 2) those of a medium specimen, 95 urn (Figs 4 &amp; 5) and a large specimen, 120 um<tei:lb/>(Figs 6 &amp; 7), show that these rods become more pronounced and areas of organic cement with the<tei:lb/>distinctive pores (Fig. 3) less numerous with increase in size. Elemental analysis of whole shells,<tei:lb/>using an energy dispersive X-ray analyser, has shown that these rods are siliceous and suggests<tei:lb/>that the organic cement that binds them contains iron.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The situation regarding the family Hyalospheniidae needs some clarification, but must await<tei:lb/>studies on clonal cultures before this is possible. However, it seems to me that there are sufficient<tei:lb/>affinities between Lesquereusia spiralis, Quadrulelia symmetrica and the new genus Netzelia to</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 1 Siliceous shell plates of Quadrulelia symmetrica. x 2400</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 2 Shell surface of small specimen of Lesquereusia spiralis, to show the curved rods and pores.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>X 2100</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 3 A higher magnification of the pores in the organic cement, from the area arrowed in Fig. 2.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>x 21 000</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 4 A medium-sized specimen of L. spiralis to show the ill-defined siliceous rods. x 490</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 5 Portion of shell surface of medium specimen, note the numerous pores. x 8900</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 6 Large specimen of L. spiralis with well-defined siliceous rods. x 480</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 7 Shell surface of large specimen, note the apparent absence of pores. x 4800</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>SILICEOUS STRUCTURES IN LOBOSIA</tei:p>
         <tei:p>205</tei:p>
         <tei:p/>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>206 C. G. OGDEN</tei:p>
         <tei:p>warrant family status within the subclass Lobosia. I therefore propose to designate a family to<tei:lb/>accommodate these species by redefining Lesquereusiidae Jung, 1942, previously synonymized<tei:lb/>by Loeblich &amp; Tappan (1961), to include those members of the subclass Lobosia which secrete<tei:lb/>siliceous elements.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Family LESQUEREUSIIDAE Jung, 1942 nom. rev.<tei:lb/>[nom. correct pro Lecuereusiidae Jung, 1942]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Shell constructed of siliceous rods, plates or idiosomes secreted in the cytoplasm, to which<tei:lb/>mineral particles may be added; aperture circular, oval or elongate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lesquereusia Schlumberger, 1845. Shell colourless, compressed ovoid or globose with asym-<tei:lb/>metrical neck, giving the appearance of a spiral, composed of interwoven siliceous rods and<tei:lb/>sometimes particles of quartz; aperture circular.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>to include: Lesquereusia epistomum Penard, 1902<tei:lb/>Lesquereusia modesta Rhumbler, 1895<tei:lb/>Lesquereusia spiralis (Ehrenberg, 1840)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Netzelia gen. n. Shell colourless, ovoid, symmetrical, with a broad crown and sides tapering<tei:lb/>smoothly to the aperture, composed of idiosomes but may incorporate grains of quartz; aperture<tei:lb/>circular, with organic collar and often with four or five small lobes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>to include: Netzelia oviformis (Cash, 1909) comb. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Quadrulella Cockerell, 1909. Shell colourless, ovoid, composed of quadrangular shell plates<tei:lb/>arranged without overlapping; aperture oval.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>to include : Quadrulella symmetrica ( Wallich, 1 863).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In defining the above taxonomic changes, none of the generic names proposed by Jung (1942)<tei:lb/>in his review of the genus Difflugia have been considered, I agree with Deflandre (1953) and<tei:lb/>subsequent authors that these must be rejected as inadequate definitions.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>It is apparent from previous descriptions of species of Difflugia that problems have arisen in<tei:lb/>identification due to differences of shell structure. For example, Penard (1902) described specimens<tei:lb/>similar to Difflugia tuberculata (Wallich, 1864) but having a thin, transparent shell without in-<tei:lb/>dentations. These specimens are listed by Jung (1942) as Cingodifflugia laevis (Penard, 1902).<tei:lb/>A species of Difflugia collected from water and mud in Alabama was tentatively identified by<tei:lb/>Owen &amp; Jones (1976) as D. tuberculata. It produced autogenous siliceous components when<tei:lb/>isolated in culture, and Owen &amp; Jones suggested that this species should therefore be referred to<tei:lb/>the genus Nebela. Their specimens do not agree with the accepted definition of D. tuberculata,<tei:lb/>which typically have distinctive tubercles of quartz grains on the shell surface (see Ogden &amp;<tei:lb/>Hedley, 1979). However, this latter description may have to be amended because examination of<tei:lb/>specimens from the Everglades National Park, Florida, U.S.A. (kindly collected by Dr C. R.<tei:lb/>Curds, British Museum (Natural History)), suggest that D. tuberculata may occasionally construct<tei:lb/>a shell of diatom frustules instead of the usual quartz particles, both examples being present<tei:lb/>in the sample. Nevertheless, I consider that the descriptions of Penard (1902), Jung (1942) and<tei:lb/>Owen &amp; Jones (1976) all refer to specimens of Netzelia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>It is probable that other smooth-shell species of Difflugia may secrete siliceous elements,<tei:lb/>although observations on such species in culture are needed. For example, the study of the shell<tei:lb/>structure of Difflugia lobostoma given by Eckert &amp; McGee-Russell (1974) must be considered<tei:lb/>with caution, as I believe from their description that these authors were studying specimens of<tei:lb/>D. tuberculata. Nevertheless, the specimens examined were composed of a single layer of siliceous<tei:lb/>particles held together by a network of cement, and dense granules similar in structure to those<tei:lb/>seen in Netzelia oviformis by Netzel (19766) were observed between the shell joints and in the<tei:lb/>cytoplasm.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>SILICEOUS STRUCTURES IN LOBOSIA 207</tei:p>
