         <tei:p>Synopsis</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Various osteological and soft anatomical systems in the families Citharinidae and Distichodontidae were<tei:lb/>examined to test: the hypothesized monophyly of the unit formed by citharinids and distichodontids</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Present address: Division of Fishes, Department of Vertebrate Zoology, National Museum of Natural History,<tei:lb/>Smithsonian Institution, Washington D.C.</tei:p>
         <tei:p/>
         <tei:p>Bull. Br. Mus. nat. Hist. (Zool.) 36 (2) : 261-344 Issued 29 November 1979</tei:p>
         <tei:p>261</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>262 R. P. VARI</tei:p>
         <tei:p>within characoids; the interrelationships of the nominal genera within these families; and the monophyly<tei:lb/>of the nominal genera and suprageneric taxa.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The evidence of this study is congruent with the hypothesis that citharinids and distichodontids form a<tei:lb/>monophyletic subunit of characoids definable by a series of derived characters. However, the arrived<tei:lb/>at hypothesis of generic interrelationships necessitates several modifications of the previous generic and<tei:lb/>suprageneric taxonomy of these families. The retention of the previously recognized family Ichthyboridae<tei:lb/>was found to result in a non-monophyletic family Distichodontidae. Consequently, the Ichthyboridae<tei:lb/>of earlier workers is sunk into the Distichodontidae. At the generic level, Congocharax and Dundocharax<tei:lb/>are placed into synonymy of Neolebias, and Gavialocharax and Phagoborus are synonymized into<tei:lb/>Ichthyborus. These changes resolve the previously non-monophyletic natures of Neolebias and Phagoborus<tei:lb/>respectively. The conclusions of this study contraindicate the monophyly of the genus Distichodus<tei:lb/>as presently defined, and cast doubt on the monophyletic nature of Hemigrammocharax and Nannocharax.<tei:lb/>These three genera are, nonetheless, tentatively retained until such time as an analysis of the phylogeny<tei:lb/>of their contained species can be undertaken.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Finally, information uncovered during this study supports the concept of the monophyletic nature of<tei:lb/>the subunit of characoids formed by the African Characidae. However, the available evidence also<tei:lb/>indicates that as presently constituted the genus Alestes is non-monophyletic. This taxon is, however,<tei:lb/>retained until an indepth analysis of African characids permits its redefinition on the basis of derived<tei:lb/>characters. The subdivision of the African Characidae into the subfamilies Hydrocyninae and Alestiinae<tei:lb/>results in the latter taxon being non-monophyletic. Consequently the Hydrocyninae is sunk into the<tei:lb/>Alestiinae, which in this broader sense now constitutes a monophyletic unit.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Introduction</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The superfamily Characoidea (Rosen &amp; Greenwood, 1970) is one of the largest groups in the<tei:lb/>ichthyofauna of the Neotropical region and Africa, and one of the major freshwater fish assem-<tei:lb/>blages. Although the classification of the superfamily has undergone extensive revision during<tei:lb/>the last century, questions on the interrelationships of characoids at all taxonomic levels remain<tei:lb/>largely unresolved. This paper deals with the relationships between and to a lesser extent within<tei:lb/>the genera which constitute the African endemic characoid families Citharinidae and Disticho-<tei:lb/>dontidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A series of workers including Boulenger (1909), Regan (1911) and Gregory &amp; Conrad (1938)<tei:lb/>have suggested that citharinids and distichodontids form a closely related subunit of characoids,<tei:lb/>with Regan (1911, p. 22) terming them 'a very natural group of African Fish'. Although<tei:lb/>Greenwood et al. (1966) did not deal with interfamilial relationships within the Characoidea, they<tei:lb/>do list these families sequentially, a procedure meant to indicate close relationship (Weitzman,<tei:lb/>pers. commun., in Roberts, 1969, p. 399). Despite this broad consensus, the basis for the hypo-<tei:lb/>thesized close relationship of these families has remained obscure. Furthermore, as shown in<tei:lb/>Table 1 the number and limits of the suprageneric taxa recognized within the families Citharinidae<tei:lb/>and Distichodontidae have been subject to considerable differences of opinion. The conflicting<tei:lb/>nature of these classifications is reflected in the history of the group recognized as the subfamily<tei:lb/>Distichodontinae by Boulenger (1909) and more recently as the family Distichodontidae by<tei:lb/>Greenwood et al. (1966) (both of these concepts differ from the Distichodontidae of this work, see<tei:lb/>p. 265). This assemblage was subdivided into two subfamilies with different limits by Eigenmann<tei:lb/>(1909) and Regan (1911). Subsequently, Gregory &amp; Conrad (1938) removed the distichodontid<tei:lb/>genera Xenocharax, Neolebias, Hemistichodus and Nannaethiops to their subfamily Citharininae.<tei:lb/>More recently Poll (1973) carried this trend further by placing all distichodontids (sensu<tei:lb/>Greenwood et al., 1966) into his family Citharinidae. Monod (1950), in turn, defined the supra-<tei:lb/>generic taxa among citharinids and distichodontids in such a manner as to exclude the disticho-<tei:lb/>dontid genera Xenocharax, Neolebias, Nannaethiops and Paradistichodus from all of his<tei:lb/>subfamilies. To the extent that these authors used their classifications as a mode of conveying<tei:lb/>concepts on the relationships between taxa, such differing classifications reflect the uncertainty<tei:lb/>that exists concerning the phylogenetic history of citharinids and distichodontids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This uncertainty was a consequence of a series of factors, three of which appear to have been<tei:lb/>of paramount importance. Firstly, earlier classifications were based on a limited number of</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>CLASSIFICATION OF CITHARINIDAE AND DISTICHODONTIDAE 263</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Table 1 Previous classifications of the families Citharinidae and Distichodontidae with members of the<tei:lb/>suprageneric units listed where originally specified</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Boulenger, 1909</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eigenmann, 1909</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Regan, 1911</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gregory &amp; Conrad, 1938</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Greenwood et al., 1966<tei:lb/>Poll, 1973</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Citharininae<tei:lb/>Distichodontinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ichthyborinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Citharininae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Neolebiinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Distichodontinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Phaginae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ichthyborinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Citharininae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Xenocharacinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Distichodontinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hemistichodinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ichthyborinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Citharininae<tei:lb/>Distichodontinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Citharinidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Distichodontidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ichthyboridae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Citharinidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ichthyboridae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Citkarinus, Citharidium</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Nannaethiops, Neolebias, Distichodus, Nanno-<tei:lb/>charax, Xenocharax</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ichthyborus, Neoborus ( = Phagoborus), Meso-<tei:lb/>borus, Eugnatichthys, Paraphago, Phago</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Citharinus, Citharidium</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Xenocharax, Nannaethiops, Neolebias</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Distichodus, Nannocharax</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hemistichodus</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ichthyborus, Neoborus { = Phagoborus), Meso-</tei:p>
         <tei:p>borus, Eugnatichthys, Paraphago, Phago</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Citharinus, Citharidium, Xenocharax, Nan-<tei:lb/>naethiops, Neolebias, Hemistichodus<tei:lb/>Distichodus, Nannocharax, Ichthyborus, Meso-<tei:lb/>borus, Phagoborus, Eugnatichthys, Paraphago,<tei:lb/>Phago</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Citharinus, Citharidium, Xenocharax, Neo-<tei:lb/>lebias, Nannaethiops, Dundocharax, Congo-<tei:lb/>charax ?, Paradistichodus, Distichodus, Nan-<tei:lb/>nocharax, Hemigrammocharax<tei:lb/>Ichthyborus, Phagoborus, Gavialocharax, Hemi-<tei:lb/>stichodus, Microstomatichthyoborus, Meso-<tei:lb/>borus, Eugnatichthys, Paraphago, Phago,<tei:lb/>Belonophago</tei:p>
         <tei:p>primarily external characters. The utility of the limited information available from these systems<tei:lb/>was, however, reduced by several misinterpretations of characters and character states. Secondly,<tei:lb/>the small size of many distichodontid species resulted in a series of errors in character state<tei:lb/>determination. These errors were especially prevalent in the description of tooth form and dis-<tei:lb/>tribution; characters which, nonetheless, were weighed heavily by many workers. Finally, and<tei:lb/>perhaps most importantly, generic and suprageneric taxa were defined on the basis of primitive<tei:lb/>or combinations of primitive and derived characters, a procedure which often failed to define<tei:lb/>monophyletic groups.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The present study attempts to determine the phylogenetic relationships, both at the generic<tei:lb/>and suprageneric levels, within the subunit of characoids formed by the families Citharinidae and<tei:lb/>Distichodontidae. The phylogenetic reconstruction is based primarily on osteological characters,<tei:lb/>although myological and other soft anatomical systems are also utilized. The three main objectives<tei:lb/>of this study are: (1) to test the hypothesis of the monophyletic nature of the unit formed by<tei:lb/>citharinids and distichodontids within characoids; (2) to determine the interrelationships of the<tei:lb/>genera within these families; and (3) to define the various generic and suprageneric taxa on the<tei:lb/>basis of shared derived characters.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>264 R. P. VARI</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Methods</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Relationships between and within the families Citharinidae and Distichodontidae are evaluated<tei:lb/>using the methods of phylogenetic analysis first described in detail by Hennig (1966). These<tei:lb/>methods along with the two predominant alternative methodologies (numerical taxonomy and<tei:lb/>evolutionary biological classification) have been and continue to be a source of controversy with<tei:lb/>respect to their relative merits. However, the author feels that the Hennigian methodology best<tei:lb/>suits the aims of this study - the erection of an hypothesis of the evolutionary relationships of the<tei:lb/>groups in question.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In using the Hennigian or cladistic methodology, certain principles are followed: recognized<tei:lb/>taxa must be monophyletic in that they include all descendants of a hypothesized common<tei:lb/>ancestor (the concept of monophyly advanced by the evolutionary biological school, in contrast,<tei:lb/>does not require the inclusion in a taxon of all descendants of a common ancestor). Monophyletic<tei:lb/>groups are defined on the basis of shared derived (synapomorphic) characters which are con-<tei:lb/>sidered to be the only type of characters valid for the erection of a hypothesis of common ancestry.<tei:lb/>In contrast, shared primitive (symplesiomorphic) characters and estimated degrees of similarity<tei:lb/>or difference are not utilized for the analysis of interrelationships. Species or species groups<tei:lb/>(two or more species forming a monophyletic unit) hypothesized to have had a common ancestor<tei:lb/>are termed sister species or sister groups. A derived (apomorphic) character used for the definition<tei:lb/>of a sister group relationship cannot serve for the definition of the contained taxa in either of the<tei:lb/>sister groups since it is primitive (plesiomorphic) at the level of the included subtaxa.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>As discussed by Nelson (1973a &amp;b), the apomorphic or plesiomorphic nature of characters<tei:lb/>can be evaluated by two methods. The first of these, outgroup comparisons, involves the examina-<tei:lb/>tion of the state of the character in a variety of other groups in order to determine which of the<tei:lb/>relevant character states is probably primitive. For the purposes of this study, outgroup com-<tei:lb/>parisons were carried out on representatives of other characoid families and selected non-<tei:lb/>characoid ostariophysans. The second method of character polarity determination involves<tei:lb/>information available from ontogenetic transitions. If in two sister groups X and Y, the species<tei:lb/>of group X undergo an ontogenetic transition in character A from state A to state A', a transition<tei:lb/>that does not occur in the species of group Y, then two explanations exist for the distribution of<tei:lb/>the transition: (1) that the transition (state A to A') was not present in the common ancestor of<tei:lb/>X and Y, but rather arose in lineage X; or (2) that the transition was present in the common<tei:lb/>ancestor of X and Y, but was secondarily lost in lineage Y. Comparing these hypotheses, we find<tei:lb/>that the first makes a single assumption; that of the acquisition of the transition in group X.<tei:lb/>The second in contrast, makes two assumptions, that of the presence of the transition in the<tei:lb/>common ancestor of groups X and Y, and a second assumption of its subsequent loss in lineage<tei:lb/>Y. If we accept a parsimony criterion for the evaluation of the preferability of alternative hypo-<tei:lb/>theses, then the first, more parsimonious, hypothesis is preferable. Consequently, in this study,<tei:lb/>ontogenetic transitions (ontogenetic shifts from state A to state A') are considered to indicate<tei:lb/>phylogenetic polarity (state A' is considered apomorphic with respect to state A).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In the following discussion, osteological terminology follows Weitzman (1962) with several<tei:lb/>exceptions. As noted by Roberts (1969) vomer is substituted for prevomer and intercalar for<tei:lb/>opisthotic. Furthermore, I follow Patterson (1975) in using epioccipital rather than epiotic, and<tei:lb/>supraethmoid rather than ethmoid, and follow Nelson (1973c) in substituting angulo-articular<tei:lb/>for articular, and retroarticular for angular. Myological terminology is that of Winterbottom<tei:lb/>(1974).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>All drawings were made using a Wild M5 drawing tube. Details were added freehand under<tei:lb/>higher magnification. Myological drawings are based on dissections of the right side of the<tei:lb/>specimen and are reversed into conventional orientation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Materials</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Osteological and soft anatomical systems were examined on alcohol preserved material, dry<tei:lb/>skeletons, and cleared, alizarin-stained specimens of representative species of the citharinid genera</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>CLASSIFICATION OF CITHARINIDAE AND DISTICHODONTIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>265</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Citharinus and Citharidium and the distichodontid genera Xenocharax, Neolebias, Nannaethiops,<tei:lb/>Paradistichodus, Distichodus, Nannocharax, Hemigrammocharax, Hemistichodus, Ichthyboms,<tei:lb/>Microstomatichthyoborus, Mesoborus, Eugnatichthys, Phago and Belonophago. In the case of the<tei:lb/>monotypic distichodontid genus Paraphago, known only from the syntypic series, only osteological<tei:lb/>characters revealed by radiographs and external anatomy could be examined. Comparative studies<tei:lb/>were carried out on representatives of all other African and Neotropical characoid families and<tei:lb/>for certain characters on examples of the major non-characoid ostariophysan groups, both<tei:lb/>otophysan and anotophysan. A detailed listing of this extensive material would add little to the<tei:lb/>paper. Rather, a list of material examined, both skeletal and whole, quoting museum catalogue<tei:lb/>numbers, is deposited in the Fish Section and General Library of the British Museum (Natural<tei:lb/>History).</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Nomenclatural comments</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The conclusions of this study necessitate several changes in the previous generic and suprageneric<tei:lb/>classifications within the family Distichodontidae. In so far as the modified terminology is used<tei:lb/>throughout the following discussion, these changes are briefly summarized at this point.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Within recent years, most workers have recognized two subfamilies (Distichodontinae and<tei:lb/>Ichthyborinae) or families (Distichodontidae and Ichthyboridae) for the unit termed the family</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>266 R. P. VARI</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Distichodontidae in this work. However, the retention of both taxa as previously defined was<tei:lb/>found to be untenable under the taxonomic procedures adopted as a basis for this study. Rather<tei:lb/>only a single suprageneric taxon, the family Distichodontidae, is recognized to contain the species<tei:lb/>previously divided between the Distichodontidae and Ichthyboridae of Greenwood et al. (1966)<tei:lb/>and the subfamilies Distichodontinae and Ichthyborinae of many other recent workers. Similarly,<tei:lb/>the genera Dundocharax and Congocharax are placed as synonyms of Neolebias, with Dundocharax<tei:lb/>bidentatus, Congocharax gossei, C. spilotaenia and C. olbrechtsi hereafter termed Neolebias bi-<tei:lb/>dentatus, N. gossei, N. spilotaenia and N. olbrechtsi respectively. Finally, both Gavialocharax and<tei:lb/>Phagoborus are placed as synonyms of Ichthyborus, with Gavialocharax monodi, Phagoborus<tei:lb/>ornatus and P. quadrilineatus hereafter referred to as Ichthyborus monodi, I. ornatus and /.<tei:lb/>quadrilineatus respectively.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Phylogenetic analysis</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The analysis of the phylogenetic relationships of the genera and suprageneric units within the<tei:lb/>complex formed by the families Citharinidae and Distichodontidae is divided into two sections.<tei:lb/>The first part of the analysis deals with the relevant characters in the various anatomical systems<tei:lb/>examined, along with a discussion of the basis for their hypothesized polarity within characoids.<tei:lb/>In the second portion of the analysis the evidence from these characters is incorporated into a<tei:lb/>reconstruction of the hypothesized most parsimonious phylogeny of the genera within these<tei:lb/>families. It should be emphasized that it is not the purpose of this study to provide detailed<tei:lb/>anatomical descriptions of the osteology and soft anatomy of all citharinid and distichodontid<tei:lb/>genera. Rather, only those characters used in the phylogenetic reconstruction are discussed.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Jaws</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A series of modifications of the upper and lower jaws distinguish the unit formed by the<tei:lb/>Citharinidae and Distichodontidae within characoids and unite groups of varying levels of<tei:lb/>universality within this complex. The following discussion will deal firstly with the hypothesized<tei:lb/>derived characters common to the upper and lower jaws; secondly, with those limited to the<tei:lb/>lower jaw; and finally, with those of the upper jaw. Dental characters of phylogenetic interest are<tei:lb/>discussed separately in the following section.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Replacement tooth trenches</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The form of the dentary and premaxillary replacement tooth trenches exhibits several character<tei:lb/>states among citharinids and distichodontids. In Xenocharax (Fig. la) the dentary and premaxilla<tei:lb/>are solid basally, with the replacement tooth trenches having the form of relatively shallow<tei:lb/>grooves, not or only slightly open to their partners across the symphyses. Such a trench form is<tei:lb/>close to the generalized and probably plesiomorphous characoid condition and is thus considered<tei:lb/>to represent the least derived state of this character within citharinids and distichodontids. Two<tei:lb/>major modifications of the Xenocharax form of replacement tooth trench occur in these families,<tei:lb/>one shared by most distichodontids and the other unique to citharinids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The distichodontid genera Nannaethiops and Neolebias share with Xenocharax the plesio-<tei:lb/>morphous condition of shallow premaxillary and dentary replacement tooth trenches. In all<tei:lb/>other distichodontids, in contrast, the trenches are expanded, bulbous cavities, broadly open to<tei:lb/>their partners across the symphysis (Fig. Ib.) The expansion of the trenches into the primitively<tei:lb/>solid centres of the premaxilla and dentary both provides an increased surface for the attachment<tei:lb/>of the pleurodont dentition common to these genera, and space for their multiple rows of<tei:lb/>replacement teeth. Such a greatly expanded replacement tooth trench would appear to be unique<tei:lb/>to and apomorphous for these genera among characoids. In contrast, the greatly expanded<tei:lb/>trenches of the Neotropical characoid family Parodontidae differ from the above in being limited<tei:lb/>to the premaxilla, in not being open to each other across the symphyses, and in having the<tei:lb/>replacement tooth series separated by bony partitions. Similarly, the broad replacement tooth<tei:lb/>trenches of the Anostomidae fail to open to their partners symphyseally.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>CLASSIFICATION OF CITHARINIDAE AND DISTICHODONTIDAE 267</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A second mode of expanded replacement tooth trench characterizes the family Citharinidae.<tei:lb/>In Citharinus and Citharidium the trenches are widened along the primitively horizontal plane<tei:lb/>of the dentaries and premaxillae to form broad shallow grooves. More significantly, the replace-<tei:lb/>ment tooth trenches of both jaws are rotated outwards relative to the Xenocharax condition.<tei:lb/>This reorientation is especially pronounced in the lower jaw where it has resulted in the shift of the<tei:lb/>primitively distal, anterior ridge of the trench to the outer surface of the dentary, and the<tei:lb/>formation of the distal edge of the lower jaw by the posterior ridge of the replacement tooth<tei:lb/>trench. Such a reorientation and broadening of the trenches appears to be unique to and auta-<tei:lb/>pomorphous for the Citharinidae among Characoids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>rt</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 1 Sagittal section through the dentary symphysis of A. Xenocharax spilurus, B. Distichodus</tei:p>
         <tei:p>brevipinnis, C. Ichthyborus quadrilineatus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lower jaw</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A series of modifications of the dentary and of the articulation between the dentary and angulo-<tei:lb/>articular characterize various assemblages among citharinids and distichodontids. One of the<tei:lb/>distinctive characters in the lower jaws of these families is their common lack of the bony inter-<tei:lb/>digitating symphyseal processes that interconnect the dentaries of most characoids. Such dentary<tei:lb/>interdigitations form a hinge permitting horizontal pivoting of the dentaries about the symphysis<tei:lb/>but reducing or eliminating twisting of the bones with respect to each other. This symphyseal<tei:lb/>dentary hinge ranges in complexity from the rather simple processes common to many tetra-<tei:lb/>gonopterines, to the massive interlocking systems in Hydrocynus (Gregory &amp; Conrad, 1936)<tei:lb/>and the Cynodontini (Nelson, 1949). An interdigitating symphyseal dentary hinge is widespread<tei:lb/>among characoids and is found in the Hepsetidae, the family that has been considered to be the<tei:lb/>most 'primitive' living member of the Characoidea (Roberts, 1969, p. 442). If Hepsetus is indeed<tei:lb/>the sister group to other characoids, its possession of the dentary hinge along with the widespread<tei:lb/>distribution of this character within the Characoidea would indicate that an interdigitating<tei:lb/>symphyseal dentary hinge is plesiomorphous for characoids. The lack of such a joint would then<tei:lb/>be a apomorphous secondary loss. It should be emphasized, however, that the phylogenetic<tei:lb/>placement of hepsetids has not been satisfactorily resolved. Furthermore, an interdigitating<tei:lb/>dentary symphyseal joint is also lacking in the Neotropical characoid families Curimatidae,<tei:lb/>Hemiodontidae, Prochilodontidae, Anostomidae, Chilodontidae and Parodontidae. Be that as it<tei:lb/>may, at the least, the common lack of the interdigitating symphyseal dentary hinge in citharinids<tei:lb/>and distichodontids is consistent with the hypothesized monophyletic nature of the unit that they<tei:lb/>form within characoids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Although the lack of an interdigitating dentary symphyseal hinge is common to all citharinids<tei:lb/>and distichodontids, the exact form of the interdentary articulation varies within these families.<tei:lb/>Citharinids and the distichodontid genera Xenocharax, Neolebias, Nannaethiops, Paradistichodus,<tei:lb/>Distichodus, Nannocharax, Hemigrammocharax and Hemistichodus have a solely syndesmotic<tei:lb/>articulation between the dentaries. Within this assemblage, in Citharinus, Citharidium, Xeno-<tei:lb/>charax, Nannaethiops and Neolebias the combination of the relatively limited contact of the</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>268 R. P. VARI</tei:p>
         <tei:p>dentaries across the symphysis and the syndesmotic joint permits a slight mobility of the dentaries<tei:lb/>relative to each other. In contrast, Paradistichodus, Distichodus, Nannocharax, Hemigrammocharax<tei:lb/>and Hemistichodus have an immobile though syndesmotic interdentary joint as a consequence<tei:lb/>of their expanded replacement tooth trenches and the resultant greater cross-sectional contact<tei:lb/>across the symphysis. This union of the dentaries is further developed in some larger individuals<tei:lb/>of Distichodus lussso and D. brevipinnis which have irregular interdigitations between the<tei:lb/>dentaries (see Daget, 1959, Fig. 5).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The dentaries in the distichodontid genera Ichthyborus, Microstomatichthyoborus, Mesoborus,<tei:lb/>Eugnatichthys, Paraphago, Phago and Belonophago are synarthritically immovably interconnected<tei:lb/>in either of two ways. In Ichthyborus this union takes the form of a symphyseal fusion of the<tei:lb/>dentaries, an adaptation which provides a firm implantation for the enlarged median canine that<tei:lb/>characterizes this genus. Microstomatichthyoborus, Mesoborus, Eugnatichthys, Belonophago,<tei:lb/>Paraphago and Phago, alternately, have a series of bony interdigitations uniting the dentaries.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1mm</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 2 Nannocharax niloticus, dentaries, ventral view.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>These interdigitations differ, however, from those forming the symphyseal dentary hinge of most<tei:lb/>characoids both in their location at the rear of the dentary symphysis and in rendering the<tei:lb/>dentaries totally immobile relative to each other. Both this synarthritic dentary articulation and<tei:lb/>the fused dentaries of Ichthyborus appear to be unique to their possessors among characoids and<tei:lb/>indicative of the monophyletic nature of each of these assemblages.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Various modifications of the dentary serve to distinguish subunits within the family Dis-<tei:lb/>tichodontidae. The genera Hemigrammocharax and Nannocharax are characterized by a<tei:lb/>pronounced posteriorly-directed process arising from the posteroventral edge of the dentary<tei:lb/>slightly lateral to the dentary symphysis (Fig. 2). This process, which serves as the point of<tei:lb/>attachment for the protractor hyoidei muscles, is unique to these genera among the characoids<tei:lb/>examined and is thus hypothesized to be apomorphous. Hemistichodus, Ichthyborus, Micro-<tei:lb/>stomatichthyoborus, Mesoborus, Eugnatichthys, Paraphago, Phago and Belonophago, in turn,<tei:lb/>have a prominent dorsally-directed posterodorsal dentary ramus that is laterally overlapped by,<tei:lb/>and tightly joined to, the closely connected maxilla and premaxilla common to these genera. Such<tei:lb/>a posterodorsal ramus of the dentary (Figs 3c &amp; d) contrasts with the hypothesized plesiomorphous<tei:lb/>dorsally straight-edged process common to most characoids (Fig. 3a). Outgroup comparisons<tei:lb/>have failed to reveal any other charcoid group with such a pronounced development of this<tei:lb/>process. Thus the prominent posterodorsal ramus of the dentary common to these distichodontids<tei:lb/>is considered derived.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Further adaptations of this dentary ramus characterize less universal subunits of the Disticho-<tei:lb/>dontidae. In Hemistichodus this posterodorsal dentary ramus is autapomorphically further<tei:lb/>enlarged into an elongate, inwardly curved process passing medial to the premaxilla (see Daget,<tei:lb/>1968, Fig. 2). Eugnatichthys, Paraphago, Phago (Fig. 3d) and Belonophago, in turn, have the<tei:lb/>lateral face of the ramus restructured to form a shallow groove articulating with the rounded<tei:lb/>posteroventral portion of the maxilla characteristic of these genera. This alteration of the dentary<tei:lb/>in conjunction with a series of modifications of the maxilla forms a sliding joint between the<tei:lb/>upper and lower jaws during jaw movements.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>CLASSIFICATION OF CITHARINIDAE AND DISTICHODONTIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>269</tei:p>
         <tei:p>den</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ra</tei:p>
         <tei:p>den</tei:p>
         <tei:p>den</tei:p>
         <tei:p>aa</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ra</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 3</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lower jaws of A. Xenocharax spilurus, B. Distichodusnotospilus, C. Ichthyborusquadrilineatus,<tei:lb/>D. Phago intermedius, left lateral view.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The greatest morphological variation in the lower jaw of the families Citharinidae and<tei:lb/>Distichodontidae involves the form of the articulation of the dentary with the angulo-articular.<tei:lb/>In Xenocharax (Fig. 3a) the angulo-articular and dentary meet along an elongate triangular joint<tei:lb/>with the posteroventral process of the dentary bearing a lengthy mandibular sensory canal<tei:lb/>segment. The tight fit of this joint and the strong connective tissue bands across the articulation<tei:lb/>immovably join the dentary and angulo-articular into a single functional unit. Thus in Xeno-<tei:lb/>charax all motion of the dentary relative to the suspensorium is a consequence of the mobility<tei:lb/>between the angulo-articular and quadrate. This form of articulation is generalized for characoids<tei:lb/>and most teleosts (see Nelson, 1973c), and undoubtedly represents the plesiomorphous condition<tei:lb/>for the Citharinidae and Distichodontidae. Such an immobile articulation is common to<tei:lb/>citharinids and the distichodontid genera Xenocharax, Neolebias, Nannaethiops and Paradisti-<tei:lb/>chodus. All other distichodontid genera, in contrast, have a mobile joint between the angulo-<tei:lb/>articular and dentary. The least restructured form of the articulation is found in Hemistichodus<tei:lb/>which retains the plesiomorphous insertion of the triangular anterior process of the angulo-<tei:lb/>articular into a notch formed by posterodorsal and posteroventral dentary processes. However,<tei:lb/>in contrast to the primitive condition, the dentary in Hemistichodus is not in tight contact with<tei:lb/>the anterior process of the angulo-articular and the connective tissue bands joining these bones<tei:lb/>are flexible. These modifications result in a limited mobility between the dentary and angulo-<tei:lb/>articular. Such motion approximates the hypothesized first stage in the phylogenetic development<tei:lb/>of the more mobile Distichodus, Ichthyborus and Mesoborus types of articulations between these<tei:lb/>bones.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The second form of mobile joint between the dentary and the angulo-articular, the Distichodus<tei:lb/>type (Fig. 3b) is synapomorphous for Distichodus, Nannocharax and Hemigrammocharax among<tei:lb/>characoids. In these genera the primitively elongate dentary is horizontally foreshortened and its<tei:lb/>posteroventral process greatly reduced. Furthermore, the axis of the body of the dentary is<tei:lb/>reorientated distinctly anteroventrally from the horizontal or anterodorsal orientation common</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>270 R. P- VARI</tei:p>
         <tei:p>to most characoids. This reorientation, which shifts the plesiomorphously anterior face of the<tei:lb/>dentary posteroventrally, is particularly pronounced in bottom-dwelling Nannocharax species<tei:lb/>which have a nearly vertical axis through the body of the dentary. An additional consequence of<tei:lb/>this dentary foreshortening and reorientation is the reduction of the dentary portion of the<tei:lb/>mandibular sensory canal in Distichodus and its loss in Nannocharax and Hemigrammocharax.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Congruent with these dentary alterations are a series of modifications of the angulo-articular<tei:lb/>and of its relationship to the dentary. In the Distichodus type lower jaw, the angulo-articular is<tei:lb/>expanded dorsally or anterodorsally into a large flat plate which lies along and is ligamentously<tei:lb/>movably attached to the medial face of the dentary. These alterations in angular-articular form<tei:lb/>and position together with the previously described dentary modifications result in a highly<tei:lb/>mobile joint between the dentary and angulo-articular, in addition to the usual mobility of the<tei:lb/>latter on the quadrate. This mode of articulation of these elements, the 'chevauchement lateral'<tei:lb/>of Monod (1950), along with the previously described reorientation of the dentary permits a<tei:lb/>marked degree of horizontal motion of the dentary.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The two final forms of mobile articulation between the dentary and angulo-articular, the<tei:lb/>Ichthyborus and Mesoborus types, share several derived characters. In both of these lower jaw<tei:lb/>forms the posteroventral ramus of the dentary is lacking as a distinct process contrary to its<tei:lb/>plesiomorphous elongate form. Congruent with this change in dentary structure is an anterior<tei:lb/>expansion of the angulo-articular and its shift onto the medial surface of the dentary. Such an<tei:lb/>expansion, which compensates for the loss of support primitively provided by the posteroventral<tei:lb/>dentary ramus, differs from that of the Distichodus type jaw in two ways. Firstly, the anterior<tei:lb/>process of the angulo-articular in the Ichthyborus and Mesoborus jaw forms is directed horizontally<tei:lb/>forward rather than having the dorsal or anterodorsal orientation that characterizes the Dis-<tei:lb/>tichodus type jaw. Furthermore, rather than simply abutting the medial surface of the dentary<tei:lb/>the angulo-articular in these taxa inserts into a depression (Ichthyborus) or fossa (Mesoborus<tei:lb/>type) on the posteromedial surface of the dentary. These modifications and other adaptations<tei:lb/>permit an apomorphic greatly increased mobility between the dentary and angulo-articular.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Ichthyborus type articulation (Fig. 3c) is specific to that genus and characterized by an<tei:lb/>elongate angulo-articular considerably thickened posterior to the rear margin of the dentary.<tei:lb/>This expanded posterior portion of the angulo-articular is undercut anteriorly to form a deep<tei:lb/>notch into which the posteroventral corner of the dentary fits. Both the thickening of the posterior<tei:lb/>portion of the angulo-articular and its relationship to the dentary are apomorphic characters<tei:lb/>seemingly unique to this genus among characoids. The Mesoborus form of articulation between<tei:lb/>the angulo-articular and dentary is common, with some variation, to Mesoborus, Microstomatich-<tei:lb/>thyoborus, Eugnatichthys, Paraphago, Phago and Belonophago. In these genera the anterior<tei:lb/>portion of the angulo-articular inserts into a definite socket on the medial surface of the dentary.<tei:lb/>Along with the pronounced overlap of the dentary and angulo-articular, this adaptation shifts<tei:lb/>the pivot point of the dentary anteromedially. Within the assemblage characterized by the<tei:lb/>Mesoborus type articulation several subunits are distinguished by further modifications of the<tei:lb/>angulo-articular. In contrast to its plesiomorphously elongate state, the angulo-articular in<tei:lb/>Eugnatichthys, Paraphago, Phago and Belonophago is a thickened element that is both shortened<tei:lb/>horizontally and shifted practically entirely onto the medial surface of the dentary (Fig. 3d).<tei:lb/>As a consequence the rear of the dentary extends nearly to the vertical through the joint of the<tei:lb/>angulo-articular with the quadrate. This apomorphic shortening of the angulo-articular is<tei:lb/>especially notable in Eugnatichthys in which the greatly thickened bone is barely visible laterally.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Keeping in mind the difficulties in determining the mode of action of a complex system on the<tei:lb/>basis of preserved material, it nonetheless appears that the two lower jaw pivot points (dentary-<tei:lb/>angulo-articular and angulo-articular-quadrate) in the Ichthyborus and Mesoborus jaw forms result<tei:lb/>in systems that are functionally unique among characoids. In Ichthyborus the ventral border of<tei:lb/>the dentary makes an oblique angle with that of the angulo-articular when the mouth is closed.<tei:lb/>As the mouth opens, the pivoting of the premaxilla on the supraethmoid causes the rear of the<tei:lb/>premaxilla to move ventrally. This motion is imparted via the reduced maxilla to the rear of the<tei:lb/>dentary. The entire lower jaw in turn shifts ventrally, with the dentary pivoting on the angulo-<tei:lb/>articular simultaneous with the pivoting of the entire dentary-angulo-articular complex on the</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>CLASSIFICATION OF CITHARINIDAE AND DISTICHODONTIDAE 271</tei:p>
         <tei:p>quadrate. Both motions continue until the ventral borders of the angulo-articular and dentary<tei:lb/>achieve their plesiomorphous straight line orientation. During the second phase of jaw motion<tei:lb/>the mobility of the dentary relative to the angulo-articular ceases and these elements act as a rigid<tei:lb/>unit pivoting on the quadrate. Thus during the opening of the mouth, two functional phases are<tei:lb/>discernible; an apomorphic first phase characterized by mobility at both pivot points, and a<tei:lb/>second phase demonstrating only the plesiomorphous motion of the angulo-articular on the<tei:lb/>quadrate. Such a two-phase system is common to Ichthyborus, Mesoborus and Microstomatich-<tei:lb/>thyoborus, and is the basis for the more derived jaw motion of Eugnatichthys, Paraphago, Phago<tei:lb/>and Belonophago which have continual mobility between the angulo-articular and dentary<tei:lb/>throughout the entire cycle of jaw action. In these latter genera the ventral borders of the angulo-<tei:lb/>articular and dentary pass from the oblique concave angle of the closed jaw, to a straight-line<tei:lb/>orientation and then to a distinct convex relationship in the fully open mouth (see Gregory &amp;<tei:lb/>Conrad, 1938, Fig. 35). This last apomorphic phase of the motion is, as far as can be determined,<tei:lb/>unique to these four genera among characoids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Upper jaw</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The plesiomorphous condition of the upper jaw in characoids appears to have the premaxilla<tei:lb/>immovably attached by tight syndesmotic articulations to the supraethmoid and lateral<tei:lb/>supraethmoid wings. Such attachment occurs either along the medial surface of the premaxilla<tei:lb/>(e.g. Hepsetus, Acestrorhynchus) or more usually to a posteriorly-directed ascending process of<tei:lb/>the premaxilla (e.g. Brycon, Alestes). Medially the premaxillae are completely or nearly completely<tei:lb/>separated symphyseally by an elongate supraethmoid spine. Plesiomorphously the maxilla is a<tei:lb/>moderately to markedly elongate element movably articulated with the posterodorsal edge of the<tei:lb/>premaxilla, and bearing anterodorsally a medially-directed process which attaches ligamentously<tei:lb/>to the palatine and ligamentum primordiale. Citharinids and distichodontids differ from this<tei:lb/>plesiomorphous upper jaw plan both in the relationships of the premaxilla with its partner and the<tei:lb/>supraethmoid, and in the form of the maxilla and its relationship to the premaxilla and dentary.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>All citharinids and distichodontids lack the prominent premaxillary ascending process and<tei:lb/>tight connective tissue bands which plesiomorphously attach the premaxilla immovably to the<tei:lb/>supraethmoid. Instead a series of modifications of the premaxilla and supraethmoid result in a<tei:lb/>mobile articulation of the upper jaw with the supraethmoid. The various adaptations of the<tei:lb/>supraethmoid will be discussed in detail later in the paper. For the purposes of the discussion at<tei:lb/>this point, it suffices to note that among citharinids and distichodontids the plesiomorphous<tei:lb/>state of the forward edge of the supraethmoid is hypothesized to be an anteriorly trifurcate<tei:lb/>complex. In this condition a median plate extends anteriorly over the premaxillary symphysis,<tei:lb/>and ventrolateral articular processes insert into articular fossae on the rear of the premaxillae.<tei:lb/>In Xenocharax the articular fossa of the premaxilla has the form of a deep horizontal depression<tei:lb/>open to its partner across the symphysis and extending from the symphysis midway across the<tei:lb/>transverse width of the premaxilla. Such a horizontal fossa is hypothesized to be plesiomorphous<tei:lb/>for citharinids and distichodontids in so far as the corresponding horizontal supraethmoid<tei:lb/>process represents the least pronounced alteration of the primitively horizontal edge of the<tei:lb/>supraethmoid. Within citharinids and distichodontids, several derived modifications of this form<tei:lb/>of premaxillary fossa are found.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Among citharinids there occurs a progressive ontogenetic reduction of the roof of the basically<tei:lb/>Xenocharax form of articular fossa that characterizes juveniles of Citharinus and Citharidium.<tei:lb/>As a consequence in adult citharinids the fossa roof is reduced to a small shelf at the lateral<tei:lb/>margin of the depression. Thus the primitively ventral surface of the fossa is now exposed dorsally<tei:lb/>and is ligamentously attached to the median process of the supraethmoid. Such an attachment<tei:lb/>contrast with the latter's plesiomorphous attachment to the dorsal surface of the roof of the<tei:lb/>fossa.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Within the complex formed by Distichodus, Hemigrammocharax and Nannocharax there occurs<tei:lb/>a phylogenetic transition in the form, position and extent of development of the premaxillary<tei:lb/>fossa. Distichodus notospilus and D. brevipinnis have a basically Xenocharax form of wide<tei:lb/>horizontal fossa on the posterior surface of the premaxilla. In comparison in Distichodus lusosso,</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>272 R. P. VARI</tei:p>
         <tei:p>D. niloticus and D. fasciolatus the fossa is a conical pit located on the posterodorsal surface of<tei:lb/>the premaxilla. These adaptations are correlated with the posteroventral shift of the premaxillae<tei:lb/>in these species, a repositioning carried further in Nannocharax and Hemigrammocharax. In these<tei:lb/>latter genera the premaxillae are located distinctly ventral to the supraethmoid and the articular<tei:lb/>fossae are reduced either to small conical depressions on the dorsal surface of the premaxillae<tei:lb/>or are entirely lacking. An evidently independent shift of the fossa to the dorsal surface of the<tei:lb/>premaxilla occurs in Hemistichodus in which the articular fossa is a rounded groove on the<tei:lb/>posterodorsal surface of the premaxilla. Finally, in Eugnatichthys, Paraphago, Phago and<tei:lb/>Belonophago the articular fossa is a transversely directed pit on the medial surface of the<tei:lb/>longitudinally-oriented posterior portion of the premaxilla. This adaptation is especially pro-<tei:lb/>nounced in the last two genera.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The above modifications, those of the supraethmoid and a series of other alterations permit<tei:lb/>varying degrees of mobility of the premaxilla on the supraethmoid. Such motion is limited in<tei:lb/>citharinids but more pronounced in distichodontids, especially in Distichodus, Nannocharax,<tei:lb/>Hemigrammocharax, Hemistichodus, Ichthyborus, Microstomatichthyoborus, Mesoborus,<tei:lb/>Eugnatichthys, Paraphago, Phago and Belonophago. The upper jaw motion of these genera takes<tei:lb/>two forms. In Distichodus, Nannocharax and Hemigrammocharax the posteroventrally shifted<tei:lb/>premaxillae are notably mobile in the horizontal plane. In contrast, in the other distichodontids<tei:lb/>listed, the jaw modifications permit a pronounced pivoting of the premaxillae on the supraethmoid<tei:lb/>with a consequent increase in the vertical extent of the gape.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Among characoids other than citharinids and distichodontids, mobile premaxillary-supraeth-<tei:lb/>moid articulations occur in the African characid genus Hydrocynus, and the Neotropical characoid<tei:lb/>families Anostomidae, Chilodontidae, Prochilodontidae, Parodontidae and Hemiodontidae<tei:lb/>(Roberts, 1974). Argonectes and Bivibranchia, in turn, have radically altered protrusible upper<tei:lb/>jaws in which the premaxilla separates from the supraethmoid during opening of the mouth.<tei:lb/>Comparison of the mobile upper jaw in Hydrocynus with that of citharinids and distichodontids<tei:lb/>reveals pronounced anatomical and functional differences between these systems. The consequent<tei:lb/>likelihood that these complexes represent independent acquisitions of upper jaw mobility is<tei:lb/>supported by the series of derived characters uniting Hydrocynus to African characids having<tei:lb/>immovable premaxillary-supraethmoid articulations (see Comments on the African Characidae).<tei:lb/>Argonectes, Bivibranchia and the family Hemiodontidae differ from citharinids and distichodontids<tei:lb/>both in their mode of premaxillary mobility and in their possession of a rhinosphenoid. The<tei:lb/>rhinosphenoid is a median orbital ossification unique to various South American characoid<tei:lb/>groups, most of which are characterized by a plesiomorphous immobile upper jaw. On the basis<tei:lb/>of the common possession of a rhinosphenoid and other characters, it is most parsimonious to<tei:lb/>assume that hemiodontids, Bivibranchia and Argonectes are closely related to Neotropical<tei:lb/>rhinosphenoid-bearing characoids with immovable upper jaws. In light of this, and the differences<tei:lb/>in the type of supraethmoid-premaxillary articulation, it appears that upper jaw mobility in these<tei:lb/>groups has been achieved independent of that in citharinids and distichodontids. Finally, pro-<tei:lb/>chilodontids, anostomids and the closely related chilodontids achieve upper jaw mobility by<tei:lb/>motion of the ascending arm (Anostomidae, Chilodontidae) or body (Prochilodontidae) of the<tei:lb/>premaxilla along the edge of the supraethmoid spine rather than via the citharinid and dis-<tei:lb/>tichodontid type of hinging of the premaxilla on anterior processes of the supraethmoid. As<tei:lb/>such, the premaxillary mobility of these South American families appears to be non-homologous<tei:lb/>with that of citharinids and distichodontids. The closest approximation among charcoids to the<tei:lb/>citharinid and distichodontid type of premaxillary-supraethmoid articulation is found in the<tei:lb/>Neotropical family Parodontidae. The members of this family have a distinct dorsomedial pre-<tei:lb/>maxillary fossa articulating with anterolateral processes of the supraethmoid. However, as<tei:lb/>discussed in the Conclusions section, the parodontid fossa appears to be convergent with that of<tei:lb/>citharinids and distichodontids rather than an indicator of close relationship between the groups.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>As was the case with the dentary symphysis, the interpremaxillary articulation among citharinids<tei:lb/>and distichodontids demonstrates several apomorphous modifications of varying levels of<tei:lb/>universality. Contrary to the plesiomorphous, limited syndesmotic contact of the premaxillae<tei:lb/>anterior to the supraethmoid spine citharinids and distichodontids have the medial surfaces of</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>CLASSIFICATION OF CITHARINIDAE AND DISTICHODONTIDAE 273</tei:p>
         <tei:p>the premaxillae broadly in contact. Within these families, however, the exact form and extent of<tei:lb/>the contact varies significantly. In Xenocharax, Nannaethiops and Neolebias the combination of a<tei:lb/>syndesmotic joint and a somewhat narrow premaxillary symphysis permits a limited mobility<tei:lb/>between the premaxillae. Although retaining the plesiomorphous syndesmotic joint, Paro-<tei:lb/>dist ichodus, Distichodus, Nannocharax, Hemigrammocharax and Hemistichodus are immovably<tei:lb/>joined symphyseally. This immobility is a consequence of the expanded cross-sectional extent of<tei:lb/>the jaws around the widened replacement tooth trenches. Finally, Ichthyborus, Microstomatich-<tei:lb/>thyoborus, Mesoborus, Eugnatichthys, Paraphago, Phago and Belonophago have a series of<tei:lb/>interdigitating convolutions at the rear of the premaxillary symphysis. This synarthritic joint<tei:lb/>eliminates all motion between the premaxillae, a trend that is carried further in Ichthyborus monodi<tei:lb/>in which the premaxillae are fused symphyseally. This fusion is, as far as can be determined,<tei:lb/>unique to this species among characoids and perhaps a function of its markedly elongate jaws.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>pmx</tei:p>
         <tei:p>mx</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 4 Ichthyborus quadrilineatus, upper jaw, left lateral view.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A second form of synarthritic interpremaxillary joint characterizes the family Citharinidae. In<tei:lb/>Citharinm and Citharidium the longitudinal extent of the premaxillary symphysis is increased<tei:lb/>by the expansion of the median portions of the premaxillae posteriorly to form a prominent<tei:lb/>symphyseal bulge. This posterior expansion of the premaxillae along with a series of highly<tei:lb/>developed symphyseal interdigitations tightly join the premaxillae synarthrically. These pre-<tei:lb/>maxillary sutures differ, however, from those of some distichodontids both in the form and<tei:lb/>extent of the interdigitations, and in their association with the posteriorly expanded portion of<tei:lb/>the premaxilla. The consequent likelihood that the premaxillary sutures in the two groups are<tei:lb/>non-homologous is supported by the overall distribution of derived characters in these families.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Although the possession of interpremaxillary sutures is considered an apomorphous character<tei:lb/>on the basis of outgroup comparisons, such adaptations are not unique to citharinids and dis-<tei:lb/>tichodontids within the Characoidea. Such sutures have been previously reported for the<tei:lb/>Neotropical genus Brycon (Weitzman, 1962) and the old world characid Hydrocynus (Eastman,<tei:lb/>1917). Interpremaxillary sutures have also been found during this study in the South American<tei:lb/>characid genera Triportheus and Serrasalmus, and the African characids Bryconaethiops and<tei:lb/>Alestes. However, on the basis of a series of derived characters (the possession of a rhinosphenoid,<tei:lb/>tooth form and distribution, etc.) the South American genera appear to be most closely related<tei:lb/>to Neotropical characoids lacking interdigitating premaxillary sutures. Similarly, the old world<tei:lb/>groups form a monophyletic unit with African genera lacking the synarthritic joint (see p. 341).<tei:lb/>Consequently, the interpremaxillary suturing in these South American and African characoids<tei:lb/>appears to have been acquired independently of that in citharinids and distichodontids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The final jaw character of interest is the form of the maxilla and its relationship to the pre-<tei:lb/>maxilla and dentary. The hypothetical plesiomorphous state of the maxilla among characoids is<tei:lb/>a relatively large, tooth-bearing element movably attached to the premaxilla, and with a dorso-<tei:lb/>medially directed process for the attachment of the palatine and ligamentum primordiale. In<tei:lb/>Citharinus and Citharidium, in contrast, the maxilla is relatively reduced but retains its mobility,</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>274 R. P. VARI</tei:p>
         <tei:p>flattened plate-like form and dorsomedially directed process. The maxilla in the distichodontid<tei:lb/>genera Hemistichodus, Ichthyborus, Microstomatichthyoborus, Mesoborus, Eugnatichthys,<tei:lb/>Paraphago, Phago and Belonophago is also reduced. However, in these genera the relative<tei:lb/>reduction of the bone is much more pronounced than in citharinids. Furthermore, the maxilla<tei:lb/>in these genera is unique among characoids examined in its lack of a dorsomedial process and in<tei:lb/>being immovably joined, but not fused, to the rear of the enlarged premaxilla (Fig. 4). These<tei:lb/>maxillary alterations are most pronounced in Hemistichodus in which the bone is greatly reduced<tei:lb/>both relative to the generalized characoid condition and also with respect to that in the other<tei:lb/>genera listed. Furthermore, the maxilla in Hemistichodus is autapomorphically shifted onto the<tei:lb/>dorsal surface of the premaxilla (see Daget, 1968, Fig. 2) and is consequently totally removed from<tei:lb/>the ventral border of the upper jaw. Finally, the assemblage consisting of Eugnatichthys, Para-<tei:lb/>phago, Phago and Belonophago is characterized by a recontouring and expansion of the postero-<tei:lb/>ventral portion of the reduced maxillary into a rounded somewhat bulbous process. During<tei:lb/>movements of the jaws this portion of the maxilla closely articulates with and slides along the<tei:lb/>previously described groove on the lateral surface of the posterodorsal dentary ramus.<tei:lb/>In summary, the diverse apomorphic jaw modifications described above are :</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 the outward rotation of the replacement tooth trench in citharinids, and the great<tei:lb/>expansion of the trenches in distichodontids other than Xenocharax, Nannaethiops and<tei:lb/>Neolebias.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 the lack of an interdigitating symphyseal hinge joint in citharinids and distichodontids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3 the fused dentaries of Ichthyborus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>4 the bony interdigitations along the posterior portion of the dentary symphysis in<tei:lb/>Microstomatichthyoborus, Mesoborus, Eugnatichthys, Paraphago, Phago and<tei:lb/>Belonophago.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5 the posteriorly directed process lateral to the dentary symphysis in Nannocharax and<tei:lb/>Hemigrammocharax.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>6 the pronounced posterodorsal dentary ramus in Hemistichodus, Ichthyborus, Micro-<tei:lb/>stomatichthyoborus, Mesoborus, Eugnatichthys, Paraphago, Phago and Belonophago.<tei:lb/>This process is laterally modified to form a groove articulating with the maxilla in the<tei:lb/>last four genera and is greatly developed autapomorphically in Hemistichodus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 the mobile joint between the dentary and angulo-articular in all distichodontids other<tei:lb/>than Xenocharax, Neolebias, Nannaethiops and Paradistichodus. The four forms of this<tei:lb/>mobile articulation are :</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(A) the Hemistichodus type limited to that genus and plesiomorphous with respect<tei:lb/>to the Ichthyborus, Mesoborus and Distichodus forms of the joint.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(B) the Distichodus type occurring in Distichodus, Nannocharax and Hemigrammo-<tei:lb/>charax.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(C) the Ichthyborus type limited to that genus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(D) the Mesoborus type common to Microstomatichthyoborus, Mesoborus,<tei:lb/>Eugnatichthys, Paraphago, Phago and Belonophago. The last four genera share an<tei:lb/>apomorphic further reduction of the horizontal extent of the angulo-articular.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>8 the premaxillary articular fossa in citharinids and distichodontids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>9 the ontogenetic reduction of the premaxillary fossa roof in citharinids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>10 the reduction in the extent, and the shift of the articular fossa to the dorsal surface of<tei:lb/>the premaxilla in Nannocharax, Hemigrammocharax and some Distichodus species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 1 the rounded articular fossa on the dorsal surface of the premaxilla in Hemistichodus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>12 the laterally-directed articular fossa in Eugnatichthys, Paraphago, Phago and Belono-<tei:lb/>phago.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>13 the reduced maxilla of citharinids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>14 the greatly reduced, immobile maxilla in Hemistichodus, Ichthyborus, Microstomatich-<tei:lb/>thyoborus, Mesoborus, Eugnatichthys, Paraphago, Phago and Belonophago.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>15 the bulbous, posteroventrally expanded maxilla in Eugnatichthys, Paraphago, Phago<tei:lb/>and Belonophago.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>CLASSIFICATION OF CITHARINIDAE AND DISTICHODONTIDAE 275</tei:p>
         <tei:p>16 the position of the maxilla on the dorsal surface of the premaxilla in Hemistichodus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>17 the interdigitating premaxillary symphyseal processes in citharinids and some dis-<tei:lb/>tichodontids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dentition</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Characoids are notable for, and largely classified on, the basis of their broad range in tooth form<tei:lb/>and arrangement. Such variation is evident in the morphology, distribution and mode of<tei:lb/>implantation of the dentition in the Citharinidae and Distichodontidae. Roberts (1967, p. 231)<tei:lb/>hypothesized that 'the most primitive dentition in characoids consists of conical teeth on the<tei:lb/>premaxillary, a single row of conical teeth extending beyond the gap of the maxillary, and two<tei:lb/>rows of conical teeth in the lower jaw separated by a shallow replacement trench'. Such a dental<tei:lb/>plan is consistent with our present knowledge of characoid ontogeny and phylogeny and would,<tei:lb/>with the exception of the tooth form, appear to have been the condition in the common ancestor<tei:lb/>of citharinids and distichodontids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A bicuspidate equally-cusped tooth (Fig. 2) is common to all citharinids and distichodontids at<tei:lb/>some point in ontogeny. Multicuspidate dentition, either in the form of linearly arranged cusps<tei:lb/>(e.g. cheirodontines) or an arched cusp series along the edge of a wide tooth (e.g. Brycon, Alestes),<tei:lb/>is widespread among characoids. However, the bicuspidate tooth form of citharinids and dis-<tei:lb/>tichodontids appears to be unique to, and apomorphic for, these families among characoids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Within the Distichodontidae two assemblages have sequential ontogenetic replacement of the<tei:lb/>equally-cusped dentition by teeth demonstrating a relative enlargement of one cusp. In Ichthyborus<tei:lb/>this takes the form of a markedly developed anterior cusp, while Microstomatichthyoborus,<tei:lb/>Mesoborus, Eugnatichthys, Paraphago, Phago and Belonophago have the posterior cusp enlarged.<tei:lb/>The shift from the equally-cusped tooth form, plesiomorphous for distichodontids, to the<tei:lb/>unequally-cusped condition can be followed ontogenetically in representative species demon-<tei:lb/>strating each form of enlarged cusp.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Among species with an enlarged anterior cusp, an ontogenetic series of Ichthyborus besse<tei:lb/>reveals a progressive shift to teeth with a relatively larger anterior cusp (Fig. 5a). In 30 mm SL<tei:lb/>specimens, the anterior cusp of the teeth at the front of each jaw is somewhat enlarged relative to<tei:lb/>the posterior cusp. This relative difference in cusp size decreases posteriorly so that the teeth<tei:lb/>at the rear of each jaw have equally-sized cusps. By 70 mm SL the anterior cusps of all teeth are<tei:lb/>larger than the posterior, with this difference again most pronounced anteriorly. Appreciably<tei:lb/>enlarged anterior cusps occur on all teeth in 100 mm SL specimens with the posterior cusp of the<tei:lb/>anterior teeth very small. Ichthyborus besse specimens of 150 mm SL have the posterior cusp on<tei:lb/>most teeth so reduced relative to the anterior cusp as to give the teeth a unicuspidate appearance.<tei:lb/>A similar, though not as pronounced, ontogenetic transition in tooth-cusp size occurs in Ichthy-<tei:lb/>borus ornatus and /. quadrilineatus over the limited size range of specimens examined. It was not<tei:lb/>possible, however, to confirm the predicted ontogenetic transition in tooth form for /. monodi<tei:lb/>which is only known from adult specimens.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A size range of Mesoborus crocodilus, a species with an enlarged posterior tooth cusp, shows<tei:lb/>a progressive ontogenetic increase in the size of the posterior cusp (Fig. 5b). In 45 mm SL<tei:lb/>specimens the anterior teeth, particularly of the upper jaw, show a distinct enlargement of the<tei:lb/>posterior tooth cusp, with the remaining teeth retaining the plesiomorphous equally-cusped<tei:lb/>condition. By 55 mm SL nearly all the teeth in the upper jaw and those in the anterior half of<tei:lb/>the lower jaw exhibit an enlarged posterior cusp to varying degrees. At 70 mm SL the anterior<tei:lb/>cusp is totally lacking on the anterior teeth and greatly reduced on the remaining teeth of both<tei:lb/>jaws. The dentition of Mesoborus specimens of greater than 120 mm SL is nearly unicuspidate<tei:lb/>with a rudimentary anterior cusp remaining only on the posterior teeth of each jaw. It should be<tei:lb/>emphasized, however, that the relative difference in tooth cusp size found in Mesoborus is not<tei:lb/>universal among genera having an enlarged posterior tooth cusp. In Microstomatichthyoborus<tei:lb/>the posterior tooth cusp is only slightly enlarged. A slightly greater relative development of the<tei:lb/>cusp occurs in Belonophago (see Poll, 1957, Fig. 141), while Eugnatichthys, Paraphago and Phago<tei:lb/>show a marked enlargement of the posterior cusp, although the difference is not as appreciable<tei:lb/>as that of Mesoborus.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>276 R. P. VARI</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The mode of implantation of the outer tooth row also varies within the complex formed by<tei:lb/>citharinids and distichodontids. In all citharinids and the distichodontid genera Xenocharax,<tei:lb/>Nannaethiops and Neolebias the teeth attach by flattened or slightly oblique bases to a series of<tei:lb/>sockets along the distal edge of the replacement tooth trench ridges (Fig. la). Such an acrodont<tei:lb/>type of tooth attachment is generalized, though not universal, for characoids and tooth-bearing<tei:lb/>ostariophysans and is thus hypothesized to be plesiomorphous for citharinids and distichodontids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A B</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 5 Ontogenetic variation in dentition of A. Ichthyborus besse (fifth premaxillary tooth at 32, 50<tei:lb/>and 115 mm SL), B. Mesoborus crocodilus (fourth premaxillary tooth at 55, 85 and 130 mm SL),<tei:lb/>left lateral view.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The outer row of dentition in all remaining distichodontid genera, in comparison, has the tooth<tei:lb/>form and mode of attachment illustrated in Figs Ib and c. In this condition, the teeth of the<tei:lb/>outer tooth row taper gradually to fit the anterior contours of the replacement tooth trench to<tei:lb/>which they have a ligamentous (pleurodont) attachment. As a consequence, the total relative length<tei:lb/>of the teeth is increased, with this elongation most pronounced in Distichodus, Nannocharax<tei:lb/>and Hemigrammocharax. The genera Hemistichodus, Ichthyborus, Microstomatichthyoborus,<tei:lb/>Mesoborus, Eugnatichthys, Paraphago, Phago and Belonophago, in turn, are characterized<tei:lb/>by relatively stronger teeth than those of citharinids and other distichodontids. Although the<tei:lb/>forward extension of the posterior wall of the replacement tooth trench results in what appear to<tei:lb/>be a series of interconnected sockets for the enlarged outer tooth row, in actuality these teeth<tei:lb/>retain their pleurodont attachment to the anterior wall of the trench (Fig. Ic).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The distribution pattern of the dentition within citharinids and distichodontids shows both<tei:lb/>reductions and increases relative to the previously described hypothetical plesiomorphous con-<tei:lb/>dition for characoids (see p. 275). The plesiomorphously present inner dentary tooth row is lacking<tei:lb/>in citharinids, Nannocharax, Hemigrammocharax, Hemistichodus and all Ichthyborus species<tei:lb/>other than /. besse. On the basis of the hypothesized phylogeny (see p. 338) this absence of the<tei:lb/>inner row of dentary teeth appears, however, to have arisen via multiple independent losses. The<tei:lb/>opposite trend of an increase in the number of inner tooth rows on the dentary occurs in<tei:lb/>Xenocharax and some Neolebias trilineatus specimens (Daget, 1965, p. 7) which have two inner<tei:lb/>tooth rows, and in Ichthyborus besse where the inner row of dentary dentition is expanded into a<tei:lb/>broad band.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In the upper jaw, the dentition of both the premaxilla and maxilla varies within the assemblage<tei:lb/>formed by the Citharinidae and Distichodontidae. Contrary to the hypothesized plesiomorphous<tei:lb/>state of a tooth-bearing maxilla, citharinids and all distichodontids with the exception of<tei:lb/>Xenocharax, Nannaethiops and Neolebias have edentulous maxillae (the reported absence of<tei:lb/>maxillary teeth in some Neolebias species is erroneous, see p. 330). An inner premaxillary tooth<tei:lb/>row occurs in all distichodontids other than Nannocharax, Hemigrammocharax, Hemistichodus,<tei:lb/>Ichthyborus ornatus and /. monodi, all of which also lack the inner dentary tooth row. The lack<tei:lb/>of the inner row of premaxillary dentition in these taxa and in citharinids would appear to be<tei:lb/>apomorphous though considered to represent several independent losses on the basis of the<tei:lb/>hypothesized phylogeny. Ichthyborus besse, in contrast, has the inner row of premaxillary dentition</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>CLASSIFICATION OF CITHARINIDAE AND DISTICHODONTIDAE 277</tei:p>
         <tei:p>expanded into a broad tooth patch. Finally, Hemistichodus is distinguished by the autapo-<tei:lb/>morphous lack of the medial premaxillary teeth (see Poll, 1957, Fig. 134).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The final tooth character of phylogenetic interest among citharinids and distichodontids<tei:lb/>involves the canine dentition in Ichthyborus and Mesoborus. Ichthyborus has an enlarged unpaired<tei:lb/>tooth in the midline of the fused dentaries, an adaptation unique to this genus among characoids<tei:lb/>examined. The median dentary tooth and that flanking it on each side interdigitate with a pair<tei:lb/>of enlarged teeth at the anterior of the premaxillae (see Poll, 1957, Figs 132 &amp; 136). In Ichthyborus<tei:lb/>quadrilineatus these dentary and premaxillary teeth are only slightly enlarged, with a limited over-<tei:lb/>lap between the anterior teeth of the upper and lower jaws. However, in /. ornatus, I. besse and<tei:lb/>/. monodi these teeth are produced into prominent, significantly overlapping canines.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A different form of caniniform dentition characterizes Mesoborus. Although sharing with<tei:lb/>Ichthyborus an enlargement of the anterior premaxillary teeth, the dentary dentition in this<tei:lb/>genus is markedly different. Mesoborus lacks the unpaired median dentary tooth and the enlarged<tei:lb/>teeth flanking it that occur in Ichthyborus. Instead, the anteriormost dentary teeth of Mesoborus<tei:lb/>are quite small and the second to fourth teeth are strongly developed. These enlarged teeth<tei:lb/>arise from a distinct convex portion of the dorsal edge of the dentary and fit lateral to a series of<tei:lb/>relatively small teeth on a corresponding concave region of the premaxilla (see Gregory &amp;<tei:lb/>Conrad, 1938, Fig. 34). Such a pattern of dentary and premaxillary dentition is not encountered<tei:lb/>elsewhere in the families under study, and is hypothesized to be derived relative to the graded<tei:lb/>dentition of most characoids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In summary, the derived states of the dentition among citharinids and distichodontids are<tei:lb/>hypothesized to be:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 the common possession in these families of a bicuspidate tooth. This tooth form is<tei:lb/>secondarily apomorphically modified by an enlargement of the anterior cusp in Ichthy-<tei:lb/>borus, and of the posterior cusp in Microstomatichthyoborus, Mesoborus, Eugnatichthys,<tei:lb/>Paraphago, Phago and Belonophago.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 the pleurodont tooth attachment in all distichodontids other than Xenocharax, Nan-<tei:lb/>naethiops and Neolebias.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3 the loss of maxillary teeth in citharinids and all distichodontids other than Xenocharax,<tei:lb/>Nannaethiops and Neolebias.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>4 the loss of the inner dentary tooth row in Nannocharax, Hemigrammocharax, Hemisti-<tei:lb/>chodus and all Ichthyborus species other than /. besse.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5 the loss of the inner dentary tooth row in citharinids, Nannocharax, Hemigrammocharax,<tei:lb/>Hemistichodus, Ichthyborus ornatus and /. monodi.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>6 the lack of the medial premaxillary teeth in Hemistichodus.<tei:lb/>1 the enlarged median dentary tooth of Ichthyborus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>8 the form of caniniform dentition in Mesoborus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Supraethmoid</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The supraethmoid form hypothesized plesiomorphous for characoids is an anteriorly triangular<tei:lb/>bone extending between, and completely or nearly completely separating, the premaxillae. The<tei:lb/>supraethmoid usually bears along its lateral margin a somewhat triangular process, the lateral<tei:lb/>supraethmoid wing, which is, however, lacking in many characoids with an elongate skull. As<tei:lb/>discussed previously, the supraethmoid of citharinids and distichodontids is greatly modified<tei:lb/>anteriorly as part of a system permitting upper jaw mobility. The least derived condition of the<tei:lb/>supraethmoid in these families occurs in Xenocharax in which the bone is relatively short longi-<tei:lb/>tudinally and lacks the plesiomorphously present lateral supraethmoid wings. More significant<tei:lb/>from a functional viewpoint are the marked modifications of its anterior edge. In contrast to the<tei:lb/>simple supraethmoid spine of the hypothesized plesiomorphous characoid state, in Xenocharax<tei:lb/>the supraethmoid is elaborated anteriorly into a wide trifurcate complex (Fig. 6a). Medially a<tei:lb/>short horizontal shelf extends forward from the anterodorsal edge of the supraethmoid to overlie<tei:lb/>and attach ligamentously to the dorsomedial portion of the premaxillae. On either side of, and<tei:lb/>slightly ventral to, this median process there is an anteriorly directed horizontal articular process</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>278</tei:p>
         <tei:p>R. P. VARI</tei:p>
         <tei:p>which partially inserts into, and ligamentously attaches to, the previously described premaxillary<tei:lb/>fossa. As discussed earlier, the Xenocharax condition of a wide horizontal articular process is<tei:lb/>considered plesiomorphous for citharinids and distichodontids in that it represents the least<tei:lb/>derived modification of the primitively horizontal edge of the supraethmoid. Although the exaci<tei:lb/>homology, if any, of the three supraethmoid processes with the primitively present supraethmoidal<tei:lb/>spine and lateral wings is unknown, these modifications of the anterior region of the supraethmoid<tei:lb/>appear to be apomorphous within characoids and as such are indicative of the monophyletic<tei:lb/>nature of the unit formed by the Citharinidae and Distichodontidae. The somewhat similar<tei:lb/>articular processes present in the South American characoid family Parodontidae differ in overall<tei:lb/>form and are considered to be independently acquired (see p. 349).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 6 Supraethmoid of A. Xenocharax spilurus, B. adult Citharinus citharus, C. Distichodus niloticus,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>D. Phago loricatus, dorsal view.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Various modifications of the Xenocharax form of supraethmoid distinguish the Citharinidae<tei:lb/>and subunits of the Distichodontidae. Juvenile citharinids have a basically Xenocharax type of<tei:lb/>supraethmoid with the anteromedial supraethmoid process overlying the premaxillae and<tei:lb/>prominent articular processes inserting into the premaxillary fossae. Congruent with the pre-<tei:lb/>viously described ontogenetic alterations of the premaxillary fossae, citharinids demonstrate an<tei:lb/>ontogenetic increase in the extent of median supraethmoid process and a reduction of the lateral<tei:lb/>articular processes. The broad articular processes that are present in juvenile citharinids are<tei:lb/>progressively reduced along their lateral margins until the remaining medial portions coalesce<tei:lb/>with the enlarged median process. These alterations result in a single enlarged median supraeth-<tei:lb/>moid process (Fig. 6b), in contradistinction to the juvenile anteriorly trifurcate supraethmoid.<tei:lb/>As a consequence of this restructuring of the supraethmoid and the correlated changes of the<tei:lb/>premaxillary articular fossa, in adult citharinids the enlarged median process of the supraethmoid<tei:lb/>overhangs and directly contacts the ventral surface of the articular fossa. Such an association<tei:lb/>contrasts with the plesiomorphous, and ontogenetically earlier, attachment of the median<tei:lb/>supraethmoid process to the dorsal surface of the fossa roof. In addition to the above adaptations<tei:lb/>of the anterior edge of the supraethmoid, Citharinus and Citharidium have the cranial fontanelle<tei:lb/>extending midway along the longitudinal extent of the bone. Such a forward extension of the<tei:lb/>fontanelle is lacking among distichodontids and rare among characoids in general. As such it is<tei:lb/>considered apomorphous for citharinids among characoids.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>CLASSIFICATION OF CITHARINIDAE AND DISTICHODONTIDAE 279</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Several subunits of the Distichodontidae demonstrate distinctive modifications to the articular<tei:lb/>processes of the supraethmoid, and of overall supraethmoid form. In Distichodus, Nannocharax<tei:lb/>and Hemigrammocharax the median supraethmoid process is greatly reduced relative to the lateral<tei:lb/>articular processes. The latter, in turn, show a transition in form and orientation within these<tei:lb/>genera. The articular processes of Distichodus notospilus and D. brevipinnis retain the plesio-<tei:lb/>morphous flattened, horizontal form, although being somewhat more medially directed than in<tei:lb/>Xenocharax. The other Distichodus species examined, along with the genera Hemigrammocharax<tei:lb/>and Nannocharax, have the lateral articular processes modified into pointed, anteroventrally-<tei:lb/>directed prongs (Fig. 6c). In these taxa the articular processes either insert into a conical fossa on<tei:lb/>the posterodorsal face of the premaxilla (Distichodus) or attach ligamentously to the dorsal<tei:lb/>surface of that element (Hemigrammocharax and Nannocharax). Congruent with these alterations<tei:lb/>of the articular processes are changes in the overall form of the supraethmoid. Whereas the<tei:lb/>supraethmoid in D. notospilus and D. brevipinnis is relatively square, as it is in Xenocharax, those<tei:lb/>Distichodus species with prong-like articular processes have narrow elongate supraethmoids<tei:lb/>(Fig. 6c). This supraethmoid elongation and that of the articular processes appear to be correlated<tei:lb/>with the posteroventral shift of the premaxilla relative to the supraethmoid in these taxa. The<tei:lb/>distichodontid genus Paradistichodus also has a long, slender supraethmoid which in overall<tei:lb/>proportions resembles that of Hemigrammocharax and Nannocharax. However, contrary to the<tei:lb/>state of the supraethmoid in those genera. Paradistichodus retains the plesiomorphous condition<tei:lb/>of wide horizontal articular processes and a relatively large median process.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Two other supraethmoid modifications of note occur among distichodontids. In Hemistichodus<tei:lb/>the supraethmoid is greatly reduced to a small element totally lacking the median supraethmoid<tei:lb/>process, and with the articular processes rounded and laterally directed (see Daget, 1968, Fig. 3).<tei:lb/>Similarly, but evidently independently, the median supraethmoid process is reduced to approxi-<tei:lb/>mately one-half of its plesiomorphous size in Microstomatichthyoborus and Mesoborus, and<tei:lb/>further diminished to a small pointed element in Eugnatichthys, Paraphago, Phago and Belono-<tei:lb/>phago. Congruent with this reduction of the median supraethmoid process is an enlargement and<tei:lb/>reorientation of the articular processes in these genera. In Microstomatichthyoborus and Mesoborus<tei:lb/>these processes retain the plesiomorphous form of anteriorly-directed, horizontal plates.<tei:lb/>Eugnatichthys and Paraphago, in contrast, have less flattened articular processes that are both rela-<tei:lb/>tively larger and more distinctly orientated. Finally, in Phago and Belonophago the articular<tei:lb/>processes are markedly enlarged, bulbous, laterally-oriented structures (Fig. 6d).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The apomorphous modifications of the supraethmoid among citharinids and distichodontids<tei:lb/>are summarized as follows :</tei:p>
