         <tei:p>1 the anteriorly trifurcate form of the supraethmoid or a further derived state of the<tei:lb/>structure that is common to citharinids and distichodontids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 the reduction of the articular processes of the supraethmoid and their fusion with the<tei:lb/>enlarged median supraethmoid process in citharinids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3 the reduction of the median supraethmoid process and restructuring of the lateral articular<tei:lb/>processes into pointed, anteroventrally-directed prongs in Hemigrammocharax, Nan-<tei:lb/>nocharax and some Distichodus species. Congruent with these changes, these taxa<tei:lb/>demonstrate a pronounced elongation of the supraethmoid.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>4 the elongation of the supraethmoid in Paradistichodus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5 the greatly reduced supraethmoid in Hemistichodus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>6 the progressive reduction of the median supraethmoid process, and the enlargement and<tei:lb/>lateral reorientation of the articular processes in Microstomatichthyoborus, Mesoborus,<tei:lb/>Eugnatichthys, Paraphago, Phago and Belonophago.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Anterior orbital region</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The plesiomorphous condition of the anterior orbital region for characoids is hypothesized to<tei:lb/>have the orbitosphenoid separated from the lateral ethmoid. In this condition the olfactory<tei:lb/>nerve exits either from the anteromedian opening of the orbitosphenoid or through a foramen<tei:lb/>along its anterior face. The nerve then extends obliquely across the anteromedial region of the</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>280</tei:p>
         <tei:p>R. P. VARI</tei:p>
         <tei:p>orbital cavity to the olfactory foramen of the lateral ethmoid. In contrast, citharinids and disticho-<tei:lb/>dontids, together with various South American and African characoid groups, have a direct<tei:lb/>contact of the lateral ethmoid and orbitosphenoid, with the olfactory bulb and tract covered<tei:lb/>laterally. In the following discussion the forms of this contact in the Citharinidae and Disticho-<tei:lb/>dontidae are first described and then contrasted to those in characoid outgroups.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2mm</tei:p>
         <tei:p>para<tei:lb/>Fig. 7 Xenocharax spilurus, anterior orbital region, left lateral view.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Distichodontids other than Nannaethiops and Neolebias are characterized by the type of lateral<tei:lb/>ethmoid-orbitosphenoid contact illustrated in Fig. 7 or a further derived state of such an<tei:lb/>articulation. In the simplest condition, such as that of Xenocharax, the lateral ethmoid bears a<tei:lb/>prominent horizontal or posterodorsally sloping process which extends posteriorly from the<tei:lb/>postermedial portion of the lateral ethmoid to contact the anterolateral edge of the orbito-<tei:lb/>sphenoid. This lateral ethmoid process forms a strut that laterally overlaps the olfactory bulb and<tei:lb/>tract and extends between the superior and inferior oblique muscles. As a consequence the<tei:lb/>entrance into the anterior myodome is horizontally divided posteriorly.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>les</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 8 Nannocharax elongatus, anterior orbital region, left lateral view.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The distichodontid genera Hemigrammocharax and Nannocharax share a further derived form<tei:lb/>of this type of contact between the lateral ethmoid and orbitosphenoid (Fig. 8). In these genera<tei:lb/>the posterior process of the lateral ethmoid undergoes a progressive vertical expansion phylo-<tei:lb/>genetically, with a consequent increase in the vertical extent of the articulation between the</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>CLASSIFICATION OF CITHARINIDAE AND DISTICHODONTIDAE 281</tei:p>
         <tei:p>lateral ethmoid and orbitosphenoid. Although the posterior process of the lateral ethmoid in<tei:lb/>Hemigrammocharax monodi and Nannocharax multifasciatus is vertically deeper than that oc-<tei:lb/>curring in Xenocharax, it is nonetheless distinctly separated dorsally from the ventral surface of<tei:lb/>the frontal. Thus these species retain a large opening dorsally for the passage of the superior<tei:lb/>oblique muscle into the anterior myodome. In Nannocharax gobioides, N. fasciatus and TV.<tei:lb/>intermedius, however, the posterior process of the lateral ethmoid is greatly expanded vertically.<tei:lb/>This expansion both increases the vertical contact between the posterior process of the lateral<tei:lb/>ethmoid and the orbitosphenoid and further reduces the dorsal aperture into the anterior<tei:lb/>myodome.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2mm</tei:p>
         <tei:p>para<tei:lb/>Fig. 9 Citharinus citharus, adult, anterior orbital region, left posterolateral view.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In contradistinction to the condition in all other distichodontids, the genera Nannaethiops and<tei:lb/>Neolebias lack any direct contact between the lateral ethmoid and orbitosphenoid. This absence<tei:lb/>of the lateral ethmoid strut is, however, hypothesized to be a secondary loss rather than a primary<tei:lb/>lack of such a structure. Such an hypothesis is congruent with the most parsimonious recon-<tei:lb/>struction of relationships among distichodontids, and with the myriad reductional trends<tei:lb/>demonstrated by the monophyletic unit formed by Nannaethiops and Neolebias. Furthermore, in<tei:lb/>Nannaethiops unitaeniatus, in which the reductional trends characteristic of these genera are least<tei:lb/>pronounced, there occurs a short posteriorly-directed lateral ethmoid process lateral to the<tei:lb/>olfactory foramen. This process may very well represent a reduced form of the Xenocharax<tei:lb/>strut.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The form of lateral ethmoid-orbitosphenoid contact common to all citharinids differs entirely<tei:lb/>from that in distichodontids. In Citharinus and Citharidium the orbitosphenoid is shifted to the<tei:lb/>anteroventral edge of the pterosphenoid as a consequence of the deep orbital lamella of the<tei:lb/>frontal characteristic of citharinids. The orbitosphenoid of citharinids extends ventrally, as a<tei:lb/>nearly vertical pillar, to contact the parasphenoid dorsally, and then continues forward as a<tei:lb/>large, anteriorly-directed, anterolaterally diverging process which articulates with a posterolateral<tei:lb/>process of the lateral ethmoid (Fig. 9). Juveniles of Citharinus and Citharidium possess solely<tei:lb/>this ventral bony contact of the lateral ethmoid and orbitosphenoid. In the anterodorsal region<tei:lb/>of the orbit, juvenile citharinids have a large cartilage block in the area between the anterior<tei:lb/>edge of the orbital lamella of the frontal and the posteromedial portion of the lateral ethmoid.<tei:lb/>This cartilage mass undergoes a progressive ontogenetic ossification from the anterodorsal portion<tei:lb/>of the orbitosphenoid. As a consequence in all larger citharinid specimens examined (Citharinus<tei:lb/>latus, C. citharus, C. congicus, C. distichoides and C. gibbosus] the area occupied earlier in<tei:lb/>ontogeny by the cartilagenous block is filled by a prominent process of the orbitosphenoid. This</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>282 R. P. VARI</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ossification extends anterior of the orbital lamella of the frontal along the ventral surface of that<tei:lb/>bone to either coalesce or synchondrally join with a smaller posterodorsal process of the lateral<tei:lb/>ethmoid. Although large specimens of all citharinid species were not available for examination,<tei:lb/>it appears that such an anterodorsal orbitosphenoid process probably occurs in the adults of<tei:lb/>Citharidium and other Citharinus species. These dorsal processes of the lateral ethmoid and<tei:lb/>orbitosphenoid, along with the aforementioned ventral articulation of these bones, restrict the<tei:lb/>entrance to the anterior myodome in citharinids to a single horizontally elongate fenestra.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Neither the dorsal nor the ventral articulation between the orbitosphenoid and lateral ethmoid<tei:lb/>among citharinids can be homologized with the bony lateral ethmoid strut joining these elements<tei:lb/>in most distichodontids. The distichodontid strut passes between the superior and inferior oblique<tei:lb/>muscles and arises directly lateral to the olfactory foramen through the lateral ethmoid. In<tei:lb/>citharinids, in contrast, the superior and inferior oblique muscles pass between the processes<tei:lb/>joining the orbitosphenoid and lateral ethmoid rather than around either or both of them.<tei:lb/>Furthermore, the lateral ethmoid olfactory foramen is located directly anterior to the central<tei:lb/>elongate fenestra between these processes, rather than medial to either of them. Consequently,<tei:lb/>other than by hypothesizing a highly complex series of alterations of the above bones, muscles<tei:lb/>and nerves, it is not possible to homologize either of the lateral ethmoid-orbitosphenoid contacts<tei:lb/>in citharinids with the bony lateral ethmoid strut of distichodontids. Thus it is most parsimonious<tei:lb/>to assume that the citharinid and distichodontid types of lateral ethmoid-orbitosphenoid<tei:lb/>articulation are distinct, independently acquired, apomorphous systems.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Outgroup comparisons have revealed various ostariophysan groups with articulations of the<tei:lb/>lateral ethmoid and orbitosphenoid somewhat similar to those of citharinids and distichodontids.<tei:lb/>Some of these in non-characoid ostariophysans (e.g. the bony tube between the orbitosphenoid<tei:lb/>and lateral ethmoid in the catfish Diplomystes) are undoubtedly convergent with those in the<tei:lb/>groups under discussion. Within characoids, however, a direct contact of the lateral ethmoid and<tei:lb/>orbitosphenoid occurs within African characids in Hydrocynus, Bryconaethiops and various<tei:lb/>Alestes species and in the Neotropical families Anostomidae, Curimatidae, Prochilodontidae,<tei:lb/>Paradontidae and Lebiasinidae. Consequently, the mere fact of a direct articulation between<tei:lb/>these bones is not a distinguishing character among characoids for either the citharinid or dis-<tei:lb/>tichodontid type of contact. Nonetheless, in each case the particular form of lateral ethmoid-<tei:lb/>orbitosphenoid contact appears to be unique to citharinids and distichodontids among characoids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The presence in distichodontids of a strut-like process between the orbitosphenoid and lateral<tei:lb/>ethmoid was noted by Starks (1926, p. 167) in Distichodus fasciolatus, D. lusosso and Mesoborus<tei:lb/>crocodilus. The same author also described a somewhat similar tubular process in the African<tei:lb/>characids Alestes grandisquamis and A. liebrechstii. This process of these characids was later<tei:lb/>noted for Hydrocynus, Bryconaethiops, Alestes baremose, A. imberi and A. macrolepidotus by<tei:lb/>Roberts (1969, p. 441), and has been found in A. dentex and A. macrophthalmus during these<tei:lb/>studies. Although the tubular process in African characids seems homologous with the dis-<tei:lb/>tichodontid strut on a purely topographical basis, closer observation reveals several major<tei:lb/>differences between these structures. As previously noted, the distichodontid strut is formed<tei:lb/>primarily by the lateral ethmoid and covers only the lateral face of the olfactory bulb and tract.<tei:lb/>The process in the above characids, in contrast, is a bony tube formed primarily or entirely by the<tei:lb/>orbitosphenoid and completely surrounding the olfactory bulb and tract to varying degrees.<tei:lb/>Differences between these structures are also apparent in the phylogenetic and ontogenetic<tei:lb/>development of the orbitosphenoid tube of characids. Commencing in some Alestes species as a<tei:lb/>short anteriorly-directed lip around the orbitosphenoid olfactory foramen, the characid orbito-<tei:lb/>sphenoid process becomes increasingly elongate anteriorly through the phylogenetic series until<tei:lb/>in Hydrocynus it is a thick tube extending to the rear of the lateral ethmoid. At no point during<tei:lb/>this phylogenetic sequence, or the similar ontogenetic transition of Hydrocynus, is there found a<tei:lb/>distichodontid type strut. Thus the characid tube and the distichodontid strut would appear to be<tei:lb/>analogous but non-homologous structures.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A closer approximation to distichodontid form of contact between the lateral ethmoid and<tei:lb/>orbitosphenoid occurs in the South American characoid family Parodontidae. Among<tei:lb/>parodontids, the genus Saccodon has a posterior lateral ethmoid process contacting the orbito-</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>CLASSIFICATION OF CITHARINIDAE AND DISTICHODONTIDAE 283</tei:p>
         <tei:p>sphenoid (see Roberts, 1974, Fig. 57). This lateral ethmoid process is rather similar to the<tei:lb/>Xenocharax strut between these elements. In Parodon, in contrast, the expanded contact between<tei:lb/>these bones is comparable to that of Nannocharax. These similarities are, however, considered<tei:lb/>to be convergent with those of distichodontids rather than an indicator of close relationship<tei:lb/>between the Parodontidae and Distichodontidae (see p. 340).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>It is interesting to note that distichodontids and parodontids, together with the African<tei:lb/>characids having a bony tube between the orbitosphenoid and lateral ethmoid all have a forward<tei:lb/>shift of the olfactory bulb (see p. 341). It seems likely that the various adaptations of the anterior<tei:lb/>orbital region in these groups are correlated with this anterior position of the bulb and the<tei:lb/>consequent necessity to protect it from compression by the superior and inferior oblique muscles.<tei:lb/>Similarly, the dorsal and ventral articulations of the lateral ethmoid and orbitosphenoid in<tei:lb/>citharinids separate the olfactory bulb, nerve and tract from the orbital cavity and the inferior<tei:lb/>and superior oblique muscles. The only characoid found during this study to have a forward<tei:lb/>position of the bulb, but lacking some form of bony protection for it, was the Neotropical genus<tei:lb/>Salminus. However, in that genus the bulb is, nonetheless, surrounded laterally by a very heavy,<tei:lb/>inflexible connective tissue capsule.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>An approximation to the citharinid form of contact between the orbitosphenoid and lateral<tei:lb/>ethmoid is found among the Neotropical families Anostomidae, Curimatidae, Prochilodontidae<tei:lb/>and Lebiasinidae. A variety of differences discriminate the form of contact in these families from<tei:lb/>that in citharinids. However, rather than dealing with these in detail, for the purposes of this<tei:lb/>study, it suffices to note that in none of them is the ventral articulation between the orbitosphenoid<tei:lb/>and lateral ethmoid as massive as in citharinids. Neither has there been found among these<tei:lb/>families any form of dorsal contact between the lateral ethmoid and orbitosphenoid comparable<tei:lb/>to that in citharinids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Citharinids also demonstrate yet another modification of this region of the neurocranium.<tei:lb/>These genera have a prominent horizontal shelf extending along the rear portion of the orbito-<tei:lb/>sphenoid and onto the anterior part of the pterosphenoid. The functional significance of this<tei:lb/>process, which is unique to Citharinus and Citharidium among the families under study, is presently<tei:lb/>unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Derived states of the anterior orbital region among citharinids and distichodontids include:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 the dorsal and ventral lateral ethmoid-orbitosphenoid contacts in citharinids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 the bony strut between the orbitosphenoid and lateral ethmoid in distichodontids. This<tei:lb/>strut is vertically expanded in Nannocharax and Hemigrammocharax, but is hypothesized<tei:lb/>to be secondarily reduced in Nannaethiops and Neolebias.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3 the shelf-like process on the lateral surface of the orbitosphenoid and pterosphenoid in<tei:lb/>citharinids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Posterior orbital and anterior otic regions</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Among citharinids and distichodontids the posterior orbital and anterior otic regions undergo a<tei:lb/>series of interrelated modifications and thus are most easily discussed as a unit. The plesio-<tei:lb/>morphous state of this portion of the neurocranium, within the complex formed by the<tei:lb/>Citharinidae and Distichodontidae, is hypothesized to be similar to that of Xenocharax (Fig.<tei:lb/>10). This genus has the dorsal margin of the orbit formed by a distinct lateral process of the frontal.<tei:lb/>The posterodorsal wall of the orbital cavity is formed by the prominent sphenotic spine. This<tei:lb/>process extends distinctly lateral to the frontal and is orientated along the vertical through the<tei:lb/>trigemino-facialis foramen. Ventrolaterally the sphenotic bears a short vertical process which is<tei:lb/>continuous dorsally with the sphenotic spine, and ventrally with the prominent sharp-edged<tei:lb/>ridge of the lateral commissure of the prootic. This lateral commissural ridge, in turn, contacts<tei:lb/>the lateral flange present on the anterior edge of the ascending process of the parasphenoid.<tei:lb/>Together these lateral processes of the sphenotic, prootic and parasphenoid form a nearly<tei:lb/>continuous, laterally-directed flange at the rear of the orbital cavity. Along its ventral border the<tei:lb/>sphenotic forms the anterodorsal portion of the hyomandibular fossa which extends anteriorly<tei:lb/>to below the sphenotic spine and contacts the posterior edge of the orbital cavity. The prootic in<tei:lb/>Xenocharax is an angular element whose lateral surface nearly forms a right angle horizontally</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>284</tei:p>
         <tei:p>R. P. VARI</tei:p>
         <tei:p>at the ridge of the lateral commissure. As a consequence the anterior portion of the prootic faces<tei:lb/>onto the orbital cavity while the posterior section contributes to the lateral surface of the neuro-<tei:lb/>cranium. In Xenocharax the prootic forms the dorsal and dorsolateral borders of the entrance<tei:lb/>into the posterior myodome, and the ventrolateral and ventral borders of the median opening into<tei:lb/>the braincase. Thus this bone broadly separates the posteroventral border of the pterosphenoid<tei:lb/>from the dorsal edge of the ascending process of the parasphenoid. Finally, the pterosphenoid and<tei:lb/>orbitosphenoid of Xenocharax are rather flat, square bones.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5mm</tei:p>
         <tei:p>para</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 10 Xenocharax spilurus, posterior orbital and anterior otic regions, left lateral view.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Xenocharax plan of the posterior orbital and anterior otic regions agrees in general<tei:lb/>morphology, although not necessarily specific detail, with that in non-specialized members of<tei:lb/>most groups of characoids. Thus this plan is hypothesized to represent the plesiomorphous<tei:lb/>condition of this region for citharinids and distichodontids. Apart from a difference in the extent<tei:lb/>of the contribution of the supraorbital to the orbital rim (see p. 301), this arrangement of the<tei:lb/>posterior orbital and anterior otic regions is shared with minor variations by citharinids and the<tei:lb/>distichodontid genera Xenocharax, Nannaelhiops, Neolebias, Paradistichodus and Hemistichodus.<tei:lb/>The remaining distichodontid genera can be divided into two assemblages on the basis of their<tei:lb/>distinct adaptations of this neurocranial region.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Within the subunit of distichodontids formed by Distichodus, Nannocharax and Hemigrammo-<tei:lb/>charax there occurs a progressive transition from the plesiomorphous ventrally sharp-edged<tei:lb/>sphenotic spine to a reduced, ventrally concave sphenotic process. Distichodus species such as<tei:lb/>D. notospilus retain the plesiomorphous condition of a large, nearly vertical sphenotic spine<tei:lb/>tapering ventrally to a thin edge. In D. niloticus and D. fasciolatus the central portion of the<tei:lb/>ventral edge of the spine is rotated slightly anteriorly, resulting in an oblique anteroventrally<tei:lb/>sloping central portion of the ventral margin of the spine. This alteration is further pronounced<tei:lb/>in species such as D. lusosso where this section of the sphenotic spine is expanded ventrally into<tei:lb/>a broad concave surface. Such a restructuring of the sphenotic spine is carried further in Nanno-<tei:lb/>charax and Hemigrammocharax where the ventrally reduced spine has the form of a short,<tei:lb/>ventrally concave, posteroventrally sloping shelf.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>CLASSIFICATION OF CITHARINIDAE AND DISTICHODONTIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>285</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The genera Ichthyborus, Microstomatichthyoborus, Mesoborus, Eugnatichthys, Paraphago,<tei:lb/>Phago and Belonophago, in turn, exhibit a different series of alterations and reductions of the<tei:lb/>bones of the posterior orbital and anterior otic regions (note: the osteology of Paraphago, known<tei:lb/>only from the type series of P. restrains, was examined primarily by radiographs). Progressive<tei:lb/>modifications of several levels of universality characterize this region of the neurocranium<tei:lb/>among these distichodontids. In the following discussion these adaptations will be dealt with<tei:lb/>sequentially. First, those apomorphic alterations found in Ichthyborus and common to, or further<tei:lb/>modified in, the other genera listed above will be described. The further derived characters that<tei:lb/>characterize less universal groups within this unit will be discussed in light of the modifications in<tei:lb/>Ichthyborus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>fr</tei:p>
         <tei:p>par</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 11 Ichthyborus besse, posterior orbital and anterior otic regions, left lateral view.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The most pronounced alterations of this neurocranial region are those of the sphenotic, in<tei:lb/>particular the reduction and reorientation of the sphenotic spine. In Ichthyborus (Fig. 11), the<tei:lb/>entire sphenotic spine is rotated so that its primitively ventral edge is shifted posterodorsally.<tei:lb/>This reorientation results in the spine forming a posteroventrally sloping shelf in contrast to its<tei:lb/>plesiomorphous state of a nearly vertical wall. In addition, the lateral extent of the spine is<tei:lb/>reduced, resulting in a truncate process that barely extends beyond the lateral margin of the<tei:lb/>frontal. The overall form of the sphenotic in Ichthyborus is horizontally elongate relative to the<tei:lb/>hypothesized plesiomorphous state. Along with a posterior shift of the prootic, this elongation<tei:lb/>has resulted in a horizontal separation of the anterior margin of the hyomandibular fossa from<tei:lb/>the posterior edge of the sphenotic spine and the vertical through the trigemino-facialis foramen.<tei:lb/>Such a separation is considered derived relative to the close approximation of these structures in<tei:lb/>the plesiomorphous condition. The prootic of Ichthyborus is also markedly restructured from the<tei:lb/>plesiomorphous condition in which the lateral commissure bears a sharp-edged lateral ridge. In<tei:lb/>this genus the prootic is a gently curved, flattened element unelaborated laterally apart from the<tei:lb/>slightly raised lips around the facialis and trigemino-facialis foramina. The prootic of Ichthyborus<tei:lb/>is also shifted posteriorly, resulting both in the aforementioned repositioning of the hyo-<tei:lb/>mandibular fossa and in the reduction of the contribution of the prootic to the edge of the<tei:lb/>opening into the posterior myodome. As a consequence of the latter change, there is a significant<tei:lb/>reduction in the plesiomorphously wide separation between the posterior border of the ptero-<tei:lb/>sphenoid and the ascending arm of the parasphenoid.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The final noteworthy adaptation of this neurocranial region in Ichthyborus involves the ventral<tei:lb/>surface of the orbital process of the frontal. In citharinids and most distichodontids that portion</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>286</tei:p>
         <tei:p>R. P. VARI</tei:p>
         <tei:p>of the frontal forming the roof of the orbital cavity is a ventrally smooth, slightly concave<tei:lb/>surface; a condition probably plesiomorphous for characoids. The ventral surface of the frontal<tei:lb/>in Ichthyborus, in contrast, bears a strong transverse ridge capped laterally by an anterodorsal<tei:lb/>extension of the sphenotic spine. This ridge is continuous with the orbital lamella of the frontal<tei:lb/>and extends transversely along the ventral surface of the bone just anterior to the suture of the<tei:lb/>frontal with the anterodorsal edge of the sphenotic spine.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>fr</tei:p>
         <tei:p>sph</tei:p>
         <tei:p>.-, ;&gt;tm_ , ....... .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>r^d"^ X,, :'.'. -'il''iSi^BrVV^?:7</tei:p>
         <tei:p>X *k.-. ..; ?v'iS^X. v -:A<tei:lb/>&amp;^-&amp;$$&amp;:.&amp;<tei:lb/>pro</tei:p>
         <tei:p>para</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 12 Mesoborus crocodilus, posterior orbital and anterior otic regions, left lateral view.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>These apomorphous modifications of the posterior orbital and anterior otic regions are common<tei:lb/>to Ichthyborus and Microstomatichthyoborus, and are the basis for a series of further derived<tei:lb/>adaptations in Mesoborus, Eugnatichthys, Paraphago, Phago and Belonophago. Congruent with<tei:lb/>the overall elongation of the neurocranium, the orbitosphenoid and pterosphenoid of these<tei:lb/>latter genera are notably elongate both relative to the Ichthyborus condition, and more notably<tei:lb/>with respect to the hypothesized plesiomorphous characoid state. These taxa also have in common<tei:lb/>a further restructuring of the sphenotic spine. The primitively ventral edge of the sphenotic has<tei:lb/>rotated posterodorsally nearly to the level of the horizontal through the anterodorsal margin of<tei:lb/>the spine. Thus in these genera the spine has the form of a nearly horizontal shelf (Figs 12, 13, 14)<tei:lb/>rather than the near vertical wall at the rear of the orbital cavity of Xenocharax, or the postero-<tei:lb/>ventrally slanting process of Ichthyborus. As described earlier, the plesiomorphous sphenotic<tei:lb/>spine extends distinctly lateral to the edge of the frontal, with Ichthyborus having the lateral extent<tei:lb/>of the spine significantly reduced. Mesoborus, Eugnatichthys, Paraphago, Phago and Belonophago<tei:lb/>show a further reduction of the Ichthyborus form of the sphenotic. In Mesoborus the sphenotic<tei:lb/>spine barely extends lateral of the edge of the frontal, and it falls distinctly short of the margin<tei:lb/>in Eugnatichthys, Paraphago, Phago and Belonophago. Within the latter assemblage, the anterior<tei:lb/>sphenotic process which caps the transverse ridge of the frontal is significantly reduced in<tei:lb/>Eugnatichthys and completely lost in Phago and Belonophago (the condition of the process is<tei:lb/>unknown in Paraphago). In addition, Belonophago lacks, evidently secondarily, the transverse<tei:lb/>strut along the ventral edge of the frontal that characterizes other members of its monophyletic<tei:lb/>unit.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Phago and Belonophago can be further distinguished within distichodontids by the broad<tei:lb/>contact between the posteroventral portion of the pterosphenoid and the dorsal margin of the<tei:lb/>ascending arm of the parasphenoid (Fig. 14). The extensive articulation between these bones</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>CLASSIFICATION OF CITHARINIDAE AND DISTICHODONTIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>287</tei:p>
         <tei:p>totally separates the prootic from its plesiomorphous location along the anterior margin of the<tei:lb/>entrance into the posterior myodome. Furthermore, radiographs of Paraphago rostratus reveal<tei:lb/>what appears to be a less extensive suture between these bones. Therefore Phago, Belonophago<tei:lb/>and perhaps Paraphago share a synapomorphous contact of the pterosphenoid and parasphenoid.<tei:lb/>Belonophago is a highly specialized genus characterized by long jaws and an extreme elongation<tei:lb/>of the skull, particularly in the posterior orbital region (Fig. 14). In this genus the pterosphenoid<tei:lb/>is expanded posteriorly and ventrally to form the entire anterior surface of the braincase. As a<tei:lb/>consequence of this elongation, the lateral commissure and hyomandibular fossa are markedly</tei:p>
         <tei:p>fr</tei:p>
         <tei:p>para</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 13 Eugnatichthys eetveldii, posterior orbital and anterior otic regions, left lateral view.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>shifted posteriorly and are removed from the rear of the orbit by a distance equal to the orbital<tei:lb/>diameter. Such an extensive separation is derived relative to the Ichthyborus condition of a slight<tei:lb/>distance between these structures, and is a pronounced apomorphous change relative to the<tei:lb/>plesiomorphous close proximity of the anterior portions of the lateral commissure and hyo-<tei:lb/>mandibular fossa to the rear of the orbital cavity. As noted previously, the pterosphenoid in<tei:lb/>Belonophago is broadly in contact posteroventrally with the ascending process of the parasphenoid.<tei:lb/>In addition, Belonophago has a median articulation between these elements. Arising from the<tei:lb/>anterior face of the pterosphenoid is a ventrally-directed medial process which contacts a cor-<tei:lb/>responding dorsally-orientated medial parasphenoid strut. Together these processes form a pedicle<tei:lb/>between the pterosphenoid and the parasphenoid (Fig. 14), an adaptation that is evidently unique<tei:lb/>to this genus among characoids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A series of autapomorphous adaptations of the posterior orbital and anterior otic regions<tei:lb/>distinguish Eugnatichthys among distichodontids. The pterosphenoid in this genus is shifted<tei:lb/>posteroventrally by the ventral expansion of the orbital lamella of the frontal. This shift, along<tei:lb/>with the horizontal elongation of the sphenotic, results in a marked separation, both vertically<tei:lb/>and horizontally, between the rear of the sphenotic spine and anterior margin of the hyo-<tei:lb/>mandibular fossa. Together with a horizontal expansion of the pterosphenoid, this sphenotic<tei:lb/>elongation has shifted the prootic and associated lateral commissure posteriorly relative to the<tei:lb/>Ichthyborus condition. Although Eugnatichthys and Belonophago both possess a pronounced<tei:lb/>posterior shift of the hyomandibular fossa and lateral commissure, the method by which this<tei:lb/>realignment is achieved differs greatly in the two genera. In Eugnatichthys this restructuring is</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>288</tei:p>
         <tei:p>R. P. VARI</tei:p>
         <tei:p>primarily a consequence of the elongation of the sphenotic and the ventral expansion of the<tei:lb/>orbital lamella of the frontal. In Belonophago, in contrast, the realignment is largely the result<tei:lb/>of the horizontal extension of the pterosphenoid.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>bo</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 14 Belonophago tinanti, posterior orbital and anterior otic regions, left lateral view.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Several modifications of the parasphenoid are of interest for an understanding of relationships<tei:lb/>within the Citharinidae and Distichodontidae. The plesiomorphous characoid parasphenoid<tei:lb/>form appears to be a flat, straight or ventrally convex element, extending posteriorly to below the<tei:lb/>basioccipital. In Citharinus and Citharidium, in contrast, the parasphenoid is markedly flexed<tei:lb/>ventral to its ascending processes and ontogenetically develops a bulbous process ventral to<tei:lb/>this point of flexure. This process serves as the area of attachment for the anteriorly shifted sus-<tei:lb/>pensory pharyngeals characteristic of this family. Posteriorly the citharinid parasphenoid has two<tei:lb/>slightly divergent lateral wings separated by a deep groove. Although such a condition occurs in<tei:lb/>many characoids in which the posterior myodome is posteroventrally open, in citharinids the<tei:lb/>myodome is closed at the rear, and the posterolateral wings of the parasphenoid surround the<tei:lb/>anterior portion of the dorsal aorta. In juveniles of Citharinus and Citharidium these parasphenoid<tei:lb/>processes are separate both from the basioccipital and the highly modified pars sustentaculum<tei:lb/>of the Weberian apparatus. In adults, however, the posterior parasphenoid processes fuse dorsally<tei:lb/>with the basioccipital and posteriorly with the ventral projections of the pars sustentaculum (see<tei:lb/>discussion on the Weberian apparatus). The overall modifications in pharasphenoid form, and<tei:lb/>the changes in its relationships to the basioccipital and pars sustentaculum are hypothesized to be<tei:lb/>apomorphous.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The distichodontid genera Eugnatichthys, Paraphago, Phago and Belonophago have the<tei:lb/>parasphenoid expanded ventrally into a flattened median ridge. This process serves as a point of<tei:lb/>attachment for the posteroventrally shifted suspensory pharyngeals occurring in these genera and<tei:lb/>is most developed in Eugnatichthys in which the shift is most pronounced (Fig. 13).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In summary, the hypothesized apomorphous states of the posterior orbital and anterior otic<tei:lb/>regions in citharinids and distichodontids include:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 the vertical reduction and horizontal expansion of the sphenotic spine in Hemigrammo-<tei:lb/>charax, Nannocharax and some Distichodus species. The restructuring of the spine is<tei:lb/>particularly pronounced in the first two genera.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 the lack of lateral flanges on the prootic and ascending arm of the parasphenoid in<tei:lb/>Ichthyborus, Microstomatichthyoborus, Mesoborus, Eugnatichthys, Paraphago, Phago and<tei:lb/>Belonophago. These genera also share a laterally reduced sphenotic spine whose plesio-<tei:lb/>morphously ventral edge is shifted posterodorsally; the development of a transverse<tei:lb/>process on the ventral surface of the frontal; a posterior shift of the hyomandibular fossa;<tei:lb/>and a reduction in the gap between the parasphenoid and pterosphenoid.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>CLASSIFICATION OF CITHARINIDAE AND DISTICHODONTIDAE 289</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3 the restructuring of the sphenotic spine to form a horizontal shelf in Mesoborus,<tei:lb/>Eugnatichthys, Paraphago, Phago and Belonophago. The lateral extent of the spine is<tei:lb/>slightly further reduced relative to the Ichthyborus condition in Mesoborus, and greatly<tei:lb/>so in the other genera listed.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>4 the reduction of the sphenotic process capping the transverse process of the frontal in<tei:lb/>Eugnatichthys, and its loss in Phago, Belonophago and perhaps Paraphago.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5 the broad articulation between the pterosphenoid and parasphenoid in Phago,<tei:lb/>Belonophago and perhaps Paraphago, with Belonophago having an autapomorphous<tei:lb/>median contact between these elements.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>6 the pronounced posterior expansion of the pterosphenoid in Belonophago.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 the ventral expansion of the orbital lamella of the frontal and a horizontal lengthening<tei:lb/>of the sphenotic in Eugnatichthys.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>8 the distinctive flexure in the parasphenoid and the development of a ventral bulbous<tei:lb/>parasphenoid process in citharinids. In these genera the posterior processes of the para-<tei:lb/>sphenoid straddle the dorsal aorta and fuse with the pars sustentaculum and basioccipital.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>9 the median ventral parasphenoid ridge in Eugnatichthys, Paraphago, Phago and<tei:lb/>Belonophago.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Occipital region</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The character of phylogenetic interest in the occipital region of citharinids and distichodontids<tei:lb/>is the number, form and extent of development of the posttemporal fossae. The most widespread,<tei:lb/>and the hypothesized plesiomorphous, state of these openings among characoids consists of a<tei:lb/>dorsal and posterolateral pair of fossae on either side of the neurocranium. The horizontal or<tei:lb/>slightly oblique dorsal fossa is bordered by the supraoccipital medially, the parietal anteriorly<tei:lb/>and the epioccipital posteriorly. The remaining fossa is located at the posterolateral corner of the<tei:lb/>neurocranium and is bordered anteriorly and ventrally by the pterotic, and posteriorly and<tei:lb/>dorsally by the epioccipital.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Citharinids and distichodontids, in contrast, also possess an additional vertically ovate fossa<tei:lb/>bordered by the epioccipital and exoccipital (Fig. 15) (citharinids although possessing this 'third'<tei:lb/>fossa have, however, lost the dorsal fossa and thus retain only two sets of openings, see below).<tei:lb/>On the basis of outgroup comparisons the possession of a third fossa appears to be derived among<tei:lb/>ostariophysans in general and characoids in particular. However, although not widespread, a<tei:lb/>third posttemporal fossa per se is not unique to citharinids and distichodontids among charcoids.<tei:lb/>Such a feature has been found in most African characids and among South American characoids<tei:lb/>in the families Curimatidae, Hemiodontidae (Roberts, 1974), Parodontidae (Roberts, 1974) and<tei:lb/>the characid tribe Cynodontini (sensu Howes, 1976). However, the third posttemporal fossa in<tei:lb/>these taxa, with the exception of the Cynodontini, is a small round opening entirely within the<tei:lb/>epioccipital. This condition contrasts with the large ovoid fossa bordered by the deeply incut<tei:lb/>exoccipital and epioccipital in citharinids, distichodontids and cynodontines.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Although the Cynodontini possess a form of third posttemporal fossa very similar to that of<tei:lb/>citharinids and distichodontids, they do not, however, appear to be the sister group to the latter<tei:lb/>families. As discussed by Howes (1976), cynodontines possess a series of derived characters<tei:lb/>uniting them to the neotropical characid tribe Characini which lacks a third posttemporal fossa.<tei:lb/>Furthermore, the members of both the Cynodontini and Characini have a rhinosphenoid, an<tei:lb/>element unique to various South American characoids, most of which lack any form of third<tei:lb/>posttemporal fossa. In light of the lack of the third fossa both in the sister group to cynodontines<tei:lb/>and in the more inclusive unit of Neotropical characoids defined by the presence of a rhino-<tei:lb/>sphenoid, it is most parsimonious to assume that the cynodontines arose from an ancestor<tei:lb/>possessing a rhinosphenoid but lacking a third posttemporal fossa. It thus appears that although<tei:lb/>convergently derived in cynodontines, the possession of a vertically ovate third posttemporal fossa<tei:lb/>bordered by the epioccipital and exoccipital is apomorphous for, and indicative of the monophyly<tei:lb/>of the unit formed by citharinids and distichodontids within characoids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The genera Citharinus and Citharidium lack the plesiomorphously present posttemporal fossa</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>290</tei:p>
         <tei:p>R. P. VARI</tei:p>
         <tei:p>on the posterodorsal surface of the neurocranium. In Eugnatichthys, in turn, there occurs a greatly<tei:lb/>reduced fossa in the same area. Both the reduction of the fossa in Eugnatichthys and its loss in<tei:lb/>citharinids are considered derived in so far as the possession of a large dorsal posttemporal fossa<tei:lb/>is generalized among characoids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cranial fontanelle</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The extent of the dorsomedian fontanelle varies considerably within the unit formed by citharinids<tei:lb/>and distichodontids. Although the plesiomorphous condition of the fontanelle for these families<tei:lb/>or indeed any otophysans is difficult to ascertain, this variation does permit certain assumptions</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ptf,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>bo</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2mm Para-</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 15 Xenocharax spilurus, neurocranium, posterior view.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>to be made. Of particular note is the extension of the fontanelle into the posterior half of the<tei:lb/>supraethmoid in Citharinus and Citharidium (Fig. 6c). Such an elongate fontanelle is rarely<tei:lb/>encountered among characoids and appears apomorphous for the superfamily. Among disticho-<tei:lb/>dontids, Xenocharax possesses an elongate fontanelle that separates the frontals, which are only<tei:lb/>in contact at the epiphyseal bar, and the parietals. The remaining distichodontids demonstrate<tei:lb/>a progressive phylogenetic reduction of this extensive fontanelle. All distichodontids apart from<tei:lb/>Xenocharax have a shorter opening which at the maximum extends slightly anterior to the<tei:lb/>epiphyseal bar. Ichthyborus, Microstomatichthyoboms, Belonophago, Mesoborus, Eugnatichthys,<tei:lb/>Paraphago and Phago have a further reduced fontanelle limited to the interparietal region, with<tei:lb/>this reduction particularly pronounced in the last four genera. The hypothesis that a progressive<tei:lb/>reduction of the fontanelle is apomorphic among distichodontids is congruent with the large<tei:lb/>fontanelle that characterizes the Citharinidae, the family which is hypothesized as the sister<tei:lb/>group to distichodontids. Such a hypothesis also agrees with the distribution of a large suite of<tei:lb/>derived characters within distichodontids. This reductional trend appears, however, to have been<tei:lb/>slightly reversed in Belonophago where the fontanelle is enlarged relative to the condition in other<tei:lb/>members of its monophyletic group.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Suspensorium</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The diverse modifications of the dentition, jaws and neurocranium that characterize the<tei:lb/>Citharinidae and subunits of the Distichodontidae are reflected in a series of alterations to the<tei:lb/>suspensorium. Two different types of suspensorium can be discriminated among citharinids and</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>CLASSIFICATION OF CITHARINIDAE AND DISTICHODONTIDAE 291</tei:p>
         <tei:p>distichodontids on the basis of the relative position of the articulation of the angulo-articular<tei:lb/>with the quadrate. In Citharinus, Citharidium, Xenocharax, Neolebias and Nannaethiops the<tei:lb/>horizontal distance between the ventral portion of the hyomandibula and the articular condyle<tei:lb/>of the quadrate is relatively short. As a consequence, the articulation of the angulo-articular with<tei:lb/>the quadrate occurs below the centre of the orbit and distinctly posterior to the vertical through<tei:lb/>the body of the lateral ethmoid. In the remaining distichodontid genera, in contrast, the sym-<tei:lb/>plectic, metapterygoid and quadrate are relatively elongate resulting in a forward shift of the<tei:lb/>articular condyle of the quadrate to below or anterior to the vertical through the lateral ethmoid.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The polarity of such changes in the position of the articulation of the angulo-articular with<tei:lb/>the quadrate is somewhat problematical in that both anterior and posterior positions of this<tei:lb/>joint occur within a variety of seemingly monophyletic characoid groups. Consequently, a shift<tei:lb/>in the position of the articulation has evidently occurred independently within the Characoidea on<tei:lb/>several occasions. It is nonetheless interesting to note that those characoid groups which have<tei:lb/>been considered to be 'primitive' (Hepsetidae and Erythrinidae) have the posterior position of<tei:lb/>this joint; a location also common to generalized members of most characoid groups. If these<tei:lb/>families do indeed possess the plesiomorphous jaw form, then the primitive joint position and<tei:lb/>type of suspensorium among citharinids and distichodontids would be the posterior articulation<tei:lb/>common to Citharinus, Citharidium, Xenocharax, Neolebias and Nannaethiops. It is furthermore<tei:lb/>noteworthy that distichodontids with an anterior articulation of the quadrate and angulo-articular<tei:lb/>have derived forms of jaws and dentition. This congruence of the forward position of the angulo-<tei:lb/>articular-quadrate joint with a series of apomorphous jaw characters, contrasted with the posterior<tei:lb/>articulation among 'primitive' and generalized characoids, supports the hypothesis that an<tei:lb/>anterior articulation of these elements is the derived condition.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>These adaptations in the suspensorium are reflective of the relative mouth sizes of the two<tei:lb/>groups of genera. In characoids with a non-protrusible mouth, the length of the jaws and<tei:lb/>consequently the extent of the gape is primarily a function of the position of the articulation of<tei:lb/>the quadrate with the angulo-articular. Thus in small-mouthed characoids the joint occurs under<tei:lb/>or forward of the ventral process of the lateral ethmoid. In large-mouthed, often predacious<tei:lb/>forms, in contrast, the articulation is distinctly posterior to the lateral ethmoid, and is sometimes<tei:lb/>also shifted ventrally. The distichodontid genera Hemistichodus, Microstomatichthyoborus,<tei:lb/>Mesoborus, Eugnatichthys, Ichthyborus, Paraphago, Phago and Belonophago, particularly the<tei:lb/>latter four genera, would appear to invalidate this distinction in being large-gaped fish with a<tei:lb/>forward angulo-articular-quadrate articulation. However, this seeming incongruity is a function<tei:lb/>of the autapomorphous manner in which the elongation of the jaws is achieved in these genera.<tei:lb/>Among other characoids the premaxilla extends little, if at all, anterior to the tip of the supraeth-<tei:lb/>moid. Thus the effective gape is a function of the distance between the anterior margin of the<tei:lb/>supraethmoid and the articular condyle of the quadrate. In the distichodontid genera noted<tei:lb/>above, however, the elongation of the gape is a function of the lengthening of the premaxillae<tei:lb/>anterior to the supraethmoid. This adaptation together with the congruent changes in the supra-<tei:lb/>ethmoid, lower jaw and suspensorium permits an elongation of the gape despite the retention of<tei:lb/>an anterior position of the articulation between the angulo-articular and quadrate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In addition to the above broad differences in overall suspensorium form, modifications of<tei:lb/>portions of this system characterize groups of varying levels of universality with the Disticho-<tei:lb/>dontidae. Two multigeneric assemblages within this family demonstrate a restructuring of the<tei:lb/>generalized characoid condition of a somewhat rectangular hyomandibula having a slightly<tei:lb/>concave anterior face. In Nannocharax and Hemigrammocharax the hyomandibula is markedly<tei:lb/>widened anteroposteriorly and has a relatively elongate articulation with the hyomandibular<tei:lb/>fossa (see Daget, 1961, Fig. 10). Ichthyborus, Mesoborus, Microstomatichthyoborus, Eugnatichthys,<tei:lb/>Paraphago, Phago and Belonophago, in contrast, have an elongate hyomandibula with a deeply<tei:lb/>concave anterior margin (see Daget, 1967, Fig. 9). Both this form of hyomandibula and that<tei:lb/>occurring in the unit formed by Hemigrammocharax and Nannocharax appear to be derived<tei:lb/>characters serving to define these multigeneric units.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The hyomandibula exhibits several other modifications of note among distichodontids. In<tei:lb/>Eugnatichthys this bone has a dorsally-directed process arising from its dorsolateral border</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>292</tei:p>
         <tei:p>R. P. VARI</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 16). A similar, although not as well-developed, process occurs in Phago and appears to be<tei:lb/>present in Paraphago. Eugnatichthys also possesses a medially-directed process on the medial<tei:lb/>surface of the hyomandibula. This structure both braces the bone against the ventral surface<tei:lb/>of the neurocranium and serve$ as a point of origin for portions of the adductor mandibulae<tei:lb/>muscles.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>sp</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 16</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eugnatichthys eetveldii, posteroventral otic region and dorsal portion of the hyomandibula,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>left lateral view.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The final hyomandibular modifications of note among distichodontids involve the relationships<tei:lb/>of this element to the dorsal portion of the preopercle. Citharinids and distichodontids other than<tei:lb/>Mesoborus, Eugnatichthys, Paraphago, Phago and Belonophago retain the plesiomorphous<tei:lb/>characoid condition of a slight overlap of the lateral face of the vertical arm of the preopercle by<tei:lb/>the posterior border of the hyomandibula. In the listed genera, however, the posterior surface<tei:lb/>of the hyomandibula bears a vertically elongate depression just ventral to the articular condyle.<tei:lb/>This groove, which appears to be unique to these genera among characoids, tightly surrounds<tei:lb/>the dorsal tip of the preopercle (Fig. 17) and further reduces the possibility of motion between<tei:lb/>these elements.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>P9P</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 17 Phago loricatus, central portion of the hyomandibula and posterodorsal section of the</tei:p>
         <tei:p>preopercle, left lateral view.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>CLASSIFICATION OF CITHARINIDAE AND DISTICHODONTIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>293</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The preopercle, in turn, has undergone several modifications that distinguish groups of varying<tei:lb/>levels of universality within distichodontids. In Hemistichodus, Ichthyborus, Microstomatich-<tei:lb/>thyborus, Mesoborus, Eugnatichthys, Paraphago, Phago and Belonophago the laterosensory canal<tei:lb/>segment in the vertical arm of the preopercle is shifted medially relative to the condition in<tei:lb/>citharinids and other distichodontids. This shift, which is especially pronounced in Ichthyborus,<tei:lb/>results in a broad separation of the laterosensory canal segment from the posterolateral edge of the<tei:lb/>bone. These genera, with the exception of Ichthyborus and Hemistichodus, are also characterized<tei:lb/>by the separation of the posterolateral portion of the preopercle as a distinct dorsally-directed<tei:lb/>process (Fig. 18). Both this lateral preopercular flange and the medial shift of the posterior portion<tei:lb/>of the preopercular laterosensory canal are hypothesized to be apomorphous characters.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>pmp</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2mm<tei:lb/>Fig. 18 Phago loricatus, posterior portion of the preopercle, left lateral view.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The final preopercular modification of note involves the development of a lateral preopercular<tei:lb/>shelf in some distichodontids. The lateral surface of the preopercle in citharinids and the dis-<tei:lb/>tichodontid genera Xenocharax, Nannaethiops and Neolebias is nearly flat except for the slightly<tei:lb/>raised laterosensory canal. Paradistichodus, Distichodus, Nannocharax, Hemigrammocharax and<tei:lb/>Hemistichodus, in contrast, have a horizontal, laterally-directed ridge along the anterior portion<tei:lb/>of the preopercle. This lateral preopercular ridge is further elaborated, both posteriorly and<tei:lb/>laterally, in Ichthyborus, Microstomatichthyborus, Mesoborus, Eugnatichthys, Paraphago, Phago<tei:lb/>and Belonophago where it extends posteriorly to the vertical arm of the preopercle. In these genera<tei:lb/>these processes of the quadrate and preopercle form a distinct trough from which the expanded<tei:lb/>origin of the large A! and A 2 portions of the adductor mandibulae muscles partially arise. Such<tei:lb/>an elaboration of the preopercle and quadrate is hypothesized apomorphous for these genera,<tei:lb/>although occurring evidently independently in the South American characoid family<tei:lb/>Anostomidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The metapterygoid-quadrate fenestra undergoes a series of apomorphic alterations in various<tei:lb/>generic and multigeneric units among distichodontids. The plesiomorphous condition of the<tei:lb/>fenestra among characoids appears to be an horizontally ovoid opening bordered primarily by<tei:lb/>the metapterygoid dorsally and the quadrate ventrally, and with the symplectic forming a limited<tei:lb/>portion of its posteroventral border. A complete eradication of the fenestra occurs in Neolebias<tei:lb/>spilotaenia in which the enlarged symplectic fills the space primitively occupied by the fenestra.<tei:lb/>Correlated with the decreased vertical extent of the suspensorium in Nannocharax and Hemigram-<tei:lb/>mocharax is a reduction or elimination of the fenestra as a consequence of the approximation of<tei:lb/>the quadrate and metapterygoid (see Daget, 1961, Fig. 10).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hemistichodus, Ichthyborus, Microstomatichthyoborus, Mesoborus, Eugnatichthys, Paraphago,<tei:lb/>Phago and Belonophago, in contrast, have a horizontally elongate metapterygoid-quadrate</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>294 R. P. VARI</tei:p>
         <tei:p>fenestra (see Daget, 1967, Fig. 9). In these genera the contribution of the symplectic to the border<tei:lb/>of the fenestra is greatly increased, with a congruent reduction of the portion of the border<tei:lb/>formed by the quadrate. Such seemingly apomorphous modifications are correlated with the<tei:lb/>lengthening of the metapterygoid and symplectic necessitated by the posterior shift of the<tei:lb/>hyomandibular fossa in these genera. This elongation of the fenestra is particularly pronounced<tei:lb/>in Phago and Belonophago in which the bones are exceptionally long and slender.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The final modifications of the suspensorium to be discussed involve the relationship of the<tei:lb/>anterior portion of the suspensorium to the upper jaw. The generalized characoid condition has<tei:lb/>a ligamentous or cartilaginous attachment of the palatine to the anteromedial maxillary process,<tei:lb/>and a loose ligamentous connection of the palatine to the vomerine region. In .Citharinus and<tei:lb/>Citharidium, however, a large cartilage pad joins the palatine to the anteromedial process of the<tei:lb/>maxilla. Furthermore, citharinids have a second cartilaginous mass joining the palatine to the<tei:lb/>posterior surface of the premaxilla. Although a cartilaginous connection between the maxilla<tei:lb/>and palatine occurs in other characoid groups, both the size of the cartilage in citharinids, and<tei:lb/>the presence of a cartilaginous body between the palatine and premaxilla is unique to, and thus<tei:lb/>considered apomorphous for, these genera among the families under study.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Some species of Nannocharax, in contradistinction, have a partially ossified cartilaginous rod<tei:lb/>joining the palatine to the maxilla. Further study is necessary to determine whether this onto-<tei:lb/>genetically variable ossification, termed the submaxilla by Daget (1961), is a defining character<tei:lb/>for the genus or some subunit of it.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In distichodontids, other than Xenocharax, Nannaethiops, Neolebias and Paradistichodus, the<tei:lb/>mesopterygoid is more tightly joined to the lateral ethmoid than in the hypothesized plesio-<tei:lb/>morphous condition. Furthermore, the palatine in these genera is distinctly more enveloped by<tei:lb/>the ectopterygoid and mesopterygoid than in the generalized state. This trend is most pronounced<tei:lb/>in Ichthyborus and the unit formed by Mesoborus, Eugnatichthys, Paraphago, Phago and Belono-<tei:lb/>phago which have a reduced palatine fitting into a depression along the dorsal surface of the<tei:lb/>ectopterygoid and lacking the plesiomorphous ligamentous attachment to the maxilla.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Finally, it should be noted that the quadrate and palatine have been found to be separate in all<tei:lb/>Paradistichodus specimens examined, contrary to Daget (1968, Fig. 10) who illustrated these<tei:lb/>elements are fused.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In summary, derived characters in the suspensorium of the citharinids and distichodontids<tei:lb/>are:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 the anterior position of the articulation of the angulo-articular and quadrate in all<tei:lb/>distichodontids other than Xenocharax, Neolebias and Nannaethiops.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 the broadened hyomandibula in Hemigrammocharax and Nannocharax.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3 the slender, anteriorly concave hyomandibula in Ichthyborus, Microstomatichthyoborus,<tei:lb/>Mesoborus, Eugnatichthys, Paraphago, Phago and Belonophago.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>4 the dorsolateral and dorsomedial hyomandibular processes present in various dis-<tei:lb/>tichodontids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5 the groove on the posterior surface of the hyomandibula in Mesoborus, Eugnatichthys,<tei:lb/>Paraphago, Phago and Belonophago.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>6 the lateral horizontal preopercular shelf in all distichodontids other than Xenocharax,<tei:lb/>Nannaethiops and Neolebias. This shelf is most distinctly developed, both posteriorly<tei:lb/>and laterally, in Ichthyborus, Microstomatichthyoborus, Mesoborus, Eugnatichthys,<tei:lb/>Paraphago, Phago and Belonophago.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 the medial shift of the laterosensory canal segment in the vertical arm of the preopercle<tei:lb/>in Ichthyborus, Microstomatichthyoborus, Mesoborus, Eugnatichthys, Paraphago, Phago<tei:lb/>and Belonophago. This assemblage, with the exception of Ichthyborus, is also character-<tei:lb/>ized by the development laterally of a distinct posterodorsal preopercular flange.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>8 the reduction or loss of the metapterygoid-quadrate fenestra in Neolebias spilotaenia<tei:lb/>and the unit formed by Nannocharax and Hemigrammocharax.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>9 the elongate metapterygoid-quadrate fenestra of Ichthyborus, Mesoborus, Micro-<tei:lb/>stomatichthyoborus, Eugnatichthys, Paraphago, Phago and Belonophago.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>CLASSIFICATION OF CITHARINIDAE AND DISTICHODONTIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>295</tei:p>
         <tei:p>10 the two large cartilage pads between the palatine and upper jaw of citharinids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 1 the increased attachment of the palatine and mesopterygoid to the neurocranium in<tei:lb/>distichodontids other than Xenocharax, Neolebias, Nannaethiops and Paradistichodus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>12 the loss of the ligamentous connection between the palatine and the maxilla in<tei:lb/>Ichthyborus, Mesoborus, Eugnatichthys, Paraphago, Phago and Belonophago.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Opercle</tei:p>
         <tei:p>On the basis of outgroup comparisons, the plesiomorphous form of the opercle among characoids<tei:lb/>is hypothesized to be a flat and unfenestrated bone. Such an opercular form occurs in the<tei:lb/>distichodontid genus Xenocharax, but is variously modified in citharinids and all other dis-<tei:lb/>tichodontids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>B</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 19 Dorsal portion of the opercle of A. Citharinus citharus (dotted line denotes position of the<tei:lb/>suprapreopercle), B. Distichodus notospilus, left lateral view.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Laterally the opercle of Citharinus and Citharidium bears a prominent, anterodorsally oriented<tei:lb/>ridge aligned at an acute angle relative to the anterior border of the opercle (Fig. 19a). This<tei:lb/>ridge extends dorsally from the body of the opercle to the tip of the elongate anterodorsal corner<tei:lb/>of the bone. Such a lateral opercular ridge has not been encountered elsewhere among charcoids<tei:lb/>except in the Neotropical characoid family Curimatidae (Roberts, 1974). The opercular flange of<tei:lb/>curimatids differs, however, from that of citharinids in its less extensive vertical development,<tei:lb/>and in not extending to the anterodorsal edge of the bone.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Among distichodontids other than Xenocharax, the opercle undergoes a progressive<tei:lb/>fenestration. The simplest condition of this opening occurs in Nannaethiops and Neolebias<tei:lb/>which have a series of small, closely apposed holes extending through the opercle. These foramina,<tei:lb/>which are located slightly posterior to the facet for articulation with the hyomandibula, appear<tei:lb/>to be the precursors of the distinct opercular fenestra occupying this region in the remaining<tei:lb/>distichodontids with the exception of Xenocharax (Fig. 19b). As far as can be determined, neither<tei:lb/>this distinct fenestra nor the series of small openings in Nannaethiops and Neolebias serve for the<tei:lb/>passage of any nerves, blood vessels or muscle fibres. In Hemigrammocharax and Nannocharax<tei:lb/>the opercle is reduced dorsally with a consequent opening of the opercular fenestra to the dorsal<tei:lb/>margin of the bone. The resultant vertical slit separates the anterodorsal portion of the opercle,<tei:lb/>to which the dilator operculi muscles attach, from the posterodorsal plate-like portion of the bone.<tei:lb/>None of these forms of fenestrated opercle have been encountered elsewhere in characoids, or<tei:lb/>among the non-characoid ostariophysans examined. Consequently, these modifications are<tei:lb/>considered to represent apomorphous characters of varying levels of universality.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In summary, the hypothesized derived opercular characters among citharinids and dis-<tei:lb/>tichodontids are :</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 the prominent lateral opercular ridge in citharinids.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>296 R. P. VARI</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 the fenestrated opercle in all distichodontids other than Xenocharax. Three increasingly<tei:lb/>apomorphous forms of the opening occur in these genera:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(A) the series of small holes in Nannaethiops and Neolebias.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(B) the distinct fenestra of all distichodontids other than Nannaethiops, Neolebias and<tei:lb/>Xenocharax.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(C) the vertical slit along the dorsal margin of the opercle in Nannocharax and Hemi-<tei:lb/>grammocharax.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>sor</tei:p>
         <tei:p>psc</tei:p>
         <tei:p>spo</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 20</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Xenocharax spilurus, supraorbital, antorbital, infraorbitals, dermosphenotic, pterotic sensory<tei:lb/>canal and suprapreopercle, lateral view.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dermosphenotic, pterotic and suprapreopercle</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The general morphological diversity of the family Citharinidae and Distichodontidae is reflected<tei:lb/>in the overall structure and in the patterns of the sensory canals of the dermosphenotic, pterotic<tei:lb/>and suprapreopercle. Prior to a discussion of these characters, however, it is necessary to comment<tei:lb/>on the nomenclature of some of the sensory canal-bearing bones of the lateral edge of the skull.<tei:lb/>Daget, in a series of publications (1958-1968), distinguished the canal-bearing dermosphenotics<tei:lb/>and dermopterotics from the underlying sphenotics and pterotics. Similarly, Gregory (1933)<tei:lb/>and Gregory &amp; Conrad (1938) illustrate a separate dermosphenotic in Distichodus langi,<tei:lb/>Mesoborus and Phago, and distinguish the scale bone (the dermopterotic of Daget) from the<tei:lb/>underlying pterotic.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 21</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Citharidium ansorgei, supraorbital, antorbital, infraorbitals, dermosphenotic, pterotic<tei:lb/>sensory canal and suprapreopercle, lateral view.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>CLASSIFICATION OF CITHARINIDAE AND DISTICHODONTIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>297</tei:p>
         <tei:p>When present the dermosphenotic (or infraorbital 6) of characoids is independent throughout<tei:lb/>ontogeny from the underlying sphenotic. In light of such a separation, this element should<tei:lb/>obviously be recognized as a distinct bone, the dermosphenotic. However, in none of the<tei:lb/>characoids examined are the pterotic (sensu stricto) and the lateral canal-bearing element (Daget's<tei:lb/>dermopterotic and Gregory &amp; Conrad's scale bone) separate elements. Neither has such a<tei:lb/>separation been reported in the literature for any adult characoid. Indeed, a separate dermo-<tei:lb/>pterotic is rare among teleosts (Patterson, 1977, p. 97). Although these elements arise indepen-<tei:lb/>dently from cartilaginous and intramembranous elements (Weitzman, 1962, p. 25) they fuse<tei:lb/>early in ontogeny and I will follow Weitzman in considering the resultant bone as a single unit,<tei:lb/>the pterotic. The pterotic in this sense is equivalent to the pterotic plus scale bone of Gregory &amp;<tei:lb/>Conrad, and the pterotic plus dermopterotic of Daget.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ant</tei:p>
         <tei:p>spo</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 22</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paradistichodus dimidiatus, supraorbital, antorbital, infraorbitals, dermosphenotic, pterotic<tei:lb/>sensory canal and suprapreopercle, lateral view.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Within the families Citharinidae and Distichodontidae four main patterns of the dermo-<tei:lb/>sphenotic and pterotic and of their relationships to the infraorbitals and supraperopercle can be<tei:lb/>discerned. On the basis of outgroup comparisons, the plesiomorphous form of these bones and<tei:lb/>the associated canals among characoids appears to be similar to that of Xenocharax (Fig. 20).<tei:lb/>The moderately sized dermosphenotic completely roofs over the dilatator fossa and carries a<tei:lb/>Y-shaped segment of the laterosensory canal system. The ventral segment of the dermosphenotic<tei:lb/>sensory canal communicates with that of the fifth infraorbital, the anterior branch with the<tei:lb/>supraorbital sensory canal of the frontal and the posterodorsal section with the pterotic sensory<tei:lb/>canal. The pterotic, in turn, is broadly exposed laterally and bears a trifurcate sensory canal<tei:lb/>system. The anterior branch of the pterotic sensory canal contacts the posterior portion of the<tei:lb/>dermosphenotic sensory canal, the posterior segment communicates with the extrascapular<tei:lb/>sensory canal, and the ventral branch receives the preopercular sensory canal by way of the<tei:lb/>suprapreopercle.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ant</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 23</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ichthyborus besse, supraorbital, antorbital, infraorbitals, dermosphenotic, pterotic sensory<tei:lb/>canal and suprapreopercle, lateral view.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>298 R. P. VARI</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The remaining genera in the families Citharinidae and Distichodontidae exhibit a series of<tei:lb/>apomorphous modifications of the above plan of these bones and sensory canals. Citharinus and<tei:lb/>Citharidium, although retaining the plesiomorphous sensory canal pattern, have greatly reduced<tei:lb/>the dermosphenotic into a tube-like element which no longer contacts the edges of the dilatator<tei:lb/>fossa and only partially covers the lateral surface of the dilatator operculi muscle (Fig. 21). In<tei:lb/>contradistinction, in all distichodontids other than Xenocharax, the dermosphenotic, when<tei:lb/>present, is posteriorly expanded relative to the hypothesized plesiomorphous condition. As a<tei:lb/>consequence of this expansion, the dermosphenotic overlaps much of the primitively exposed<tei:lb/>lateral surface of the pterotic and separates the suprapreopercle from its direct contact with the<tei:lb/>pterotic laterosensory canal system (see below with respect to Nannaethiops and Neolebias).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>spo</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 24 Phago intermedius, antorbital, infraorbitals, dermosphenotic, pterotic sensory canal and</tei:p>
         <tei:p>suprapreopercle, lateral view.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This shift of the contact of the suprapreopercle and the expansion of the dermosphenotic results<tei:lb/>in a marked change in the sensory canal system in these bones. Whereas the dermosphenotic<tei:lb/>sensory canal is bifurcate anteriorly as in Xenocharax, the posterior branch of the canal is drawn<tei:lb/>out along the horizontally elongate dermosphenotic and bifurcates posteriorly (Figs 22, 23, 24).<tei:lb/>As a consequence the posteroventral branch of the canal contacts the dorsal tip of the supra-<tei:lb/>preopercle while the posterodorsal segment communicates with the pterotic sensory canal.<tei:lb/>This expansion of the dermosphenotic sensory canal results in a horizontally elongate, somewhat<tei:lb/>H-shaped system. Outgroup comparisons among characoids have failed to reveal a comparable<tei:lb/>posterior expansion of the dermosphenotic. Neither have there been discovered any other<tei:lb/>characoids in which the dermosphenotic directly communicates both with the infraorbital and<tei:lb/>preopercular sensory canal systems. Furthermore, the reduced lateral exposure of the pterotic<tei:lb/>and the shift in the contact of the suprapreopercle has resulted in a pronounced reduction of the<tei:lb/>pterotic sensory canal segment. Rather than the plesiomorphous Y-shaped system of most<tei:lb/>characoids, in these genera the pterotic laterosensory canal is a simple, short tube joining the<tei:lb/>dermosphenotic and the extrascapular sensory canals. Such a reduction is particularly pronounced<tei:lb/>in Mesoborus, Eugnatichthys, Paraphago, Phago and Belonophago in which the laterally exposed<tei:lb/>portion of the pterotic is a small wedge of bone between the rear of the dermosphenotic and the<tei:lb/>margin of the extrascapular.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Autapomorphous modifications of the above form of dermosphenotic and of the associated<tei:lb/>laterosensory canals characterize several subunits of the assemblage having this pattern of these<tei:lb/>bones. In Ichthyborus the dermosphenotic is shifted posterodorsally and thus is totally removed<tei:lb/>from the orbital rim. This shift, along with the dorsal elongation of the suprapreopercle in this<tei:lb/>genus, is reflected in the posteroventral reduction of the dermosphenotic and in the shortening<tei:lb/>of the posterodorsal and posteroventral portions of the dermosphenotic sensory canal system<tei:lb/>(Fig. 23). In Paraphago, in contrast, the dermosphenotic is somewhat expanded ventrally. This</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>CLASSIFICATION OF CITHARINIDAE AND DISTICHODONTIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>299</tei:p>
         <tei:p>expansion is a precursor of the markedly expanded dermosphenotic in Phago and Belonophago<tei:lb/>where the large plate-like bone extends ventrally midway along the posterior rim of the orbit<tei:lb/>(Fig. 24). The enlarged dermosphenotic of Belonophago is autapomorphously further modified<tei:lb/>by the total loss of its sensory canal system.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>sor</tei:p>
         <tei:p>spo</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 25 Nannaethiops unitaeniatus, supraorbital, antorbital, infraorbitals, dermosphenotic, pterotic<tei:lb/>sensory canal and suprapreopercle, lateral view.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The monophyletic unit formed by Nannaethiops and Neolebias is characterized by a progressive<tei:lb/>apomorphic reduction of the dermosphenotic and pterotic sensory canals common to disticho-<tei:lb/>dontids other than Xenocharax. The least pronounced reduction is found in Nannaethiops<tei:lb/>unitaeniatus (Fig. 25) which has a slight shortening of the posteroventral branch of the dermo-<tei:lb/>sphenotic sensory canal. The reduction of this canal segment, which primitively communicates<tei:lb/>with the suprapreopercle, is congruent with the loss of the suprapreopercular sensory canal in<tei:lb/>Nannaethiops and Neolebias (see discussion on the suprapreopercle). The dermosphenotic,<tei:lb/>pterotic and their sensory canals in Neolebias unifasciatus (see Daget, 1965, Fig. 7) and N.<tei:lb/>trewavasae are similar to that of Nannaethiops other than for the pronounced reduction or loss<tei:lb/>of the anterodorsal and posterodorsal branches of the dermosphenotic sensory canal system.<tei:lb/>Apomorphic reduction of the dermosphenotic laterosensory canals is further advanced in N.<tei:lb/>trilineatus, N. bidentatus and N. axelrodi where the sensory canals of the dermosphenotic and<tei:lb/>pterotic are totally lacking. This reductional trend reaches its terminal stage in N. spilotaenia<tei:lb/>in which the dermosphenotic is lost, together with that portion of the pterotic which plesio-<tei:lb/>morphously carries the pterotic sensory canal segment. These progressive reductions of the<tei:lb/>dermosphenotic sensory canals and the eventual loss of the bone itself are considered to be a<tei:lb/>series of derived characters of decreasing levels of universality (see the Phylogenetic analysis).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The marked modifications of the dermosphenotic and pterotic described above appear to have<tei:lb/>resulted in several misinterpretations of distichodontid skull osteology by Gregory &amp; Conrad.<tei:lb/>In their figure of the skull of Phago (1938, Fig. 35) those authors illustrate the dermosphenotic<tei:lb/>and pterotic as part of a single ossification. The bone indicated is, however, the dermosphenotic<tei:lb/>which almost totally overlaps the pterotic in this genus. The exposed portion of the pterotic is<tei:lb/>actually the small scale bone of those workers. The same authors in their drawing of the skull of<tei:lb/>Mesoborus (1938, Fig. 34), show an unlabelled dermosphenotic which incorporates the sensory<tei:lb/>canals of the pterotic and extrascapular along its posterodorsal margin. Examination of this<tei:lb/>species, however, shows that these sensory canals are actually separate tubes in their respective<tei:lb/>bones.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In the course of the above discussion, it was noted that the preopercular sensory canal of<tei:lb/>citharinids and distichodontids communicates with the sensory canal system of the pterotic or<tei:lb/>expanded dermosphenotic by way of an ossified suprapreopercle. Such a canal-bearing supra-<tei:lb/>preopercle or a derived form of the bone is common to all citharinids and distichodontids other</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>300 R. P. VARI</tei:p>
         <tei:p>than some Neolebias species in which it is hypothesized to be secondarily lost (see below). The<tei:lb/>possession of a suprapreopercle would appear apomorphous in characoids although occurring<tei:lb/>in a variety of ostariophysan groups. Despite the uncertainty on the exact distribution of this<tei:lb/>element and on the interrelationships of the groups possessing it, at the least, the common<tei:lb/>possession of this element is congruent with the hypothesized monophyletic nature of the unit<tei:lb/>formed by the families Citharinidae and Distichodontidae. In its simplest form the suprapre-<tei:lb/>opercle is a bony tube extending from the dorsal opening of the preopercular sensory canal to the<tei:lb/>sensory canal system of the pterotic or dermosphenotic. Such a suprapreopercular form, which<tei:lb/>represents an ossification of the primitively unossified tube joining these systems, is modified in<tei:lb/>the Citharinidae and subunits of the Distichodontidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In Citharinus and Citharidium the elongate tube-like suprapreopercle extends over the lateral<tei:lb/>surface of the anterodorsal corner of the opercle (Fig. 21). Such a transversing of the opercle by<tei:lb/>the suprapreopercle has not been encountered elsewhere among characoids examined and thus<tei:lb/>appears autapomorphous for these genera. Among distichodontids the plesiomorphous tubular<tei:lb/>suprapreopercle is modified in several distinctive apomorphous modes. The simplest of these<tei:lb/>adaptations occurs in Ichthyborus besse where the suprapreopercle bears anterodorsal and postero-<tei:lb/>dorsal flanges that give it a somewhat triangular form (Fig. 23). In Xenocharax, in contrast, the<tei:lb/>suprapreopercle retains its basically tubular shape, but is subdivided horizontally into two short<tei:lb/>tubes (Fig. 20). The remaining and most radical restructuring of the suprapreopercle occurs in<tei:lb/>Nannaethiops and Neolebias. As illustrated in Fig. 25 for Nannaethiops unitaeniatus these genera<tei:lb/>have an independent ossification fitting the posteroventrally concave border of the dermosphenotic<tei:lb/>(see also Daget, 1965, Fig. 7). Although it carries no sensory canal segment, this independent<tei:lb/>ossification is hypothesized to represent a highly modified suprapreopercle. Such an hypothesis is<tei:lb/>congruent with its location in the region primitively occupied by the plesiomorphous tubular<tei:lb/>suprapreopercle. Furthermore, this element contacts the posteroventral dermosphenotic sensory<tei:lb/>canal segment which plesiomorphously communicates with the suprapreopercle. In light of this<tei:lb/>association and the relative position of the element, it is most parsimonious to assume that this<tei:lb/>plate-like, non-canal-bearing element is homologous with the tubular suprapreopercle of<tei:lb/>citharinids and other distichodontids. This flattened suprapreopercle is lost, evidently secondarily,<tei:lb/>in Neolebias spilotaenia which is characterized by an extreme reduction of various dermal elements<tei:lb/>of the skull.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Daget, in his illustration of Neolebias unifasciatus (1965, Fig. 7), identified the element herein<tei:lb/>considered the suprapreopercle as an infraorbital (the postorbital of Daget). It would appear that<tei:lb/>Daget believed this bone to be a posteriorly shifted fourth or fifth infraorbital. Such an homology<tei:lb/>would give a full series of five infraorbitals plus the dermosphenotic for the species.
