However,<tei:lb/>the identification of this independent ossification as an infraorbital appears erroneous if we<tei:lb/>examine the infraorbital series of Neolebias trewavasae and Nannaethiops unitaeniatus (Fig. 25).<tei:lb/>These species, which have the infraorbital reductional trends characteristic of these genera least<tei:lb/>pronounced, retain a full series of infraorbitals in addition to the independent ossification termed<tei:lb/>an infraorbital by Daget. In light of this condition and the previously discussed information<tei:lb/>indicating that the independent ossification is a modified suprapreopercle, the identification of the<tei:lb/>element as an infraorbital is herein considered incorrect.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hypothesized apomorphic states of the dermosphenotic, pterotic, suprapreopercle and their<tei:lb/>associated sensory canals among citharinids and distichodintids are:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 the reduced tubular dermosphenotic of citharinids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 the posterior expansion of the dermosphenotic in all distichodontids other than<tei:lb/>Xenocharax. These genera have a congruent reduction of the laterally exposed portion<tei:lb/>of the pterotic and a shift of the contact of the suprapreopercular sensory canal to the<tei:lb/>dermosphenotic.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3 the posterodorsal shift of the dermosphenotic in Ichthyborus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>4 the ventral expansion of the dermosphenotic in Paraphago, Phago and Belonophago.<tei:lb/>This expansion is particularly pronounced in the last two genera.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5 the loss of the dermosphenotic sensory canal system in Belonophago.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>CLASSIFICATION OF CITHARINIDAE AND DISTICHODONTIDAE 301</tei:p>
         <tei:p>6 the progressive reduction of the dermosphenotic and pterotic sensory canal systems in</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Nannaethiops and Neolebias.<tei:lb/>1 the suprapreopercle common to citharinids and distichodontids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>8 the subdivision of the suprapreopercle in Xenocharax.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>9 the extension of the suprapreopercle across the opercle in citharinids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>10 the modification of the dermosphenotic into a flat, non-canal-bearing plate in Neolebias<tei:lb/>and Nannaethiops.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Supraorbital and infraorbitals</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The hypothetical plesiomorphous infraorbital series for characoids consists of a chain of six<tei:lb/>canal-bearing bones (a dermosphenotic and five infraorbitals) which, together with the supra-<tei:lb/>orbital, form a bony rim to the orbit. The modifications of the dermosphenotic (infraorbital 6)<tei:lb/>and its associated sensory canals were discussed in the previous section. Reductions, expansions<tei:lb/>and losses of the supraorbital, infraorbitals 1 to 5 and the infraorbital sensory canal system<tei:lb/>characterize subunits of varying levels of universality among distichodontids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A large supraorbital forming the anterodorsal portion of the orbital rim is common to<tei:lb/>Citharinus and Citharidium (Fig. 21). Although somewhat enlarged relative to that of many<tei:lb/>characoids, the citharinid form of supraorbital nonetheless appears to be plesiomorphous among<tei:lb/>citharinids and distichodontids in forming a large portion of the anterodorsal rim of the orbit and<tei:lb/>in extending beyond the posterior margin of the lateral ethmoid. The distichodontid genera<tei:lb/>Xenocharax (Fig. 20), Nannaethiops, Neolebias, Paradistichodus (Fig. 22), Distichodus, Nanno-<tei:lb/>charax, Hemigrammocharax, Hemistichodus and Ichthyborus (Fig. 23) differ from citharinids<tei:lb/>and the generalized characoid condition in having an anteriorly shifted supraorbital which is<tei:lb/>variously reduced. The remaining distichodontid genera, in turn, have the supraorbital totally<tei:lb/>lacking, a loss that is considered apomorphous within distichodontids (in Neolebias spilotaenia,<tei:lb/>a supraorbital ossification was found only in the largest specimens examined). Although David &amp;<tei:lb/>Poll's illustration (1937, Fig. 9) of the jaws and dermal bones of the anterior portion of the<tei:lb/>head of Microstomatichthyoborus bashforddeani and M. katangae includes a prominent 'supra-<tei:lb/>orbital', examination of these species has shown that those 'supraorbitals' are actually the<tei:lb/>antorbitals.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Subunits of the Distichodontidae also differ in the total number of infraorbitals, their relative<tei:lb/>sizes and the extent of the infraorbital sensory canal system. Three different types of reduction<tei:lb/>from a full series of five canal-bearing infraorbitals are discernable in different subunits of the<tei:lb/>family (see the previous section for a discussion of the variation in the dermosphenotic, infra-<tei:lb/>orbital 6). Two of these reductions result in a partially unossified orbital rim, while the third<tei:lb/>retains a continuous infraorbital series.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The first of these modifications to be discussed is the progressive reduction of the infraorbital<tei:lb/>series within the genus Neolebias. Neolebias trewavasae has a full series of five infraorbitals, with<tei:lb/>two elements (infraorbitals 4 and 5) forming the posterior rim of the orbit. In N. unifasciatus<tei:lb/>and N. bidentatus, in contrast, there is only a single infraorbital at the rear of the orbit, with<tei:lb/>the remaining elements shifted so as to retain a fully ossified orbital rim (see Daget, 1965, Fig.<tei:lb/>7). The remaining infraorbital at the posterior margin of the orbit is lost in N. trilineatus, N.<tei:lb/>ansorgei, N. axelrodi and N. spilotaenia in which the posterior orbital border is unossified. This<tei:lb/>reductional trend reaches its terminal stage in N. spilotaenia which additionally lacks infraorbitals<tei:lb/>2 and 3 and the sensory canal segment in infraorbital 1. The progressive reduction of the infra-<tei:lb/>orbital series from a chain of five canal-bearing elements to a single non-canal-bearing bone is<tei:lb/>considered to represent a series of derived reductional characters of varying levels of universality,<tei:lb/>and is congruent with the overall reduction of the dermal skull elements in these genera.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The second reduction of the infraorbital series among distichodontids occurs in Nannocharax<tei:lb/>and Hemigrammocharax. In Nannocharax multifasciatus, N.fasciatus (Daget, 1961, Fig. 7) and<tei:lb/>Hemigrammocharax wittei the fourth and fifth infraorbitals are reduced to two bony tubes dorsal<tei:lb/>to an expanded third infraorbital. In contrast, the specimens of Nannocharax niloticus, N.<tei:lb/>ansorgei, N. gobioides, N. intermedius, Hemigrammocharax machadoi and H. polli examined have</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>302 R. P. VARI</tei:p>
         <tei:p>infraorbitals 4 and 5 totally lacking. Although this reduction results in an unossified posterior<tei:lb/>orbital border similar to that in some Neolebias species, the phylogenetic sequence of the<tei:lb/>reductions and losses leading up to this condition differ significantly from that in Neolebias.<tei:lb/>Consequently, the unossified posterior orbital rim in the listed Nannocharax and Hemigram-<tei:lb/>mocharax species and that of the previously noted Neolebias species are considered to be non-<tei:lb/>homologous.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ant</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1mm</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 26 Eugnatichthys eetveldii, antorbital, infraorbitals, dermosphenotic, pterotic sensory canal</tei:p>
         <tei:p>and suprapreopercle, lateral view.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The final reductional transition scries of the infraorbitals among distichodontids occurs within<tei:lb/>the assemblage consisting of Ichthyborus, Microstomatichthyoborus, Mesoborus, Eugnatichthys,<tei:lb/>Paraphago, Phago and Belonophago. Contrary to the hypothesized plesiomorphous condition<tei:lb/>of an infraorbital series with five elements, these genera are characterized by a maximum of four<tei:lb/>infraorbitals. This reduced infraorbital count appears to be a consequence of the loss of an<tei:lb/>infraorbital at the posterior margin of the orbit. The exact homology of the remaining element,<tei:lb/>that is whether it represents the plesiomorphous infraorbital 4, infraorbital 5 or a fusion of these<tei:lb/>bones, is uncertain. However, for simplicity in the following discussion the bone is arbitrarily<tei:lb/>termed infraorbital 4. Within this assemblage, Ichthyborus (Fig. 23) has a relatively narrow<tei:lb/>infraorbital series, but with infraorbital 4 expanded posterodorsally so as to separate distinctly<tei:lb/>the dermosphenotic from the orbital rim. In contrast, Microstomatichthyoborus, Mesoborus,<tei:lb/>Eugnatichthys (Fig. 26), Paraphago, Phago (Fig. 24) and Belonophago have the posterior infra-<tei:lb/>orbital elements widened, with infraorbital 3 expanded posteriorly so as to cover a major portion<tei:lb/>of the cheek. Anteroventrally infraorbital 3 is produced into a distinct process extending ventral<tei:lb/>to infraorbital 2 and almost to the vertical through the articular condyle of the quadrate. Within<tei:lb/>this assemblage Paraphago has the fourth infraorbital reduced to a narrow, horizontally elongate<tei:lb/>element and it is completely lacking in Phago (Fig. 24) and Belonophago. As a consequence of<tei:lb/>these changes the enlarged third infraorbital of Phago and Belonophago completely covers the<tei:lb/>cheek and is in direct contact dorsally with the expanded dermosphenotic. Among members of<tei:lb/>these families, the enlarged third infraorbital in Belonophago is also unique in its total lack of a<tei:lb/>sensory canal segment. The loss of infraorbitals 4 and 5 in these genera differs from that among the<tei:lb/>previously described Neolebias, Nannocharax and Hemigrammocharax species in that the ex-<tei:lb/>pansion of the remaining infraorbitals fills the space primitively occupied by the missing elements,<tei:lb/>and a fully ossified orbital rim is thus retained.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Two differences between the observations of this study and those of Gregory &amp; Conrad (1938)<tei:lb/>and Daget (1968) should be noted. In their illustration of the skull of Mesoborus, Gregory &amp;<tei:lb/>Conrad (1938, Fig. 34) show a single infraorbital (the suborbital of those authors) in the region<tei:lb/>plesiomorphously occupied by infraorbitals 1 and 2. However, examination of the specimen<tei:lb/>probably illustrated by those workers, along with other Mesoborus material, shows there to be<tei:lb/>two distinct infraorbitals preceding the expanded infraorbital 3. Similarly, Daget (1968, Fig. 4)</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>CLASSIFICATION OF CITHARINIDAE AND DISTICHODONTIDAE 303</tei:p>
         <tei:p>in his illustration of the skull of Hemistichodus vaillanti shows a single large infraorbital in the<tei:lb/>region normally occupied by infraorbitals 2 and 3. However, all specimens of the three nominal<tei:lb/>Hemistichodus species examined have the second and third infraorbitals as separate elements.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In summary, hypothesized apomorphous supraorbital and infraorbital characters among<tei:lb/>distichodontids are:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 the reduction and anterior shift of the supraorbital in Xenocharax, Nannaethiops,<tei:lb/>Neolebias, Paradistichodus, Distichodus, Nannocharax, Hemigrammocharax and<tei:lb/>Ichthyborus. This reduction is a precursor of the further apomorphous loss of the<tei:lb/>element in Microstomatichthyoborus, Mesoborus, Eugnatichthys, Paraphago, Phago and<tei:lb/>Belonophago.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 the reduction to a single infraorbital at the rear of the orbit in Neolebias unifasciatus<tei:lb/>and N. bidentatus, with the remaining element lost in N. trilineatus, N. ansorgei, N.<tei:lb/>axelrodi and N. spilotaenia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3 the loss of infraorbitals 2 and 3 and the sensory canal of infraorbital 1 in N. spilotaenia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>4 the reduction of infraorbitals 4 and 5 to bony tubes or a loss of these elements in<tei:lb/>Nannocharax and Hemigrammocharax.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5 the loss of infraorbital 5 in Ichthyborus, Microstomatichthyoborus, Mesoborus, Eugna-<tei:lb/>tichthys, Paraphago, Phago and Belonophago.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>6 the expansion of infraorbital 4 to exclude the dermosphenotic from the orbital rim in<tei:lb/>Ichthyborus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>7 the reduction of infraorbital 4 in Paraphago and its loss in Phago and Belonophago.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>8 the loss of the sensory canal segment of infraorbital 3 in Belonophago.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>9 the anterior and posterior expansion of infraorbital 3 in Microstomatichthyoborus,<tei:lb/>Eugnatichthys, Mesoborus, Paraphago, Phago and Belonophago.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Branchial apparatus</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The morphology of the branchial apparatus among members of the families Citharinidae and<tei:lb/>Distichodontidae demonstrates a significant degree of variation for a system that is otherwise<tei:lb/>rather stable among characoids. Major branchial apparatus modifications occur in Citharinus<tei:lb/>and Citharidium, whereas less pronounced adaptations distinguish various distichodontid sub-<tei:lb/>units.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The fifth ceratobranchial (lower pharyngeal) of citharinids is highly modified with respect to<tei:lb/>the relatively flat, anteromedially tooth-bearing elements common to most characoids. In<tei:lb/>Citharinus and Citharidium the medial portion of the fifth ceratobranchial is a dorsally bulbous,<tei:lb/>highly fenestrated structure bearing only a few greatly reduced, loosely attached teeth (Fig. 27).<tei:lb/>These genera also demonstrate a comparable reduction and modification of the upper pharyngeal<tei:lb/>tooth plates and their associated dentition. Among most characoids, the fourth epibranchial<tei:lb/>and cartilaginous fourth pharyngobranchial articulate with the tooth-bearing fourth and fifth<tei:lb/>upper pharyngeal tooth plates respectively (see Rosen, 1973, Fig. 3). In contradistinction,<tei:lb/>citharinids either have the upper pharyngeal dentition totally lacking or reduced to a few loosely-<tei:lb/>attached minute spicules. More significantly, the fourth and fifth upper pharyngeal tooth plates<tei:lb/>of citharinids are fused to form an elongate bony plate (Fig. 28). Such a distinctive upper pharyn-<tei:lb/>geal ossification has not been encountered elsewhere among characoids and would appear to be<tei:lb/>apomorphous, as is its edentulous nature. Similarly, the highly modified lower pharyngeals of<tei:lb/>Citharinus and Citharidium are, as best as can be determined, autapomorphous for these genera<tei:lb/>among characoids. Further apomorphic characters in the branchial apparatus of citharinids<tei:lb/>include their loss of the first pharyngobranchial and the elongation and reorientation of the<tei:lb/>second and third pharyngobranchials. These alterations result in a close approximation of the<tei:lb/>tips of the first epibranchial and the second and third pharyngobranchials.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The marked restructuring of the branchial apparatus among citharinids would seem to be an<tei:lb/>adaptation to their filter-feeding mode of life. An additional gill arch character congruent with<tei:lb/>this feeding method is the presence of micro-gillrakers in all citharinids. Micro-gillrakers are a<tei:lb/>series of parallel bands of small, bony spicules located along both faces of the gill arch between</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>304</tei:p>
         <tei:p>R. P. VARI</tei:p>
         <tei:p>the gillrakers and gill filaments (Gosse, 1956; Daget, 1962). On the basis of our present knowledge<tei:lb/>on micro-gillraker distribution, it appears that these structures are unique to citharinids among<tei:lb/>characoids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1mm<tei:lb/>Fig. 27 Citharidium ansorgei, fifth ceratobranchial, right side, medial portion enlarged, dorsal view.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Alterations of the branchial apparatus among distichodontids are not as radical as those in<tei:lb/>citharinids and are primarily reductional. In most Neolebias species the fourth upper pharyngeal<tei:lb/>tooth plate is slightly ossified, with this element and its associated dentition totally lacking in N.<tei:lb/>spilotaenia (Fig. 29). Furthermore, in N. spilotaenia the fifth upper pharyngeal tooth plate is a<tei:lb/>reduced rounded ossification bearing approximately only six teeth. Similarly, the tooth-bearing<tei:lb/>portion of the lower pharyngeals is reduced to a small ovoid patch with a correlated reduction in<tei:lb/>the number of teeth.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pb</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 28 Citharidium ansorgei, gill arches, dorsal parts of right side, ventral view.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>An ossified fourth upper pharyngeal tooth plate and its associated dentition is also lacking in<tei:lb/>Hemigrammocharax machadoi, Nannocharax fasciatus and N. niloticus. However, based on the<tei:lb/>most parsimonious reconstruction of the phylogeny of citharinids and distichodontids, this loss<tei:lb/>is considered to have occurred independently of that in Neolebias. Furthermore, it is noteworthy<tei:lb/>that the lack of a fourth upper pharyngeal tooth plate is not universal within Nannocharax.<tei:lb/>Nannocharax intermedius has a small, slightly ossified fourth upper pharyngeal tooth plate,</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>CLASSIFICATION OF CITHARINIDAE AND DISTICHODONTIDAE 305</tei:p>
         <tei:p>whereas TV. gobioides and N. ansorgei have a larger but still reduced form of the bone. The resolu-<tei:lb/>tion of the question of whether this variation in the extent of the ossification of this element<tei:lb/>represents a phylogenetic reductional trend within the genus or whether it is a function of<tei:lb/>ontogenetic variation awaits further study.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>up.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 29 Neolebias spilotaenia, gill arches, dorsal parts of right side, ventral view.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Among the remaining distichodontid genera no alterations of branchial apparatus structure<tei:lb/>have been found. However, congruent with their restructured neurocranial form, Ichthyborus,<tei:lb/>Microstomatichthyoborus, Mesoborus, Eugnatichthys, Paraphago, Phago and Belonophago have<tei:lb/>a posterior shift in the attachment of the suspensory pharyngeals to the neurocranium. Within<tei:lb/>this assemblage Mesoborus, Eugnatichthys, Paraphago, Phago and Belonophago have an additional<tei:lb/>shift of this attachment ventrally, a trend that is most pronounced in the latter four genera where<tei:lb/>the pharyngeal attachment is to the previously described median parasphenoid ridge. It would<tei:lb/>appear that these shifts of gill arch attachment in these genera are a function of the extension of<tei:lb/>the adductor mandibulae muscle onto the medial surface of the hyomandibula and its expansion<tei:lb/>into regions plesiomorphously occupied by the branchial apparatus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In summary, hypothesized derived states of the branchial apparatus among citharinids and<tei:lb/>distichodontids are :</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 the highly fenestrated, dorsally bulbous, nearly edentulous lower pharyngeal in<tei:lb/>citharinids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 the fusion of the fourth and fifth upper pharyngeal tooth plates in citharinids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3 the loss of the first pharyngobranchial and the anterior elongation of the second and third<tei:lb/>pharyngobranchials in citharinids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>4 the loss of the fourth upper pharyngeal tooth plate and its associated dentition in<tei:lb/>Neolebias spilotaenia. This species also demonstrates a reduction of the fifth upper<tei:lb/>pharyngeal tooth plate and of the dentition associated with that element and the fifth<tei:lb/>ceratobranchial.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5 the micro-gillrakers in citharinids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>6 the reduction or loss of the fourth upper pharyngeal tooth plate in various Nannocharax<tei:lb/>and Hemigrammocharax species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>7 the posterior shift of the attachment of the suspensory pharyngeals in Ichthyborus,<tei:lb/>Microstomatichthyoborus, Mesoborus, Eugnatichthys, Paraphago, Phago and Belonophago.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>8 the ventral shift of the suspensory pharyngeals onto the median parasphenoid ridge in<tei:lb/>Eugnatichthys, Paraphago, Phago and Belonophago.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Weberian apparatus</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The common possession of the Weberian apparatus, an otophysic connection between the<tei:lb/>anterior chamber of the swimbladder and the middle ear, characterizes the series Otophysi of</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>306 R. P. VARI</tei:p>
         <tei:p>the superorder Ostariophysi (Rosen &amp; Greenwood, 1970). The Weberian apparatus is composed<tei:lb/>of the Weberian ossicles (the pars auditum) and their supporting vertebrae (the pars sus-<tei:lb/>tentaculum). The Weberian ossicles are four small bones, the tripus, intercalarium, scaphium<tei:lb/>and claustram (the intercalarium and claustrum are lacking in some groups), that are joined<tei:lb/>by ligamentous bands and pivot on the anterior vertebrae. It is believed that vibrations induced<tei:lb/>in the anterior chamber of the swimbladder by soundwaves in the surrounding medium are<tei:lb/>transmitted by these ossicles to the middle ear, thereby aiding in sound reception (see Alexander,<tei:lb/>1966, for a discussion of the mechanism). The pars sustentaculum is derived from the four or<tei:lb/>more anterior vertebrae and serves as a base for the Weberian ossicles and the shortened first<tei:lb/>pleural rib. In the generalized characoid condition the vertebrae of the pars sustentaculum are</tei:p>
         <tei:p>QS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>v \</tei:p>
         <tei:p>vpv</tei:p>
         <tei:p>cts v / V p v</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1mm</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 30 Nannaethiops unitaeniatus, posteroventral section of neurocranium, ventral portion of pars<tei:lb/>sustentaculum and connective tissue sheath, left lateral view, Weberian ossicles removed.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ventrally unfused and unmodified, with the fourth vertebrae bearing a pair of shortened,<tei:lb/>modified pleural ribs. Arising from the medial surface of each of these ribs is a distinct process, the<tei:lb/>os suspensorium, which serves for the support and attachment of the peritoneal layer of the<tei:lb/>anterior swimbladder chamber. The dorsal aorta, which is in contact with the ventral surface of<tei:lb/>these vertebrae, is surrounded laterally and to varying degrees ventrally by the shortened first<tei:lb/>pleural rib and os suspensorium.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>All characoids examined have a triangular connective tissue system associated with the pars<tei:lb/>sustentaculum, the anterior section of the coeliac artery and the peritoneal covering of the anterior<tei:lb/>chamber of the swimbladder. This complex (Fig. 30) arises anterodorsally from the parasphenoid<tei:lb/>and basioccipital and posterodorsally from the os suspensorium. Dorsally it encompasses the<tei:lb/>dorsal aorta and anteriorly surrounds the anterior portion of the coeliac artery. The posterior<tei:lb/>section of this complex is formed by a medial thickening in the peritoneal covering over the<tei:lb/>anterior swimbladder chamber. This connective tissue band extends from the os suspensorium<tei:lb/>to the point of contact of the coeliac artery with the anterodorsal surface of the swimbladder<tei:lb/>chamber. Alexander (1962) applied the term 'coeliac sheath' to that portion of the system en-<tei:lb/>compassing the coeliac artery in the Neotropical characoid genus Leporinus. In the following<tei:lb/>discussion, however, the term sheath is applied to the entire complex, unless a specific section<tei:lb/>(e.g. coeliac sheath) is cited.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Although the Weberian apparatus, particularly portions of the pars sustentaculum, undergoes<tei:lb/>pronounced restructuring in various ostariophysan groups (see Alexander, 1962, \964a, 19646)<tei:lb/>it has been traditionally considered morphologically conservative among characoids. However,<tei:lb/>an examination of the Weberian apparatus in the families Citharinidae and Distichodontidae has<tei:lb/>revealed a series of modifications of the pars sustentaculum, os suspensorium and of their<tei:lb/>relationships to the connective tissue sheath. Four major types of modifications to this complex</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>CLASSIFICATION OF CITHARINIDAE AND DISTICHODONTIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>307</tei:p>
         <tei:p>are distinguishable in these families. These are hereafter termed the Nannaethiops, Citharinus,<tei:lb/>Xenocharax and Nannocharax types of pars sustentaculum.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Nannaethiops possesses the simplest form of modification to the pars sustentaculum and os<tei:lb/>suspensorium in the families Citharinidae and Distichodontidae. In the Nannaethiops type pars<tei:lb/>sustentaculum (Fig. 30) the second and third vertebrae bear paired, ventrally-directed projections<tei:lb/>arising from their ventrolateral borders, contrary to the plesiomorphous, ventrally unelaborated<tei:lb/>state of these bones. Furthermore, the os suspensorium in Nannaethiops is enlarged and extends<tei:lb/>anteriorly to contact the posterior margin of the ventral process of the third vertebra. The ventral<tei:lb/>projections of the second and third vertebrae, together with this anterior process of the os<tei:lb/>suspensorium, form a longitudinally orientated vertical wall lateral to the dorsal aorta. This</tei:p>
         <tei:p>bo</tei:p>
         <tei:p>cts</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ICO</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 31 Citharinus citharus, juvenile, posteroventral section of neurocranium, ventral portion of<tei:lb/>pars sustentaculum, connective tissue sheath and independent coeliac ossifications, left lateral view,<tei:lb/>Weberian ossicles removed.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>structure also serves as a broad area of attachment for the connective tissue sheath associated<tei:lb/>with the dorsal aorta and coeliac artery. Such adaptations, either in the Nannaethiops form or<tei:lb/>further derived states, are common to all species of the families Citharinidae and Distichodon-<tei:lb/>tidae. On the basis of their unique nature within characoids these modifications are hypothesized<tei:lb/>as being synapomorphous for these families.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>As noted previously, the Nannaethiops type of pars sustentaculum and os suspensorium is the<tei:lb/>ontogenetic precursor of more complex structures in citharinids and some other distichodontids.<tei:lb/>One of the more elaborate alterations of this system is common to Citharinus and Citharidium.<tei:lb/>In the smallest individuals of Citharinus examined, the pars sustentaculum is similar to the<tei:lb/>Nannaethiops type other than for the slightly more anteroventrally expanded os suspensorium<tei:lb/>and a pair of slight ossifications along the anterior surface of the coeliac sheath. Later in ontogeny,<tei:lb/>juveniles of Citharinus and Citharidium possess the pars sustentaculum and os suspensorium<tei:lb/>form illustrated in Fig. 31. The ventral processes of the second and third vertebrae are more<tei:lb/>anteroventrally produced than in the Nannaethiops pattern or earlier in ontogeny. Similarly,<tei:lb/>the os suspensorium is anteroventrally expanded into a prominent, ventrally-directed process<tei:lb/>that partially encompasses the connective tissue band on the anteromedial surface of the swim-<tei:lb/>bladder. The os suspensorium is also expanded anterodorsally to surround the lateral surface of<tei:lb/>the dorsal aorta and tightly contact the rear of the expanded ventral process of the third vertebrae</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>308</tei:p>
         <tei:p>R. P. VARI</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Finally, the coeliac sheath is encompassed anteroventrally by a prominent ossification derived<tei:lb/>from the independent ossifications present earlier in ontogeny.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>With increasing age the os suspensorium, the ventral process of the second and third vertebrae<tei:lb/>and the independent ossifications of the coeliac sheath coalesce with each other and with the<tei:lb/>posterior projections of the parasphenoid and ventral projections of the basioccipital. In large<tei:lb/>individuals of Citharinus and Citharidium this results in a triangular, highly ossified structure<tei:lb/>which corresponds in shape to, and largely replaces, the connective tissue sheath present earlier<tei:lb/>in ontogeny (Fig. 32). This complex is anteriorly continuous with the elongate posterior ramus<tei:lb/>of the parasphenoid and encompasses the dorsal aorta laterally, ventral to the first three vertebrae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 32 Citharinus citharus, adult, posteroventral section of neurocranium and ventral portion of<tei:lb/>pars sustentaculum complex, left lateral view, Weberian ossicles removed. The dotted line indicates<tei:lb/>the position of the anterior chamber of the swimbladder.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Similarly, the coeliac artery is surrounded laterally and ventrally from its divergence from the<tei:lb/>dorsal aorta to its point of contact with the peritoneal covering of the anterior chamber of the<tei:lb/>swimbladder. Posteriorly the third portion of this structure consists of a thick bony strut formed<tei:lb/>by a ventral projection of the os suspensorium. This portion of the complex serves as an expanded<tei:lb/>area of attachment for the peritoneal layer covering the anterior swimbladder chamber. These<tei:lb/>modifications of the pars sustentaculum and os suspensorium, together with the strong attachment<tei:lb/>of the neural process of the Weberian apparatus to the supraoccipital, eliminate any possibility<tei:lb/>of motion, either between the vertebrae forming the pars sustentaculum or between the pars<tei:lb/>sustentaculum and the skull. With increasing age, these ossifications expand further so that in the<tei:lb/>largest citharinid examined (a skull of Citharinus citharus, 170 mm from snout to rear of the<tei:lb/>fourth vertebrae) the processes surrounding the dorsal aorta and coeliac arterly are nearly in<tei:lb/>contact with their fellows along the internal midline of the complex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Examination of the Weberian apparatus in characoid outgroups has failed to reveal modifica-<tei:lb/>tions homologous to those of citharinids, nor have such adaptations been encountered among<tei:lb/>other ostariophysans. An analogous envelopment of the dorsal aorta and coeliac sheath has been<tei:lb/>found in the Neotropical characoid genera Anostomus, Leporinus, Schizodon and Laemolyta. In<tei:lb/>these genera the parasphenoid bears posteriorly-directed processes which laterally encompass<tei:lb/>the dorsal aorta ventral to the basioccipital and first vertebra. In large individuals of these genera,<tei:lb/>these parasphenoid processes extend posteroventrally along the lateral surface of the strongly</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>CLASSIFICATION OF CITHARINIDAE AND DISTICHODONTIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>309</tei:p>
         <tei:p>developed coeliac sheath, and an independent ossification overlies the dorsal aorta laterally<tei:lb/>under the first three vertebrae. Although similar in superficial form to those of citharinids, these<tei:lb/>ossifications in anostomids differ in their ontogenetic origins and are thus considered non-<tei:lb/>homologous with those of citharinids although synapomorphous for some or all anostomids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>bp</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 33</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1mm</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Xenocharax spilurus, posteroventral section of neurocranium and ventral portion of pars<tei:lb/>sustentaculum, left lateral view, Weberian ossicles removed.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The second apomorphous modification of the Nannaethiops type of pars sustentaculum and os<tei:lb/>suspensorium occurs in the monotypic distichodontid genus Xenocharax. In this species the<tei:lb/>longitudinal axis of the first four vertebrae is strongly angled posterodorsally with respect to the<tei:lb/>skull and anteroventrally relative to the longitudinal axis through the remaining abdominal<tei:lb/>vertebrae (Fig. 33). The shift in the axis of these vertebrae is reflected in two adaptations. Firstly,<tei:lb/>the axis through the chain of the Weberian ossicles is nearly horizontal in Xenocharax, rather than<tei:lb/>demonstrating the posteroventral slope generalized for characoids. This shift is, however, a<tei:lb/>consequence of the reorientation of the anterior vertebrae with respect to the skull, rather than a<tei:lb/>repositioning of the ossicles relative to the pars sustentaculum. The second adaptation of the<tei:lb/>Xenocharax os suspensorium is consequent upon the retention by this genus of the primitive<tei:lb/>relationship of the os suspensorium and the anterior chamber of the swimbladder. Due to the<tei:lb/>reorientation of the pars sustentaculum with respect to the vertebral column, this alignment<tei:lb/>represents a marked decrease in the angle between the axis of the os suspensorium and that of<tei:lb/>the longitudinal axis of the vertebrae of the pars sustentaculum. This alteration is of sufficient<tei:lb/>magnitude so that the ventral tip of the os suspensorium extends to below the first or second<tei:lb/>vertebrae. This contrasts to the generalized characoid condition where it reaches only to below<tei:lb/>the third vertebra.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The fourth and final form of pars sustentaculum among citharinids and distichodontids occurs<tei:lb/>in some Nannocharax species. The species of this genus range from moderately deep-bodied,<tei:lb/>generalized forms such as N. multifasciatus, N. ansorgei and TV. minutus to ventrally-flattened,<tei:lb/>bottom-dwelling species such as N. brevis, N. gobioides, N. niloticus and N. intermedius. One of<tei:lb/>the myriad adaptions to a bottom-dwelling habit demonstrated by the latter group of species is a<tei:lb/>restructuring of the pars sustentaculum and the first and second pleural ribs. Generalized<tei:lb/>Nannocharax species have the basically Nannaethiops type of pars sustentaculum. In the specialized<tei:lb/>forms, however, the proximal section of the first pleural rib is expanded anteriorly to form a<tei:lb/>prominent flange extending over the dorsal surface of the anterior swimbladder chamber. The<tei:lb/>second pleural rib has a similar, though posteriorly-directed and somewhat smaller, process<tei:lb/>proximally. Further distally this rib also bears an anteriorly directed flange extending along the</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>310 R. P. VARI</tei:p>
         <tei:p>lateral wall of the anterior chamber of the swimbladder. More notably, the ventral processes<tei:lb/>of the second vertebra are expanded into a common, transverse, plate-like structure covering the<tei:lb/>anterior and anteroventral surfaces of the anterior chamber of the swimbladder (Fig. 34).<tei:lb/>Associated with these expanded ventral processes of the second vertebra is the development of a<tei:lb/>bony tube along the anteromedial face of this plate. This canal surrounds the coeliac artery from<tei:lb/>its point of origin to the point where, plesiomorphously, it contacts the anterior chamber of the<tei:lb/>swimbladder. It should be emphasized that although superficially similar to the bony tube around<tei:lb/>the coeliac artery in citharinids, this channel in Nannocharax is formed by a process of the second<tei:lb/>vertebra rather than by the citharinid independent ossifications.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ac</tei:p>
         <tei:p>pc</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 34 Nannocharax niloticus, swimbladder and bony capsule of anterior swimbladder chamber,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ventral view.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Such an encapsulation of the anterior swimbladder chamber has not been reported previously<tei:lb/>among characoids or encountered elsewhere in the superfamily during this study and undoubtedly<tei:lb/>represents a synapomorphy for some Nannocharax species. Functionally, this partial encapsula-<tei:lb/>tion of the swimbladder appears to be related to the bottom-dwelling habits of the species<tei:lb/>possessing it, as is the case in cobitids, various catfish groups and perhaps the small capsules<tei:lb/>around the anterior swimbladder chamber in some gymnotids (e.g. Rhamphichthys rostratus).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Derived states of the Weberian apparatus in the families Citharinidae and Distichodontidae<tei:lb/>are:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 the expanded os suspensorium and the ventrolateral projections of the second and third<tei:lb/>vertebrae common to all citharinids and distichodontids at some point in ontogeny.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 the highly ossified triangular pars sustentaculum complex of citharinids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3 the marked reduction in the angle between the axis of the os suspensorium and that of the<tei:lb/>pars sustentaculum in Xenocharax.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>4 the expansion of the ventral processes of the second vertebra and modifications of the<tei:lb/>first and second pleural rib to partially encapsulate the anterior chamber of the swim-<tei:lb/>bladder in some Nannocharax species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Postcleithra</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The pectoral girdle of citharinids and distichodontids is distinctive in having a maximum of two<tei:lb/>postcleithra rather than the three postcleithral elements that characterize most characoids. The<tei:lb/>upper postcleithrum in these families overlaps the junction between the cleithrum and supra-<tei:lb/>cleithrum and is homologous with the element termed postcleithrum 1 in Byrcon meeki by</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>CLASSIFICATION OF CITHARINIDAE AND DISTICHODONTIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>311</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Weitzman (1962). The remaining postcleithrum in citharinids and distichodontids is located<tei:lb/>posteromedial to the cleithmm and has the form of an elongate plate with a pronounced antero-<tei:lb/>ventral strut that is ventrally continuous with a rod-like process (Fig. 35a) (see also below with<tei:lb/>respect to Phago and Belonophago). In overall form this postcleithral element is very similar to<tei:lb/>the flat, ovoid postcleithrum 2 and the separate rod-like postcleithrum 3 overlapping and ventral<tei:lb/>to the former that occupy this region in most characoids. Because of this similarity in form,<tei:lb/>the ventral postcleithral element of citharinids and distichodontids is hypothesized to represent<tei:lb/>an apomorphous, fused postcleithrum 2 and 3. Nannocharax and Hemigrammocharax, in addition,<tei:lb/>lack the dorsal postcleithral element (postcleithrum 1) that plesiomorphously overlies the<tei:lb/>junction between the cleithrum and supracleithrum. A final postcleithral character of note in<tei:lb/>these families is the expansion of the ventral postcleithral element in Phago and Belonophago to<tei:lb/>form a rigid strut around the posterior border of the pectoral fin base (Fig. 35b).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A B</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 35 Cleithrum and postcleithra of A. Citharidium ansorgei, B. Phago intermedius.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pelvic bone</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The form of the pelvic bone shows considerable variation from the generalized characoid con-<tei:lb/>dition both throughout and within the assemblage that constitutes the families Citharinidae and<tei:lb/>Distichodontidae. The pelvic bone of anotophysans and generalized characoids has anteriorly<tei:lb/>a single tapering process braced by a longitudinal ridge. However, among citharinids and parti-<tei:lb/>cularly distichodontids, the pelvic bone has two anterior processes giving it an anteriorly bifurcate<tei:lb/>form (Fig. 36a). The longer lateral process extends almost directly anteriorly and bears a<tei:lb/>longitudinal ridge along its dorsal surface. The smaller medially slanting process, in turn, has a<tei:lb/>shorter ventral ridge. A somewhat bifurcate pelvic bone also occurs in various neotropical<tei:lb/>characoid groups, but in none of them is the bifurcation as pronounced as that in citharinids and<tei:lb/>distichodontids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Further modifications to the pelvic bone occur in bottom-dwelling Nannocharax species (N.<tei:lb/>niloticus, N. gobioides, N. intermedius and N. fasciatus) in which the pelvic bone is distinctly<tei:lb/>widened anteriorly to form a broad plate-like structure (Fig. 36b). This modification, the con-<tei:lb/>gruent expansion of the ischiac process of the pelvic bone and the elongation of the pelvic fin<tei:lb/>rays is evidently an adaptation to the bottom-dwelling habits of these species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Caudal skeleton</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The caudal skeleton of citharinids and distichodontids exhibit several characters of interest both</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>312</tei:p>
         <tei:p>R. P. VARI</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 36 Pelvic girdle of A. Xenocharax spilurus, B. Nannocharax niloticus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>relative to the question of the monophyletic nature of the complex formed by these families and<tei:lb/>to the hypothesis of relationships within the assemblage. The hypural fan form hypothesized<tei:lb/>plesiomorphous for characoids consists of six separate hypural elements. All citharinids and<tei:lb/>distichodontids differ from this condition in having hypurals 1 and 2 (the ventral elements) fused<tei:lb/>into a single unit not articulating with the fused PUj and U l (Fig. 37).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Such an apomorphic fusion of the two ventral hypurals also occurs within the Characoidea in<tei:lb/>the South American family Hemiodontidae (including Anodus), the characid subfamily Ser-<tei:lb/>rasalminae and the African characid Lepidarchus adonis (Roberts, 1966). As noted earlier the</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1mm</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 37 Xenocharax spilurus, caudal skeleton.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>CLASSIFICATION OF CITHARINIDAE AND DISTICHODONTIDAE 313</tei:p>
         <tei:p>members of the Hemiodontidae possess a rhinosphenoid; an apomorphous median ossification<tei:lb/>unique to various Neotropical characoids. With the exception of hemiodontids, all members of<tei:lb/>these rhinosphenoid-bearing groups examined during this study have separate hypurals. Similarly,<tei:lb/>although the exact relationships of the Serrasalminae are unknown, their multicuspidate dentition<tei:lb/>ties them to various Neotropical groups which lack any hypural fusions. Finally, Lepidarchus<tei:lb/>is a member of the African Characidae (Roberts, 1966) whose members are otherwise character-<tei:lb/>ized by six separate hypurals.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Two other South American characoid groups have fused hypurals 1 and 2. However, in each<tei:lb/>of these cases the fused hypural plate differs from that of citharinids and distichodontids in such<tei:lb/>a way as to cast doubt on the homology of this fusion with that in the latter families. In the<tei:lb/>Cynodontini the genera Hydrolycus and Cynodon have hypurals 1, 2 and 3 joined into a large<tei:lb/>plate encompassing the ventral and part of the dorsal portions of the hypural fan. However, the<tei:lb/>cynodontine genus Rhaphiodon, has hypurals 2 and 3 fused, but separate from hypural 1. Finally,<tei:lb/>Roestes, the most plesiomorphous cynodontine (Howes, 1976), has a completely separate hypural<tei:lb/>fan. Thus it is most parsimonious to assume that the phylogenetic progression of hypural fusion<tei:lb/>of cynodontines is a joining of hypurals 2 and 3 followed by the fusion of the resultant plate with<tei:lb/>hypural 1 . Such a sequence does not demonstrate a fusion homologous with the fused hypurals<tei:lb/>1 and 2 that characterize citharinids and distichodontids. Finally, fused hypurals 1 and 2 have<tei:lb/>also been discovered in Crenuchus and Poecilocharax. The fused hypurals in these genera differ,<tei:lb/>however, from the pattern in citharinids and distichodontids in being joined to the fused PU X<tei:lb/>and Uj.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The number of separate hypural elements is further reduced in Neolebias, Nannaethiops and<tei:lb/>Paradistichodus in which only three upper hypurals exist. Although the question of whether this<tei:lb/>reduction is a consequence of the fusion of hypurals 5 and 6, or a loss of the latter, has not<tei:lb/>been resolved, such a reduction is nonetheless considered to be a derived feature. Finally, a<tei:lb/>reduction from the two epurals plesiomorphous for citharinids and distichodontids has occurred<tei:lb/>in Paradistichodus, Phago and Belonophago in which only one epural is present.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scale form</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Unlike most anatomical features, the scale form among members of the Characoidea exhibits<tei:lb/>little variation at the gross morphological level. The majority of characoids are characterized by<tei:lb/>the possession of a simple cycloid scale form. Within the families Citharinidae and Distichodon-<tei:lb/>tidae, however, this seemingly plesiomorphous scale form is limited to the genus Citharinus.<tei:lb/>Citharidium has ctenoid scales, while all distichodontids have a second, non-homologous form of<tei:lb/>serrate scales.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In Citharidium the prominent, distinctly pointed ctenii are continuous with the main body of<tei:lb/>the scale (Fig. 38a). In this scale form a strong ridge extends from the scale body radially along the<tei:lb/>centre of each cteni, with the distal circuli diverging outwards along the ridge. The members of<tei:lb/>the family Distichodontidae, in contrast, possess a very different type of ctenoid scale, the<tei:lb/>simplest form of which is illustrated in Fig. 38b. In the distichodontid ctenoid scale, the scale<tei:lb/>body is comparable to that of a typical characoid scale except for a shift of the scale focus towards<tei:lb/>the scale margin. Along the scale margin there occurs a line of irregular ctenii that vary in number<tei:lb/>between different taxa. These ctenii differ from those of Citharidium in being formed by a series<tei:lb/>of independent ossifications attached to the scale body and each other by unossified connective<tei:lb/>tissue.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Examination of the ctenoid scales reported in other characoid groups has shown the term to be<tei:lb/>applied to an assemblage of very different scale types characterized by various forms of serrate<tei:lb/>posterior margins. In Cynopotamus and other genera in the Neotropical tribe Characini the<tei:lb/>ctenoid nature of the scales is a consequence of a series of spicules along the posterior margin and<tei:lb/>exposed lateral surface of the scale. The ctenoid scales of the tetragonopterine Ctenobrycon,<tei:lb/>various curimatids and the prochilodontid genus Prochilodus are characterized by an irregularly<tei:lb/>notched posterior scale margin, whereas the curimatid genus Psectrogaster has definite although<tei:lb/>somewhat irregular ctenii. However, none of the above forms of ctenoid scales is comparable</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>314</tei:p>
         <tei:p>R. P. VARI</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>CLASSIFICATION OF CITHARINIDAE AND DISTICHODONTIDAE 315</tei:p>
         <tei:p>to those in the African families under discussion. In the South American genus Ctenolucius the<tei:lb/>scales bear strong ctenii formed primarily by posterior continuations of the pronounced ridges<tei:lb/>that radiate outwards from the focus. In the closely related Boulengerella a less well-developed<tei:lb/>form of the same scale type occurs. Although these scale types approximate to that in Citharidiwn,<tei:lb/>they differ in the form of the ridges and in possessing strong radii which are totally lacking in that<tei:lb/>genus. These differences and the large number of derived characters uniting Citharidiwn into a<tei:lb/>monophyletic unit with Citharinus (which retains the plesiomorphous cycloid scale form) support<tei:lb/>the hypothesis that the Ctenolucius and citharinid forms of ctenoid scales were acquired indepen-<tei:lb/>dently.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5mm</tei:p>
         <tei:p>aa /-k-i</tei:p>
         <tei:p>T<tei:lb/>Fig. 39 Xenocharax spilurus, superficial cranial musculature, lateral view.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Although the distichodontid form of ctenoid scale does not appear to be approximated within<tei:lb/>characoids, a similar ctenoid scale with serrations formed by a series of independent ossifications<tei:lb/>occurs in the anatopysan ostariophysan Gonorhynchus greyi. However, the similarity in scale<tei:lb/>form between such phylogenetically separated members of the Ostariophysi undoubtedly rep-<tei:lb/>resents independent acquisitions.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The distichodontid form of ctenoid scale undergoes further modifications in the genera Phago<tei:lb/>and Belonophago. In these taxa the greatly thickened scales and strong connective tissue bands<tei:lb/>joining them result in a bony but flexible body covering. Furthermore, as a consequence of their<tei:lb/>elongate cylindriform bodies, the relatively large scales in these genera are distinctly flexed<tei:lb/>horizontally. This flexure is especially pronounced in the vertically elongate scales of Phago.<tei:lb/>Phago and Belonophago have a distinct ossified bump overlying the scale focus, with this structure<tei:lb/>produced into a posteriorly directed spinous process in Belonophago (Fig. 38c).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The final character of note in the scalation of these families is the form and extent of develop-<tei:lb/>ment of the lateral line system. Although the plesiomorphous lateral line form among characoids<tei:lb/>is unknown, it is noteworthy that citharinids and distichodontids have a straight or nearly straight<tei:lb/>lateral line. This contrasts with the distinctly ventrally-curved lateral line in all other African and<tei:lb/>most Neotropical characoids. A reduction from a complete lateral line occurs in all Neolebias<tei:lb/>and Hemigrammocharax species. However, Roberts (1967) has questioned whether the reduced<tei:lb/>lateral line of Hemigrammocharax represents single or multiple reductions from the complete<tei:lb/>lateral line of Nannocharax. Two species of Hemistichodus (lootensi and mesmaekersi) have a<tei:lb/>distinctive medially interrupted lateral line.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Myology</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The osteological characters described above have included a variety of alterations of the jaws, the</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>316 R. P. VARI</tei:p>
         <tei:p>jaw suspensorium, the operculum and the parts of the neurocranium associated with these systems.<tei:lb/>Congruent with these osteological changes are a series of adaptations in the cheek and opercular<tei:lb/>musculature of these genera.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In the following discussion the musculature of the distichodontid genus Xenocharax will first<tei:lb/>be described in detail. As far as can be determined from outgroup comparisons to generalized<tei:lb/>characoids, the myological plan of Xenocharax is the least derived overall among citharinids and<tei:lb/>distichodontids. Thus it serves as a useful basis of comparison for the myological variation that<tei:lb/>occurs in these families. In the case of Paraphago, which is known only from two syntypes and<tei:lb/>which was consequently not examined myologically, it is assumed that the myological characters<tei:lb/>of the genus are congruent with those of its monophyletic group. The muscles providing informa-<tei:lb/>tion relevant to a reconstruction of the hypothesized phylogeny of citharinids and distichodontids<tei:lb/>are the adductor mandibulae, the levator arcus palatini and the dilatator operculi.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The adductor mandibulae in Xenocharax (Fig. 39) is composed of sections A 1} A 2 (divisible<tei:lb/>into medial and lateral portions), A 3 and A w . The A x portion of the adductor mandibulae is a<tei:lb/>somewhat tubular muscle extending anterodorsally from its origin on the lateral flange of the<tei:lb/>horizontal process of the quadrate. It is dorsally encompassed by a connective tissue sheath<tei:lb/>continuous with the strong tendon that runs along the anterior surface of the muscle. This tendon,<tei:lb/>in turn, inserts onto the maxilla at the point of merger between the anteromedial maxillary process<tei:lb/>and the broad lateral plate of the bone.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The remainder of the adductor mandibulae consists of the two sections of the A 2 portion of the<tei:lb/>muscle and medial to these an A 3 . Posteriorly the two portions of the A 2 arise in common from<tei:lb/>the lateral face of the hyomandibula and vertical ramus of the preopercle. Along their postero-<tei:lb/>dorsal borders these portions of the muscle contact the ventrolateral face of the dorsally widened<tei:lb/>levator arcus palatini. Ventrally A 2 has an origin from the lateral face of the horizontal portion<tei:lb/>of the preopercle and the posteroventral process of the quadrate (the medial portion of A 2<tei:lb/>does not arise from the latter element). The A 2 divides into two sections parasagittally slightly<tei:lb/>anterior to the point where the levator arcus palatini passes between the A 2 and A 3 portions of the<tei:lb/>adductor mandibulae. The lateral section of A 2 extends forward over the posterodorsal surface<tei:lb/>of A! to insert onto the posterior edge of the dentary, just dorsal to the articulation of that element<tei:lb/>with the angulo-articular. The medial portion of A 2 , in contrast, has its anterodorsal surface<tei:lb/>invested by a connective tissue band that is continuous with a prominent tendon extending<tei:lb/>anteriorly from the forward tip of the muscle and joining a comparable tendon from the A 3 .<tei:lb/>This common tendon inserts onto the A w and the coronomeckelian ossification (Fig. 40). The<tei:lb/>A 3 section of the adductor mandibulae is posteriorly separated from the medial section of A 2<tei:lb/>by the ventral portion of the levator arcus palatini. The A 3 arises from the anteromedial surface<tei:lb/>of the hyomandibula and is surrounded anteriorly by a connective tissue sheath that is continuous<tei:lb/>with the tendon arising from the medial section of A 2 . Finally, the A w (intramandibular) section<tei:lb/>of the adductor mandibulae is a relatively flat muscle filling the meckelian fossa and attaching to<tei:lb/>the angulo-articular and dentary.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The levator arcus palatini of Xenocharax is a triangular muscle, laterally exposed along the<tei:lb/>posterodorsal region of the cheek. From its origin on the posteroventral portion of the sphenotic<tei:lb/>spine the levator arcus palatini extends ventrally between A 3 and the medial section of A 2 to insert<tei:lb/>on the anteroventral portion of the hyomandibula. The dilatator operculi is a pinnate muscle<tei:lb/>arising from the broad dilatator fossa of the sphenotic and pterotic and inserting onto a raised<tei:lb/>ridge along the anterodorsal corner of the opercle.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The above pattern of cheek and opercular musculature is common to Xenocharax, Nannaethiops<tei:lb/>and Neolebias. Citharinids and other distichodontids differ to varying degrees from the Xeno-<tei:lb/>charax cheek musculature pattern. This variation in muscle origins, insertions, proportions and<tei:lb/>interconnections serves to define a series of multigeneric units within these families.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Citharinus and Citharidium have an elongate A x portion of the adductor mandibulae with a<tei:lb/>more extensive origin on the horizontal process of the quadrate and the ventral arm of the<tei:lb/>preopercle than in the Xenocharax condition (Fig. 41). More significantly, the citharinid Aj<tei:lb/>differs from that of Xenocharax in attaching directly to the rear of the dentary rather than ten-<tei:lb/>dinously to the maxilla. Citharinids have, however, a ligament running from the point of contact</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>CLASSIFICATION OF CITHARINIDAE AND DISTICHODONTIDAE 317</tei:p>
         <tei:p>of the A! with the dentary to the region of the maxilla where the tendon of A x inserts in Xeno-<tei:lb/>charax. This ligament, the ligamentum primordiale of previous authors, may be homologous to<tei:lb/>the tendinous band along the anterior surface of the A x section of the adductor mandibulae in<tei:lb/>Xenocharax. On the basis of outgroup comparisons, the citharinid insertion of the A x to the<tei:lb/>dentary in conjunction with the retention of a distinct ligamentum primordiale is hypothesized<tei:lb/>to be the plesiomorphous characoid condition. The derived attachment of the A x to the maxilla<tei:lb/>in Xenocharax together with the seeming incorporation of the ligamentum primordiale into<tei:lb/>its tendon is evidently correlated with the increased upper jaw mobility of distichodontids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>den</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 40 Xenocharax spilurus, adductor mandibulae, anterior portions, medial view.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The A 2 portion of the adductor mandibulae in Citharinus and Citharidium arises posteriorly<tei:lb/>from the lateral surfaces of the hyomandibula and preopercle, but does not extend as dorsal on<tei:lb/>these elements as in Xenocharax. Anteriorly the lateral portion of the A 2 in citharinids inserts<tei:lb/>onto the rear of the A w through a tendon that is anteriorly continuous with that of the medial<tei:lb/>section of A 2 . This common insertion contrasts with the separate attachment of these muscles on<tei:lb/>the dentary and A w respectively in Xenocharax. That portion of the adductor mandibulae of<tei:lb/>citharinids comparable to the A 3 of Xenocharax (that portion of the muscle medial to the levator<tei:lb/>arcus palatini) is greatly reduced and usually has the form of a series of muscle slips arising from<tei:lb/>the hyomandibula and metapterygoid. Furthermore, rather than having a distinct tendon,<tei:lb/>anteriorly continuous with the anterior tendon of A 2 , the slips of muscles forming the A 3 of<tei:lb/>citharinids attach individually along the inner surface of the medial portion of A 2 .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The A w section of the adductor mandibulae in Citharinus and Citharidium is greatly expanded<tei:lb/>to fill entirely the large meckelian fossa and extends dorsally over the upper edge of the dentary.<tei:lb/>The levator arcus palatini of these genera, although relatively longer than in Xenocharax, has a<tei:lb/>similar origin and insertion apart from an expanded insertion posterodorsally on the preopercle.<tei:lb/>The dilatator operculi is significantly larger than that of Xenocharax and totally fills the large<tei:lb/>dilatator fossa on the sphenotic, pterotic and lateral edge of the frontal. This pinnate muscle<tei:lb/>inserts on the distinctive, elongate opercular spine that extends anterodorsally towards the<tei:lb/>middle of the fossa in citharinids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Within distichodontids, several genera and generic assemblages show various modifications<tei:lb/>of the Xenocharax pattern of cheek musculature. In Paradistichodus the overall proportions of the<tei:lb/>muscles are changed, perhaps as a consequence of the elongate head that characterizes the genus.<tei:lb/>The A x portion of the adductor mandibulae is notably elongate and the muscle extends along the<tei:lb/>tendon anterodorsally, nearly to the maxilla. Overall, the A 2 is smaller than in Xenocharax and<tei:lb/>arises solely from the ventral half of the preopercle and hyomandibula. This reduction of the A 2<tei:lb/>is especially notable in the longitudinal extent of the lateral section of the muscle which con-<tei:lb/>sequently attaches to the dentary through an elongate tendon.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Distichodus, Nannocharax and Hemigrammocharax have a series of modifications of the<tei:lb/>adductor mandibulae correlated with their unique jaw morphology (Fig. 42). The elongate A x</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>318</tei:p>
         <tei:p>R. P. VARI</tei:p>
         <tei:p>pmx</tei:p>
         <tei:p>den</tei:p>
         <tei:p>LP a'a</tei:p>
         <tei:p>pof</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 41 Citharinus citharus, superficial cranial musculature, lateral view.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>portion of this muscle arises from the quadrate and extends anteriorly to attach to the maxilla<tei:lb/>by way of a ligament running across the lateral face of the dorsally expanded dentary. As in<tei:lb/>Xenocharax the A 2 section of the adductor mandibulae is subdivided into medial and lateral<tei:lb/>segments with a prominent A 3 also present. However, as a consequence of the radically re-<tei:lb/>structured jaw form of these genera, the relationships between the sections of the adductor<tei:lb/>mandibulae are somewhat altered. In other distichodontids the anterior sections of A 2 and A 3<tei:lb/>run in parallel and the lateral portion of A 2 inserts lateral to, or only slightly dorsolateral to, the<tei:lb/>point where the joined tendon of A 3 and the medial portion of A 2 contacts the A w . In Dis-<tei:lb/>tichodus, Nannocharax and Hemigrammocharax, in contrast, the insertion of the lateral portion<tei:lb/>of A 2 is distinctly dorsal to the level where the combined tendon from A 3 and the medial section<tei:lb/>of A 2 attach onto the coronomeckelian ossification. The A w of Distichodus, Nannocharax and<tei:lb/>Hemigrammocharax arises from the dorsal edge of the latter tendon and extends from distinctly<tei:lb/>posterior of the rear of the angulo-articular forward onto the bone. Both the origin of the A w<tei:lb/>solely from the dorsal border of the ligament and its posterior position relative to the angulo-<tei:lb/>articular appear apomorphous relative to the generalized characoid condition. An additional</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5mm</tei:p>
         <tei:p>pmax</tei:p>
         <tei:p>den</tei:p>

         <tei:p>CLASSIFICATION OF CITHARINIDAE AND DISTICHODONTIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>319</tei:p>
         <tei:p>consequence of these osteological and myological alterations is a shift of the relative position of<tei:lb/>the ligamentum primordiale and the tendon of Aj. Instead of running in common or parallel as<tei:lb/>in the plesiomorphous condition, the connective tissue bands in these genera cross at right angles,<tei:lb/>with the tendon of A x passing over the ligamentum primordiale.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>pmx</tei:p>
         <tei:p>m</tei:p>
         <tei:p>OOP</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 43 Ichthyborus quadrilineatus, superficial cranial musculature, lateral view.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>As discussed earlier the ventral edge of the sphenotic spine undergoes a progressive phylo-<tei:lb/>genetic enlargement within the unit formed by Distichodus, Hemigrammocharax and Nannocharax.<tei:lb/>Congruent with this alteration of the spine is an expansion in the extent of the origin of the<tei:lb/>levator arcus palatini. This trend is especially pronounced in Nannocharax and Hemigrammo-<tei:lb/>charax in which the broad ventrally concave sphenotic process serves as an expanded area of<tei:lb/>origin for the levator arcus palatini. Furthermore, in these genera the dilatator operculi rather<tei:lb/>than having the hypothesized plesiomorphous origin from the dilatator fossa has a broad attach-<tei:lb/>ment to the lateral surface of the sphenotic. This shift from the generalized characoid condition is<tei:lb/>carried further in some of the larger Nannocharax species examined (N.fasciatus and N. elongatus).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5mm</tei:p>
         <tei:p>aa</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A-| q pop</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 44 Ichthyborus besse, adductor mandibulae, lateral view.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In these species the anterior portion of the dilatator operculi arises from the anterior face of the<tei:lb/>sphenotic and passes medial to the levator arcus palatini to insert on the anterodorsal process of<tei:lb/>the opercle. The broad, shallow depression on the sphenotic and pterotic of Nannocharax and<tei:lb/>Hemigrammocharax does not serve as a dilatator fossa, but is instead occupied by the plate-like<tei:lb/>dermosphenotic present in these genera.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>320</tei:p>
         <tei:p>R. P. VARI</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The remaining distichodontid genera, Hemistichodus, Ichthyborus, Microstomatichthyoborus,<tei:lb/>Mesoborus, Eugnatichthys, Paraphago, Phago and Belonophago, have the A x portion, of the<tei:lb/>adductor mandibulae arising from the trough formed by the lateral processes of the quadrate and<tei:lb/>preopercle. This muscle inserts on the posterolateral and posterior surface of the angulo-articular<tei:lb/>(Figs 43, 44). Such an insertion differs radically from the tendinous attachment of this muscle<tei:lb/>section to the maxilla in all other distichodontids. This change and the congruent loss of a</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5mm</tei:p>
         <tei:p>LAP</tei:p>
         <tei:p>a</tei:p>
         <tei:p>pop</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 45 Ichthyborus ornatus, adductor mandibulae, lateral view, A t portion removed.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>definitive ligamentum primordiale appears consequent upon the radically altered upper jaw<tei:lb/>morphology of these genera. These changes result in the elimination of the functional advantage<tei:lb/>that an attachment of the A x to the maxilla provides in less derived forms of distichodontid<tei:lb/>jaws. These genera, with the exception of Hemistichodus, also have a significantly enlarged origin<tei:lb/>of the adductor mandibulae on the lateral and medial surfaces of the hyomandibula and the<tei:lb/>lateroventral portions of the sphenotic and pterotic. This expanded origin is particularly pro-<tei:lb/>nounced in Eugnatichthys.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Within the above assemblage, both Ichthyborus and Eugnatichthys present further apomorphic<tei:lb/>myological characters. The A x of Ichthyborus besse is distinctive in having its lateral portion<tei:lb/>autapomorphously altered into a distinct triangular muscle slip which attaches to the lateral<tei:lb/>portion of A 2 via a connective tissue band (Fig. 44). In addition, all Ichthyborus species are dis-<tei:lb/>tinctive among distichodontids in having the lateral portion of the A 2 inserting on the angulo-<tei:lb/>articular, contrary to the plesiomorphous attachment of this muscle segment on the dentary.<tei:lb/>This insertion is through an elongate anterior tendon in Ichthyborus ornatus, I. monodi and /.<tei:lb/>quadrilineatus (Fig. 45) and by way of the aforementioned modified section of the A x in /. besse<tei:lb/>(Fig. 44).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eugnatichthys has the primitively single A 3 portion of the adductor mandibulae parasagittally<tei:lb/>subdivided into two sections. The lateral portion of the A 3 in this genus extends anteriorly to join<tei:lb/>the medial section of A 2 and inserts in common with that muscle directly on the dentary. This<tei:lb/>insertion contrasts with the plesiomorphous insertion of the A 3 on the coronomeckelian ossifica-<tei:lb/>tion, an insertion that is retained by the medial portion of the A 3 section of the adductor<tei:lb/>mandibulae of Eugnatichthys.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The levator arcus palatini in Ichthyborus, Microstomatichthyoborus, Mesoborus, Eugnatichthys,<tei:lb/>Paraphago, Phago and Belonophago has an apomorphous expanded origin on the ventral<tei:lb/>(primitively anterior) surface of the posteroventrally sloping or horizontal sphenotic spine<tei:lb/>characteristic of these genera. Phago and Belonophago, in turn, have the muscle origin further<tei:lb/>expanded onto the ventral face of the frontal in the posterodorsal orbital region; an adaptation<tei:lb/>unique to these genera among characoids examined. Finally, the levator arcus palatini of</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>CLASSIFICATION OF CITHARINIDAE AND DISTICHODONTIDAE 321</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eugnatichthys, Phago and Belonophago has a distinctly reduced vertical extent relative to that of<tei:lb/>other distichodontids and consequently does not directly insert onto the hyomandibula. Instead,<tei:lb/>these genera have the muscle inserting onto that element via a broad aponeuroses.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In summary, hypothesized derived states of the adductor mandibulae, levator arcus palatini<tei:lb/>and dilatator operculi among citharinids and distichodontids are:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 the insertion of the Aj portion of the adductor mandibulae on the maxilla in Xenocharax,<tei:lb/>Neolebias, Nannaethiops, Paradistichodus, Distichodus, Nannocharax and Hemigram-<tei:lb/>mocharax. This attachment is hypothesized, however, to have been secondarily lost in<tei:lb/>all other distichodontids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 the insertion of the lateral section of the A 2 portion of the adductor mandibulae to the<tei:lb/>A w via a tendon in citharinids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3 the reduction of the A 3 portion of the adductor mandibulae in citharinids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>4 the greatly expanded A w portion of the adductor mandibulae in citharinids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5 the expanded dilatator operculi in citharinids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>6 the reduced lateral portion of the A 2 section of the adductor mandibulae in Para-<tei:lb/>distichodus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 the elongation of the A l portion of the adductor mandibulae in Distichodus, Nannocharax<tei:lb/>and Hemigrammocharax.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>8 the relatively dorsal insertion of the lateral portion of A 2 in Distichodus, Nannocharax<tei:lb/>and Hemigrammocharax.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>9 the posterior origin and expanded extent of the A w portion of the adductor mandibulae<tei:lb/>in Distichodus, Nannocharax and Hemigrammocharax.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>10 the expanded origin of the levator arcus palatini on the ventrally broadened sphenotic<tei:lb/>spine in Nannocharax, Hemigrammocharax and some Distichodus species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 1 the shift of the origin of the dilatator operculi to the lateral surface of the sphenotic<tei:lb/>in Nannocharax and Hemigrammocharax.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>12 the insertion of the lateral portion of the A 2 on the angulo-articular in Ichthyborus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>13 the expansion of the origin of the A 2 section of the adductor mandibulae onto the medial<tei:lb/>surface of the hyomandibula and ventral surfaces of the pterotic and sphenotic in<tei:lb/>Ichthyborus, Microstomatichthyoborus, Mesoborus, Eugnatichthys, Paraphago, Phago<tei:lb/>and Belonophago. These genera also have the origin of the levator arcus palatini expanded<tei:lb/>onto the anterior surface of the sphenotic spine.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>14 the partial origin of the levator arcus palatini from the ventral surface of the frontal in<tei:lb/>Phago and Belonophago.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>15 the reduction of the vertical extent of the levator arcus palatini and its insertion on the<tei:lb/>hyomandibula through an aponeuroses in Eugnatichthys, Phago and Belonophago.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Swimbladder, intestinal and epibranchial organ forms</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Swimbladder</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Within the assemblage consisting of the Citharinidae and Distichodontidae, the form of both the<tei:lb/>anterior and posterior chambers of the Swimbladder undergoes several modifications. The<tei:lb/>generalized Swimbladder morphology in characoids consists of two chambers connected by a<tei:lb/>short narrow tube. The rotund anterior chamber is slightly elongate and is attached by the<tei:lb/>peritoneal layer surrounding it to the os suspensorium and the triangular connective tissue<tei:lb/>complex associated with the pars sustentaculum of the Weberian apparatus. The posterior<tei:lb/>chamber is of slightly greater diameter than the anterior and several times the longitudinal extent.<tei:lb/>Although the plesiomorphous relative proportions of the chambers of the Swimbladder among<tei:lb/>characoids is presently unknown, it is noteworthy that in both citharinids and distichodontids the<tei:lb/>posterior chamber of the swimbladder is distinctly elongate with respect to the anterior (approxi-<tei:lb/>mately four times the longitudinal length). Despite this uncertainty about the phylogenetic<tei:lb/>polarity of an elongate posterior swimbladder chamber, the possession of such a structure is,<tei:lb/>nonetheless, at least congruent with the hypothesis of the monophyly of the unit formed by</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>322 R. P. VARI</tei:p>
         <tei:p>citharinids and distichodontids among characoids. Is should be emphasized, however, that even<tei:lb/>if apomorphous for characoids, such an elongate posterior chamber of the swimbladder is also<tei:lb/>characteristic of the South American characoid family Hemiodontidae and occurs in various<tei:lb/>forms in some Neotropical characids (e.g. Iguanodectinae, see Vari, 1977).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Within the Distichodontidae, the evenly curved oblong anterior and elongate posterior swim-<tei:lb/>bladder chambers that are plesiomorphous for the family are modified in Hemigrammocharax<tei:lb/>and Nannocharax. These genera have anteriorly-directed diverticulae of the anterior swimbladder<tei:lb/>chamber. These diverticulae extend from the anterior face of the chamber lateral to the ventral<tei:lb/>process of the os suspensorium and the posterior portion of the triangular connective tissue<tei:lb/>complex associated with the pars sustentaculum. The extent of these diverticulae range from the<tei:lb/>slight bulges of Hemigrammocharax and generalized Nannocharax species to the pronounced<tei:lb/>anterior diverticulae found in specialized Nannocharax species such as N. niloticus, N. gobioides<tei:lb/>and N. intermedius. The latter Nannocharax species also have the posterior swimbladder chamber<tei:lb/>greatly reduced to a small tubular structure (Fig. 34) ; an adaptation evidently correlated with their<tei:lb/>bottom-dwelling habits.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Intestinal form</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Two modifications of the morphology and convolution patterns of the intestinal tract distinguish<tei:lb/>citharinids within the complex formed by the families Citharinidae and Distichodontidae. On the<tei:lb/>basis of information from ontogenetic and outgroup comparisons, the plesiomorphous form of the<tei:lb/>intestinal tract among characoids appears to be a moderately looping, smooth-walled system.<tei:lb/>In both Citharinits and Citharidium, however, the intestine is elaborated into a highly convoluted<tei:lb/>system (see Daget, 1962, Fig. 9) characterized by distinctive multiple outpocketings of its terminal<tei:lb/>loop. Whereas the elongation of the intestine is evidently correlated with the microphagous<tei:lb/>habits of these genera, the functional significance of the intestinal outpocketings is obscure.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Epibranchial organ form</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Epibranchial organs of differing levels of complexity have been described for a variety of Neo-<tei:lb/>tropical and African characoids (see Nelson, 1967, p. 73). Within the families under discussion,<tei:lb/>a slightly developed diverticula in the posterior portion of the gill arches has been reported among<tei:lb/>distichodontids in Paradistichodus (Daget, 1958, p. 1368), Distichodus (Daget, 1959, p. 1289),<tei:lb/>Xenocharax (Daget, 1960, p. 41), Nannocharax (Daget, 1961, p. 172) and Neolebias (Daget, 1965,<tei:lb/>p. 9). The structure has also been found in Nannaethiops and Hemigrammocharax during this<tei:lb/>study. Daget reported that the epibranchial organ was absent in Ichthyborus besse (1967, p. 145)<tei:lb/>and Hemistichodus (1968, p. 16). This study has also found such outpocketings to be lacking in<tei:lb/>the remaining Ichthyborus species, Microstomatichthyoborus, Mesoborus, Eugnatichthys, Phago<tei:lb/>and Belonophago. The lack of epibranchial organs in these genera is considered to be an apo-<tei:lb/>morphous secondary loss on the basis of the presence of such outpocketings in the Citharinidae,<tei:lb/>which is the sister group to distichodontids, and in all other distichodontids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Citharinus and Citharidium, in contrast, have greatly elaborated epibranchial organs. In these<tei:lb/>genera the diverticulae are expanded into lobulate muscular structures (Fig. 46) with ramifying<tei:lb/>internal chambers supported by spicules of bone (see Daget, 1962a, Figs 7, 8). Prominent epi-<tei:lb/>branchial organs also occur in the Neotropical characoid families Prochilodontidae and<tei:lb/>Curimatidae. In neither of those families, however, are these outpocketings as greatly developed<tei:lb/>as they are in citharinids. Neither do the epibranchial organs of the Neotropical groups have the<tei:lb/>distinctive lobed forms of those in the Citharinidae. Thus the form of the citharinid epibranchial<tei:lb/>organs is considered synapomorphous for Citharinus and Citharidium among characoids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Olfactory bulbs</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Among anotophysans and most characoids the olfactory bulb lies immediately anterior to, and<tei:lb/>in contact with, the telencephalon and is laterally enclosed by the orbitosphenoid. In this state<tei:lb/>the olfactory nerve passes anteriorly either through the anteromedial opening in the orbito-<tei:lb/>sphenoid or through foramina in that bone, and extends anterolaterally to the olfactory foramen</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>CLASSIFICATION OF CITHARINIDAE AND DISTICHODONTIDAE 323</tei:p>
         <tei:p>of the lateral ethmoid. Citharinids and distichodontids, in contrast, have the olfactory bulbs<tei:lb/>shifted anteriorly to contact or nearly contact the posterior surface of the lateral ethmoid. This<tei:lb/>shift in olfactory bulb position results in a shortening of the olfactory nerve and an elongation of<tei:lb/>the olfactory tract. These alterations of the olfactory system are hypothesized apomorphous for<tei:lb/>these families within characoids. This hypothesis is based both on the widespread distribution of a<tei:lb/>posterior position of the olfactory bulb among teleosts in general and characoids in particular,<tei:lb/>and on the ontogenetic anterior movement of the bulb that has been observed in various<tei:lb/>citharinids and distichodontids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 46 Citharidium ansorgei, epibranchial organ,<tei:lb/>left lateral view.</tei:p>
