         <tei:p>Several other characters are of relevance for an understanding of the relationships within the<tei:lb/>African Characidae and for questions on the validity of the presently recognized generic and<tei:lb/>suprageneric taxa in this group. In the course of the discussion on the morphology of the anterior<tei:lb/>orbital region, it was noted that a bony tube surrounding the olfactory tract and bulb was<tei:lb/>described by Starks (1926, p. 167) for Alestes liebrechstii and A. grandisquamis. More recently<tei:lb/>Roberts (1969, p. 441) also noted this orbitosphenoid process in Alestes baremose, A. imberi, A.<tei:lb/>marcolepidotus, Bryconaethiops and Hydrocynus, and it has also been found in Alestes dentex<tei:lb/>and A. macrophthalmus during this study. This bony tube, which is lacking in all other African<tei:lb/>characids examined, is hypothesized as being apomorphous for these taxa among characoids<tei:lb/>on the basis of ontogenetic and outgroup comparisons. Those species with an orbitosphenoid<tei:lb/>tube also have the premaxillae joined by interpremaxillary interdigitations. As discussed earlier,<tei:lb/>both the broadened contact of the premaxillae anterior to the supraethmoid spine, and the<tei:lb/>associated symphyseal interdigitations are considered apomorphous and thus indicative of the<tei:lb/>monophyletic nature of the assemblage formed by the taxa possessing them. Congruent with<tei:lb/>these apomorphic modifications of the premaxillae and orbitosphenoid is the forward shift of<tei:lb/>the olfactory bulb in Hydrocynus, Bryconaethiops and various Alestes species (imberi, dentex,<tei:lb/>liebrechstii, macrophthalmus, macrolepidotus, nurse, rhodopleura and lateralis; the condition of</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>342 R. P. VARI</tei:p>
         <tei:p>the orbitosphenoid and premaxillae is unknown for the last three species). Such a derived anterior<tei:lb/>shift of the olfactory bulb is lacking among the other Alestes species and African characid genera<tei:lb/>examined. On the basis of these characters (the orbitosphenoid tube, the anterior shift of the<tei:lb/>olfactory bulb and the interdigitation of the premaxillae) it appears that the above Alestes species<tei:lb/>and the genera Bryconaethiops and Hydrocynus form a monophyletic subunit of the African<tei:lb/>Characidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Further studies are required to determine the exact distribution of the above derived osteology<tei:lb/>and neurological characters within African characids. Nonetheless, the available evidence<tei:lb/>contraindicates the inherent hypotheses of the monophyly of the genus Alestes and the subfamily<tei:lb/>Alestiinae as now defined. The genus Alestes, in its present sense, does not form a monophyletic<tei:lb/>unit in so far as the distribution of apomorphous characters indicates that some of its members<tei:lb/>are more closely related to species of the genera Bryconaethiops and Hydrocynus than to the<tei:lb/>remaining Alestes species. A redefinition of Alestes as a monophyletic unit must, however, await<tei:lb/>a detailed anatomical study of African characids and a phylogenetic analysis based on information<tei:lb/>from derived characters, both those discussed previously and others.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Roberts (1969, p. 442) divided the African Characidae into two subfamilies. These were the<tei:lb/>Hydrocyninae limited to the genus Hydrocynus and the Alestiinae for all other African characids.<tei:lb/>However, although the Hydrocyninae of such a classificatory scheme represents a monophyletic<tei:lb/>unit, the Alestiinae of that system is an unnatural grouping. As detailed above, the genera<tei:lb/>Hydrocynus and Bryconaethiops share a series of derived characters and form a monophyletic<tei:lb/>assemblage with some Alestes species. Consequently, a subdivision of African characids into<tei:lb/>two subfamilies along the lines proposed by Roberts results in some members of the subfamily<tei:lb/>Alestiinae (Bryconaethiops and various Alestes species) being more closely related to members of<tei:lb/>another subfamily (Hydrocyninae) than they are to the remaining taxa within their own subfamily.<tei:lb/>Thus the Alestiinae of Roberts must be considered a gradal non-monophyletic assemblage.<tei:lb/>Although the exact distribution of the derived characters discussed above is undetermined, the<tei:lb/>evidence is sufficient to indicate that the Hydrocyninae of Roberts (1969) should be sunk into the<tei:lb/>Alestiinae in order to resolve the present non-monophyly of the latter subfamily. The Alestiinae<tei:lb/>in this broader sense forms an evidently monophyletic assemblage within the Characoidea.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acknowledgements</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A number of individuals and institutions have been instrumental to the completion of this study.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I thank Dr Donn E. Rosen for directing my interests towards questions of characoid inter-<tei:lb/>relationships. Dr P. Humphry Greenwood and Mr Gordon J. Howes contributed significantly<tei:lb/>to this study by their informative comments on characoid morphology and interrelationships,<tei:lb/>together with helpful criticisms of earlier drafts of the manuscript. Mr Howes and Mrs Margaret<tei:lb/>Clarke were most helpful in locating specimens, preparing radiographs and other assistance<tei:lb/>during this study.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The majority of the research associated with this project, together with the synthesis of the<tei:lb/>results, was undertaken in the Department of Zoology, British Museum (Natural History).<tei:lb/>Research at that institution was supported by a NATO Postdoctoral Fellowship to the author.<tei:lb/>Supplemental studies were undertaken at the American Museum of Natural History and the final<tei:lb/>draft of the paper was prepared at the Smithsonian Institution, Washington D.C. under a<tei:lb/>Smithsonian Postdoctoral Fellowship.</tei:p>
